title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVERY, DAVID WAINWRIGHT
description: AVERY-David Wainwright. On May 18, 2000 of Essex, CT died after a short illness. He was 83 years old. A tall man with a big heart, he was devoted to his family and his church and was blessed with the gifts of song and laughter. Dave Avery was born on his family's farm in Aurora, NY on December 17, 1916. He graduated from Cayuga Lake Academy and Syracuse University. Early on he chose to work in advertising and spent most of his career with the National Geographic Magazine in New York, retiring in 1983 to Riverside and Essex, CT. He was a member of the University Glee Club of New York, an Elder and Deacon of the Rye Presbyterian Church in Rye, NY, a founding member of the Rye Walking, Chowder and Poker Society and a long-time member of the Manursing Island Club in Rye. Although at home in corporate offices along Madison Avenue, he was molded by his early years in Aurora, NY. His easy, open manner, his generosity, sense of humor and pride made him a successful salesman, a loving husband, dedicated father and joyful relative. The farm never left him, as his success in nurturing tomatoes, radishes and scallions out of the most unpromising ground in suburban New York attests. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Irene Avery of Essex, CT, his children by a previous marriage, William of New Canaan, CT, David Jr. of Stamford, CT, Thomas of Oakland, CA, Chris of Royaton, CT and Carol of New York City, his step-daughters Elizabeth Bagley of New Canaan and Sue Howland of Chicago, his sister Jean Wagner of Hampton Falls, NH, his brother Baldwin of Pocono Lake Preserve, PA., and seven grandchildren. Services will be held at The First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, CT on June 6, 2000.

title: A Harlem Theater Is Filled With Glitter and Gleam
description: On May 22, when Ingo Maurer, the German lighting designer, gave a happening for 600 people called ''Harlem Lights: A Night at the Alhambra,'' he was a groundbreaker. It was the first time that the 1905 Alhambra Theater, at Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and 126th Street, where Billie Holiday performed in the 1930's, had come alive since it was abandoned in the 1960's. And for Mr. Maurer, right, it was a first-time exhibit in Harlem. He illuminated the theater with an aluminum heart sprouting his Lucellino light bulbs, with goose feather wings, far left. At one end, more than 100 candles suspended on thin steel wires hung as if floating in air over a shallow trough of water. When guests put on special glasses, left, and looked at a point of light, they saw paired hearts. ''I like the vitality, the tenderness that is there in Harlem,'' said Mr. Maurer, who created the evening with Cheryl Hill, a film producer. ''I wanted to create an atmosphere and use light as a fluid element.'' He and Ms. Hill plan to stage more events at the Alhambra.

title: Public service campaigns try to catch the attention of the public and the media gatekeepers.
description: WHEN it comes to public service campaigns, the goal is not so very different from the intent of advertising for commercial goods and services. Public service announcements, which appear pro bono on behalf of organizations that promote safety, health and social causes, must engage the audience and build awareness.

title: Hoofing, Stripping, Collaborating
description: The New York City Ballet and Dance Theater of Harlem happily joined forces once again Saturday night at the New York State Theater. Members of the two troupes, conducted by Andrea Quinn, appeared in repeat performances of ''Tributary,'' collaboratively choreographed by Robert Garland and Robert La Fosse, and George Balanchine's ''Agon'' and ''Slaughter on Tenth Avenue.''

title: Hope and Fear on Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: A Midlife Leap Finds A Cushioned Landing
description: THE last time I saw Tom Ashbrook, he was scraping off dirty plates in my college dining room at Yale and regaling those of us on the serving line with wild stories about working the Alaskan pipeline and fixing sheep on his father's Illinois farm. His experiences were so out of my suburban-bred league. I noticed, even with a hair net, he had a great ponytail.

title: Unfit for the West Village
description: To the Editor:

title: Ask Jeeves President Quits
A Peek Into the Theater District
description: The New 42nd Street Studios, opening June 21, proves that a glass building can have a 21st-century reason for its transparency and not just be a nod to old-fashioned Modernism. The 10-story building, left, is 84,000 square feet, including offices, the Duke on 42nd Street Theater, and studio space for actors, dancers, musicians -- the people who make theater. The glass walls allow passersby to see dancers leaping, actors emoting, and musicians playing their horns.

title: Pataki Orders Tour Bus Line Off the Streets
description: Nine days after a double-decker tour bus killed a pedestrian at a Midtown Manhattan intersection, Gov. George E. Pataki today shut down the tour company for at least two weeks, and vowed to put it out of business permanently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHT, COHEN, ARLENE
description: LICHT-COHEN-Arlene, on May 30, 2000. Loving mother of Stephanie, Jason and Dara. Beloved sister of Louise Ungar (Louis) and Arnold Licht (Susan). Devoted daughter of Esther and the late Meyer Licht. Best possible aunt of Eliza and Jonah Licht, Joshua and Zachary Ungar. She was a teacher to us all whose lessons we will keep forever. Shiva until June 6th at the home of Dr. Licht, 130 Amity Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201.

title: Dangerous Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton's Best Deal Would Be No Deal
description: Barring a sudden change of heart, President Vladimir Putin of Russia will do the United States a great service when he sits down with President Clinton this weekend and refuses to modify the Antiballistic Missile Treaty to allow the United States to deploy a limited missile defense.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Married, Advising Singles

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with an On the Road article about visiting Philadelphia misidentified the boating sport shown. The crew teams on the Schuylkill were rowing shells; sculling is typically an individual activity.

title: In Bush-Gore Race, 3 Words For Media: 'You've Got Mail'
description: ''Gore Coverup Revealed!'' read the headline on the e-mail message from Washington.

title: Behind a Death on the Street, a Life on the Stage
description: After nearly 25 years in the business, Randolph Walker knew better than to bank on an audition. Still, when he headed home last week after trying out for a bit part in a movie called ''Dummy,'' he could not help feeling a little hopeful.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a large shareholder's objections to the election of Robert Taubman to the board of Sotheby's Holdings, where his father is a former chairman, misstated the father's given name. He is A. Alfred Taubman, not Albert.

title: World Bank Cites Itself in Study of Africa's Bleak Performance
description: Devastated by war, corruption and disease, people in sub-Saharan Africa live less well today than they did in the 1960's, and aid donors have to share the blame, the World Bank said in a comprehensive study issued today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about laboratory-grown neural cells misstated the given name of a doctor who implanted them into the brains of stroke patients. He is Dr. Douglas Kondziolka, not John.

title: Biotechnology Is Taking Aim At Psoriasis; 30 Companies Have Drugs In Various Trial Stages
description: When his psoriasis is at its worst, David G. Metz has a silvery scale covering his entire body except the soles of his feet. ''You leave a trail behind you where you've been -- the skin cells just fall off,'' he said, adding that this makes him very self-conscious and reclusive.

title: Plan Is Disclosed to Curb Role Of Hyundai Founding Family
description: The founder and chairman of the Hyundai Group announced radical changes today that will greatly diminish his family's management role and help the company, South Korea's biggest conglomerate, repay billions of dollars in debt through asset sales. But the surprise announcement was nearly overshadowed by the refusal of the chairman's eldest son to relinquish control of Hyundai's flagship automaker.

title: VIBRANT CANADIAN GROWTH
description: Helped by strong export sales and capital investment, Canada's gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the first quarter, down from 5.1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1999. Exports grew 3.3 percent and outlays for plant and equipment were up 2.7 percent, Statistics Canada said. Timothy Pritchard

title: Copland in the Spotlight But Not Exclusively So
description: The Kaye Playhouse is devoting its annual 20th Century Masters series to Aaron Copland, a natural choice in his centenary year. In some ways, the series is more expansive than usual. Where past installments (Shostakovich, Faure and Barber have been the earlier honorees) have been concentrated at the end of the season, the Copland series continues into the fall, with a concert version of ''The Tender Land'' promised for September.

title: Cone Tells His Story In His Body Language
description: David Cone's right hand was locked on his hip, his eyes were focused on the grass and his mind seemed to be wondering what he could do to emerge from this predicament. It was only the first inning and the Yankees trailed the Oakland Athletics by a mere three runs, but Cone already looked deflated.

title: Wisdom for the Ages, by Book, Not Chip
description: To the Editor:

title: Unicef Issues Report on Worldwide Violence Facing Women
description: The prevalence of domestic abuse of women and girls around the world is ''alarming,'' Unicef reported today, with statistics suggesting that up to half the female population comes under attack by those closest to them at some time in their lives.

title: DC Air Names Acting President
description: DC Air, a new regional airline to be created from assets divested as part of the proposed acquisition of US Airways Group by the UAL Corporation, named a US Airways executive, N. Bruce Ashby, as its acting president.

title: For Belfour, Medicine Was a Culprit in Loss
description: Will Eddie Belfour still be dazed and confused? That is the main question facing the Dallas Stars when they play Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals Thursday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLOCK, JOHN LAURENCE
description: POLLOCK-John Laurence. Loving and devoted husband of Mary Maher Pollock, brother of Rita Murphy and uncle of Maryellen Maher and Patricia Maher Wangsness. Visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday, June 1st Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1 Ave. Funeral Mass 10 AM, Friday, June 2nd, Our Lady of Peace, 237 E. 62 St.

title: The Nomad Jukebox Holds A Hefty Store of Music
description: Creative Labs has upped the ante in the MP3 sweepstakes with the release of the new Nomad Jukebox.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BECTON, DICKINSON & CO., Franklin Lakes, N.J., named John Considine chief financial officer, succeeding Kenneth Weisshaar, who left. Mr. Considine had been senior vice president for finance at American Home Products.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're New York City and we have the crummiest waterfronts in the United States.''

title: Car Rental Spinoff By AutoNation Is Set
description: AutoNation Inc., the nation's largest automobile retailer, today set June 30 as the date it will spin off its unprofitable car rental unit.

title: Sea Turtles Nearing Extinction in Pacific, Study Says
description: Leatherback turtles, whose numbers in the Pacific have plunged in recent years, will all but disappear within a decade unless commercial fishing practices are changed, according to a new analysis of the giant animals' nesting activity.

title: DiMassimo Appoints 5 Partners
description: DiMassimo Brand Advertising in New York has named five executives as partners. Each will be given an equal, undisclosed minority stake in the agency and take on the additional title of managing partner. They are: Melissa Brooks, 31, director for brand management; Lee Goldstein, 28, director for business development; Carla Hall, 32, executive producer; Jonathan Lee, 30, director for brand planning; and Doug Ray, 30, director for brand media and new media.

title: On the Web, Untouched By Human Hands
description: At Eppraisals.com, a new Web site, it is possible to have antiques appraised online. It was started this spring by Leslie Hindman, who sold her Chicago auction house to Sotheby's in 1997. She has 700 experts who will evaluate digital photos of objects for a $20 fee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, FRANCES
description: COHN-Frances. Age 94. Beloved wife of the late Seymour, cherished mother of Paula Semel and Gerald Cohn and mother-in-law of Jessica Cohn and Martin Semel. Devoted grandmother of Michael Semel, Alissa Sherwin, Jennifer Blanchard and Jason Cohn. greatgrandmother of Zachary and Rachel Semel, Kate Sherwin, Andrew and Gregory Blanchard. Services June 2, 9:30AM Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills

title: Art for Art's Sake, the Mobster Says
description: ''Anonymous,'' a comedy at the McGinn/Cazale Theater on the Upper West Side, is about an unappreciated and lonely writer who finds happiness in the conventional pleasures of living in a civilized society and pays the price for it. It's a play that tries to make the case for being true to yourself, but its more cogent accomplishment is to ask the question: Why would a man need a good job and a loving woman when he can suffer with his art in obscurity?

title: Call It Gentrification
description: To the Editor:

title: African Identity? An Art Show Turns the Tables
description: It started in the early years of the 20th century, when the Cubists broke down their subject matter in ways that resembled African masks. Later Surrealists, Expressionists and even Pop artists took visual ideas and concepts from Africa. Now contemporary African artists are appropriating their traditions themselves.

title: Following a Cue From McCain, Lazio Campaigns by Bus
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio sought today to build momentum in his campaign for the Senate, riding his newly christened ''Mainstream Express'' across upstate New York as he greeted supporters and stepped up criticism of his opponent.

title: ONEIDA TO BUY DELCO INTERNATIONAL, A TABLEWARE MAKER
description: The dinnerware maker Oneida Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy the privately held tableware maker Delco International Inc. for $76 million in its third acquisition in the last week. Oneida, a maker of consumer products, said it wanted to diversify its product line. Delco, which is based in Port Washington, N.Y., makes tableware for the food service industry. Oneida, based in Oneida, N.Y., has also agreed to buy the privately held Sakura Inc. of New York, a maker of consumer dinnerware and theme dishes for companies like Walt Disney, and the privately held British cookware maker Viners of Sheffield Ltd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, SAMUEL
description: TAYLOR-Samuel. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of Dramatists Play Service mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend. Sam was President and Chairman of the Board of the play service for over twenty years. We will miss his artistic and business acumen and his counsel. Sam was not only a successful playwright and screenwriter but a true gentleman in every positive sense of the word. Our deep sympathy goes to his wife, Suzanne, his family and friends. Dramatists Play Service Stephen Sultan, President

title: SCHLUMBERGER AND BAKER HUGHES FORM SEISMIC VENTURE
description: Schlumberger Ltd., the world's No. 2 oil field services company, agreed yesterday to pay $500 million to a rival, Baker Hughes Inc., for a 70 percent stake in a new joint venture to provide seismic services used to locate oil and gas. Seismic technology is used to study the physical properties of land or water in an effort to save on the expense of drilling into dry areas. Schlumberger and Baker Hughes will combine their seismic divisions to form a venture called Western GECO. The shares of Schlumberger rose $2.3125 each, to $73.3125. Baker Hughes rose $2.125, at $36.25.

title: Clinton Signs E-Signature Bill
description: Clinton Signs E-Signature Bill

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column last Thursday about the new Boffi kitchen showroom in SoHo misidentified its designer. He is Piero Lissoni, not Antonio Citterio.

title: FRIEDE GOLDMAN TO SELL SHIP-REPAIR OPERATION
description: Friede Goldman Halter Inc., the fourth-largest United States shipbuilder, agreed yesterday to sell its vessel-repair unit to the closely held Bollinger Shipyards Inc. for $80 million. The unit operates five repair yards in Louisiana and Texas. Friede Goldman, based in Gulfport, Miss., was formed last November when Friede Goldman International Inc. bought Halter Marine Group Inc. for $398.7 million. The company has sold or closed 8 of its 24 United States shipyards to cut costs.

title: An Atrocity's Mystery of Evil; Open-and-Shut Case, but Suspect Is a Closed Book
description: For eight hours after his arrest last week, John Taylor sat with investigators in a second-floor squad room at the 111th Precinct in northern Queens, unwinding the spool of his life, from his childhood in a Brooklyn housing project to what prosecutors charge was his role last week in the execution-style slayings of five people in the basement of a Wendy's on Main Street in Flushing.

title: Most Editorials Endorse Florio
description: Jon Corzine is easily winning the spending race, but former Gov. Jim Florio is emerging as the clear choice of newspaper editorial writers in the race for New Jersey's Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.

title: The Paperless Newspaper
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, HENRIETTE
description: ROTHSTEIN-Henriette. Died age 78 of cardiac arrest May 8 at home Glen Cove, NY. Survived by husband Arnold; daughter Amy, grandson Adrian Elfersy. Chapel service was at Gutterman's Woodbury, NY, burial Mt Hope Cemetery, Hastings-On-Hudson. All who knew her loved and honored her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNSHINE, ALBERT A., DR.
description: SUNSHINE-Albert A., Dr. Age 78, died May 30, 2000 in Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Victoria, devoted father of Randi Sunshine of Los Angeles, CA, and Dr. William Sunshine of Boca Raton, FL. He is survived by two sisters, Naomi Trigg of Stony Brook, NY and Caryl Hillelson of Pittsburgh, PA. His joys were his four grandchildren, Jacob Sherkow, Abigail Sherkow, Benjamin Sunshine and Jonathan Sunshine. Dr. Sunshine maintained a private practice in Mattituck, NY for 40 years and upon retirement became a professional bridge teacher and Director. He will be interred in the Veteran's Cemetery in Calverton, NY. A memorial service will be held at a later time. Donations: The Mattituck/Laurel Library, Box 1434, Mattituck, New York 11952.

title: Hope and Fear on Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Changes in Welfare Bring Improvements for Families
description: A rigorous, large-scale evaluation of changes in welfare in Minnesota has found extremely positive effects: higher earnings and income for parents, less poverty, an increase in marriage rates and marital stability and improvements in children's behavior and school performance -- a combination never seen before.

title: As Widmer and Way Exit, Barrow Emerges at Linebacker
description: The Giants' changeover at middle linebacker was made official today during the team's minicamp when Corey Widmer, the starter at the position for the last four seasons, was not at the Giants Stadium workouts. The job now belongs to Mike Barrow, the Giants' principal off-season free-agent acquisition.

title: This Feels Like '88, Good News (Maybe) for Gore
description: The ghost of the 1988 election is a comforting spirit to many Democrats, who like to remember another sitting vice president, George Bush, who was trailing in the polls in May only to prevail, handily, in November.

title: Mrs. Gore Takes Turn On Stump
description: After having kept a low profile on the campaign trail in recent months, Tipper Gore, the wife of Vice President Al Gore, emerged today in the kind of setting where she clearly feels most comfortable: a forum on mental health policy.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Cornell University's graduation exercises misidentified the event at which Charles E. Schumer of New York spoke. It was the senior convocation on Saturday, not the commencement on Sunday. The commencement address was given by the university's president, Hunter R. Rawlings III.

title: Laptop Innovations
description: To the Editor:

title: KPMG Selects Worldwide Agency
description: KPMG International in Montvale, N.J., said yesterday that it had named J. Walter Thompson in New York, part of the WPP Group, as the agency to handle its worldwide account, including creative duties and media planning and buying. Billings were estimated at $90 million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: NYT Article

title: Bush Expects to Grant His First Reprieve To Killer-Rapist on Texas' Death Row
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said today that he was ''more than likely'' to grant a temporary reprieve for a man scheduled to be executed on Thursday so that DNA evidence in the case could be tested. It would be the first such stay Mr. Bush has issued as governor.

description: Internet Company Sues CBS

title: Texas Radio Station Deal
description: The Hispanic Broadcasting Corporation, the largest United States Spanish-language radio broadcaster, agreed today to buy two radio stations in San Antonio for about $45 million in cash and expects the purchases to cause two years of operating losses. Hispanic Broadcasting, based in Dallas, agreed to buy KBUC-FM from the closely held Redding Enterprises and KRNH-FM from the closely held Radio Ranch Management. Hispanic Broadcasting owns or operates 45 radio stations. Hispanic Broadcasting shares rose $5.625, to $75.75, in New York Stock Exchange trading today.

title: ESPN Stumbles in Knight Interview
description: If you were to interview Richard Nixon about his vice presidential years, surely you would watch his Checkers speech. If you were to chat with President Clinton about his impeachment, surely you would watch his taped deposition.

title: Putin's Plan to Centralize Power in the Kremlin Wins a Round
description: Russia's lower house of Parliament ignored misgivings by political analysts and democracy advocates today and resoundingly endorsed a first draft of President Vladimir V. Putin's plan to concentrate state power in the Kremlin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COVAN, MARY SARIN
description: COVAN-Mary Sarin. May 30, 2000. Dear wife of the late Sidney Covan. Devoted sister of Dorie Sarin. Beloved mother of Dr. Frederick (Diane), loving grandmother of Alexander, Daniel, Zachary and Benjamin Covan, dearest friend of Jack Epstein. Well known owner of Sarin's Accessories on University Place. Services 10 AM, Friday, Gramercy Chapel, 152 2nd Ave.

title: Gore Calls for Better Benefits For Children With Mental Ills
description: Vice President Al Gore called today for legislation that would require health insurance companies to provide children with mental health benefits comparable to coverage for physical ailments.

title: POWERTEL INVESTING $125 MILLION IN ELISKA WIRELESS
description: The wireless service provider Powertel Inc. said yesterday that it would buy a 49.9 percent stake in Eliska Wireless Ventures I for $125 million in one in a series of deals that will help Powertel get more customers. In connection with the deal, the Sonera Corporation, Finland's biggest phone company, agreed to buy $125 million of Powertel stock and to invest $75 million in Eliska. Eliska, which is based in Mobile, Ala., is a venture of Powertel, Sonera and other investors. In a separate deal, Eliska agreed to pay $375 million for the wireless operations of the privately held DiGiPH Communications Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECARLO, LEWIS
description: DeCARLO-Lewis. On May 29th, 2000. Beloved husband of Cynthia Hickey DeCarlo. Father, grandfather, and brother. Funeral Mass Thursday, June 1st, 10AM, at St. Patrick's Church, Bedford, NY. Donations may be made to the Northern Westchester Shelter, POB 203 Pleasantville, NY. 10570.

title: Pentagon Test-Fires Missiles To Finish T.W.A. Inquiry
description: Federal crash investigators had the Pentagon test-fire Stinger missiles last month off the coast of Florida to see if the resulting streaks resembled those described by witnesses to the explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800, a spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board said this evening.

title: All the Weather You'll Ever Need
description: CAREY HOFFMAN describes himself as a weather nut.

title: IRISH CREDIT CARDS
description: British financial companies see a market for credit cards in Ireland. Egg, Prudential Life's consumer bank, confirmed that it will offer an Irish credit card to take advantage of the lack of competition in the market. Tesco, the British supermarket chain, recently introduced a credit card for its Irish customers. Brian Lavery

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Sports of The Times; Holzman Had The Formula For Winning
description: HE would listen in as the news media know-it-alls argued over dinner, the debate raging over the establishment of the half-court game against the need to get out and run. Twenty years ago, the extreme strategic positions were all the source of comic amusement to the sagacious basketball lifer.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFERT, ROSOLYN
description: HOFFERT-Rosolyn. We record with deep sorrow the passing of Rosolyn Hoffert, beloved wife of Dr. Paul W. Hoffert, loving mother of Dr. Marvin Hoffert, Dr. Renee Gutman and Dr. Deborah Hoffert. Adored grandmother of Alexander, Jason and David Hoffert, Benjamin and Rachel Gutman, Isaac Robinson. Funeral services were held at Congregation Shaarei Tikva on Wednesday, May 31st. Shiva is being observed through Tuesday morning, June 6th at the Gutman residence, 48 Country Road, Mamaroneck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITSKY, LEON
description: LITSKY-Leon. Our deepest sympathies to our son-in-law, Michael, our daughter, Denise, and grandchildren, Sage and Morgan, on the loss of Leon Litsky, a devoted friend, husband, father and grandfather. He will be missed by all of us who knew him and loved him. Marilyn and Ben Ossman

description: To the Editor:

title: Motorola and Flextronics Sign Production Deal
description: June 1, 2000

title: Phone Rates Head Downward
description: Telephone customers will soon begin to save money on their long-distance calls, courtesy of decisions made yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission. Families that make few long-distance calls will save the most under the commission's intricate ruling, as much as 50 percent -- a nice touch that brings the benefits of deregulation to low-income families. But buried among the regulatory rulings is something that should prove even more important to most customers in the long run. The commission wrung subsidies out of regulated rates that have kept prices too high and have stymied the outbreak of competition that Congress promised when it passed the 1996 Telecommunications Act.

title: Software to Predict Power Needs
description: IF nothing else, most American computer users have been able to count on one thing: electricity to run their machines. But high demands for electricity this summer could produce power shortages like those in parts of the country last year.

title: Presidential Succession in Israel
description: Ezer Weizman is justly admired for his many contributions to Israeli public life, including crucial support for peace efforts with Egypt and the Palestinians. But a withering government report detailing his receipt of more than $300,000 from two businessmen a decade ago left him little choice but to resign from the largely ceremonial office of president effective July 10. Appropriately, the leading choice to succeed him is another man closely identified with the quest for Mideast peace, former Prime Minister Shimon Peres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, KEREN E., PHD.
description: ALEXANDER-Keren E., PhD., of Ridgefield, CT, on May 28, 2000, in Jerusalem. Cherished wife of Jonathan Alexander, M.D., proud and adoring mother of Jessica, Daniel and Benjamin, devoted daughter of Elsie Einhorn Koffer of Delray Beach, FL and the late Oscar Einhorn, loving sister of Roland Einhorn. A graduate of Queens College of CUNY and NYU, and a Postdoctoral Fellow at Yale, she devoted her career as a psychologist to helping disadvantaged children. She is irreplaceable. Services 1PM Friday, June 2 at United Jewish Center, 141 Deer Hill Avenue, Danbury, CT. The Keren E. Alexander Foundation will be established in her memory for the benefit of disadvantaged children. Donations may be made to Sharon Wicks Dornfeld, Trustee, 42 Main Street, Danbury, CT. 06810.

description: To the Editor:

title: PALM BUYS ANYDAY.COM, AN INTERNET CALENDAR COMPANY
description: Palm Inc., the manufacturer of a hand-held organizer, agreed yesterday to pay $80 million in cash and stock options for AnyDay.com, an Internet-based calendar and scheduling company. Under the terms of the deal, AnyDay.com employees will continue to work from their current headquarters in Cambridge, Mass. Palm said the acquisition would eventually allow AnyDay.com users to have access to their calendar information and update it on the AnyDay Web site or by hand-held Palm devices. Shares of Palm, based in Santa Clara, Calif., fell $1, to $23.

title: Editorial Observer; Republicans Find Comfort With Rick Lazio
description: The dominant emotion at this week's New York State Republican convention was relief that Representative Rick Lazio has stepped in to replace Mayor Rudolph Giuliani as the party's Senate nominee. Sometimes this relief was unspoken, but in a surprising number of cases, top Republicans expressed it openly.

title: Pump Up the Power In a Cell Phone Battery
description: If the battery in your cell phone is about to die, get a grip.

title: New-Home Sales Hit 5-Month Low in April
description: New-home sales fell in April to their lowest level in five months, government figures showed today, indicating that six increases in interest rates by the Federal Reserve over the last year may be starting to cool the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ELIZABETH ANN
description: HARRIS-Elizabeth Ann. Age 43, of Plymouth, MA. Formerly of Greenlawn, NY. Died May 16, 2000. Beloved daughter of Gordon and Sondra. Loving sister of Louis and Paul. A graduate of S.U.N.Y., Albany. MBA from Penn State University. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to gather at the Delaney Funeral Home, 48 Common St., Walpole, MA on Saturday, June 3 at 2 PM for a memorial service. Donations in her memory may be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, Central New England Chapter, 101 First Ave., Suite 6, Waltham, MA 02451. For additional information please call 508-668-0858 between 7 PM and 9 PM.

description: Sites and Events This Week

description: The Milstein real estate family has lost a bruising battle with Prince Faisal ibn Khalid of Saudi Arabia and Pakistan International Airlines over the historic Roosevelt Hotel, near Grand Central Terminal.

title: Lost in Technology's Rush
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer-Share Citizenship?
description: Summer residents from the Hamptons to the Rockies are raising their voices in protest over being required to pay high taxes in their vacation getaways while being denied the right to vote in local elections. Second-home owners, including many who are superrich, are quick to evoke the Boston Tea Party motto -- no taxation without representation. They should reread their history; there they will discover a rather different lesson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORSKY, MORRIS
description: DORSKY-Morris. Loving father of Daniel and Joshua. Devoted grandfather of Jessica and David. Lasting is the song, though the singer passes. Memorial services in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, IDA
description: GROSSMAN-Ida. On May 29, 2000. At age 94. Beloved wife of the late Sydney. Loving mother of Paul and Stanley and mother-in-law of Vivian and Adele. Cherished grandmother of Steven, Stuart, Richard, Susan and great-grandmother of Bari and Jacqueline. Interment was held on May 31, 2000 at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Microsoft Files Sharp Critique Of a Breakup
description: Ignoring the judge's assertion that he wanted no more briefs, Microsoft filed a detailed criticism of the government's breakup plan today, the last filing for the record before the judge rules on how to deal with the company's antitrust violations.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Twelve Smug Minutes That Are Hard to Explain
description: You walk by each cubicle in the visitor's locker room at Conseco Fieldhouse, and you get the same hangdog look from each of them. They cannot tell you exactly where Game 5 went or how it got so bad so fast in the second quarter.

title: Philharmonic Appointing Zarin Mehta As Executive
description: The New York Philharmonic said yesterday that it was naming Zarin Mehta, who runs Chicago's prestigious Ravinia Festival, to be its executive director starting in September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, ROSLYN
description: SUSSMAN-Roslyn. We extend our sincerest condolences to Marvin Sussman and Judy Sokolow on the passing of their beloved mother. Throughout her life, Roslyn exemplified the values of kindness, modesty and dignity, and was a true ''woman of valor.'' Silver Founders of the Medical Center, Marvin and his wife, Aviva, personify the values of tzedakah and chesed, which they learned from this special woman. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. For Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr. Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres. Sidney Adler, Treas. Lee Weinbach, Pres., Nat'l Women's Div. Stuart Tauber, Exec. Dir.

title: In India, the Wheels of Justice Hardly Move
description: Way back when or, to be more precise, way, way, way back when -- an illiterate meat cutter, Abdul Waheed, filed a lawsuit against his next-door-neighbor, a stubborn milk merchant named Mohammad Nanhe.

title: British Company to Buy Struggling Dutch Software Concern
description: Invensys P.L.C., a British manufacturer of factory controls, agreed today to buy Baan N.V. for $802 million, promising to turn around the company, a Dutch software maker that has relentlessly lost money and share value for nearly two years.

title: School Board Member Investigated for Conflict
description: The special investigator for the New York City school system has opened an inquiry into potential conflicts of interest involving Irving S. He was a longtime conservationist and friend of the Adirondacks. With his brother Robert, he was one of the first three people to climb the 46 High Peaks of the Adirondacks. And, with his father Louis and brothers James and Robert, George was one of the foremost defenders of the ''Forever Wild'' Clause of the New York State Constitution, which protects the Adirondack and Catskill Forest Preserves. Our sympathies to the Marshall and Scholle families, who continue this tradition of passionate work on behalf of the Adirondacks.

title: Devils Miss When Hull Shoots for the Stars
description: Brett Hull scored the goal that won the Stanley Cup for the Dallas Stars last season, and he leads the tournament this season with 11. A veteran who has proven he is more than just a star shooter, Hull retains the finishing touch to break open a game, and to close one, too.

title: DEAL FOR COAL MINER
description: One of the world's largest mining concerns, Anglo American, has reached an agreement with the Shell Petroleum Company Ltd. to acquire Shell Coal Holdings for $850 million to $900 million. Shell Coal, which was put on the block last year, operates several mines, all but one of them in Australia, and acquiring them will help Anglo increase production outside South Africa and expand distribution into the Indo-Pacific market. Henri E. Cauvin

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a United Nations envoy's statement that Syria is ready to accept Israel's retreat from Lebanon as a complete withdrawal misstated the timing of Security Council Resolution 425, calling for Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon. It was adopted in 1978, after Israeli occupied part of southern Lebanon, not in 1982, after Israel's full-scale invasion of Lebanon.

title: SIGNET, A SPECIALTY JEWELER, TO ACQUIRE MARKS & MORGAN
description: Signet Group P.L.C., the world's largest specialty retail jeweler, agreed yesterday to acquire Marks & Morgan, the ninth-biggest specialty jeweler in the United States, for $115 million in cash. London-based Signet, which operates 832 stores in the United States, will also assume about $45 million in debt of the privately owned Marks & Morgan. Marks & Morgan has 137 stores in the southeastern United States; about 80 of those stores will be converted to Signet's Kay Jewelers brand, Signet said.

title: A Park to Stir Me, and Soothe You
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviving Dental Clinics
description: To the Editor:

title: Blazers Feel Confident Amid Confines of Home
description: The ultrasound wire poked from underneath the bandage on his left hand, causing Scottie Pippen's two dislocated fingers to look like an antenna.

title: Tony Forecast: Dramatic Races, Musical Chairs
description: Unless there are some major surprises -- and there always are -- on Sunday night, Tony voters will declare that Broadway's best musical is ''Contact,'' which many people say is not a musical, and that its best play is ''Copenhagen,'' which many people say they simply don't understand.

title: Survival Drama: 'He's Lazy!' 'Pass the Suntan Oil!'
description: I recently read a newspaper article about a Vermont farmer who has found a way to make his unprofitable family farm profitable. He sold his milk cows and started leading tours of the farm, obligingly chewing on pieces of hay for photographs. ''The simple old life is gone,'' the farmer was quoted as saying. ''It don't fit in today's world. Our crop is fleecing the city folks.''

title: The F.C.C.'s Ownership Rules
description: The Federal Communications Commission, under heavy political pressure, is preparing to loosen rules that limit the ability of television broadcasters to own other communications properties. This is a bad idea. There is no evidence that weakening the rules will help consumers.

title: Thorn to Be Named to Direct the Nets
description: The man who drafted Michael Jordan will soon be hired to lead the Nets. Rod Thorn, the league's executive vice president of basketball operations, has agreed in principle to become the Nets' new president and director of basketball, according to a member of the YankeeNets organization.

title: Court Upholds I.N.S.'s Rejection Of Asylum Effort for Cuban Boy
description: A federal appellate panel today upheld the right of immigration officials to let Elian Gonzalez's father take the boy back to Cuba.

title: BISYS AGREES TO BUY PROVIDER OF INSURANCE SOFTWARE
description: Bisys Group Inc., a provider of technical services to financial companies, agreed yesterday to buy the Pictorial unit of Primedia Inc. for $129 million in cash. Pictorial, based in Indianapolis, provides software and services to help insurance companies and agencies comply with licensing and continuing-education requirements. The sale by Primedia, a publisher of magazines, is part of the company's plan to sell assets that cannot be integrated with other businesses. Proceeds from the sale will be used to pay debt.

title: Piazza May Play Tonight
description: Wednesday night's 4-3 loss to the Dodgers concluded a grueling nine-game road trip for the Mets in which they went from New York to San Diego to St. Louis to Los Angeles and managed to win five of nine games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIDEMAN, MARION
description: HEIDEMAN-Marion. The conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations expresses condolences to our distinguished colleague Richard Heideman, President of B'nai B'rith, on the loss of his beloved mother. We pray that the family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: So Crude Even Daddy the Porn King Disapproves
description: Here's a conundrum: How can a movie effectively satirize the bottom-feeding world of talk show television without stooping to its level of prurience and being as crude and boisterous as a roaring, profanity-spattered brawl on ''The Jerry Springer Show''? The answer, of course, is that it can't. But that's not necessarily a bad thing as long as the movie wears its nose-thumbing attitude on its sleeve.

title: Companies Pay $1 Million in Harassment Suit
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it would pay $850,000 to settle a lawsuit in which the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission charged managers at a Maryland food-processing plant with egregious sexual harassment of 22 female workers from Central America.

title: Tottenville Meets Monroe for Title
description: Tottenville of Staten Island will square off against Monroe of the Bronx for the Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship next Monday morning at Yankee Stadium.

title: The Favorites Win Their Opening Heats
description: Cal-Berkeley's undefeated men's heavyweight varsity crew, favored to defend its Intercollegiate Rowing Association national title on the Cooper River in Cherry Hill, N.J., tomorrow, won its opening heat yesterday to advance to today's semifinals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHT, COHEN, ARLENE
description: LICHT-COHEN-Arlene. Dearest friend, devoted and proud ''aunt'' to Melissa, Andy, David and Max. We will treasure our memories of you always. Bonnie and Stu GraBois

title: A Ruling's Risks for Other Elians
description: Juan Miguel Gonzalez is another step closer to taking his son Elian home to Cuba, thanks to yesterday's ruling by the Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, and Americans who have been caught up in the drama of a divided family may be feeling happy for him. But for those of us who try to help refugees fleeing from oppression and mistreatment in their home countries, this case is not so easy to celebrate.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE STATES

title: AOL and Hughes to Test Satellite Service in 16 Cities
description: AOL and Hughes to Test Satellite Service in 16 Cities

title: Momma's Big Persona Hides a Secret Agent
description: The fitfully amusing ''Big Momma's House,'' starring the comic whirligig Martin Lawrence, could best be described as ''Stakeout'' goes ghetto, with a touch of ''Tootsie'' for flava -- er, flavor. Mr. Lawrence plays Malcolm, an F.B.I. agent with a penchant for doing undercover work in full body makeup, apparently to use some of the disguises he didn't get around to in ''Blue Streak,'' his last ''Where's Martin?'' picture.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: A Park to Stir Me, and Soothe You
description: To the Editor:

title: Troopers' Version of Shooting Is Disputed
description: Two New Jersey state troopers who face trial in the 1998 shooting of three minority men in a van on the New Jersey Turnpike told the authorities they shot in self-defense as the van backed toward one of them. But the state released a court document Wednesday in which one of the men, Danny Reyes, said he had raised his hands and was pleading as a trooper shot him four times.

title: ASPEN ACQUIRES ANOTHER PETROLEUM SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: Aspen Technology Inc., a maker of software for oil refiners and chemical companies, said yesterday that it had bought the Petrolsoft Corporation for about $59.6 million in stock to add distribution software for the petroleum industry. Aspen, based in Cambridge, Mass., issued about 2.6 million shares for the closely held Petrolsoft, which is based in San Diego, Calif. Aspen's shares rose $2.3125 each, to $22.9375. Petrolsoft had 1999 sales of about $4 million and 50 employees. Its software helps petroleum companies manage their inventory and get products into the hands of retail customers.

title: Playing Down the Politics
description: This is a 30-second commercial that the Conservative Party of New York has begun broadcasting in Albany and on New York 1 News in New York City. It is the first to include Representative Rick A. Lazio since he announced his candidacy for the United States Senate two weeks ago.

title: Fans and Friends Say Goodbye to Their Mambo King
description: The cars, some with Puerto Rican flags fluttering from windows, slowed to a crawl yesterday as they passed Tito Puente's, the restaurant on City Island in the Bronx co-owned by the mambo king himself.

title: Even the Egalitarian Bauhaus Had a Hausfrau Tendency
description: It's always startling to be reminded that the Bauhaus, that font of modernist invention, did not allow women to participate in its architecture, wall-painting and furniture workshops because they were considered too physically demanding. Such genteel, if chauvinistic, concern seems out of character at a place where aesthetic equality -- the elevation of craft and design to fine-art status -- was a founding principle. But no, at the Bauhaus, women had only gentler options: ceramics, metalwork and especially the ancient, implicitly female craft of weaving.

title: Black Secret Service Agents Say Agency Tried to Intimidate Them
description: Lawyers for a group of black agents who have filed a racial discrimination lawsuit against the Secret Service asked a federal judge today to stop what they said were efforts by the agency to intimidate their clients.

title: Daughters' Gift To the Modern
description: Ian Woodner, the Manhattan real estate developer who died in 1990, was one of the greatest collectors in the United States. Besides an extraordinary group of drawings, some of which were acquired by the National Gallery of Art in Washington in 1991, he amassed a large group of Cycladic works of art.

title: Hull Scores 2 Goals, And Goes 1-Up on Dad
description: The Golden Jet is looking up at his son.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Rallying Round To Get Out Votes

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline jumped after an industry report showed an unexpected decline in inventories. In New York, unleaded gasoline for July delivery rose 4.12 cents, or 4.2 percent, to $1.0167 a gallon.

title: Clinton Finds Germans Critical of U.S. Missile Defense Plan
description: President Clinton arrived in Germany for a three-day visit today and faced immediate criticism of his administration's plans to build a limited missile defense system.

title: THE BIDDING GAME: A special report; In Online Auction World, Hoaxes Aren't Easy to See
description: When eBay, the Internet auction company, suspended the seller and voided the sale of a vivid abstract painting whose price shot from 25 cents to $135,805 last month, his offense had nothing to do with the authenticity of the painting or the story he invented to go with the work.

title: Gore Urges Doubling of Funds in War Against Cancer
description: Invoking World War II and the race to the moon, Vice President Al Gore promised today to double federal spending on cancer research and to make ''a flood'' of new cancer treatments and tests available to all Americans who need them.

title: A Park to Stir Me, and Soothe You
description: To the Editor:

title: Clooney's Warm Glow For Moody Bossa Nova
description: Sooner or later, almost every great popular singer has a moment of reckoning with the wistful bossa nova ballads of Antonio Carlos Jobim. Frank Sinatra's albums of Jobim songs were the quietest and arguably the most intimate recordings of his career. And in her latest album, ''Brazil'' (Concord Jazz), Rosemary Clooney, joined by the guitarist and singer John Pizzarelli, applies her warm, earthy stamp to songs like ''Quiet Nights,'' ''Desafinado'' and ''Once I Loved.''

title: A Defender of Public Beauty (as She Sees It)
description: LET suburbia's guardians wrestle with the heartache of sprawl. Jean Parker Phifer, president of New York City's endangered Art Commission, has her hands full trying to cut down on clutter in a cluttered metropolis.

title: Chicago Schools' Answer to Tug of the Suburbs
description: The struggles of Chicago public schools seem a world removed from North Side College Preparatory, a gleaming new high school with six computers in every classroom, a 525-seat theater and a student body loaded with academic stars.

title: WOODS WILL HIT NIKE
description: In a move that had been anticipated for several weeks, Tiger Woods will use the Nike golf ball on a long-term basis, starting with the United States Open later this month in Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: Auto Sales Declined 2% Last Month
description: Auto sales dropped 2 percent last month from May of last year, the first year-to-year drop since the summer of 1998. Dismal results at DaimlerChrysler and General Motors entirely accounted for the decline as other manufacturers posted record sales, leaving it unclear whether a long-expected decline in sales had begun.

title: Sure, but Are the Pacers Better Without Smits?
description: Q.: Does a bull get mad when he sees red?

title: Tepid Endorsement Of Government's Actions
description: The Federal appeals court ruling yesterday in the Elian Gonzalez case reaffirmed legal principles that give Federal agencies -- and particularly immigration officials -- wide authority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLE, ANNETTE GRUBER (HANIA)
description: BARTLE-Annette Gruber (Hania). Died May 25. A dear friend, gifted artist, writer, journalist, world traveler, teacher, linguist, community volunteer, and lover of nature, astronomy, and animals. She will be remembered with respect and love and greatly missed by Halinka, Sally, Janet and Jerry, Joan, John, Gunther, Anne, Wanda, Katy, Rose, Maureen, Kathleen, and Tony.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN DECLINES. The yen fell for a second day after a Japanese life insurance company failed. In New York, the dollar settled at 108.55 yen, up from 107.78 on Wednesday.

title: Rand McNally Picks An Agency Team
description: Rand McNally in Skokie, Ill., said yesterday that it had named three units of the B Com3 Group -- the Leo Burnett Company, Starcom Worldwide and Starcom IP, all in Chicago -- as its first creative and media agencies. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISAN, LILLIAN (BRAHAM)
description: WISAN-Lillian (Braham). Died April 16 age 93. Wife of the late Jesse H. Mother of Mark. Grandmother of Liz and Anne. Motherin-law of Jane. Sister of the late George Braham. Memorial service at Temple Beth Elohim, 8th Avenue and Garfield Place, Brooklyn on June 4 at 10:30AM.

title: Taking an Obsessive Approach To the Daily Problems of Life
description: Jennifer Muller and her company the Works have covered a wide range of styles in 25 years. Ms. Muller's opening night program on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater suggested that range in its satisfying balance of abstraction and narrative.

title: Moscow Foresees a Balanced Budget
description: Russia's next federal budget should be balanced for the first time in the government's 10-year history, even allowing for a sizable increase in social spending, Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov told the cabinet today.

title: INSIDE
description: A Fuel Economy Loophole

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judge in Microsoft Trial Delays Ruling for U.S. Reply

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORSKY, MORRIS
description: DORSKY-Morris. The Brooklyn College community mourns the passing of Morris Dorsky, professor emeritus and former chairperson of the Department of Art. His forty-one years of teaching and service will be long remembered. Christoph M. Kimmich, President Brooklyn College

title: IRIDIUM IS IN TALKS TO SELL SATELLITES TO CASTLE HARLAN
description: Iridium L.L.C., a bankrupt satellite-telephone company, is in talks to sell satellites and other assets to the investment firm Castle Harlan Inc. for $50 million, Iridium said yesterday in a court filing. The company had planned to shut down and destroy its 66 satellites after failing to find a buyer in March, seven months after filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Motorola Inc., the founder of the Washington-based Iridium, said in March that it would maintain the Iridium system until a plan to take the satellites out of orbit was completed. The United States Bankruptcy Court in New York scheduled a hearing for next Wednesday to decide on Castle Harlan's bid.

title: Mogilny a Bright Note On a Turnover Night
description: The Devils acquired Alexander Mogilny from Vancouver hours before the trading deadline in March for the same reason they traded for Claude Lemieux and Vladimir Malakhov earlier this season: to win a Stanley Cup.

title: Satirical to Sinister, a Gay Festival of Many Moods
description: The mainstreaming of gay and lesbian themes into mass culture has proceeded so swiftly in the last several years that the notion of a film or television show's being a piece of ''gay'' popular art isn't as clear-cut as it used to be.

title: With Loophole, Carmakers Post Mileage Gain
description: A soon-to-be- released government report shows a slight increase in the fuel economy of family vehicles in the 2000 model year. But the rise is mostly thanks to a loophole that gives carmakers extra mileage credit for vehicles that can run on ethanol, even though virtually no one uses that fuel.

title: Islanders Go From Fifth To First in Entry Draft
description: Things could turn around for the recently sold Islanders more quickly than anyone imagined. Yesterday, the Islanders, who were sold in April to Charles Wang and Sanjay Kumar of Computer Associates for $190 million, won the No. 1 pick in the June 24-25 National Hockey League entry draft.

title: Tired Man and Fresh Question
description: Just after the Knicks lost Game 5 Wednesday night, the door to the locker room swung open. Slumped forward in a chair, his face weary from exhaustion, Patrick Ewing was decorated in ice bags.

title: GLOBO IN DEAL WITH TELECOM ITALIA
description: In another partnership of telecommunications and Internet companies in Latin America, Brazil's largest media company, Organizacoes Globo, sold a 30 percent stake in the Web portal Globo.com to Telecom Italia for $810 million. Globo plans to use the capital to expand in Latin America and to develop wireless Internet capabilities. Globo said the Web site, which started at the end of March, had an average of 700,000 visitors a day in April. The company plans to issue shares of Globo.com on the Nasdaq.

title: For Knicks, Everything Hurts but Pride
description: When the Knicks' practice ended today, the doors to the gym opened, and scattered around the court were hobbled players with ice packs strapped to their appendages and electric-stimulation machines wired to their aching bones.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a heading in the World Briefing column yesterday referred incorrectly to efforts to form a new United Nations arms inspection commission for Iraq. The Iraqi oil minister rejected the panel, saying his government would not cooperate. The heading should have read, ''U.N. Panel Rejected,'' not ''Re-elected.''

title: Making It 'To Go'
description: New York, with its large and diverse selection of restaurants, has always been a great place for dining out, but it also has an impressive range of cuisines available for takeout. Here are a dozen places for those times you prefer to eat in. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLIE, ROSALIE L.
description: COLIE-Rosalie L., of East Amwell Twp., NJ, formerly of Short Hills, NJ, on May 31. Widow of Hon. Frederic L. Colie. Arrangements and interment private. No calling hours. Memorial contributions may be made to Catskill Fly Fishing Center and Museum, PO Box 1295, Livingston Manor, NY 12758.

title: Pilgrim's Progress
description: Signs of the new millennium will be as scarce as unicorns at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine tomorrow. In fact, the atmosphere on the church grounds will be more reminiscent of the year 1000 than 2000.

title: Mexico's Dot-Com Generation Is Voting for Change
description: The presidential campaign has opened a vast demographic divide between the old and new Mexicos, a political fault line that runs smack through the Martinez household, tucked along a tidy suburban street in central Mexico.

description: To the Editor:

title: Symbolic Line Divides Jews In Borough Park; A Debate Over Strictures For Sabbath Observance
description: At dawn on a Friday morning, hours before the Sabbath, Rabbi Moshe Unsdorfer stepped into a cherry picker and sent himself 20 feet into the air above Borough Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ARLENE LICHT
description: COHEN-Arlene Licht, on May 30, 2000. Loving mother of Stephanie, Jason and Dara. Beloved sister of Louise Ungar (Louis) and Arnold Licht (Susan). Devoted daughter of Esther and the late Meyer Licht. Best possible aunt of Eliza and Jonah Licht, Joshua and Zachary Ungar. She was a teacher to us all whose lessons we will keep forever. Shiva until June 6th at the home of Dr. Licht, 130 Amity Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201.

title: FEUD INTENSIFIES AT HYUNDAI
description: Resisting orders from Chung Ju Yung, the founder of the Hyundai Group, to hire a professional manager, the board of an affiliate, the Hyundai Motor Company, voted to retain its chairman, Chung Mong Koo, left, who is also the eldest son of the Chung family. The vote came a day after the elder Chung said he and his other son would cede management control of South Korea's largest business conglomerate as part of a major downsizing effort.

description: To the Editor:

description: June 2, 2000

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.

title: Report Gives U.S. Education 'A' for Effort
description: An annual survey issued by the federal government today paints a picture of a nation newly committing itself to education at all levels, with more toddlers in preschool, more high school students going directly to college and more adults returning to class.

title: Science Finding A Home Onstage
description: DURING previews for ''Copenhagen,'' the playwright Michael Frayn received a letter from a woman who had just seen it. ''She said that neither she nor anyone she was with liked all the science in the show,'' Mr. Frayn recalled in a recent interview, ''and that unless I took it out it wasn't going to last long on Broadway.''

title: Marketers bet on the concept of good luck as a selling tool.
description: WHO knew when Barbra Streisand asked the musical question ''How Lucky Can You Get?'' that Madison Avenue would provide this answer: You ain't seen nothing yet.

title: Flexibility On Nature Is Needed, Bush Says
description: Gov. George W. Bush criticized the Clinton-Gore administration today for an approach to land conservation that he said involved too much federal muscle and too little local flexibility. Instead, he proposed using federal resources and incentives to coax state governments and private citizens into greater conservation efforts.

title: Final Ruling in Microsoft Antitrust Case Is Unexpectedly Delayed for About a Week
description: The federal judge trying the Microsoft antitrust case unexpectedly agreed to delay his final ruling for about a week today, giving the Justice Department time to reply to Microsoft's proposal to water down the government's breakup plan.

title: Bruised Foot Sidelines Behrens
description: Behrens, the 7-5 favorite in tomorrow's Massachusetts Handicap, was scratched yesterday after his trainer decided that his bruised left front foot was too tender to race.

title: Disney Launches Co-Branded Auction Service With EBay
description: Disney Launches Co-Branded Auction Service With EBay

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Yonkers Girl, 3, Found Safe After Abduction, Police Say
description: A 3-year-old girl turned up in Harlem, unhurt but terrified, after she was abducted from her grandmother by seven armed men this morning.

title: Governors End Port Authority Rift That Blocked Billions in Projects
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman settled an 18-month standoff at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday, clearing the way for long-blocked projects worth billions to both states.

title: School Vendors Charged With Price Fixing
description: The Justice Department yesterday charged more than a dozen food vendors that supply New York City schools with rigging prices on multimillion dollar contracts for produce and frozen foods.

title: Murdoch's Son Gets Post
description: The News Corporation, the giant Australian media company that owns the Fox television network, said this week that it had named James Murdoch to be chief executive and chairman of Star TV, an Asian satellite television service,which reaches 80 million households in 53 countries. Mr. Murdoch, 27, is the youngest of the four children of the chairman of the News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch. John Murdoch has been interim co-chairman of Star TV since February. He replaces Gareth Chang, who stepped down earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, RUTH
description: DAVIS-Ruth, died peacefully on May 31 at Elim Park, Cheshire, CT. Wife of the late Edward English, who predeceased her; wife of the late Robert Davis; beloved mother of Nancy Kaufmann; devoted grandmother of Sally Kirkpatrick and John Kaufmann; great grandmother of Molly and Gabriel Kirkpatrick, and Michael Kaufmann. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her.

title: New Leaders At American Legacy
description: The American Legacy Foundation in Washington said yesterday that it had named three executives to new posts as part of a reorganization that comes after the departure of Charles A. Wolfe, 38, chief operating officer. The foundation is financed by the recent $206 billion settlement reached by 46 state attorneys general and the tobacco industry.

title: Nassau G.O.P. Leaders Balk at Plan for Nonunion Layoffs
description: Just hours after Gov. George E. Pataki's emissary came here today urging cooperation among Nassau County leaders as they try to solve the county's fiscal crisis, a new row broke out over a Democratic proposal to lay off a 10th of the county government's nonunion work force.

title: I.B.M. Signs Wireless Deals With Internet Consulting Companies
description: I.B.M. Signs Wireless Deals With Internet Consulting Companies

description: Feature

title: Sua Wins Discus Title For 4th Straight Year
description: Seilala Sua of U.C.L.A. won her fourth consecutive women's discus title at the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships yesterday at Duke University in Durham, N.C.

title: Public Interests; A Month to Remember
description: I tell you, it's good to have May over with.

title: It's Vivaldi, but It Might Have Been Another Guy
description: The Little Orchestra Society's production of Vivaldi's ''Tamerlano'' at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday was the second American premiere performance of an opera by the composer within a month. At this rate, the store of unheard Vivaldi pieces will last only a few more years.

title: While Conservatives and Liberals React, Gore and Bush Hedge on Ruling
description: Conservatives condemned and liberals applauded the court decision today denying Elian Gonzalez an asylum hearing, while the two politicians most prominently seeking support in the political center -- Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas -- temporized.

title: Rangers Are Giving Sather Complete Control of the Team
description: The Glen Sather reign officially began yesterday, when Madison Square Garden's president, Dave Checketts, named him the Rangers' team president and general manager.

title: GILLETTE IS NEGOTIATING TO SELL PEN BUSINESSES
description: The Gillette Company, the world's largest maker of razors and blades, said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its lagging Paper Mate, Parker and Waterman pen businesses to Newell Rubbermaid Inc. Gillette said the talks also included its Liquid Paper correction fluid unit. The businesses had $743 million in sales last year. Negotiations with Newell, which makes Berol pens and other office products, are expected to continue for several weeks. Shares of Boston-based Gillette rose $1.375 each, to $34.75, while Newell, which is based in Freeport, Ill., rose 50 cents, to $26.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Pickens Is Not Released
description: The Cincinnati Bengals did not release their disgruntled wide receiver Carl Pickens as expected yesterday, and so his agent, Steve Zucker, could not begin working the phones -- with the expected first call to the Jets -- to find his client a new home.

title: Euro RSCG Buys Internet Specialist
description: Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, part of Havas Advertising, said yesterday that it had acquired Middleberg & Associates in New York, a public relations agency specializing in Internet clients. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, DOROTHY
description: SILVER-Dorothy, on June 1, 2000. Beloved wife of Allan Silver. Loving mother of Laurie (John) Wells. Adoring grandmother of Meagan. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday, June 4, 9:45 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Robert Mapplethorpe
description: 'Auto-Portrait Polaroids of the 1970s'

title: Metro Business; Retailer Will End Selective Check Rule
description: Family Dollar Stores, a national discount retailer, has agreed to end its practice of refusing checks from customers in minority neighborhoods, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said yesterday.

title: 1945 War Story Reborn at Last
description: During World War II it was possible to play a recorded greeting from home, but for Sgt. Warnicki (Freddie Steele) in William Wellman's ''Story of G.I. Joe,'' it necessitates lugging a large Victrola all over Italy. At each pause in battle he hauls out the carefully wrapped machine and the record his wife and child have made for him. Each time the recording plays backward, emitting unintelligible squawks. By the time it spins properly, he has gone mad with battle fatigue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, SELMA
description: BLACK-Selma. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society express profound sorrow at the loss of Selma Black of Portland, Maine. We extend heartfelt condolences to her son, Scott Black, a visionary supporter who spearheaded the innovative Scott Black Executive Management Program at the Technion Institute of Management. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shephard, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President David Friedman, President New England Region Frank Resnek, Chairman New England Region

title: True North Shifts Health Care Units
description: True North Communications in Chicago said yesterday that it would realign its health care agency operations. The reorganization mirrors the changes made in September at its two principal advertising agency operations, Bozell Worldwide and FCB Worldwide.

title: Tokyo Journal; The Little White Ball That Put Japan in the Red
description: During the economic boom in the 1980's, few things reflected this country's exploding wealth better than its sudden madness for golf.

title: Big Women, 'Little Women'
description: Even as Sunday's Tony Awards signal the end of one season, another slate of shows is wheeling into sight, whether you're ready or not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHN, DR. RICHARD JAY
description: KOHN-Dr. Richard Jay. 51, passed peacefully at home in Kensington, CA on May 28, 2000. Beloved husband of Marianne Betterly-Kohn and father of Jack. Richard directed Lord of the Dance/Destroyer of Illusion, a film on the Tibetan and Sherpa Buddhist ritual and festival in Nepal. He was founding director of the International Buddhist Film Festival, executive editor of the forthcoming Buddhism on Film and Lord of the Dance. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, GEORGE IRVING
description: BELL-George Irving, died on May 28th, 2000, from leukemia complications following routine surgery. George was born August 4, 1926, in Evanston, Illiois. He received a BS in Physics from Harvard University in 1947 and a PhD in Theoretical Physics from Cornell University in 1951, where he studied nuclear physics under Hans Bethe. George moved to New Mexico in 1951, where he was a driving force in the Theoretical Physics Division of the Los Alamos National Laboratory until his death. In the early part of his career there, he worked on reactor physics and safety. By the 60's, his interests shifted towards biology and immunology. He served as a group leader for the Theoretical Biology and Biophysics from 1974-1990 and Theoretical Physics Division leader from 1980-1989. He was a founder of the Center for Human Genome Studies in 1988. George authored three books and hundreds of scientific articles and was elected a fellow of the American Physical Society and the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS). George was also an avid mountaineer and outdoorsman. His first exposure to technical climbing came during a summer camp to the Tetons while he was in high school. It quickly developed into a passion and he went on four expeditiions to the Peruvian Andes in the 50's. He and is team made the first ascent of Yerpaja in 1950 and of Salcantay in 1952, two of Peru's highest and most difficult peaks. In 1953, George attempted K2 (then unclimbed) with a well-knit team. They endured a horrific storm for a week at 25,000', and a terrible accident on the way down. The entire team could easily have been lost, but miraculously all but one team member staggered into base camp. This was a pivotal event in the lives of the seven surviving team members, who became as close as brothers. George was carried out from the base camp and eventually lost two toes to frostbite. Despite this, his enthusiasm for climbing was undiminished. He went on several more Himalayan expeditions, culminating in the first ascent of Masherbrum (the 25th highest peak in the world) in 1960. George then married Virginia (Ginny) Lotz in 1956. In Ginny, he found an enthusiastic life partner and together they enjoyed many outdoor adventures. They had two children: Carolyn and George, Jr. Family backpacking and climbing trips were the norm. In their later years, George and Ginny enjoyed a dozen treks in the Himalayas, and another dozen to mountain ranges in the rest of the world. Even at age 73, he remained in remarkable physical shape, hiking 14 miles the weekend before his death. A brilliant but unassuming man, he was a great inspiration to his family, his many friends, colleagues, and young aspiring mountaineers. George is survived by his wife, Ginny of Los Alamos, New Mexico; his daughter, Carolyn BellPrince and grandchildren Kaitlin, Austin and Derek Prince all of Los Alamos; his son, George Irving Bell, Jr. and wife, Esther Brady, and grandchildren, Allison and Henry Bell all of Boulder, CO. He is also survived by his elder sister. Dr. Barbara Bell, of the Harvard Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics. A memorial service is planned and will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers the family suggests donations to the American Himalayan Foundation, 909 Montgomery St., Suite 400, San Francisco, CA 94133 or the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 201 Eubank Northeast, Suite B2, Albuquerque, NM 87123. For information contact Berardinelli Family Funeral Service, 1399 Luisa, Santa Fe, 984-8600.

title: NEXIS AGREES TO PURCHASE OF RISKWISE INTERNATIONAL
description: Nexis, known best for its Lexis-Nexis database of legal information, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the privately held consumer data company RiskWise International L.L.C. for about $90 million. RiskWise, based in St. Cloud, Minn., sells information gathered from consumer records to help businesses manage customer risk. The purchase is part of Nexis's effort to expand its product line. The Dayton, Ohio company, which is owned by the Dutch-British publisher Reed-Elsevier P.L.C., sells its database services to businesses, government agencies and schools.

The company, which was put up for sale in November, reorganized under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after a series of asbestos-products lawsuits. title: CRESTLINE CAPITAL AND BEDROCK PARTNERS TO BUY HOTELS
description: The Crestline Capital Corporation, which leases and manages upscale hotels, signed a letter of intent yesterday to form a joint venture with Bedrock Partners II L.P. to buy hotels worth $250 million in the next two to three years. The venture plans to buy 15 to 20 midprice hotels and turn them into more-upscale properties, the companies said. Crestline said it expected to manage most or all of the hotels through its Crestline Hotels and Resorts Division. Separately from the venture with Bedrock, Crestline may invest another $600 million in hotels over the next two or three years, the company has said. Crestline was formed last year when it was spun off into a separate company from the Host Marriott Corporation.

title: Public Necessities
description: In a city of millions, it is a disgrace that there are so few public bathrooms and that New York City officials have failed to build any new pay toilets for public use despite years of debate. Now Peter Vallone, the City Council speaker, has proposed a modest start -- 50 toilets that would be deployed on city streets where most urgently needed. The proposal should not get sidelined again as city leaders finish their budget negotiations in the next few days. If Paris, London, Athens and even Palo Alto can manage to make modern, even stylish toilets available, New Yorkers deserve their own advanced resolution to this civic need as well.
