title: HOW RACE IS LIVED IN AMERICA
description: Two generations after the end of legal discrimination, race still ignites political debates -- over Civil War flags, for example, or police profiling. But the wider public discussion of race relations seems muted by a full-employment economy and by a sense, particularly among many whites, that the time of large social remedies is past. Race relations are being defined less by political action than by daily experience, in schools, in sports arenas, in pop culture and at worship, and especially in the workplace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAZIER, REV. DONALD HART
description: FRAZIER-Rev. Donald Hart Frazier, 88, of 1821 Mooring Line Dr., Vero Beach, FL., and Old Orchard Lane, East Marion, LI, NY, died May 31, 2000 at Eastern Long Island Memorial Hospital. He was the husband of Elizabeth Hart Frazier. He was born Oct. 18, 1911 in Forksville, PA, son of the late Rev. William Fiske Frazier and Minnie Hart Frazier. He was a graduate of Oberlin College, 1933, Oberlin, OH and Yale University Divinity School, 1938, New Haven, CT. He was a member of the faculty of the New Haven Junior College of Commerce, predecessor institutionto Quinnipiac College and at the Arnold College of Physical Education, where he taught history, government and economics. Rev. Frazier served as minister of the First Congregational Church of West Haven, CT from 1960 to 1970. He also served as minister of Congregational churches in Easton and Shelton, CT, Proctor, VT, and in Cedar Grove, NJ from 1949 to 1959. He and Mrs. Frazier, who was ordained in the United Church of Christ in 1972, co-ministered in 14 Connecticut interim pastorates. During these years, he also represented the Presbyterian Minister's Fund, and had been development director of Albertus Magnus College. He was scribe of the Middle Atlantic conference of the United Church of Christ. Rev. Frazier was a director of the Commission on Development of the United Church of Christ in New York City and responsible for nationwide seminars for ministers and lay leaders on special gifts and wills. He was the Associate Western Regional Director of the Christian Higher Education Fund of the Congregational Churches, which was a special effort of the denomination to strengthen its higher education interests in the United States and 14 countries abroad. He helped found and organize the Community Church in Cedar Grove, where he was also instrumental in the organization of the Jewish community, and together with the congregation of the Community Church provided the Jewish community with a place of worship until the temple was dedicated. He served as a spiritual advisor to the newly organized Jewish community as well as a congregational minister. In West Haven, CT he was a chaplain of the US Veterans Administration Hospital, and helped found the community church nursery school, and educational organization open to all pre-school level children. He was a member of the Rotary Club and a director of the New Haven Visiting Nurse Association, and a founding member of the West Haven Human Relations Council. In Florida, since 1984, he was a member of the Yale Club of the Treasure Coast, and on the Board of Directors of the Atlantic Classical Orchestra, and a supporter and volunteer at the Environmental Learning Center and Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institute. He was an active member of both the Community Church and the Unitarian Universalist Church in Vero Beach. He was instrumental in helping save land for a bike and walking path around the West Haven shore, and for saving Devella-Mills land in New Jersey as open space. Rev. Frazier has written many books and publications. His interests included nature study, birding, geology and travel. He and Mrs. Frazier travelled extensively on all seven continents, seeing the Antartic for the second time last year. He leaves his wife of 64 years, Elizabeth Hart Frazier, two sons, William H. Frazier, M.D. of Vero Beach, FL and Robert H. Frazier or Rowayton, CT, two daughters, Bonnie F. Lancraft of Madison, CT and Mary F. McDaniel of Troy, NY, and 10 grandchildren. Gifts in his memory may be made to Planned Parenthood, Vero Beach, FL 32963 or AIDS Research and Treatment Center, 2407 Okeechobee Road, Fort Pierce, FL 34950. Memorial services will be held Saturday on Long Island.

title: A Mambo King Bows Out
description: The orchestra leader Tito Puente, who died Wednesday at the age of 77, fronted a hot Latin jazz orchestra for more than half a century and was broadly influential as a percussionist, composer and arranger. Known in the Latino community as El Rey -- The King -- Mr. Puente is primarily viewed as a pillar of Latin music. But he was also an American original -- and a crossover figure in the 1950's, before the term was invented.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; GULF OF MEXICO OIL ZONE
description: Mexico and the United States have agreed to divide a 6,640-square-mile area of continental shelf in the middle of the Gulf of Mexico, a region both sides believe is rich in oil. Luis Tellez, Mexico's energy minister, said at a news conference that after two years of talks, Mexico will claim 4,100 square miles, or 62 percent of the region, and the United States will take the rest. Both sides agreed not to drill for oil for 10 years while they study the geology of their segments. The treaty must be ratified by both the Mexican Senate and the United States Congress. Dan Fineren

title: A Lamentation by Philip Roth In a Black Woman's Voice

Toward the end of the book Ernestine describes the circumstances of Coleman's early years to Nathan, and the two discuss how Coleman, who is passing himself off as white, was hounded from his teaching position at Athena College for remarks mistakenly taken to be racist. Both the portrayals of the black characters and the views Roth puts into their mouths have generated some uneasiness among a number of reviewers and critics. Here is the ''good and virtuous'' Ernestine lamenting the atmosphere of intimidation on college campuses today, the role of Black History Month, and the general decline of academic standards.

title: CIGNA SELLS PORTION OF ITS REINSURANCE BUSINESS

Cigna said the businesses it sold included its United States individual and group life reinsurance businesses as well as its United States accidental death reinsurance business. title: A Cleanup at Brookhaven Is Not the Major Problem

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHEY, SIMON C. (CY)
description: GERSHEY-Simon C. (Cy), died at home on June 2, 2000. Son of a rabbi, born in Johnstown, PA on May 12, 1902, Cy raised himself up from poverty and abandonment to become a nationally known and respected leader of the jewelry industry. While his career included long and productive tenures with the Benrus, Gruen and Bulova watch companies, his personal and professional associations extended across the U.S. from small stores and small towns to all the major jewelry chains in the largest cities. Cy was widely read and had a strong grasp of history, but he received his informal education through interactions with the broadest range of people. He loved challenges and all aspects of boxing, from training to strategy and execution, and he practiced them literally and figuratively all of his life. His successes may be measured in many ways, but most of all by his many good friends and aquaintances, and never forgetting his origins. To his devoted and loving wife of 60 years, Mimsi, his son, Edward, daughter-in-law, Barbara, grandchildren, Simon and Cristina, and surviving friends, he says, ''Just keep smiling.''

title: Where I Seem to Find the Happiness I Seek
description: STANDING in front of 200 earnest female faces and a smattering of sympathetic men at a recent Harvard Hillel conference on ''superwomen,'' I realized my customary ironic autobiographical anecdotes were falling flat. This audience expected substance, a concrete point of view on ''having it all'' -- plus relevant thought on the future of feminism, not to mention Judaism. And I was offering my best stories about my mother.

title: Today's Style, Tomorrow's Antique
description: THE extraordinary popularity of ''Antiques Roadshow'' on public television has made us more sensitive to the treasures that lie all around, just waiting to be discovered. The antiques business is flourishing. Just before Memorial Day weekend I took an exploratory tour, starting from Eastport and ending in East Hampton, where my stamina ran out. In a driving distance of 40 miles, I counted no fewer than 27 antique shops.

title: Targeting Mosquitoes
description: Westchester County officials have embarked on a comprehensive program to eradicate the mosquitoes that carry the West Nile virus.

title: Silent Cal's Home Speaks Volumes
description: FOR anyone weary of the glitz and spin of modern presidential campaigns and longing for a quieter time when American presidents wore hats and spared the electorate their confessions, it may be time to repair, as my wife, Jaqueline, and I did, to Plymouth Notch, the Vermont birthplace and home of Silent Cal, as Calvin Coolidge was nicknamed by contemporaries.

title: Who Dares Call This Maestro a Lame Duck?
description: KURT MASUR and the New York Philharmonic ended another season at Avery Fisher Hall last night with Mahler's Ninth Symphony, one of the great valedictory works in the symphonic repertory. And indeed, goodbyes might seem to be in order, as talk in musical circles centers increasingly on who will replace Mr. Masur as the orchestra's music director.

title: Waiting For Parole
description: IAN HAWKER was convicted and sentenced in Bergen County last year for a fairly simple offense, hindering arrest, and was eligible for parole March 10. While the rest of the Knicks gathered their things and left Madison Square Garden after their elimination, he leaned back in his locker as if retreating into an isolation booth.

title: High-Tech Philanthropy in a Low-Tech Guatemalan Village

title: It Shares Custody, but PBS Gets the Tonys First
description: JEFF FOLMSBEE seems calmer now. ''Do You Wanna Dance?'' is playing, and Boyd Gaines is onstage in the empty Vivian Beaumont Theater, wooing Deborah Yates, better known as the Girl in the Yellow Dress (but at the moment wearing a fleece top and pants). A crew of five is filming the couple's every move as they run through a scene from Susan Stroman's dance play ''Contact.'' The crew has already shot Ms. Stroman leading a rehearsal of dancers and a rehearsal of the show's 18th-century girl-in-a-swing scene.

title: John Coolidge, Guardian of President's Legacy. Dies at 93
description: John Coolidge, the son of President Calvin Coolidge and the oldest living offspring of an American president, died on Wednesday in Lebanon, N.H. He was 93.

title: Third Parties Make Choices In Senate Race
description: With as much relief as enthusiasm, New York's Conservative and Liberal Parties reverted to type today, endorsing Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Senate after both parties had endured a queasy several months that had left their nominations in doubt.

title: Corzine Deplores an Ad Linking Him to Slavery
description: In a last-ditch effort to woo minority voters, Jon S. Corzine stumped tirelessly today in black neighborhoods from Montclair to Trenton. He shook hands, kissed babies, and then pulled out what might be his best campaign weapon: a glossy attack ad that links him to slavery in Africa.

title: May 28-June 3; A Statement, Not Fashion
description: The arrival of 2 of the 11 women legislators at the opening of Iran's new Parliament, the first dominated by reformers since the 1979 Islamic revolution, signaled a change. Elaheh Koulai from Tehran and Tahreh Rezazadeh from Shiraz chose not to wear the chador, the head-to-toe black covering that has been an Iranian symbol for two decades. More reformist chic than radical, they wore long shapeless coats and pinned their black scarves tightly under their chins so no hair showed, which the law requires.

title: Robert C.Bassett, 89, Lawyer and Publisher

title: MERCHANTS LOSE LICENSES
description: The tobacco-selling licenses of five Westchester businesses were suspended for selling tobacco to people under 18 several times. The suspensions were a result of a crackdown on violators of the state's Adolescent Tobacco Use Prevention Act. Under the law, first-time offenders can be fined up to $1,000. Those who have violated the law three times in two years, or four times overall, are subject to a suspension and can only reapply for a license after a year. Licenses were suspended from the CVS store Brook's Drugs, Rye Brook; CVS Pharmacy, Ardsley; Grand Union, Dobbs Ferry; West Hempstead Service Center, Pelham Manor; and Manor Market, Hastings-on-Hudson. ELSA BRENNER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, HELENE
description: ISAACS-Helene. AMIT is deeply grieved by the untimely passing of our beloved past Director of Programming in America and Israel. A true ''woman of valor,'' Helene Isaacs, in her long Jewish communal service career, taught us all how to love, cherish, and appreciate Torah values, the State of Israel and Yiddishkeit. Her loving kindness, dynamism and caring heart will be missed by the thousands who call her ''a dear friend.'' Shiva is being observed at her home in Israel. Heartfelt condolences to her beloved husband Kim, children Rebecca, Shira and Judah, and the entire family. Sondra Sokal, President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSE, EVELYN
description: ROSE-Evelyn. 50 years ago today, we clasped hands and vowed in sickness and in health to love and cherish til death do us part. It's a little over a year that you're gone. When we were together, each year I loved you more. Now that we're apart, each day I miss you so much more. But I am comforted that the essence of your beautiful self has been so strong in our daughters Leslie and Lauren and the granddaughters, Anya and Julia. Happy Golden Anniversary, my Beloved. Peace and Love, Phil

description: Merton H. Miller, a professor of finance who won the 1990 Nobel in economic science for helping develop theories that were used to evaluate the risks of individual investments, died yesterday at his home in Chicago. He was 77 and had been suffering from lymphoma, said Allan Friedman, a spokesman for the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business.

title: QUICK BITE/Millington -- Atlantic City; The Sub and the Sublime
description: The James Beard Foundation Awards, presented since 1991, are something like the Academy Awards of restaurants and chefs, recognized for setting ''new or consistent standards of excellence.'' This year's prizes, awarded last month in Manhattan, recognized two New Jerseyans. One was Craig Shelton, named best chef in the Mid-Atlantic region. He cooks at the elegant Ryland Inn in Millington, which he also owns. When we called him for a comment, he was in Chicago being inducted into the Fine Dining Hall of Fame, so we were directed to his press spokeswoman, Joan Szibdat. Mr. Shelton was ''delighted and thrilled,'' to win the award, she said, and he gave the black-tie crowd at the ceremony last month his heartfelt and emotional thanks. Since the annoucement, she added, ''Craig has received a torrent of responses from people in and outside the industry.''

title: Race in America
description: A generation ago, after riots in several major cities, the Kerner Commission warned that the United States was in danger of becoming two nations, one black and one white. That has not happened. America is now an inescapably multiracial society from which there is no turning back for whites or blacks -- in its schools, its workplaces, its churches, its military and its cultural institutions. Yet divisions and frustrations persist on both sides, in minds and hearts if not in the laws of the land.

title: NO DAMAGES IN REZONING
description: The town of Cortlandt does not have to pay $15 million in damages for rezoning the site of a mine, an appeals court has ruled. Briarcliff Associates of Briarcliff Manor had bought the mine in 1985 and had hoped to expand it into a gravel mine. After the town rezoned the site to prevent its further use in 1988, Briarcliff Associates filed suit, claiming that the rezoning resulted in an unconstitutional taking of property. The State Supreme Court ruled in Briarcliff's favor and set damages at $15 million. The Appellate Division, however, overruled that decision. But Briarcliff plans to appeal to the State Court of Appeals, said Stuart R. Shamberg, a lawyer for Briarcliff Associates. ROBERT WORTH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACRAE, CAMERON F. LEBOEUF
description: MacRAE-Cameron F. LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae mourns with profound sorrow the death of our founding and name partner on May 29 in Hobe Sound, Florida. He was Senior Partner and Chairman of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae for many years, and set the mold for the national and international growth of the Firm. During the Second World War, Mr. MacRae served as Assistant Director of the Readjustment Division of the War Department, while on active duty as a Colonel in the Army. He also served as President of the Federal Energy Bar Association from 1969-1970, and served as a consultant to the Task Force on Water Resources and Power of the Hoover Commission from 1953-1955. He will be sorely missed, and we extend our deepest sympathy to all members of his bereaved family. Funeral services will be private.

title: May 28-June 3; A Question of $70,000
description: A psychiatrist discharged from the Air Force after announcing that he was gay filed a lawsuit challenging a demand that he reimburse the government for the cost of his education: more than $70,000. Dr. John Hensala said he did not know he was homosexual in 1986 when he joined a Pentagon program that paid for a medical degree from Northwestern University. In return, he was to serve four years in the Air Force. But seven months before he was to begin active duty, Dr. Hensala told the Defense Department that he was gay. The Air Force said he did so to avoid serving. JANE FRITSCH

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; Designs That Reach Out and Grab
description: DANIEL LIBESKIND is a phenomenon. With only two completed buildings to his credit -- one the much-publicized Jewish Museum in Berlin, the other the Felix-Nussbaum-Haus in Osnabruck, Germany -- Mr. Libeskind, the 54-year-old American architect, is already an acknowledged leader in his field. That both buildings are museums, one of the most coveted of architectural commissions, is in itself unheard of for first projects. That this debut breaks all rules about museum architecture is also unusual. Add to this Mr. Libeskind's deep commitment to music, poetry and philosophy and you come up with an individual as complex as his designs.

The hotel will be connected to the newly renovated War Memorial building near the State House complex. The $58 million project, to be built with the help of several state and local loans and grants, is to be completed by spring of 2002. The 200-room hotel also will include a 15,500-square-foot conference center and a 657-space parking garage. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Police Brace For Protests In Windsor And Detroit
description: For the next three days, anyone wearing a mask in this city or carrying gasoline in a portable container will go to jail. And those in possession of just about anything that could cause a disruption can expect intense police scrutiny.

title: Tony Blair's Modernizing Ways
description: Traveling in York, England, recently, I latched on to a tour group of local primary school children who were visiting the Yorkshire Museum (Warren Hoge, May 14). The museum guide stimulated group discussion by throwing out the odd question. York is the major religious center of North England, and the guide asked the children to name England's patron saint. He and I did our best to stifle our laughter at the unhesitating reply: Tony Blair.

title: Jessica Rosenworcel, Mark Bailen
description: Jessica Rosenworcel, the daughter of Willa Rosenworcel and Dr. Elliott Rosenworcel of West Hartford, Conn., is to be married today to Mark Ira Bailen, a son of Helene Bailen and Dr. David A. Bailen of Newton Centre, Mass. Rabbi Bernard H. Mehlman is to officiate at the Lord Thompson Manor, a historic house in Thompson, Conn.

title: Lives; Clicking the Habit
description: Now that my habit is history, I don't mind going public. Sharing, that is. Sure, I miss the high. I'll miss it every day for the rest of my life. But I know I'm better off clean.

description: A Wall Street Skyscraper

title: When Iced Tea Is More Than a Drink
description: ICED tea season has started. Though there is a vast array of ready-to-drink bottled iced tea in all sorts of flavors, and iced tea mix galore, homemade iced tea, brewed from high-quality tea leaves, is so easy to prepare it can always be kept on hand.

description: McDANIEL-Wilbert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Wilbert McDaniel, associated with The Times from 1966 until retiring in 1992.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALINOTI, VIRGINIA A.
description: VALINOTI-Virginia A. on June 2, 2000 of Plandome Manor, NY. Beloved wife of Joseph R. Dear mother of Joseph III, Virginia Oates, Richard and Jean Stern. Also survived by 5 grandchildren. Sister of Isabel Ferrara & Thomas Ferrara. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Monday from 2-5 & 7-9pm. Funeral Mass on Tuesday, June 6th, 9:45am, St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset with interment to follow in Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Pt. Washington, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Breast Cancer Research c/o Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, 1275 York Ave, NYC, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, THEODORE (TED)
description: STONE-Theodore (Ted). We mourn, with his devoted son Michael and cousins Ted and Erica Braude, the loss of or our beloved friend, Ted Stone. His presence enriched our lives during more than 45 years in Croton. A memorial service will be held Sunday, June 25th, 12 Noon at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glengary Rd, Croton-on-Hudson, New York. Elaine and Sol Gluck

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Cafe for All Types, Active and Passive

title: May 28-June 3; Record Outs
description: Randy Velarde, the Oakland Athletics' second baseman, became the 11th player in major league baseball history to turn in an unassisted triple play. With none out and runners on first and second, the Athletics' opponents, the Yankees, tried a double steal. Velarde went to cover second base. Shane Spencer hit a line drive up the middle right to Velarde, who tagged out Jorge Posada as he ran from first and then stepped on second base to force out Tino Martinez. Three outs in less than three seconds. ''You have a better chance of getting struck by lightning,'' Velarde said afterward. ALAN SCHWARZ

title: A Mother's Place, And a Father's
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of the Times; Interleague Gimmick Can Have Its Moments
description: DURING this brief June tomfoolery, interleague ball brings out a few interesting matchups, but mostly meetings between strangers that strike no sparks.

title: A Safer, Slower Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Bridge, the Magazine: Born 1995; Suspended, 2000
description: Brooklyn may be enjoying a boom period, but Brooklyn Bridge has fallen down.

title: Sailing Fast Downwind and Into a Different Age
description: ''I won't do cheesy to win; I won't protest when it's not necessary,'' said Amanda Clark, allowing the qualifying conjunction to begin tacking around her port side. ''But I will not let the girls think that they can beat me. I will try to keep the image of advantage.''

title: Christina von Riesenfelder, Kevin Roe
description: Christina von Riesenfelder, the daughter of Elizabeth and Carl von Riesenfelder of Manchester, Vt., was married yesterday to Kevin Michael Roe, a son of Joan Ellen Roe and Dr. Patrick A. Roe of Fox Point, Wis. The Rev. Warren Sazama performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church in Bennington, Vt.

title: May 28-June 3; Closer to Going Home
description: In a decision that caused several people in Miami's Little Havana to sink to their knees in despair, a federal appellate panel upheld the right of immigration officials to deny 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez a political asylum hearing. It was one more hurdle, but not the last, in Juan Miguel Gonzalez's legal fight to return his son to Cuba. Lawyers for Elian's Miami relatives are expected to appeal. RICK BRAGG

title: East, Meet West
description: CONTRARY to what you might think, the name of this restaurant has nothing to do with Montclair's best-known citizen, Yogi Berra, who is famously (and probably erroneously) supposed to have said, ''It's deja vu all over again.'' Manop Sutipayakul, who is both co-chef and co-owner, says modestly that the name was meant to suggest that diners might want to return again and again.

title: Ideas & Trends: Rear Window; What Are You Afraid Of? A Hidden Issue Emerges
description: A HOT new issue is lurking just below the political radar, ready to explode onto the American electorate.

title: Of, by and for Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: Christoph Blocher's Dual Career
description: Martin Ebner, the Swiss billionaire, may have received most of the attention last week when, as the chairman and largest shareholder of Algroup of Switzerland, the world's second-largest aluminum producer, he engineered the company's $4.7 billion sale to Alcan Aluminium of Canada. But the major supporting character in the company's action, and its second-largest shareholder, is his old friend Christoph Blocher, who has come to prominence in a whole new arena.

title: Poor Driving Habits Indicate Danger Ahead
description: To the editor:

title: Discovering America, In 50 Steps
description: SOME Americans know immediately, rattling the number off with a healthy braggadocio. Others have to ponder for a while, count on fingers, use a pencil. ''Uh, can I consult a map?'' they say, or later, ''Does just being in an airport count?'' Others, knocking off the entire list, are so proud of the fact that they arrange to have it listed in their obituaries: ''Jane Doe loved to travel, and was particularly proud of having visited all 50 states.''

title: Mets' Leiter Manages a Good Result Despite Bad Stuff
description: As he answered questions after last night's game, Al Leiter had to stop several times and insist that he was happy. The Mets' left-hander had just beaten the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, 1-0, but he had done it in spite of himself. Leiter tried to acknowledge the satisfaction in winning while admitting his own failings.

title: The World; To Win the Peace You Dance With the Devil
description: NORTHERN IRELAND is locked in a grim struggle to trade in tested old tribal instincts for risky new communal ones, and the qualms and tensions in that swap were on display last week in Belfast in the actions of a central figure in the peace negotiations, David Trimble.

title: Microsoft Will Test Justices' Prowess
description: WHEN the Supreme Court confronted its first Internet case three years ago, the justices received special training from their library staff. The lessons ''helped assure each of us that we knew how to use the Net and understood the technical matters at issue,'' Justice Stephen G. Breyer recalled a few weeks ago at a symposium on biomedical research in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Margaret Porter, William Bond Jr.
description: Dr. Margaret Louise Porter, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Porter of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Edward Bond Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bond of Rochester. The Rev. Daniel Wehmeier officiated at Immanuel Lutheran Church in Danbury, Conn., with the Rev. James Higgins, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on May 14, about Seattle, misstated the price of French press coffee at the Cascadia restaurant. It is $8 for a pot (of four cups), not $8 a cup.

title: Burlington
description: Rudyard Kipling, a short-time resident of Vermont, said Lake Champlain was one of the finest places in the world to view a sunset. But for decades, outdoor enthusiasts on their way to Vermont's renowned mountains passed within a few miles of the lake and never knew what they were missing. They lingered at the Burlington airport only long enough to pick up their luggage.

title: Reaping Marijuana in Hills Emptied of Stills
description: Call it green lightning, the seedling crop of countless hidden marijuana patches now stippling the springtime ''hollers'' of Appalachia the way moonshine stills used to when Sheriff Wheeler Jacobs was a boy.

title: The Brooklyn Meetings, From Sea Gate to Dumbo
description: DISTRICT 1: Greenpoint, Williamsburg; usually the second Tuesday of the month; but the next meeting is Tuesday, 6:30 p.m.; Swinging Sixties Senior Center, 211 Ainslee Street, corner of Manhattan Avenue, Williamsburg; Board chairman: Vincent V. Abate; District manager: Gerald Esposito; (718) 389-0009.

title: Borghese's First Releases
description: The labels are familiar -- white wooden latticework partly obscured by a grapevine -- but the letterhead is new: ''Castello di Borghese,'' and, subordinated under it, ''Hargrave Vineyard.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, MARIAN
description: GINSBERG-Marian. Of Fort Lee, N.J. Devoted mother of Ellen Nusbaum and Ann Ginsberg. Dear sister of Harvey Rosenwasser. Loving grandmother of Zachary, Paul and Samuel. For information, ''Wien & Wien'' 1 800 378-1892.

title: A Serious Chef and Staff Make a Difference
description: THE long-running Inn at Ridgefield is now Bernard's Inn at Ridgefield, with new ownership, new chef, staff and decor. This means a lighter, fresher look and a staff that is alert and attentive. Even more important are the beguiling menu and food befitting the 21st century. We appreciated extra touches like the fresh cut flowers on each table, the lagniappe served before dinner and delicious petit fours as a finale. One pleasant reminder of times past is the live piano music on Friday and Saturday evenings and at Sunday brunch.

title: Dogs Run At a Park With Art . . .
description: The Dada artist Marcel Duchamp caused a minor stir in 1917 when he unveiled a ready-made urinal with the tag ''R. Mutt'' scrawled on its side. A similar debate is taking place over a small statue inside the Madison Square Park dog run, near 24th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: JAPAN PACKAGES -- Kintetsu International has two budget packages to Japan, one with Continental Airlines and one with Japan Airlines, that start at $1,040 and $1,100 respectively. The Continental Express package includes round-trip air fare from New York, four nights' standard-class hotel in Japan and either airport transfers in Tokyo or a half-day of sightseeing; the price is $1,040 through July 1, then $1,100 until Aug. 29. The Japan Airlines Express package includes similar features and costs $1,100 through June and $1,200 in July and August. Various options, like rail passes and extended stays, are possible. Kintetsu International, which has been selling travel from North America to Japan for 30 years, is a subsidiary of the Kinki Nippon Tourist Company of Tokyo. Information and reservations: (800) 225-5543 or www.kintetsu.com.

title: The Name's the Same, but . . .
description: An old-fashioned crooner, sometimes referred to as Tom Jones-lite, Engelbert Humperdinck is perhaps a bit more hip than one might think. After all, Jimi Hendrix was his opening act in the 1960's and Elvis Presley's look -- the long sideburns and jumpsuit -- came from Mr. Humperdinck. Then there is his ability to fire up female fans, even if they are grandmothers now.

title: Practical Use for a Fishing Course
description: At Weber State University in Ogden, Utah, the Honors Program sponsors a course called ''The Epistemology of Fly Fishing.'' The point of the class, says the school's syllabus, is to ''use fly fishing as a way to know the world, or at least as a window to explore biology, literature, gender, physics and environmental issues,'' as well as to teach students how to catch a fish with a fly.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on May 14 about opposition to ferry landings along the East River quoted incorrectly from a comment by an opponent, Roberta Greebel Zuckerman. She said, ''If I wanted to live across from a recreation area, I would have moved to Coney Island,'' not ''If I wanted to live next to such a carnival atmosphere.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Warrior Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Courtney Gerber, Christopher Kunzelmann
description: Courtney Jane Gerber, the daughter of Penelope and A. Richard Gerber of Penllyn, Pa., was married yesterday to Christopher Ely Kunzelmann, the son of Joan A. and C. Dixon Kunzelmann of New York and Fisherton de la Mer, England. The Rev. Stanley E. Johnson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church Whitemarsh in Fort Washington, Pa.

title: In the Region/Westchester; In Yonkers, an Archive for New York Archdiocese
description: CARDINAL JOHN O'CONNOR long dreamed of establishing an archive center for the Archdiocese of New York on the campus of St. Joseph's Seminary. And the sprawling 18,000-square-foot granite and limestone Archbishop John Hughes Archives and Heritage Center, scheduled to open here officially in the fall, is testament to Cardinal O'Connor's desire to provide a permanent repository for the documents, historical papers and artifacts of the parishes of New York over their nearly 200-year history.

title: BRIEFING: EDUCATION; MONTVALE PRANK
description: A high school prank in Montvale turned serious late last month. Seniors at Pascack Hills High School had planned to throw thousands of rubber balls down a hallway on May 25, but someone added thousands of crickets and a dozen mice and rats to the mix. Two false fire alarms also sounded, forcing evacuation of the school's 600 students. The principal, Manuel Ferreira, collapsed and was taken to Hackensack University Medical Center for an angioplasty for a clogged artery; he was released on May 27. SARA TREFFINGER

title: By Buckingham Palace, A Place for Pampering
description: The place for royal treatment in London is Buckingham Palace, of course. Wrong lineage? Well, 41, a new hotel just down the street at 41 Buckingham Palace Road, may be the next best option.

title: A Folk Artist and Family Man
description: THE singer-songwriter John Gorka is an odd yet refreshing combination of intensity and deadpan humor. He can follow a song about fascism with another of how, when his infant son cries, the baby resembles Charles Bronson. His power of observation lends him an unusual voice in the heavily populated modern folk movement.

title: Matan Has Two Mommies, and Israel Is Talking
description: Four-year-old Matan Berner-Kadish, the center of a swirling debate about alternative families, is not at all conflicted about his identity. He knows he is a Power Ranger, fiercer than any Ninja warrior by far.

title: Liability And Boards Of Co-ops
description: ON April 11, the New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, addressed the issue of whether corporations, including co-op housing corporations, can be required to pay punitive damages assessed against their board members. The court's answer -- a qualified no -- has been unsettling for co-op corporations and their board members.

title: From a Couch Potato, Another Way to Surf
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Projects Seek Lobster Deaths Answer
description: Two projects have been announced to help deal with mysterious lobster deaths that have decimated Long Island Sound's $100 million-a-year lobster industry.

title: May 28-June 3; Arrests in Slaying of Five At a Fast-Food Restaurant
description: As families buried the dead, two men were arrested and charged with the killings of five people who were herded into the basement of a Wendy's restaurant in Queens, N.Y. Two others were wounded. A prosecutor described how the victims were bound, gagged and blindfolded with duct tape, their heads covered with plastic bags, and shot one by one as they knelt in a freezer room. The suspects, John B. Taylor, 36, and Craig Godineaux, 30, could face the death penalty. JANE FRITSCH

title: Youth Court Of True Peers Judges Firmly
description: Baseball caps and do-rags are dutifully removed while court is in session. The prosecutor is a deliberative, soft-spoken young man of 16 with a crown of cornrows. The defense lawyer is 16, too, only recently out of jail on a charge of attempted murder. On the six-member jury sits a girl with searing eyes and the memory of juvenile jail still fresh in her mind. And when the accused, a gawky 15-year-old charged with graffiti writing and weapons possession, rattles off the names of gangs he has a ''beef'' with at school, the courtroom congregation nods and murmurs knowingly.

title: Eastern Europe's Foray Into 'M-Commerce'
description: THERE'S no need to fiddle in your pocket for loose change if you want a Coke on the streets of downtown Prague. Simply walk up to a Coca-Cola vending machine and point your mobile telephone at it.

title: D.M.V. INSPECTIONS
description: The state had set June 1 as the date when the new enhanced car inspections would be offered at all lanes in all inspection stations. But the goal was not quite met, with 100 of 114 lanes offering the tests. The Division of Motor Vehicles has decided to give inspections at seven stations by appointment only starting Aug. 1 to try to avoid a return to the long lines that plagued the system last winter. The stations will be in Montclair, Ridgewood, Westfield, Washington, Bridgeton, Cape May and Salem. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: The Dogness of Dogs
description: THE SOCIAL LIVES OF DOGS

title: A Post-Zionist Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Let the Trumpets Sound
description: FORGET the lone bugler. Instead picture 650 trumpet players gathered in one place, then imagine about half of them trying out new instruments, practicing scales or rehearsing. The result -- a joyous noise, a distinctive clamor, a common language spoken by a tribe that perfectly understood one another's blasts and toots.

title: Dismissals Ignite a Furor on the Hudson River
description: The Pataki administration ordered the chairmen of the state's two Hudson River Greenway organizations late last month to fire their executive directors and several board members, an action that has angered environmentalists and prompted a backlash by state legislators.

title: Cary Paras, Sid Garbanzos
description: Ma Caridad Paras and Sid Garbanzos are to be married today by the Rev. Thaddeus Grzelak at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Francis Garbanzos, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, will take part in the ceremony.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LIVINGSTON

title: Cahors Turns 'Sensitive' For Its Arts Festival
description: From June 16 through July 2, the medieval city of Cahors in the Lot region of France, north of Toulouse, swings into summer with its annual Printemps de Cahors arts festival. This avant-garde event attracted 100,000 visitors in 1999.

title: Closely Watched Consultant
description: Jackson L. Wilson Jr. oversees a small fraction of Andersen Consulting's 65,000 employees, but he may be the most closely watched member of the firm.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Up From S.R.O. Blight for a Hotel With a Proud History
description: Like a missing tooth in a beautiful smile, the gap between two buildings on Clark Street is a sad reminder of a fire that devastated part of the St. George Hotel five years ago.

title: The Eroded Self
description: Your article prompted me to take stock of my Internet use for the past year. I have searched topics on spinal stenosis for my 84-year-old neighbor, bought books on power tools and remodeling for my father, registered my cousin for a Krohn's disease newsletter and looked up information on snowboarding and ski resorts for my nephew. The way I see it, my Internet image is that of an 84-year-old woman with Krohn's disease and spinal stenosis who has an interest in power tools, remodeling and snowboarding. Good luck in targeting my purchasing habits.

title: Sculptors: A Giant and Company
description: THE gang is all here at what seems like a campy garden party. There is the hot dog vendor, the lumberjack, the bowler, the sword swallower, the running back, the construction worker, the bicyclist and the cowboy. Weightlifters, firefighters and sanitation workers make appearances. Balzac, Joseph Beuys, Davy Crockett, Joe DiMaggio, Piet Mondrian, Henry Moore, and David Smith mingle with the anonymous characters from ordinary American life. All these subjects by Red Grooms, an internationally acclaimed contemporary sculptor, have come together for this exhibition.

title: In Harrison, a Place for Homemade Pasta
description: WE think of Emilio as we do old friends infrequently seen. Trusting the restaurant will always be there, we look for new places and tempting culinary innovation, while Emilio carries on as it has for 21 years, quietly freshening a little of this and rethinking a bit of that, waiting patiently for our return every few years.

title: WINSTON ESTATE UP FOR SALE
description: Stonwin Farm, the 15-acre Scarsdale estate of the late jewelry legend Harry Winston, went on the market Wednesday for $27 million, and the broker for the property, Patricia Burnham, said she already had five potential buyers. The estate has eight and a half bathrooms, a pool, tennis courts, stables and its own gas pump. It has been in the Winston family for 60 years and is being sold by Mr. Winston's son, Ronald, president of Harry Winston Inc. ''It is the cherry orchard with apple trees,'' he said, explaining how he agonized about the sale by recalling the Chekhov play about a family's angst in selling its cherry orchard. AL BAKER

title: Where Real and Surreal Coexist: The Eye
description: THE old saying goes, ''Seeing is believing,'' but scientists who study vision might prefer to go with Groucho Marx on this one: when caught in a compromising situation, he came up with the classic alibi, ''Who are you going to believe, me or your own eyes?''

title: A Treasured Mural Vanishes After 6 Decades in a Lobby
description: Whoever stole the 20-by-10-foot mural from the former Long Island Savings Bank in Long Island City was smooth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALARCO, FRANK C.
description: CALARCO-Frank C. Age 90. Veteran of WWII, U.S. Navy. Past Commander of American Legion Post #

title: In the Pilot's Seat
description: Q.: My husband and son are very interested in airplanes and I thought it might be a good idea for their birthdays to find an airline that had a flight simulator open to the public. Can you help? -- Caryn Heaven, Woodmere, N.Y.

title: Ilana Roth, Victor Escandon
description: Ilana Gusta Roth, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Byron M. Roth of Orlean, Va., was married at their home yesterday to Victor Escandon, a son of Yvonne Timm Escandon of San Antonio and Dr. Roberto Escandon Dominguez of Mexico City. Judge Dudley Payne Jr. of the Juvenile Domestic Relations Court of Fauquier County, Va., officiated.

title: Donald W. Davies, 75, Dies; Helped Refine Data Networks
description: Donald W. Davies, who proposed a method for transmitting data that made the Internet possible, died Sunday at a hospice in Esher, England. He was 75 and had been suffering from cancer, according to a spokesman for the British National Physical Laboratory.

title: NOTICED; Fashion's Time Machine Lands in the 80's
description: REMEMBER the 1980's? ''Dynasty,'' affluence, opulence, jewels, high heels, designer labels and entirely new categories of luxury goods, from foods to expensively scented candles to indulgent accessories for the bath?

title: Chimin Hu, Howard Hampel
description: Dr. Chimin Hu, a daughter of Tao-Yun Lee and Ping-Hung Hu of Taipei, Taiwan, is to be married today to Dr. Howard Hampel, a son of Rose and Daniel Hampel of Little Silver, N.J. Rabbi Michael Shevak will officiate at the Oyster Point Hotel in Red Bank, N.J.

title: A Nation of Liberty, Justice and Free Beaches for All
description: ON May 16, the Connecticut Appellate Court unanimously held that a long-standing policy of Greenwich barring nonresident access to its public parks and beaches was invalid as violative of well-established public policy, and further held that ''the town is required to allow state residents the same access to its public beaches and public parks as it offers to its residents.''

title: Costumes in the Attic, Fit for a Museum
description: FROM birth to death, the clothes found in the attic of the Osborn Retirement Community here span life's milestones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, PHILIP J.
description: RYAN-Philip J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Philip J. Ryan, associated with The Times from 1947 until retiring in 1987.

title: All College Graduates, Please Apply
description: The 1.2 million college graduates in the nation's class of 2000 are entering an unusually strong job market that is a result of a flourishing economy and, especially, the boom in high technology.

title: Former Eagles Drummer Is Back, Making His Own Way
description: FOLLOWING the flourishing career path of Phil Collins, another classic rock drummer who left a superstar band to find great success as a solo act, Don Henley etched out a solo career that was both commercially and creatively auspicious.

title: Wendy Toll, Douglas Topkis
description: Wendy Diane Toll, a daughter of Robbi and Bruce Toll of Rydal, Pa., was married there last evening at her parents' house to Douglas Lee Topkis, a son of Zelda and Stuart Topkis, also of Rydal. Rabbi William Kuhn performed the ceremony.

title: Bad Girls Don't Cry
description: FIONA RANGE

title: Happy for Team That's a Mirror
description: The facial pallor said everything. It had a reddish-pink hue to it, almost as if it belonged to a player rather than a coach -- as if Larry Bird had dropped all those 3-point bombs and gone for 34 points against the Knicks, instead of Reggie Miller.

title: New Peas and Little Leaf Lettuces
description: AFTER a dreary winter, a sort of spring fever of the palate now affects many of us; such a malady is best satisfied by the arrival of the first fresh, locally grown produce of the season.

title: Ideas & Trends; Even a Worm Needs Love
description: LAST month a hyperactive computer program bearing the message ''I Love You'' ricocheted around the world's e-mail systems in less than 24 hours and infected tens of millions of computers.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Fed's Moves Brighten The Outlook For Equities
description: REMEMBER the Goldilocks economy? The not too hot, not too cold, low inflation porridge beloved by Alan Greenspan and financial markets?

title: Suzanne Irving, Charles Baillie
description: Suzanne Jeannette Irving, the daughter of Joyce E. Irving and J. Bruce Irving, both of Miami, was married yesterday to Alexander Charles Michener Baillie, a son of Marilyn and A. Charles Baillie of Toronto. The Rev. George Chalmers, a minister of the Church of Scotland, performed the ceremony at the Sorn Parish Church in Sorn, Scotland.

title: Krista Abolins, Nicholas Sonne
description: Krista Marisa Abolins, the daughter of Frances and Maris Abolins of East Lansing, Mich., was married yesterday to Nicholas Bartlett Sonne, a son of Sally and Christian R. Sonne of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Edwin H. Cromey, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo in Tuxedo Park.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LURAY, MARTIN
description: LURAY-Martin. Although it's been seven years since you left us, your presence remains a constant part of us. Edith, Jennifer and Jon

title: It May Be Vacation Time, But Not for Performers
description: FOR generations vacationers in resort towns throughout the Northeast would spend lovely summer evenings enjoying plays put on by summer stock theaters. The stock companies would stay all summer, churning out a play a week, and big stars would often perform. In 1941, among those making the summer circuit were Tyrone Power, Tallulah Bankhead and Sally Rand. But the advent of television, changes in vacation destinations and sky-rocketing production costs proved too much for those little theaters.

title: 'A Giant of the Theater'
description: O'NEILL Life With Monte Cristo. By Arthur Gelb and Barbara Gelb. Illustrated. 758 pp. New York: Applause Books. $40.

title: Pass the Margaritas, Please
description: It's party time in Camden. Parrotheads by the thousands will be on hand at the Blockbuster Sony Entertainment Center on Thursday to sing and sway with their idol, Jimmy Buffett. Yes, it will seem like a Key West beach. Yes, margaritas will be the drink du jour. Yes, everyone will know the lyrics to ''Why Don't We Get Drunk.''

title: Exhibit With No End in Sight: Picketing Workers at the Museum of Modern Art
description: The strike by workers at the Museum of Modern Art has entered its sixth week with no sign of a settlement in sight. The two sides have not held face-to-face negotiations since before the walkout began.

title: ON THE MAP; A Pondful of Boats Stuart Little Might Pilot
description: During the spring and summer, the Meadowland Park pond in South Orange becomes a marina as dozens of radio-controlled model boats, built and operated by members of the South Orange Seaport Society, set sail every Thursday evening. Founded in 1989, the South Orange Seaport Society is made up of around 30 members who are interested in building scale (or close to scale) models of electric, steam and sailing boats. Commodore Tom Waldron of Livingston, the head of society, recently discussed the hobby.Q. How are the boats made?

title: From, and About, the Circus
description: FOR the last 40 years, Karen E. Gersch, artist and acrobat, has traveled the world chronicling her love of circuses in oil paintings, watercolors, quick line sketches and pastels. She is a Russian-trained performer herself and a founder of the Big Apple Circus.

title: The Warrior Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: A Summer Vacation That's On the House
description: Need some extra cash to help pay for your summer vacation? If you live in a city like New York, Chicago or San Francisco where hotel rooms can cost hundreds of dollars a night, one way to get it is to rent out your home while you are away.

title: Our Towns; Trial of One Pirro Creates Image Problems Big Enough for Two
description: AL!'' Jeanine Pirro scolded her naughty husband. ''Al!''

title: Music of the Spheres: 'Carbon Is a Girl's Best Friend'
description: PERHAPS it was inevitable that as the Internet began permeating the culture, the techie language that was once confined to textbooks and instruction manuals would begin to sound beautiful, or at least pretty enough to sing. Physicists, who among other things invented the World Wide Web, have been quick to realize that their lexicon is no longer too obscure for pop songs.

title: The Eroded Self
description: So where is it written that gossiping, pursuing a romantic sexual liaison or cussing out the boss are activities that you're obliged to do in cyberspace? What about the water cooler, the telephone, the neighborhood pub? E-mail addicts might find it delightful to get out in the world and listen to laughter, see the sparkle in someone's eyes. Those who spend their lives in front of a computer have a serious problem, and loss of privacy is quite possibly the least of it.

title: Telling Her Story in Italian-American
description: IN an Italian-accented voice that is no less friendly than it is forthright, Edvige Giunta has much to talk about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEIDLE, MARC
description: NEIDLE-Marc. Beloved husband of Sandra. Loving and devoted father of Ilyssa. Dear brother-inlaw of Barbara and Richard Leeds. Cherished uncle of Morgan and Blake Leeds. Services today, 10 AM, at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels,'' 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, corner Ave V.

title: Wowing'Em With Rakes and Power Saws
description: Not long ago, Christopher Lowell, the host of a home design show on the Discovery Channel, was eating peacefully in a restaurant in the South Beach area of Miami, when a burly, bearded Hell's Angel-type gentleman approached. ''Are you Christopher Lowell?'' the biker asked. ''Stand up!''

title: When Refinancing a Car Loan, It's Driver Beware
description: WHEN Gerald Jutting drove his 1997 Oldsmobile Bravada home from the dealership, he thought he had found a good deal. The interest rate on the loan the dealer secured for him from a local bank was 8.75 percent, better even than the employee rate at the bank where he works.

title: Barbara Martinez, Jason Griggs
description: Barbara Martinez, the daughter of Laurea Lageyre of Newark and the late Manuel Martinez of Miami Beach, was married yesterday to Jason John Griggs, the son of Rosemary and Roger Griggs of Frankfort, Ill. The Rev. Michael V. Guglielmelli performed the ceremony at St. Francis Roman Catholic Church in Hoboken, N.J.

title: The Face of Westchester In the Near Future
description: It's people like Iris Kalt that are helping turn Westchester into a place where 18-year-olds drive red Mercedes convertibles and where every undeveloped piece of land will one day have a house bigger than the one next door to it.

title: Political Briefing; Nevada G.O.P. Vote A Shift on Abortion
description: Nevada is a state in which voters are always given an extra choice on the ballot: ''None of These Candidates.'' And ''None'' has been known to finish first in some minor races.

title: Jane Chang, Jeffrey Kvaal
description: Dr. Jane Chang, a daughter of Lina Chang and Dr. Tai Hwan Chang of Locust Valley, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey Thomas Kvaal, a son of Martha and Robert Kvaal of Lexington, Mass. The Rev. Laurie Ann McNeill performed the ceremony at the Glenwood Presbyterian Church in Glenwood Landing, N.Y.

title: Dry 'n' Wild
description: Even if, as the Beach Boys sang, everybody did have an ocean across the U.S.A., they still might not be surfin' like Californ-eye-ay. As any novice can attest, it's at least as hard as it looks.

title: Patti LuPone Bringing Her Songs, With Heart
description: WHY is the whole town in a tizzy over Patti LuPone?'' Gino Megaro wanted to know. ''Who is she anyway?'' he kept asking as delirious people descended upon his namesake pizzeria on Irving Street in Rahway, just across the street from the Union County Arts Center.

title: Technology Stages a Big Comeback
description: For investors on Wall Street, bad news was good news, at least when it came to the economy.

title: Condo Board's Powers
description: Q May a condominium board use a simple majority vote to impose restraints on the sale or leasing of individual units? Wouldn't the board first be required to change the condominium bylaws, something that typically takes a two-thirds majority vote? . . . Raymond K. Hormon, the Bronx.

title: How Hip? Undressing Those Trendy 'City' Girls
description: PERHAPS because I am not from New York, and even now do not live there but rather arrive each morning by train through the aqua light of Grand Central, then up the Vanderbilt stairs and into the glare and slow-moving traffic of 43rd Street, I am more apt to identify with writers who saw the city from afar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACZ, MARIA
description: RACZ-Maria, age 89, died peacefully June 1, 2000 in Paris, France, after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Adelbert Bela Racz, she is survived by her loving son Bertrand Leary and his wife Sybil and her nephew, Michael Racz and his wife Gail. A burial will be held privately.

title: Computers Really Are Easy: RadioShack Chief Reboots
description: Leonard H. Roberts, chief executive of RadioShack, misses no chance to show that his company wants to make technology more friendly -- especially to women, who remain a clear minority among his customers. On Wednesday, Maria Bartiromo interviewed him for her CNBC show at her office off the New York Stock Exchange floor. Mr. Roberts was in town to herald the change of his company's name from the Tandy Corporation (and its new stock symbol, RSH instead of TAN).

title: French Company Opens Outlet at The Westchester
description: L'Occitane en Provence, a 23-year-old French purveyor of bath and beauty products, has opened a compact store in The Westchester mall in White Plains, joining the company's more than two dozen shops in Manhattan and upscale communities like Beverly Hills, Calif., and Short Hills, N.J. ''The Westchester is definitely our clientele,'' said Wendy Terebesi, New York regional manager for the company, which offers essential-oil perfume, candles and skin-care products.

title: At More Parks, Smog Is Obscuring the Views
description: AS another smog season begins, it's likely that some of the country's most popular national parks, especially in the east, will once again be troubled by haze and smog rivaling the levels in crowded metropolitan areas.

title: A Broadway Dream Realized, After 20 Years
description: ANN HAMPTON CALLAWAY stood on East 30th Street on a September day 21 years ago, surrounded by suitcases and boxes. Just in from Chicago at 21, she had come to New York with two dreams: to become a jazz singer and to star in a Broadway show. Within three days, she had a job as a singer in a piano bar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, SAMUEL
description: SILBERSTEIN-Samuel. Of Munich, Germany, (originally of Warsaw, Poland). Died suddenly on May 30, 2000. Beloved husband of Luba. Dedicated father of Yankel, and grandfather of Benjamin and Joab. A survivor of the horrors of World War II, he rebuilt his life through much hard work and became a successful and loyal member of his community. He will be remembered for his generosity & love of family. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him.

title: POSTINGS: Winner of Architectural Competition Is Chosen; Design for A.I.A. Chapter's New Home
description: A year after buying three floors -- two of them below ground -- of an eight-story co-op building at 534 La Guardia Place in Greenwich Village for $1.2 million, the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects has settled on an architect for its new home -- Andrew Berman, the winner of the chapter's design competition.

title: GUN BUYBACK PROGRAM
description: Authorities last month collected 49 handguns and 37 rifles in the first phase of Westchester's gun buyback program. The county paid $3,400 for the guns during the no-questions-asked, three-day gun amnesty held in Ossining. A second phase, held in in Croton last week, netted 29 more weapons in six hours, at a cost of $1,225. A combined effort of the district attorney's office and the county executive, the program offers $50 for each handgun and $25 for each rifle or shotgun. The county will not trace the origin of the guns or attempt to see whether they were involved in crimes. The plan is to melt the guns down and possibly use the metal to build a memorial to victims of gun violence. ELSA BRENNER

title: Natasha Friedman, Daniel Tauber
description: Natasha Eden Araby Felicite Friedman, a daughter of Marvin Ross Friedman of Coral Gables, Fla., and the late Sheila Friedman, is to be married today to Daniel Efrem Tauber, a son of Adele and Ronald Tauber of New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the Vizcaya Museum and Gardens in Miami.

title: Special Teams Hold Off The Stars
description: Jason Arnott and Petr Sykora rebounded by scoring last night, but goalie Martin Brodeur and the Devils' special teams, particularly the penalty killers, were the keys in New Jersey's 2-1 victory over the Dallas Stars in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals.

title: The Smart Set
description: On a wet, blustery April morning, mist blowing sideways across the docks marking the lower end of Union Street on the Brooklyn waterfront, 17-year-old Alice Warren-Gregory races down the steps from her family's third-floor apartment a little after 5:30 a.m. Clutching a calculator and a copy of ''The Great Gatsby,'' she hurries up the block in the predawn darkness to catch a waiting B71 bus. As we step on board, the driver says, ''Good morning, Alice,'' and closes the door.

title: S.E.C. Plans Warning on Annuities
description: FOR months, federal regulators have been looking into whether people who invest in variable annuities are getting a fair shake.

title: The Way We Live Now Poll
description: Your special issue (May 7) provided a special gem, ''The Self-Discovery Dial,'' that indicates many of the innumerable facets of everyone's experience. Thank you for a vivid tool.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 4, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Old-School Maestro For the 21st Century
description: ALFREDO SILIPIGNI pored over the books in his ample library. Unsatisfied, he consulted with music historians. Finally, enlisting the help of the author Susan Vandiver, he sent an e-mail message to Italy. Just days before rehearsals were to begin for the New Jersey State Opera's production of ''Tosca,'' one simple fact plagued Mr. Silipigni: the color of choir robes in Rome in 1800, the setting and time of Puccini's opera.

title: Green Monsters
description: A PLAGUE

title: Compromise Bill Is Sought Over Fire-Safe Cigarettes
description: Legislative leaders and Gov. George E. Pataki are in intensive talks on a bill to require less flammable cigarettes -- a compromise to replace a bill Mr. Pataki vetoed late last month -- while the Assembly seriously considers a vote to override that veto.

title: Angeline Bafford, Ted Grace
description: Margaret Angeline Brand Bafford and William Edward Grace were married yesterday by the Rev. Susannah R. Smith at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: Kristin Lemkau, Craig Lunde
description: Kristin Carroll Lemkau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curt W. Lemkau of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Craig Areskog Lunde, a son of Martha K. Lunde of Freeport, N.Y., and Henry C. Lunde of Garden City, N.Y. The Rev. Bruce W. Forbes, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York.

title: Patient: Know Thy Rights
description: IN recent years, Congress has passed several laws designed to help people remain insured when they change jobs and obtain coverage for life-altering medical situations that insurers often shunned.

title: Emerging From the Shadows of Broadway's Past
description: HAS there ever been a more obscure Tony Award honoree than Sylvia Herscher? Even Ms. Herscher herself does not think so.

title: Rose Is a Rose Is a Job Is a Joy
description: ROSES? I love 'em. It's the gardening I don't like. So for the last 20 years I've devoted myself to one goal: the maximum number of flowers for the minimum amount of work.

title: Programs to Get Students to Write
description: LIKE a starting gun, the loudspeaker at the Douglas E. Grafflin Elementary School here burst forth with the announcement: ''Get your writing pencils ready. Get your writing packets ready. Here comes the prompt: what would you do to make the world a better place?''

title: The Hudson River Park, on Track
description: New York City residents have long hoped to reclaim their Hudson River shoreline south of 59th Street by restoring rotting piers and replacing the parking lots and other bleak spaces that now exist with an inviting mix of walkways, playing fields and modest commercial development. The last major obstacle to that dream has now been removed. On Thursday, the United States Army Corps of Engineers gave final approval for work to begin.

title: At 75, a Drummer Whose Beat Is Always Modern
description: AFTER a performance in Chicago a few years ago, a woman came up to Roy Haynes and told him that the way he played drums reminded her of the four seasons. Not Vivaldi, but winter-spring-summer-fall.

title: Metropolitan
description: THE FUNDAMENTALS OF PLAY

title: Battle Lines Drawn on New Zoning Plan
description: BY a margin of almost 2 to 1, the 26 speakers at the City Planning Commission hearing last month offered their support for a zoning proposal that would reshape development, neighborhood character and architectural innovation in every corner of New York.

title: THEATER: Broadway: Devil or Angel for Nonprofit Theater?; Finding the Right Way To Cross the Divide
description: Who ever heard of an intermission that lasted 26 years? Well, to be honest, people in the theater, and to be precise: the First Annual Congress of Theater, which was held in 1974 and brought together representatives of the country's commercial and nonprofit theaters. Sparks flew, as described in the following articles, and the group never met again. Much has happened in the theater since, so much, in fact, that it seemed a good idea to some optimists to see how commercial and nonprofit interests can relate to each other today for the betterment of the nation's stages. Thus, ACT II, the second congress of theater, will take place June 16-18 on the Harvard campus in Cambridge, Mass. Here are some thoughts from members of the planning committee who represent the commercial (Rocco Landesman) and the nonprofit (Ben Cameron) sides of the debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, CIREL
description: BERGER-Cirel. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the mother of its member, Danielle Berger. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Meals Where Iced Tea Is Used for More Than Just Drinking
description: ICED tea season has started. Though there is a vast array of ready-to-drink bottled iced tea in all sorts of flavors, and iced tea mix galore, homemade iced tea, brewed from high-quality tea leaves, is so easy to prepare it can always be kept on hand.

title: Pacers' Game 7 Intensity Meant No Seventh Game
description: The Indiana Pacers never trailed in the Eastern Conference finals. And yet, after losing two lackluster games to the Knicks in Madison Square Garden last week, they seemed like a train derailed, the players ready to scatter their separate ways to free agency, if not their summer tee times.

title: New York's Fourth to Be a Sailing Extravaganza
description: About 125 tall ships and warships from around the world will sail into New York July 4 for the centerpiece of OpSail 2000, an eight-city tour from San Juan, P.R., to Portland, Me.

title: Midtown Journal; Islands in the Stream of Traffic Provide an Escape
description: Not long ago, the two concrete traffic islands in Midtown, near Macy's, were symbols of a blighted New York. Grandly named Herald Square and Greeley Square, they were cracked slabs set in the midst of cacophonous traffic. There were scraggly bushes along the edges and some benches, where homeless people dozed and drug dealers rested between sales.

title: THEATER: Broadway: Devil or Angel for Nonprofit Theater?; A Vital Movement Has Lost Its Way
description: Who ever heard of an intermission that lasted 26 years? Well, to be honest, people in the theater, and to be precise: the First Annual Congress of Theater, which was held in 1974 and brought together representatives of the country's commercial and nonprofit theaters. Sparks flew, as described in the following articles, and the group never met again. Much has happened in the theater since, so much, in fact, that it seemed a good idea to some optimists to see how commercial and nonprofit interests can relate to each other today for the betterment of the nation's stages. Thus, ACT II, the second congress of theater, will take place June 16-18 on the Harvard campus in Cambridge, Mass. Here are some thoughts from members of the planning committee who represent the commercial (Rocco Landesman) and the nonprofit (Ben Cameron) sides of the debate.

title: Amy Eisner, Daniel Reich
description: Amy Lee Eisner, the daughter of Paula and Mark Eisner of Ithaca, N.Y., is to be married today to Daniel Salo Reich, a son of Tova Reich and Dr. Walter Reich of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Avi Weiss, the bridegroom's uncle, is to perform the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: Where Geeks and Freaks Are Just Plain Folks
description: He's only three-foot-eleven and still he doesn't believe it.

title: Looking Around The Corner In Camden
description: Carl Dranoff has always prided himself on looking one step over the horizon.

title: Women as Peacemakers
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Wants To Be A Style Icon?
description: WEIRD? Please! I don't even want to think about it!'' Regis Philbin said in his dressing room at the ABC studios on West 67th Street last week. Mr. Philbin was not referring to the immense, bizarre popularity of his show ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire.'' He was rifling through a rack of shirts and ties bearing his own name. ''Regis by Van Heusen'' is a line whose label promises to capture ''the style and essence of Regis Philbin, America's favorite television personality.''

title: Chinatown Hails Heroes
description: About 900 marchers, some from as far away as San Francisco, paraded through Chinatown yesterday to honor Chinese-Americans who served in the United States military.

title: Things Fall Together
description: Every week I scan the letters column hoping that someone will write to thank you for Melanie Rehak's profile of Anne Carson (March 26). So far no one has, so I will. The last few years have been a time of felicitous ferment in literature, with established talents producing major works as well as new voices emerging. Still, Carson's ''Autobiography of Red'' excited me as few other recent books have. Discovering it gave me an authentic ''looking into Chapman's Homer'' moment.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-4-00: On Language; Summitese
description: 'A parley at the summit'' was what Winston Churchill called for a half-century ago. He envisioned an intimate get-together of a few world leaders and not a paperbound conference ''zealously contested by hordes of experts and officials drawn up in a vast cumbrous array.''

title: Growing Club of Left-Leaning Leaders Strains to Find a Focus
description: When they met in Italy one year ago, they were leaders of a ''Third Way'' and their founding members were President Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain.

title: Political Briefing; Term-Limit Reneger Gets Party Help
description: Reinforcements are coming to the aid of Representative George Nethercutt, Republican of Washington.

title: AT REHEARSAL WITH/Arthur Aitkens; A Pianist's Circuitous Route to the Van Cliburn Competition
description: WHEN Arthur Aitkens had a devastating horse-riding accident in 1988, he had no idea that it would reunite him with music, his childhood passion. This week, 12 years after doctors told Mr. Aitkens that he would always be mostly paralyzed on his right side, he will perform in the Van Cliburn Foundation's Second International Piano Competition for Outstanding Amateurs.

title: Speed Demon
description: Hackett explains Marion Jones's success (May 14) in terms of her ''genetic makeup'' and of being ''born strong, with fast-twitch muscles.'' Yet Hackett goes on to describe the 100-meter sprint, her ''signature event,'' as ''the most technical and intellectual of all track events.'' He also describes her mental strength, rigorous self-appraisal, willingness to change, incredible discipline, pragmatism and hard work.

title: Irving Rudd, 82, Press Agent In Baseball, Racing, Boxing
description: Irving Rudd, a Runyonesque character who used wit and gimmickry to promote the Brooklyn Dodgers, Yonkers Raceway, Nathan's Famous and boxers like Muhammad Ali and Sugar Ray Leonard, died on Friday. He was 82.

title: Where 'No Parking' Is Merely A Suggestion, Not a Command
description: In some neighborhoods, a ''No Parking'' sign clearly remains a matter of interpretation.

title: Lord of the Gnats
description: The first airing of the ''Survivor'' game show on CBS last week, with 16 strangers marooned on a Malaysian island, produced an oddly captivating form of entertainment. Unlike the usual fare for reality voyeurs, there was no sex or madness or murder, not even any real nudity in this first of 13 programs scheduled over the summer. But many of the nation's young adult viewers seem to be titillated by how modern Americans fare in what passes these days for wilderness -- a few tough weeks without hot showers, frozen dinners and cell phones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEIL, BARBARA
description: BEIL-Barbara. Beloved wife of Sheldon. My beloved wife died June 3rd, 2000. Vivacious, beautiful, compassionate and with a dynamic spirit, she sparked my days and illuminated my nights. She added enrichment to life and fulfilled her last few years with spirit, strength and a zest to live. She was unique and unforgettable. All who new her loved her. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday 2:15pm. Devoted to her infirmed brother, Leonard Miller. She raised money and worked to help the severely handicapped. Donations to The Disabled And Alone For The Handicapped, 352 Park Avenue South, New York 10010.

title: BRIEFING: DEVELOPMENT; FLOOD RELIEF
description: The state Department of Community Affairs will give a total of $7.85 million to Bound Brook, Manville and South Bond Brook to make up for tax ratables lost in Hurrican Floyd in September. Local officials had anticipated tax increases ranging from $800 to $1,200 per home without the aid, though there may still be hikes. SARAH TREFFINGERNO MORE

title: A More Exclusive 914
description: If you live in Putnam County and feel terribly attached to the 914 area code, owning a cellular phone is your only lifeline as of tomorrow.

title: For Low-Turnover Management, Steer Clear of Connecticut
description: Fund investors worried about the government's tax bite may just want to steer their money to a portfolio manager who is based in Houston. For those with money in individual retirement accounts or other tax-advantaged vehicles, Connecticut could be the place to look.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Enjoying the Feel of Earth, Not Pavement, Underfoot
description: On a recent drizzly Saturday morning, a group of nine girls from New York City's poorer neighborhoods walked over soil so soft it sank under their footsteps. Unlike the hard asphalt and caked dirt in the city's empty lots, the girls discovered, this ground was ripe with fertility. The girls were participating in a program run by the Fresh Air Fund, a nonprofit agency that provides summer camp vacations to needy children from New York City.

title: Needs of the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Six Legs Good. Also Eight.
description: MILLIONS OF MONARCHS, BUNCHES OF BEETLES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, DR. MIRIAM
description: SCHNEIDER-Dr. Miriam. The members of Shelter Rock Tennis Club record with great sorrow the passing of our charter member, Miriam Schneider. She was a friend to all and will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to her daughters, Joan and Susan, and the entire family. Joel Jacobson, President

title: A Neighborhood Holds Its Breath
description: PERHAPS no neighborhood in Greenwich will be as affected by the State Appellate Court ruling on the Greenwich beach than that of Mary Staples-Webber. She has lived in the Lucas Point neighborhood, just outside the entrance to the beach, for 32 years, long enough for her to liken her neighborhood to ''a comfortable old shoe.''

title: William Blair Value Discovery
description: GLEN A. Kleczka, 37, the lead manager of the $58.0 million William Blair Value Discovery fund, admits to being a foodie, but he rarely finds time to cook at home in Chicago.

title: 7-11 Fought as the Thin Edge Of an Undesirable Wedge
description: Fearing that drug use, racy magazines and other ills might descend on their neighborhood, more than 150 people, mostly Orthodox Jews, packed a meeting of Community Board 15 on Tuesday to protest plans to open a 7-Eleven store next to their synagogue.

title: 2 Guides Can Help Find African-American Sites
description: Two new guides showcase contributions of African-Americans to the history and culture of North Carolina and Florida.

title: May 28-June 3; The Physicist and the Wrapper
description: Like poets who find inspiration on the kitchen table or back porch, physicists are rediscovering the world they can see with the unaided eye. The trend began at least a decade ago when they began pondering why Brazil nuts, the largest and heaviest nuggets in a can of mixed nuts, always end up on top after being jostled during shipping.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Upscale Rentals Finding a Ready Market in Suffolk
description: REFLECTING the continuing popularity of upscale rental housing, Trammel Crow Residential has started construction on almost 800 luxury apartments in central Suffolk County.

title: '60 Minutes' Producer Aims Bitter Blast at Ex-Colleague
description: The simmering five-year debate over the way ''60 Minutes'' handled a controversial report about the tobacco industry heated up again yesterday as the show's executive producer attacked Lowell Bergman, a former ''60 Minutes'' producer and longtime investigative reporter, in a speech to more than 1,000 journalists in New York.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Honda Insight; High-Mileage, High-Stakes Hybrid
description: WITH gasoline prices pushing toward $2 a gallon in some parts of the country, Honda could not have picked a better time to bring out a car that gets 70 miles to the gallon on the highway. Sure enough, the Honda Insight, the first hybrid car to be sold in the United States, is off to a fast start, at least by the standards used to measure alternative vehicles.

title: Summer Books
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Holiday Books issue of December 1999. It is meant to suggest some of the high points in this years fiction, poetry, nonfiction, mysteries and science fiction. The books are arranged alphabetically under genre headings. The complete reviews of these books may be found at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.

title: CLINTON AND PUTIN MEET AT KREMLIN WITH WIDE AGENDA
description: In his final visit to Moscow as president, Bill Clinton arrived here today and dined tonight with Russia's new president, Vladimir V. Putin, at the Kremlin palace, where the two leaders made a ''very serious and focused beginning'' on a full range of issues, including the search for a compromise on antimissile defense.

title: Oh, For a Line of Keats
description: Fashion often revives past successes and presents them in a fresh mix.
