This spring, it's the romantic blouse for day and evening, made of see-through fabric, always worn with a bra, and now worn with trousers rather than a skirt. The dressy blouse was a major fashion player during World War II, when fabric restrictions turned it into the center of style, dressing up the tailored suit. The new crop of blouses, with their long poet's sleeves, came into focus at a recent reception, when three women appeared wearing the same dotted style by Tuleh. Other designers have shown the ruffly styles peeking out from under day jackets. The most modern shape is Helmut Lang's (far right), without sleeves, worn over slim trousers with strappy high heels.

title: The Real Miami Beach
description: To the Editor:

title: Monica Washington, Daniel Rothbaum
description: Monica Janine Washington, a lawyer, and Dr. Daniel Laurence Rothbaum were married yesterday at the Seven Hills Inn in Lenox, Mass. Rabbi Martin Siegel officiated, with the Rev. Sylvester Peterka, a Roman Catholic Priest, taking part in the ceremony.

title: Advantage, Devils
description: A day after their coach criticized them pointedly and publicly, the Devils' top line responded. Jason Arnott, Patrik Elias and Petr Sykora accounted for both goals and took 13 shots to pace the Devils to a 2-1 victory over the Dallas Stars tonight and a two-games-to-one lead in the Stanley Cup finals.

title: A Plan to Revive State Fire Engine Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrorism Panel Faults U.S. Effort on Iran and 1996 Bombing
description: The Clinton administration has not done enough to press Iran for cooperation in the investigation of a 1996 bombing that killed 19 American servicemen, despite evidence of Iranian involvement, a bipartisan commission on terrorism has concluded.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-4-00: Questions for Peter Piot; Epidemic Proportions
description: Q: Several pharmaceutical companies have recently decided to slash the price of antiretroviral drugs for developing countries, most notably Africa. But even with the price cut, a year's supply of drugs still would cost about $1,000 -- more money than most Africans earn in a year. So is there less to this than meets the eye?

title: A Producer Who Made a Dream Come True
description: THE producer T. Edward Hambleton, the human engine behind New York's storied Phoenix Theater for three decades, is an anomaly in his family. None of his own children have gone into the arts and his father's life was the Baltimore banking firm of Hambleton & Company. Yet from the time Mr. Hambleton, the descendant of an old and wealthy Maryland family, graduated from Yale University in 1935, his mind was set.

title: Soldini Is a Favorite In Trans-Atlantic Race
description: When Prada Challenge of Italy advanced to last spring's America's Cup finals, the team's helmsman and leader, Francesco de Angelis, found himself at the center of a news media onslaught. Back home, the Prada crew members had become national heroes. But when asked how he handled the burden of his newfound celebrity, de Angelis shrugged and invoked the name of his country's most famous sailor.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-4-00: Shop Talk; I'm a Loser
description: Have expectations of success fundamentally changed the way we think about ourselves? Nicholas Hall is the founder of startupfailures.com, a new Internet ''community focused on supporting individuals that have recently gone through . . . the experience of a start-up failure.'' Scott A. Sandage is a historian at Carnegie-Mellon University and is finishing a book called ''Forgotten Men: Failure in American Culture.'' Here, they discuss the current meaning of this familiar condition.

title: Nicole Tell, Richard Thau
description: Nicole Gail Tell, the daughter of Barbara and Victor Tell of Charlotte, N.C., is to be married this afternoon to Richard Dean Thau, the son of Adrienne and Herbert Thau of Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Bonnie Steinberg is to officiate at Land's End, a restaurant in Sayville, N.Y. Chief Judge Marilyn Hall Patel of the Federal District Court for the Northern District of California will take part in the ceremony.

title: Information Gathering
description: To the Editor:

title: A Noteworthy Collection
description: This collection of paperbacks is from the New & Noteworthy column since the 1999 Holiday Books issue.

title: Balancing Hybrids vs. Electrics on the Environmental Scale
description: HYBRID gas-electric cars can be clean and very fuel-efficient, and may, if automakers persuade regulators, be used to fill the quota for battery-electric cars that California, New York and Massachusetts plan to require. But engineers are learning that hybrids cannot accomplish everything that environmentalists want.

title: Who Turned On The Noise?
description: CURT PEOPLES of Toronto went to Myrtle Beach, S.C., with a friend for a weekend of golf last month. He was taken aback to discover they had arrived in the midst of a huge convergence called Harley-Davidson Week. Mr. Peoples said that from his hotel, the Caribbean Resort on Ocean Boulevard, he could hear the parade of bikes making its way around the Route 17 loop until 1 a.m. nightly. Sleep was elusive, Mr. Peoples said, and the drive back to the Charlotte, N.C., airport, a trip that normally takes three hours, took four and a half because of the traffic.

title: Political Memo; Bush's Odd Pitch: Ignorance Is Bliss
description: In the annals of political hucksterism, it will undoubtedly go down as one of the strangest pitches ever made.

title: Young Rowers' Biggest Problem Is Ashore
description: JUST as the ospreys and swans begin their spring ritual of building nests, young rowers from neighboring high schools have appeared on the chilly waters of Oyster Bay for the last three years, dipping their oars in unison and sending their long narrow boats quietly racing across the waves.

title: Glimpses Inside a World Barely Imagined by Men
description: LOVE is a minefield, but women would rather blow up than be single,'' says the unflappable heroine of ''Love and Sex,'' Valerie Breiman's romantic comedy (opening in August) that could be the female response to ''High Fidelity.'' Kate (Famke Janssen), the movie's Don Juanita, casts an eye over the loves of her life, affectionately sending up the pretenses of men as she surveys sexual warfare in the trenches from a survivor's-eye view. She has emerged bloody but unbowed, having withstood even a traumatic childhood passion which in the film's hilarious opening flashback locates the love-hate roots of screwball comedy squarely in the playground.

title: Living in the Shadow of Chernobyl's Reactors
description: They are gardening again at Chernobyl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLOF, GEORGIA BOGARDUS
description: HOLOF-Georgia Bogardus, on June 1, 2000. Loving and best friend of her husband, Robert. Irreplaceable mother of Amy. Caring sister-in-law to Harry and Norma Holof. Loving aunt of Richard, Linda and Katy, and loyal friend to many. Service Sunday 11:15AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Food; A Cut Above
description: A sharp knife in a skilled hand is a scary thing. The best cooks do not simply use knives. They allow knives to become their hands.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-4-00: Idea Lab; Greens Peace
description: Since the rise of the nation-state, scholars and politicians have been struggling to answer the critical question of geopolitics: Why do some countries fight wars and others remain at peace? Yet to date, they have made little progress. Some contemporary thinkers, alarmed by Kosovo and Rwanda, predict that ethnic conflict will be the prime cause of war in the 21st century. Environmental scholars argue that scarce water and land will drive nations to battle. Students of the theory of interdemocratic peace contend that the structure of national government will be the driving factor. But policy makers should discard these dry, unsatisfying academic formulations and start paying attention to a much more powerful explanatory tool: golf.

title: Lisa Jankowsky, Darius Brawn
description: Lisa Jankowsky, a daughter of Carol and Joel Jankowsky of McLean, Va., was married last evening to Darius David Brawn, the son of Suzy and Edwin Brawn of McLean. Rabbi Joseph Levenson officiated at the Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md.

title: Hurricane Warning
description: To the Editor:

title: Rising Early, Liberty Finds Way To Win
description: The Liberty players practically passed the Knicks in the hallway of Madison Square Garden yesterday morning, so early were they arriving to work. More than two hours before the tip-off in the Liberty's 1 p.m. home opener against Utah, at an hour of the morning when the Liberty players would usually be having a leisurely cup of coffee and a doughnut on their way to work, they were already watching film. The players, seeking their first victory of the season after two losses on the road, were desperately trying to squeeze in a few more seconds of preparation for teammates who might need name tags to identify each other.

title: PATERSON PLAN
description: Paterson, the state's third largest school district with 25,000 students, will need 10 new elementary schools, a new high school and extensive renovations to many remaining schools in order to meet the state Supreme Court's mandate to upgrade the educational system, said Edwin Duroy, the state-appointed superintendent in the district. The cost of construction alone will be $570 million. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Maine Man
description: STERN MEN By Elizabeth Gilbert. 289 pp. New York: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.

title: Justine Simons, Christopher Huntington
description: Justine Simons and Christopher Bowditch Huntington, television producers in New York, were married yesterday in Weekapaug, R.I. Associate Justice Pamela M. Macktaz of Rhode Island Family Court in Providence officiated at the Weekapaug Inn.

title: Voula Tsoutsoplides, Nicholas Katsoris
description: Voula Tsoutsoplides, a daughter of Aspasia Tsoutsoplides and Dr. George Tsoutsoplides of Shavertown, Pa., is to be married today to Nicholas C. Katsoris, a son of Ann Katsoris and Prof. Constantine Katsoris of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Nicholas Anctil will perform the ceremony at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Careless Love
description: SWIMMING SWEET ARROW

title: SOAPBOX; 'The Shame of the Nation'
description: AMIDST hand-wringing among urban sociologists about supposedly ''deficient social values'' in the children of low-income neighborhoods like the South Bronx, it is a refreshing pleasure to walk into St. Ann's Church, on St. Ann's Avenue, a little after three o'clock on any weekday when children from the local public schools arrive for afterschool tutorial.

title: Warmth, Wariness Greet Homes for the Retarded
description: Angela Augugliaro, the president of the Queens Colony Civic Association, said many of her neighbors had no idea that the spanking white Colonial on 247-22 88th Road in Bellerose was a group home for six developmentally disabled and retarded adults.

title: It Floats! It Speeds! It's a Train!
description: IT was a dark and stormy night, as James Powell likes to tell it, when he got stuck in a traffic jam on the Throgs Neck Bridge in the early 1960's, heading for Boston. The five long hours he spent in that jam gave Dr. Powell, a Brookhaven National Laboratory scientist, a lot of time to think.

title: Confessions of a Closet Homemaker
description: Carreno's article struck me as tragic. Here is a woman who admirably is trying to fulfill herself in a most unselfish way. Yet she feels compelled to tell us that she has a real life other than that of making others happy. That creating a warm domestic environment can become something to be ashamed of is disturbing.

title: Blazers Fired Up And Ready for Game 7
description: Intensity turned into raw emotion Friday night before spilling toward the Portland Trail Blazers' bench with 36.6 seconds left in Game 6 of the Western Conference finals.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Suffolk County's difficulties in buying land for conservation referred to two funds incorrectly. A $20 million fund for farm preservation and a $20 million fund for parks are part of the $60 million Greenways program, not separate funds.

title: Shared Prayers, Mixed Blessings
description: Howard Pugh, head usher, is on patrol. May the good Lord have mercy on any child, or adult for that matter, who dares to tread across the lobby of the Assembly of God Tabernacle with so much as an open Coca-Cola in his hand. Because first he will get the look, the alert glare of a hunting dog catching its first scent of game. Then he will get the wag, the slightly palsied shake of the left index finger. And then the voice, serious as a heart attack and dripping with Pensacola pinesap: ''Son, this is the Lord's house. And they just shampooed that carpet last week.''

title: Two Lanes, Many Diversions
description: MIDSUMMER in the Monadnock region of New Hampshire invites nostalgia. Long, gently rising two-lane blacktop roads wend their way through corridors of stately pines. Sunlight ricochets off lakes and ponds. The hum of mosquitoes fills the gathering dusk; thunder rumbles comfortably in the distance. The series of little towns nestled in the southwest corner of the state around Mount Monadnock seems untouched by the passage of time.

title: Over Lunch at Sardi's
description: To the Editor:

title: RYE APPROVES LIGHTS
description: After months of public debate, the Rye Board of Education voted 4 to 3 last week to install permanent lights for night play at John Nugent Stadium at the high school. A group of parents will provide $160,000 to buy the lights. Opponents said the lights would mar the adjoining neighborhood, but supporters said it would allow families with two working parents to attend their children's sporting events. The board stipulated that the lights may be turned on only seven times during the school year and only for varsity games. ''We're happy with the vote,'' said John Eyler, president of Toys ''R'' Us and a leader of the pro-light group. LYNNE AMES

title: On First Looking Into Gates's Crichton
description: ''Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested.'' Francis Bacon, ''Of Studies''

title: Playing Through the Pain
description: THERESA McGee is a freelance pianist, organist and choral conductor. Last December she was in so much pain that she feared that she would not be able to meet her many holiday performance commitments. That's when she went to the Musicians Clinic at the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington.

title: Can Craig McCaw Keep His Vision Of Teledesic From Crashing?
description: IT'S time for the latest installment of ''Who Wants to Second-Guess a Billionaire?'' In today's episode, Craig O. McCaw, the publicity-shy cable television and telecommunications entrepreneur with a fabled knack for anticipating the future, hits quicksand in his pursuit of a high-risk dream.

title: The Wages Of Empowerment
description: It seems that the North Stonington Selectman, Nicholas H. Mullane II, (''Another Round of Questions Aimed at Pequots,'' May 14) would have found it acceptable if federal recognition of the Mashantucket Indian Tribe had meant only federal aid -- if the tribe, in other words, had remained poor and powerless. That the tribe has become rich and influential is, to him, unacceptable.

title: Young, Talented and Going Places
description: She won the first Paper Mill ''Rising Star'' award at 16 for ''Hello, Dolly!'' -- the title role -- in Kinnelon High School. Then the Millburn playhouse hired her for two productions. Now going on 21, Laura Benanti is a Broadway rising star, up for a Tony Award tonight, as best featured musical actress.

title: Ground Broken for Project At Port Chester Waterfront
description: Ground was broken last week for a $100 million, 400,000-square-foot retail redevelopment project in Port Chester's downtown waterfront area. Mayor Christine Korff said she liked ''to think of it as a mall turned inside out: the facades and entrances of the stores and businesses will face the street.''

title: Political Briefing; Polls Say Bush Leads In Electoral Votes
description: The Hotline, the popular Internet political tip sheet, keeps a running tab of presidential preference polls in various states as they become available. Here is how things stood overall at the end of last week:

title: Still in the Hospital 9 Months Later
description: IT has been nine months since Danuta Trojanowska, 56, first became ill with the West Nile virus. But she is still lying in a bed at New York United Hospital in Port Chester, unable to walk, her muscles so atrophied that she cannot even turn in her bed. A housekeeper with prominent cheekbones and long dark hair, she spends her days watching soap operas and reading Danielle Steel novels translated into Polish, her native language.

title: On the Nominators
description: To the Editor:

title: When Nike Missiles Were Next Door
description: So, there were nuclear tips on the Nikes, and that fact was not made plain to us. We are, I suppose, to be shocked and indignant.

title: Having Her Say at The See
description: When a man with a gift for charming others meets a woman with a gift for making others feel charming, there is no telling how it will end. Sometime around Easter of 1997, Bill Clinton called Lindy Boggs, whom he had known since he was a college student, and asked her, somewhat improbably, to become his ambassador to the Holy See. (She ''is maybe the only person on the earth who could convince the pope that I am worth dealing with,'' Clinton has joked to his friends.) Lindy told Clinton she would think about it, but she was only being polite. Almost as soon as he had made the offer, she had made up her mind to decline it. She was 82 years old, spoke no Italian and knew no one in Rome. She intended to end her days as she had begun them, in private life, in New Orleans.

title: Travel
description: TRAVEL writing seems to exist in a permanent state of near extinction. People who ponder the health of literary genres have assumed that in a world where anybody with enough money can launch an assault on Everest and intrepid octogenarians routinely hobble around the Galpagos, few would settle for merely reading about the experience. These days, many of our most popular travel books -- Frances Mayess paeans to Tuscany come to mind -- are not really travel books but lavish fantasias of home renovation, which only serve to confirm the fact that anyone with two weeks vacation and a credit card can join an eco-tour of the Costa Rican rain forest but a good team of construction workers, whether at home or abroad, is almost impossible to find.

title: PACE PRESIDENT RETIRING
description: Patricia O'Donnell Ewers, Pace University's first female president, is stepping down on July 15. Dr. Ewers has been at the helm of Pace since July 1990. Her accomplishments include the completion of a $55 million fund-raising effort; increasing the university's endowment to $100 million; developing resources and infrastructure for information technology; and renovating dormitories and academic buildings at the university's campuses in Pleasantville and Manhattan. MERRI ROSENBERG

title: Three Airlines Add Ways to Earn Miles
description: Continental, America West and Delta Airlines have developed new partnerships allowing customers to earn frequent flier miles without leaving terra firma.

title: Political Briefing; Bowing Out in Ohio With Eye on Future
description: Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio was one of the first candidates to drop out of this year's race for the Republican presidential nomination. And though he is chairman of the House Budget Committee, a major power post, he is not seeking re-election to a 10th term in Ohio's 12th Congressional District, which stretches north from Columbus.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILFORD, JACK
description: GILFORD-Jack. July 25, 1908-June 4, 1990. Never forgotten, loved forever. Madeline and all the Gilford's.

title: The View From/Trumbull; From Many Voices, Four-Part Harmony
description: BARBERSHOP singers don't always match the image of men with handlebar mustaches and derby hats harmonizing to ''Down by the Old Mill Stream.''

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Building for High-Tech Tenants in the Meadowlands
description: HOPING to capitalize on the expansion of technology companies, a small group of developers in the Hackensack Meadowlands are constructing buildings or converting warehouses for new-economy tenants.

title: Portraying the Past and the Present
description: IN the centuries before the modern age, artists were commissioned to depict their life and times for posterity. Influenced by the patrons that commissioned them, the art they produced had a decided twist with regard to style and accuracy.

title: Sather Still Waits for Lowe
description: Glen Sather, the Rangers' new president and general manager, should know better by Wednesday whether Kevin Lowe will follow him from Edmonton to become the Rangers' head coach.

title: Behind Geography Whiz Stood a Patient Teacher
description: WHEN Felix Peng of Guilford won the National Geographic Bee last month, it was the culmination of years of drilling and studying, not only for the 13-year-old history and geography lover, but also for his teacher.

title: To Combat Both Racism And Censorship
description: Given the constitutional protections that even hate speech enjoys, Jim Panos [''Stretching the Limits of Free Speech,'' Opinion, May 7] despairs of being able to counteract toxic messages attacking immigrants in the rudest language.

title: The Ultimate Toy: The Pool Table at Home
description: JOHN A. DeVITO JR. of Somers, who builds luxury homes, was planning to build one for his family when a classic local estate from the 1870's, Orchard Hill Farm, came on the market four years ago. He and his wife, Janet, bought it, and were faced with a problem (all right, so it's a nice problem): how do you start furnishing a 54-by-26-foot living room?

title: Yours, Mine and Theirs: Toe to Toe, We Are Too Many
description: IF I had been the person on duty that day at the booth at Greenwich Point when Brenden Leydon tried to jog into the park, I, as a believer in always cutting an innocent some slack, would have allowed him to come in, extend his run and smell the salt breeze. He had already run this far, it was a slow day, he didn't know the rules, so be my guest.

title: Susan Strauss, Keith Andruschak
description: Susan Mary Strauss and Keith Michael Andruschak were married yesterday by the Rev. Joe A. Francis at St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Modified Foods Put Companies In a Quandary
description: Frito-Lay announced in January that it would stop using biotechnology-based corn in its chips. Gerber Products has banned genetically modified ingredients from its baby food. And McDonald's has asked its suppliers not to ship it genetically altered potatoes.

title: The Missile Drain
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tanorexic in the Family
description: ME TALK PRETTY ONE DAY

title: A Suffocating Carpet on the Floor of the Sea
description: WHEN beachgoers in Atlantic Beach notice seaweed, they see a nuisance. When Morris Kramer and Tom Doheny spy a certain type of seaweed, they see a peril to the marine ecosystems of Nassau's South Shore bays and creeks.

title: Riverhead to Tighten Rules for Chaperons
description: The Riverhead Central School District is considering changes in rules for chaperons on school trips after the suicide of a student arrested on a drug charge at a New Jersey amusement park in April.

title: No Room at the Top
description: True Summit

title: Board Draws a Line in the Park Over a Plan for a Food Concession
description: Community board members are sharply opposing a plan to put a food stand in Stuyvesant Square Park. But park officials say the resistance is much too early, because nothing has been put on paper yet.

title: Cooking
description: ''Authentic is a funny word. In a lot of recent books about food and cooking, authenticity seems to entail being somebody entirely other than who you actually are. Enter the magical kingdom of the book and you become a Vietnamese farmer, a Manhattan chef, your great-grandmother, a Roman housewife. Of course, these transformations are fundamentally impossible. Youre still you -- youre just pretending. And so ''authentic comes to mean its opposite. For your spaghetti carbonara, you may search out real pancetta or, even better, guanciale, if youre trying to recreate the experience of the dish as its known and loved in Italy. But lets face it, the only truly authentic spaghetti carbonara is made by Romans in Rome. Does this mean that American cooking enthusiasts, we supremely multicultural omnivores, are condemned to inhabit a culinary Epcot, a universe of simulations?

title: Elizabeth Garno, William Reid
description: Elizabeth Fogarty Garno, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Forsythe Garno Jr. of Gladwyne, Pa., was married on Friday evening to William Rogers Reid, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Rogers Reid of Waccabuc, N.Y. The Rev. James L. Burns performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDD, IRVING
description: RUDD-Irving. 82. Internationally known sports publicist passed away on June 2, 2000. Beloved and devoted husband for 57 years of Gertrude; a truly special father to Susan and Philip Cohen and Nanci and Ronald Marmer; adored grandfather of Jodi and Pete Sabal, Allison Marmer and Davina and Tobias Cohen; and especially proud great-grandfather of Zoe Anna Sabal. The love and affection he gave to his family, friends and colleagues in the sports world is legendary. He will be missed by all. Services 1:30 PM, Gutterman's, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the NY Heart Fund.

title: An Improbable Pair on a Quest Into the Past
description: FROM opposite ends of the dance universe come two superstars: Mikhail Baryshnikov and Yvonne Rainer. He from the purest centuries-old classical tradition, she from the rule-breaking Judson Dance Theater of the 1960's. He the prince of Russian ballet; she the high priestess of the American avant-garde. He known for his natural theatricality, she for her resistance to anything theatrical.

title: Weekend in Williamstown
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., in the Purple Valley of the northwestern Berkshires, does all of the stereotypical things that New England towns are supposed to do: it charms, calms and beguiles. Most of all, it nestles. The dramatic peaks of the mountain ranges that surround Williamstown are echoed by the undulating topography of the town itself, and of the Williams College campus at its center. In 1849, Henry David Thoreau famously described the organic relationship of this community to its environment: ''Some will remember, no doubt, not only that they went to the college, but that they went to the mountain. Every visit to its summit would, as it were, generalize the particular information gained below, and subject it to more catholic tests.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, ARTHUR IRVING
description: BRODSKY-Arthur Irving. On Saturday, June 3, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Betty Brodsky. Cherished father of Harold, Laura and Ellen. Grandfather of Russell, Mark and Susan Brodsky, and of Jaime and Carrie Osterman. Great-grandfather of Wendy, Samantha, Paige and Benjamin Brodsky. Services Monday, June 5, at 11:30 AM, at Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave. (near Ave. U), Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Lung Association would be appreciated.

title: May 28-June 3; To Be or Not to Be, Texas Style, and Bush-Lessness
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has the distinction of presiding over more executions (131) than any governor in the country. So, on Thursday, when he granted his first 30-day reprieve to a death-row inmate, the political world took note: was it an instance of a man running as a compassionate conservative trying to advertise his charitable nature?

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Not a Face to Launch Many Ships at All

title: May 28-June 3; An End to Privacy
description: For more than 2,000 adoptees in Oregon who have applied to see their original birth certificates, the long wait is about to end. United States Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor refused a request by a group of birth mothers to block a law passed by the state's voters in 1998 granting any adopted adult access to the birth records. The birth mothers had argued that the nation's first such voter-approved law was an unconscionable privacy violation, but adoptees said they have an even more basic right to try to discover where they came from -- and what their biological parents' medical histories might be. SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

title: Racism and Sexism
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: SONGLIAN is 19 and has just left her parents' home to become the fourth wife of a rich man in Zhang Yimou's wise, hauntingly beautiful drama RAISE THE RED LANTERN (1991), set in 1920's China. The master is so weathly, in fact, that each of his wives has a house of her own. (And the servants light the red lanterns each evening at the house in which he plans to spend that night.) Mistress No. 2 is warm and welcoming, but she may be hiding a vicious side. Mistress No. 3, a former opera singer, is glamorous, jealous and a little too friendly with the family doctor. As Mistress No. 4, Songlian (the gorgeous Gong Li, whose every subtle facial expression is a life lesson) learns fast about the politics of power. And as she learns, she does a great deal of damage - Sunday at 2 p.m. and Sunday/Early Monday at 3:30 a.m. on Bravo.

title: May 28-June 3; Spy and Entrepreneur
description: He said he did nothing to betray the country he adopted decades ago, but Cuban-born Mariano Faget, a high-ranking supervisor in the Miami office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, is facing five years in prison after being convicted on espionage charges.

title: Introduction
description: Tony Hackett's profile of Marion Jones prompted a spirited debate on the role that the track star's confidence -- some might say arrogance -- plays in her success in competition. Other readers continue to respond with both alarm and amusement to Jeffrey Rosen's article on the invasion of Internet privacy.

title: The World; 2 Elections On an Island. So Close, So Far Apart.
description: WILDA SEVERE carried the future in her mind and body as she waited to cast her ballot last month in Haiti's legislative elections. Though five months pregnant, she stood for hours on a slowly moving line, hoping that her vote would usher in a better life for her baby.

title: Overnight Sensation
description: The tabloid headlines didn't begin their screaming with O. J., Diana, the Princess of Wales, and Eli'an. A very New Jersey event, the Lindbergh kidnapping trial in Flemington in 1935, gave the tabloid press the chance to flex its muscles, aided by high-speed printing, improved telephone service and flashbulb photography. With the addition of national radio networks, celebrity -- and infamy -- could explode into the American consciousness. In ''Legacy of a Kidnapping: Lindbergh and the Triumph of the Tabloids,'' Lewis H. Lapham, editor of Harper's magazine, presents a documentary essay that uses the trial to connect the sensational journalism displayed in Flemington with the coverage of today, comparing Walter Winchell with Peter Jennings, the ''Sob Sisters'' of the Hearst machine with Diane Sawyer and Barbara Walters. The program will be broadcast Tuesday at 9 p.m. on WLIW, the public television station based on Long Island.

title: A Dose of Sense From Viagra's Spokesman
description: IN SOME ways, Bob Dole is an unlikely spokesman for older Americans.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 21 about the singers Lou Reed and Patti Smith as custodians of the Beat aesthetic misstated the order of deaths of the writers Allen Ginsberg and William S. Burroughs. Ginsberg died in April 1997; Burroughs died four months later.

title: Confessions of a Closet Homemaker
description: I delighted in Carolynn Carreno's Lives column (April 30). It reminded me of me. I love to cook. For me, it's relaxation. And making special dishes for friends coming to dinner is always a challenge I enjoy.

title: Deli Mavens Weigh In On Pastrami Palaces
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUENTE, TITO
description: PUENTE-Tito. The Hackley School Community is saddened by the death of legendary musician Tito Puente and offers its heartfelt condolences to his family. Few individuals have reached so many with such joyous influence. Jack M. Ferraro, President of the Board Walter C. Johnson, Headmaster

title: Nureyev's Partner, the Camera
description: THIRTY-FOUR years ago, during the filming of his ballet ''Le Jeune Homme et la Mort,'' the French choreographer Roland Petit walked into Rudolf Nureyev's dressing room to check on his star's makeup. ''He said to me, 'Am I looking good?' '' Mr. Petit recalled recently. ''I said, 'You're as good as Marilyn Monroe.' He looked at me. 'Is it a compliment?' I replied, 'Of course.' ''

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-4-00: The Ethicist; The Gift That Keeps On Giving
description: In my job, I get many presents from vendors. Recently, I received a particularly thoughtful gift that I have no use for. Instead of having it clutter my office or throwing it away, I am considering giving it to someone else in appreciation for some work done on a recent project. Is such regifting ethical? -- Anonymous, San Francisco

title: BOOKEND
All Aboard for the A Train And the 181st St. Exhibition
description: THE SETTING -- Memorial Day, 2 p.m., on the 181st Street platform of the A train. A dozen friends and relatives helped Margery Cohen, an artist, attach 124 portraits to the blank spaces on the walls where advertisements used to be displayed. To keep things legal, Amy Melnick, a video teacher, captured the scene on a video camera: Ms. Cohen hadn't been able to get permission from the M.T.A. to install the exhibition, but she obtained a permit to film the installation of an exhibition.

title: Special Tonys for a Threesome of Octogenarians
description: I'VE swept the plate,'' said Eileen Heckart during a telephone conversation from her home in Norwalk.

title: The Poseurs of Missile Defense
description: Thus far into the presidential campaign, the debate over national missile defenses has been nothing short of surreal.

title: With 24 Years For Robbery, He Has Time To Pursue His Parole
description: TIME is of the essence in prison, but Atiba Kwesi has had a lot of it to serve -- 24 years for robbery -- and a lot to spend on litigation against the New Jersey Parole Board.

title: A Verbal Way to Stand Tall
description: SOME months back, I took my 2 1/2-year-old son to the pediatrician for a checkup and got some unexpected news: he had shrunk half an inch from his previous visit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, MICHAEL, M.D
description: SACKS-Michael, M.D. Columbia's Mailman School of Public Health extends deepest sympathy to the family of Dr. Michael Sacks. In his lifetime of dedication to the field of international public health, he was instrumental in global campaigns against smallpox, for the provision of primary health care, sanitation and clean drinking water for all, and raised the quality of life for the underserved of the world. He served the poorest of the poor in the developing world with boundless enthusiasm and sound advice. Allan Rosenfield, M.D., Dean

title: Children's Books
description: AROUND MY ROOM

title: Corzine's Spending Accurately Reflects The Larger Trend
description: Everyone knows by now that Jon Corzine's personal spending on his campaign for the United State Senate primary on Tuesday has dwarfed any previous records in the state, including personal money that his rival for the Democratic nomination, Jim Florio, has made.

title: How U.S. Left Sierra Leone Tangled in a Curious Web
description: As Sierra Leone slid back into war last month, the British were conspicuous as the one Western power willing to shore up the faltering United Nations peacekeeping force. To many, their presence merely emphasized the absence of the United States, which last year was a major backer of the peace agreement that granted amnesty to a brutal warlord, Foday Sankoh, and even brought him into government.

title: Craving Solitude but Needing Community
description: WENDY PARIS, a travel writer, bikes across Lower Manhattan to get to work at an office loft shared among a dozen writers, editors and graphic artists. Ms. Paris, who also contributes to women's magazines, sought out the ersatz newsroom at 72 Madison Avenue to beat back the sense of anonymity she felt when working at home. For $315 a month she gets not only a desk with fax, phone and computer lines, but a conference room, cafe and camaraderie.

title: Alexandra Ascher, David Hochman

title: Style; Art Decor
description: There's something about a portrait of a room that's as compelling as a portrait of a person. Its details -- from the style of architecture to the fringe on a pillow -- are like the clothing and jewelry on a human subject. They give us clues to the occupant's social or economic status, culture and personality. Moreover, in a really good portrait of a room, the room itself becomes a personality, with a story of its own to tell. Anna Goth Werner's painting of the interior of the Abigail Adams Smith Museum in New York, shown here, needs no one to populate it; the human presence that shaped these rooms is evident in line and shade, in the placement of a mirror or the swag of a curtain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, JAMES M.
description: HUGHES-James M. Beloved husband of Catherine M. Hughes (nee; Enright.) Born in New York City, he was a graduate of City College of New York and St. John's University Law School. After admittance to the New York Bar he served as an Assistant Attorney General of the State of New York, assigned to the Stock Fraud Bureau. After his service in the Attorney General's office, he entered into the private practice of law in New York City. he served in the War Shipping Administration during World War II and thereafter joined the Wall Street law firm of Bigham, Englar, and Jones & Houston where he continued to work for 38 years retiring from there as a partner of said firm. During his law practice with the law firm he was admitted to practice in the Supreme Court of the United States as well as the U.S. District Courts for the Southern and Eastern Districts of New York in addition to the Courts of New York State. He was a fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. He was an honorary member of St. John's Law School Alumni. He was also a member of the American Bar Association, the Maritime Law Association of the United States, the Catholic Speakers Assembly, the Knights of Columbus and the Telistians. Mr. Hughes was predeceased by his two brothers, Robert and Thomas, both of who were residents of Fort Lee at the time of their deaths. He was also a long time parishioner of Madonna Church in Fort Lee. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Patti & Mikatarian Funeral Home, 327 Main Street, Fort Lee. (201)944-0100. Funeral Mass Monday 10A.M. at Madonna RC Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERBILT, HUGH BEDFORD, SR.
description: VANDERBILT-Hugh Bedford, Sr., of Greenwich, CT, Palm Beach, FL, and Devil Lake, Canada, died June 2, 2000, after a valiant battle with cancer. He was 79 years old. He was born in Brooklyn, NY, the youngest son of the late Robert Thurlow and Mildred Bedford Vanderbilt. He attended the Allen Stevenson School, Choate School and Trinity College in Hartford. He served in the Army from 1942 to 1946, participating in the battle of Iwo Jima while attached to the 5th Marine Division. He remained on Iwo for a year. He was President, CEO and Chairman of the R.T. Vanderbilt Company, a mining and manufacturing company founded by his father in 1916. He was also an avid collector of early American antiques, and served on the Boards of the Greenwich Historical Society as well as that of Historic Deerfield. He was a passionate golfer, fisherman and downhill skier. He is survived by his wife of fifty-four years, Claire F. Vanderbilt, a brother, Robert T. of London, England, a son, Hugh, Jr., and two daughters, Linda and Laura. He was predeceased by a brother, F. Bedford Vanderbilt. He also leaves five grandsons, Thaddeus, Alexander, Nicholas, Michael and Tyler. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich Building Fund. Services will be held at the Christ Church, 11 AM, Wednesday, June 7.

title: Sports of The Times; The Woman Firmly Behind Palmer's Legend
description: ARNOLD PALMER had never had such a terrible first round at the Masters. America's golfer, a four-time winner at Augusta National, had opened the 1985 Masters with an embarrassing 83, and now, as he was about to tee off in the second round, somebody asked Winnie Palmer if her famous husband had considered withdrawing.

title: Better Ways to Find the Guilty
description: When Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who had always denied pleas for reprieves from execution, finally granted one last week, he made the right call, acknowledging the importance of DNA evidence and the right of a condemned man to ask for testing. Whether or not political considerations of Mr. Bush's presidential campaign were at work, the prisoner, Ricky McGinn, now has time for the tests that might clear him of murder.

title: Divisiveness at Parade as Mrs. Clinton and Lazio Salute Israel

title: Acquisitions by the technology companies of start-up small-fry offer a sampler on how deals can go wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, HARRY A.
description: BROOKS-Harry A. Of Glen Head, LI, on June 2, 2000, age 87. Beloved husband of Helen M. (Holly). Father of Melissa Brooks Zakarian and Miranda Brooks Meyer. Stepfather of James R. Lowell III and Howard B. Lowell; their spouses and seven grandchildren. He was in the class of 1935 at Princeton University and graduated from New York Law School in 1938. From 1941 to 1945 he served in the U.S. Army, eventually as Assistant Chief of Staff on the American Delegation at the Allied Kommandatura in Berlin, 1945 to 1946, before retiring as a Lieutenant Colonel. He was awarded the Bronze Star and Army Commendation Ribbon. After the war, he began a long career in the art business in New York City, beginning with E. Coe Kerr Gallery and then at Knoedler & Co., where he remained for 21 years. In 1968, he went to Wildenstein & Co. as Vice President, and later as President, before retiring in 1990. Thereafter he remained a Director and advisor on the firm's special projects. He married Helen Moffett Lowell in 1963. He devoted much of his time to many organizations. He served as Director of the Art Museum at Princeton University and the Nassau County Museum of Art, Roslyn, NY. He was a member of the Advisory Committee at the Metropolitan Opera in NYC and a Trustee of the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in Saratoga, NY. He was a Manager of the Racquet and Tennis Club in New York. He also had many charitable interests. Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY, Tuesday, June 6, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers the family asks that a donation be made to Nassau County Museum of Art, Roslyn, New York.

title: What Will Happen to the Baby? Among Other Cosmic, One-Act Questions
description: Leslie Caputo's ''Birth Marks,'' which closes the first half of the third and final installment of Marathon 2000, the Ensemble Studio Theater's annual festival of new plays, has enough situational complexity to make you want a second act. As it opens, a young woman named Terry -- she's maybe 18 or 20 -- has just given birth to a baby in a hospital on the Lower East Side. Played by Jenna Lamia, she's blond, lovely, Irish Catholic and alone. Her husband, who is Hispanic, hasn't shown up at the hospital, and he never will.

title: Enough Wagnerian Conflict for an Opera
description: Passions are not often stirred in Germany, a country that has learned to mistrust the giddier emotions, but a long-simmering battle for control of the annual Wagner Festival at Bayreuth is now coming to a head with an unusual clamor. At stake is the directorship of the festival, a position held for the past 49 years by Wolfgang Wagner, the composer's 80-year-old grandson. Because Bayreuth, where Wagner introduced his ''Ring of the Nibelung'' in 1876, occupies such a central, if contested, place in German culture, the fight is bitter and widely watched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUDIS, DR. MORRIS MAC
description: HUDIS-Dr. Morris Mac, of Monroe Township, NJ, formerly of Yonkers and Irvington, NY. Died peacefully after a long struggle on June 3, 2000. Son of the late Ida and Rafael Hudis. Born in the Bronx, NY. Beloved husband for 53 years of Dr. Ann Hudis, devoted father of Dr. Paula Hudis (Dr. Ira Fink) of Berkely, CA, Iris Hudis of New York City and Dr. Stephen (Merrye) of Princeton, NJ, and adored grandfather of Loel and Suzanne. He graduated from CCNY in 1938,and from NYU Dental School in the Class of 1942. Served from 1941 to 1968 in the U.S. Navy and Naval Reserve, retiring with the rank of Lt. Commander. For 42 years he taught Prosthodontics to many students at NYU Dental School where he was a Professor. A Fellow of the International College of Dentists (FICD), the American College of Dentists (FACD), and the American Academy of Oral Medicine. He lectured internationally and authored numerous articles in the field of Prosthodontics, including a textbook entitled ''Dental Laboratory Prosthodontics.'' He was a leader of the Men's Club at the Jewish Community Center of Tarrytown. He will be missed by everyone who knew and loved him. Graveside services are Monday 2 PM, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. The period of mourning will be observed at the Hudis residence at (The Ponds) in Monroe Township, NJ, on Monday and Tuesday, and at the Hudis Residence in Princeton on Wednesday. For information: Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 609883-1400. Contributions to Parkinson's research or a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACRAE, CAMERON F. LEBOEUF
description: MacRAE-Cameron F. LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae mourns with profound sorrow the death of our founding and name partner on May 29 in Hobe Sound, Florida. He was Senior Partner and Chairman of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae for many years, and set the mold for the national and international growth of the Firm. During the Second World War, Mr. MacRae served as Assistant Director of the Readjustment Division of the War Department, while on active duty as a Colonel in the Army. He also served as President of the Federal Energy Bar Association from 1969-1970, and served as a consultant to the Task Force on Water Resources and Power of the Hoover Commission from 1953-1955. He will be sorely missed, and we extend our deepest sympathy to all members of his bereaved family. Funeral services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDER, DR. DANIEL
description: FEDER-Dr. Daniel. Born December 28, 1909 in Norristown, PA. The son of Max and Fannie Feder, the eighth of 12 children, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his family on June 4, 2000. A Commander in the U.S. Navy during W.W.II, he served with honor in his ship's dental, medical and photography corp. A graduate of Temple University and NYU, Dan became a restorative dentist of world renown, treating patients with compassion and professionalism for over 60 years. A Los Angeles resident for over 52 years, he never gave up his passion for tennis, travel, world affairs and his family. He was a gentle man with a deep sense of integrity, and an endless supply of generosity, humor & love. Dan will always be cherished and missed by his family, friends, colleagues and patients. He is survived by Ruth, his wife of 50 years; his children, Michael, David and Kayla; his son-inlaw Jesus; his daughters-in-law Jennie and Polly; his devoted companion Pita; and his beautiful grandchildren Madeline, Jackson and Spencer. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Dan's name to the following important charity: The Dental Volunteers of Israel, c/o Lila Seiler, 11 Sage Circle, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

title: TELEFONICA TO BUY INTERNET CONCERN

Telefonica said it would pay Bertelsmann, Europe's biggest media company, with stock in Telefonica Data, a data-transmission unit for which it has yet to issue separate shares, or stock in Telefonica itself. Bertelsmann has the option to complete the sale in January 2001. If it does not, the Spanish company can force a sale at an unspecified higher price in April 2001, Telefonica said. Mediaways, founded in 1996, is Germany's second-largest Internet network operator after Deutsche Telekom.

France Telecom is selling the shares because of its pending investment in a competitor in the cellular transmission tower business, NTL Inc. of New York. The shares are about 15 percent of Crown Castle's stock outstanding. France Telecom also agreed to sell the 17.7 million Crown Castle shares it will own after the offering within 30 days after the first sale. Shares of Houston-based Crown Castle rose $4.875, or 15.9 percent, to $35.625.

title: What Shatner Hath Wrought; The Intersection of the Internet and Celebrity
description: Joe Montana and Ronnie Lott, former stars of the San Francisco 49ers, were there. So was Keyshawn Johnson, the outspoken wide receiver who was recently traded to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers from the New York Jets.

title: Morgan Stanley Is Cited for Discrimination Against Women
description: A federal agency determined yesterday that Morgan Stanley Dean Witter had discriminated against women working in one of its divisions, opening the door for lawsuits -- and possibly a class action -- against the firm.

title: I.M.F. Warns Indonesia Against Capital Controls
description: In a move that seems likely to snuff out Indonesia's latest flirtation with capital controls, the new managing director of the International Monetary Fund declared today that closing off Indonesian capital markets would hinder the nation's fragile economic recovery.

title: Celebrating the Poetry of Imagination Without Boundaries
description: In the bitter cold of Antarctica and the blistering heat of Texas, scientists recently coaxed the universe to display its hidden structure. In the past weeks, two different high altitude balloon experiments studying the microwave radiation left over from the Big Bang independently reported that the universe is very close to being ''flat.''

title: What Could Be Good About Morning Sickness? Plenty
description: Evolution has not always come up with things people consider wonderful. Note mosquitoes, sickle cell anemia and the killer instinct. But according to evolutionary theory, there is a reason for everything that has evolved. However obnoxious it may seem, somehow it enhances survival.

title: Of Rats, Cocaine and Addiction Mysteries
description: Cocaine is indisputably addictive, but while many fall into its hold, others simply dabble and move on. To date, predicting how a user will react to the drug has been anyone's guess.

title: EFFICIENT NETWORKS HALTS PLAN TO BUY NETSCREEN
description: Efficient Networks Inc., the biggest maker of high-speed modems for telephone networks, yesterday dropped plans to buy NetScreen Technologies Inc. for stock. The closely held NetScreen, based in Santa Clara, Calif., sells security equipment and software for Web sites and corporate networks. Dallas-based Efficient said it would instead license NetScreen's technology. The transaction was valued at $834.2 million when the agreement was first announced on March 28. Based on Friday's closing price, the stock swap would be valued at $349.14 million. Efficient's shares fell 87.5 cents, to $65.25, still far above its initial offering price of $15 each last July.

title: SUNY Fight Over Curriculum Mirrors Larger Debate
description: In the growing nationwide battle over who really runs higher education -- the professors or the university trustees -- one of the most closely watched contests is taking place here, at the State University of New York. To the consternation of many faculty members, SUNY's trustees have moved to hold down the university's budget, to make the campuses more self-supporting and, most provocatively, to establish a common required curriculum on all campuses.

title: LONDON JOURNAL: Mad About Art in London; Th Weird Fascination of the New Is Packing Galleries and Museums
description: The British are nuts about their artists, and by nuts I mean they are out of their minds. The condition shows no sign of easing -- the reverse in fact, thanks to the Tate Modern, a huge new engine of national self-congratulation spurring many ancillary goings-on. Fresh galleries are suddenly open, including another branch of the American dealer Larry Gagosian's empire. American colonization betrays growing trans-Atlantic regard, a sure sign of change.

title: Type of Biotech Corn Found to Be Safe to a Butterfly Species
description: A strain of genetically modified corn that produces its own insecticide, known as Bt, does not appear to harm black swallowtail butterflies in the wild, according to a report published today in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Stellar Cast of Democrats Raises $3.7 Million in New York
description: High above Midtown Manhattan, Vice President Al Gore said last night that Representative Charles B. Rangel was ''in the catbird seat.'' And the Harlem Democrat, grinning through his mustache, looked as if he was indeed in a position of power.

title: Top Field at Buick Classic Is Tuning Up for U.S. Open
description: Instead of resting before next week's United States Open, many of the world's top golfers have come to New York.

title: BAA PROFIT FALLS
description: The world's biggest airport operator, BAA, said its second-half profit fell 8.2 percent because of weaker retail sales after the abolition of duty-free shopping in Europe. Profit from operations for the six months that ended on March 31 fell to $:145 million ($219 million) from $:158 million in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: S.E.C. Warns Against Misleading Buyers of Annuities
description: In the midst of a federal examination of the sale of variable annuities, a fast-growing and controversial combination of mutual funds and insurance, a senior regulator issued a stern warning today that misleading tactics and incomplete disclosure would not be tolerated.

title: Chirac Seeks Shorter Term For President
description: President Jacques Chirac proposed today that France's presidential term be shortened from seven years to five, a move that could profoundly change the nature of French politics and help him in the next elections.

title: Trinidad Supplies Relief and Hitting
description: Pablo Trinidad's standout performance led Monroe to a 7-5 victory over Tottenville yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League Class A baseball championship at Yankee Stadium.

title: From the Life of Evita, a New Chapter on Medical Secrecy
description: When Eva Peron, the first lady of Argentina, underwent a hysterectomy in November 1951, she did not know that her husband, Juan, had summoned a Manhattan cancer surgeon to perform the procedure. The surgeon, Dr. George T. Pack, flew to Buenos Aires, entered the operating room after Eva was anesthetized, and left before she awoke.

title: John Millis, 47, Aide in Congress
description: John I. Millis, a former case officer with the Central Intelligence Agency who for the last three years served as the top staff member of the House Intelligence Committee, committed suicide on Sunday, the police and Congressional officials said today. title: As Rate Fears Ebb, Treasury Yields Fall
description: Yields on Treasury securities fell to six-week lows yesterday on expectations that the Federal Reserve would not need to raise interest rates as much as forecast to slow the economy and curb inflationary pressure.

title: In Rural Enclaves of U.S., Cockfights Are Flourishing
description: In urban America the blood sport of cockfighting survives only furtively, in seedy pits like one that the police raided in the Bronx on Saturday night. But the game remains far more entrenched in many rural communities like this one in Oklahoma, where cockfighting is legal and where on Friday night 200 people gathered in a carnival atmosphere to watch roosters tear each other apart and to bet on their fates.

Sabrina Tavernise

title: SINGAPORE LOOSENS MEDIA RULES
description: Moving to enliven its tightly controlled local media in the face of slicker foreign offerings, Singapore said it would turn its two media monopolies into duopolies. The minister for information and the arts, Lee Yock Suan, said the government-owned broadcaster, the Media Corporation of Singapore, would be allowed to publish a daily newspaper for commuters. Singapore Press Holdings, meanwhile, will be allowed to apply for two radio licenses and two television licenses. The government said that it would not lift the 3 percent limit on ownership of a local media company by a single foreign investor but that it would review its ban on satellite dishes in 2002.

title: Prosecutor Drops Charges of Murder In Deal With Lewis
description: Murder and assault charges against Ray Lewis, the Baltimore Ravens' star linebacker, were dropped in an Atlanta courtroom yesterday after he pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of obstructing justice and agreed to testify against two co-defendants.

title: Bush May Scoff at Polls, but Aides Call Them Reliable Predictor of Victory
description: You could buy a Texas ranch if you had a dollar for every time Gov. George W. Bush has dismissed polls by saying that the only meaningful one is on Election Day. But his aides seem plenty attuned to the growing number of voter surveys that telegraph that moment.

title: Talks Reported on German Bid for British Internet Service
description: Britain's largest Internet service provider, Freeserve P.L.C., is in talks to be acquired by Deutsche Telekom's Internet arm, T-Online International, according to executives close to the discussions. Freeserve, not yet two years old, was the first in Britain to market an Internet service with no online charges, a business model that has been widely imitated.

title: Sex and the Therapist: Views of the Couch
description: Dr. Susie Orbach -- the therapist who treated Diana, Princess of Wales, for her eating disorders; the founder of the Women's Therapy Center of London; a former columnist for The Guardian; a visiting professor at the London School of Economics; and the author of 1978 best-seller ''Fat is a Feminist Issue'' -- is, aside from Sigmund Freud, probably the most famous psychotherapist to have ever set up couch in Britain.

title: CHERRY CORPORATION ACCEPTS BUYOUT BID FROM CHAIRMAN
description: The Cherry Corporation, an electrical switch maker, accepted a sweetened buyout offer of $26.40 a share, or about $128 million, from its chairman, Peter Cherry, and affiliates for the 48 percent of the company that they do not already own. The bid, valuing all of Cherry Corporation about $266 million, topped an offer of $26 a share made last month by an undisclosed company. The Cherry group bid $18.75 a share in April. The shares rose $5.375 each yesterday, or 26 percent, to $25.75. The company, based in Waukegan, Ill., had sales of $360.7 million in the year that ended on Feb. 29. It makes sensors and controls for automobiles and computers, and switch assemblies.

title: Protecting Parental Rights
description: The Supreme Court has wisely affirmed a ruling by the Washington State Supreme Court that a state statute goes too far in permitting courts to grant grandparents visiting rights over a parent's objections. The case, Troxel v. Granville, raises the question of whether and when states can intrude on parental rights to recognize other family ties. It has been closely watched because family structures are changing, and grandparents and other adults are taking on parental roles.

He created the internationally acclaimed Childrens Garden in 1984 and in 1998 it was renamed in his honor The Jeff Dullea Intergenerational Garden. title: BRAZIL'S PRODUCTION INCREASES
description: Brazil's industrial output rose 3.3 percent in April compared with last year, the ninth consecutive month of growth. Auto and electronics makers led the advance, as declining domestic interest rates fostered an increase in demand for durable goods. Automakers also increased exports by 78.9 percent in the first four months of the year compared with a year earlier. The output of consumer and nondurable goods fell by 7 percent in April compared with the year-earlier period, under pressure from falling wine production.

title: Wagner Festival Succession Is Delayed
description: The Richard Wagner Foundation today postponed a decision over who should take over from Wolfgang Wagner as director of the annual Wagner Festival in Bayreuth, Germany, leaving a long-running battle among descendants of the composer to continue at least until this summer's festival is over.

description: A deep division within the nation's largest Protestant denomination, the Southern Baptist Convention, has developed to the point that a significant moderate minority has been creating a separate existence from the denomination's increasingly conservative leadership.

title: Peace Across the Hudson
description: The biggest network of airports, train lines, bus terminals and port facilities in the New York region is run by one giant agency, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Last week, Gov. George Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman reached an important agreement to end a fight over distribution of the authority's subsidies and projects. The accord, which ends 18 months of paralysis, grants Mr. Pataki's request for more resources spent in New York. It was a welcome step, but much more thinking is needed to revitalize the authority as an engine of economic growth.

title: SHARES OF CDNOW DROP AFTER CAUTION ABOUT MERGER
description: The shares of CDNow Inc. dropped yesterday after the company said it could not guarantee that it would reach an agreement for a new merger or investor by the end of June. Shares of the online music retailer fell 68.75 cents, or 14.1 percent, to $4.1875. On Friday, the company's shares rose sharply when CDNow said it had identified a ''short list'' of prospective investors and merger partners. The company issued the news in response to a Goldman, Sachs & Company report that mentioned CDNow among a number of businesses that would fall victim to an Internet shakeout.

description: Ellis Clary, the archetype of the baseball lifer who wisecracked his way through more than half a century in the game as a player, manager, coach and one of its best-known scouts, died last Friday in Valdosta, Ga. He was 85.

title: PATHOGENESIS SEEKING WAYS TO RAISE ITS STOCK PRICE
description: The PathoGenesis Corporation, a biotechnology company, said yesterday that it had hired Goldman, Sachs to seek out ''strategic options'' to raise its stock price. The Seattle-based company develops drugs to treat infectious diseases -- particularly lung infections -- including those common in cystic fibrosis. Maryellen Thielen, a spokeswoman for the company, said no timetable had been set. She would not comment whether PathoGenesis is seeking a merger partner or an outright sale of the company. Shares in PathoGenesis traded above $59 before beginning a steep descent in May 1999. The stock rose $1.9375 yesterday, to $19.9375.

title: Youths Get a Dose of Salt-Water Therapy

After being jailed on assault and theft charges two years ago, however, the court assigned Mr. Immel to Baltimore's Fresh Start Program, which uses sailing as a therapeutic tool for troubled teenagers. Soon he was racing a 23-foot Rainbow sail boat in Baltimore Harbor.

title: Modest Gains in Moscow
description: Little progress on arms control was expected from President Clinton's weekend visit to Moscow, and little occurred. President Vladimir Putin of Russia acknowledged that there might soon be a need to counter nuclear threats from unpredictable powers like North Korea. But he did not soften his opposition to American plans for a national missile defense. Mr. Clinton agreed that there should be significant new reductions in offensive missiles as part of a deal that would also amend the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty to allow a limited defensive shield. But Mr. Clinton held back from steeper cuts that Russia favors and the Pentagon resists.

According to a report in yesterday's Times by William Glaberson, one race for the Ohio Supreme Court this year is going to cost up to $12 million. We have candidates spending a couple of million dollars to become state legislator, a job that generally carries less prestige than that of nightclub bouncer. At this rate, the next bunch of people stranded on a desert island with a TV crew is going to demand a whole lot more than a lousy million dollars for the effort. title: Too Eager to Close the Deal

On the left were those who seemed to support any agreement so long as the process moved forward. On the right, many opposed any territorial compromise with the Palestinians, regardless of the where, when and how.

The numbers are now sufficient, scientists say, to recognize patterns and to understand where, when and how the most powerful black holes typically develop.

But Mr. Puente, who died Wednesday at 77, was as much a symbol of New York City as the Empire State Building or the Statue of Liberty.

description: Last year, the art world was abuzz about elephant dung and a shark in formaldehyde at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. This year, animals are once again capturing artistic attention: a parade of artist-designed cows are posing throughout the city this month, and yesterday, the artist Jeff Koons unveiled a 43-foot puppy sculpture carpeted with living flowers in Rockefeller Center.

title: AIRBUS SUPERJUMBO ORDER
description: The European aircraft consortium Airbus Industrie appeared to inch a step closer to a decision to build a new superjumbo jetliner, the A3XX, announcing that the International Lease Finance Corporation of Los Angeles, a unit of the American International Group, had expressed interest in acquiring five of the planes, which will be able to carry at least 555 passengers. John J. Leahy, senior vice president for sales at Airbus, said that airlines had expressed interest in 32 of the aircraft and that the number would reach 50 ''very readily.'' Emirates Airlines, Singapore Airlines and Air France have also shown interest in the giant aircraft. John Tagliabue

title: AT&T's ACQUISITION OF MEDIAONE WINS APPROVAL BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved AT&T's acquisition of MediaOne today after ordering the companies to sell some of their assets, clearing the final obstacle to a merger that will create the nation's largest provider of cable television, long-distance telephone service and high-speed Internet access.

title: Despite Ferment, Gene Therapy Progresses
description: Gene therapy burst into the news last fall, when a teenager from Tucson died in an experiment at the University of Pennsylvania. But while politicians and the press have spent the year focusing on accusations of lax government oversight and shoddily run clinical trials, the science of gene therapy has been making quiet, steady progress.

title: Perfection Is Distant Memory for Cone
description: Orlando Cabrera made the last out in David Cone's perfect game last July and was ecstatic afterward, feeling he had played a part in history, saying it ranked among the greatest moments of his career.

title: Bolshoi's New 'Quixote' Is Faithful to the Old Yet More Classical in Its Mien
description: Lucky Chicago, Seattle, Los Angeles and Costa Mesa. Audiences there will be able to see the Bolshoi Ballet on its current national tour in ''Don Quixote'' and as the weekend's performances here at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts confirmed, nobody dances ''Don Quixote'' like the Bolshoi. The effect is overwhelming, a blaze of color on every level of perception.

title: CISCO WILL BUY HYNEX AND GAIN A.T.M. TECHNOLOGY
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the world's biggest maker of computer networking equipment, agreed yesterday to buy a privately held automated teller machine specialist, HyNex Ltd., from Elbit Ltd. of Israel for about $127 million in stock and cash. The purchase of HyNex, which is also based in Israel, will give Cisco access to the company's A.T.M. network technology. Cisco said it would keep HyNex's 49 employees. The price includes $9.2 million cash, with the rest in Cisco stock. The stock of Cisco was down $1.125 a share, to $63.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLENGREN, HENRY M.
description: WALLENGREN-Henry M. After living with AIDS, Henry succumbed to complications from cancer on June 2nd, 2000. He was 54 years old. He grew up in East Longmeadow, MA but had called NYC home for the last 26 years. He was a proud and active member of the Arts Community whose interests spanned a wide spectrum. In the art world, he was the owner of Wallengren USA, a SoHo gallery. From there he explored the world of theatrical publishing with the Samuel French Company. Most recently, he worked as an agent and manager, first at the Ann Steele Agency and then for his own client group, Wallengren. He leaves a daughter, Emily Wallengren of Boston, and a son, Dr. Matthew Wallengren of Baltimore, as well as Willy, his 9-year old yellow lab. He will be greatly missed but fondly remembered by his family and close group of friends. There will be a small private service with a memorial service to be announced.

Based on a true story, it was Verdi's only contemporary opera, one inspired by events and attitudes of his time. In fact, even today, it requires no great leap of imagination for audiences to accept that the tragic love of Violetta Valery and Alfredo Germont is unfolding in and around mid-19th-century Paris, and not on stage.

The overheated sweep of its stories, the swell of its choruses and the toil of its divas make it the supremely human art form. But what constitutes opera's bones? title: WELLS FARGO TO BUY CHARTER FINANCIAL
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the nation's seventh-largest bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire privately held Charter Financial Inc. to gain more customers. The price was not disclosed. Charter Financial, based in New York, provides loans for equipment leasing and financing to midsize businesses. It has 100 employees, 4,000 commercial customers and $950 million in receivables. The company is expected to become part of Wells Fargo Equipment Finance Inc., which is based in Minneapolis.

description: Jon S. Corzine, the Wall Street multimillionaire whose $35 million spending spree shattered all records for a Senate race, easily defeated former Gov. Jim Florio on Tuesday in the Democratic primary for the seat being vacated by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRAN, JAMES LEO
description: CURRAN-James Leo. Died June 2, 2000, in his 77th year. Resident of Brooklyn, NY, he was a graduate of Columbia University and an accomplished pianist. He worked in public relations for many organizations including the United Nations, the Multiple Sclerosis Society and the Arthritis Foundation. He is survived by his nieces Linda Wexelblatt and Mary Beth Casey, his grandniece Ann Wexelblatt and his sister-in-law Alice Wood Curran. He was predeceased in 1997 by his close friend of 46 years, John Van Pelt Lassoe, Jr. Memorial gifts in his name may be made to the Heights and Hill Community Council, Meals-on-Heels Program, 160 Montague St., Bklyn, NY 11201.

description: Long viewed as the more dignified and cautious body of Congress, the Senate now finds itself mired in partisan, sand-lot warfare more typical of the House of Representatives.

description: James V. Kimsey, an Internet billionaire who grew up in Washington when the area was a cultural backwater, gave $10 million to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts today to help in the steady move away from that status.

description: The City Council moved quickly yesterday to adopt a $37.6 billion budget package that would cut city taxes by more than $400 million, while increasing city spending at a rate that far exceeds inflation.

title: Corrections

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIGIOVANNI, CONSTANCE
description: DIGIOVANNI-Constance. June 7, 1960-December 3, 1994. Happy 40th Birthday in heaven to my beautiful little sister, my forever friend.

title: A Wistful Smile for Treemonisha, a Sad Farewell (but Not Addio) for Violetta
description: For 25 years the Opera Theater of St. Louis has believed that the best way to draw American audiences into an appreciation of opera as an involving form of theater is to present works in English only. Naturally, American operas like Scott Joplin's ''Treemonisha,'' which recently opened this adventurous summer company's current season, as well as British operas, have figured often in the repertory. But equally common are European works translated into English, even staples like Verdi's ''Traviata,'' the second of this summer's four operas. Performing opera in translation was once common. But this venerable practice has virtually disappeared with the coming of supertitles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, PHYLLIS MCELHONE

title: 3COM FORMS NEW COMPANY TO HANDLE MODEM BUSINESS
description: The 3Com Corporation intends to announce today that it has formed a new company to take over its analog modem business, according to a person close to the company. The new company, which 3Com is forming in partnership with the Accton Technology Corporation of Taiwan and NatSteel Electronics Ltd. of Singapore, is to be called U.S. Robotics. In 1997, 3Com acquired the U.S. Robotics Corporation, which included the group that eventually produced the popular Palm Pilot computer but which was best known for making high-performance computer modems. In recent years, however, 3Com has struggled to manage its disparate product lines, so it spun off Palm and said in March that it would spin off its modem business. Seth Schiesel

description: Eugene M. Zuckert, the secretary of the Air Force during the Bay of Pigs invasion, the Cuban missile crisis and the deepening American involvement in Vietnam, died on Monday in Washington. He was 88 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: MERRILL TO PAY $914 MILLION FOR NO. 3 MARKET MAKER
description: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that it would pay about $914 million in stock to acquire the closely held Herzog Heine Geduld Inc. and become the No. 2 stock-market middleman. It was reported on Monday that the firms were in talks. The purchase will move Merrill up from sixth place in a business it shunned three years ago. Since then, technology has cut trading costs, making the business more attractive. Herzog, a 74-year-old business based in Jersey City, is the No. 3 market maker for Nasdaq stocks. The acquisition increases the number of companies in whose stock Merrill makes a market to more than 8,000 from 650. Market makers purchase and sell specific companies' shares, profiting on the gap between the buy and sell prices.

title: Rangers' Bid for Lowe Gaining Momentum
description: It appears increasingly likely that Kevin Lowe will follow his mentor, Glen Sather, to New York and become the new head coach of the Rangers.

title: AOL OFFERS CONCESSIONS ON BID
description: The European Commission said America Online Inc. had offered concessions to try to win approval for its $146 billion purchase of Time Warner Inc., although the commission did not say what they were. The executive arm of the 15-nation European Union has until June 19 to decide whether to approve the transaction, which would form the world's largest media and Internet company or to examine it for another four months.

title: ASIAN NETWORKING ALLIANCE
description: Japan's largest computer maker and provider of support service, Fujitsu Ltd., and Lucent Technologies Inc. of Murray Hill, N.J., said they would form an alliance to provide networking equipment to companies in Asia, a market expected to reach at least 14 trillion yen ($131 billion) within four years. The companies will jointly manufacture and sell communications network systems for carriers throughout Asia. The equipment will use Internet Protocol technology, a standard digital transmission over phone lines.

description: The young player spread the newspaper on a table and calmly tore out the article about his decreased playing time. He found a roll of athletic tape and affixed the article to the top of his locker stall.
