description: If CBS were truly devastated by the lower-then-ever ratings for Sunday night's Tony Awards broadcast, it could do something about it: the network has a yearly option to drop the show.

title: Bringing in Europe on Missile Defense
description: Washington and Moscow are the two main protagonists in the current debate about missile defense. But they are not the only ones. Many Europeans fear that American plans to build a limited national shield could unravel the treaty system that restrains the Russian and American nuclear arsenals and thereby unleash a dangerous new arms race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANES, MAX
description: MANES-Max, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan, June 5, 2000, aged 94. Max was born in tsarist Poland and came to this country in 1923. He was a hatter for most of his adult life, and was an active union member, organizer and retiree, receiving a Lifetime Achievement Award from UNITE! in 1995. He struggled for social justice throughout his life, working for civil rights, for welfare rights, and against the war in Vietnam. Upon reaching the age of 65, he and his wife, Isabel, organized Seniors for Adequate Social Security (SASS), to defend Social Security and Medicare against cutbacks and privatization. From that time, despite failing hearing and eyesight, he was active in senior citizen and health care issues, working with the Congress of Senior Citizens and the New York Network for Action on Medicare, among others. In 1981 Max was a delegate to the White House Conference on Aging. In 1992 he received the Senior Citizen of the Year Award from Canaan Senior Service Center. He is survived by his children, Joan and Michael, his daughter-inlaw, Kieu Manes, his son-in-law, Wes Phillips, his grandson, Sean Manes, his brother, Sidney, and his sister, Ruth Duckstein. He was a fighter to the end.

title: Library Gets Dance Collection
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Foundation Collection, an assemblage of dance documentation and memorabilia that goes back to the 1930's and includes some 6,000 hours of film and video material, is going to the New York Public Library, the library announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDEGGER, CECILIA

Devoted sister of the late Elena Ugarte. She was the daughter of the late Joaquin Elizalde who was the Philippine ambassador to the United States and Foreign Secretary. She will be deeply missed. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street Monday, June 12, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, June 13, 10AM at the Church of the Epiphany, 239 E. 21 St, NYC. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

Today they will pitch their business plans, each in a span of 10 minutes, each hoping to secure the start-up money to become an overnight Internet success, complete with initial public offering and a listing on Nasdaq.

title: FRANCE MOBILE-PHONE PERMITS
description: France will charge a total of $19 billion for four new mobile phone licenses and invite companies to show why they should provide the next generation of wireless Internet services. France's three existing cellular companies -- France Telecom, Cegetel's SFR unit and Bouygues Telecom -- have said they will bid. Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux, which has linked with Spain's largest phone company, Telefonica, and Deutsche Telekom have also expressed interest. Britain raised $33.6 billion selling five licenses in an auction last month. France resisted the auction process because of concern domestic companies might spend more than they could afford or lose to foreign rivals.

Directed by Alan Arkin and starring Matthew Broderick and Parker Posey, the play will have run for 56 regular performances and 37 previews.

title: How D-Day Was Won
description: By midnight on D-Day, June 6, 1944, Allied forces held a truly marginal amount of terrain on the European landmass -- a few Normandy beaches and headlands, some isolated pockets of French soil further inland, all of it scattered over a disjointed front some 55 miles long. But that was enough. What followed in the next few days and weeks was an industrial infusion of sorts, the landing of men and machines at a rate that had never been imagined before.

Of all the products that can be traded in such exchanges, the humble automobile tire, a circular piece of rubber compound with a tread, is near the top of many lists.

description: CacheFlow Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Springbank Networks for about $180 million in stock to add to its products that help speed delivery of Web pages. CacheFlow, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., designs caching devices, which reduce the time it takes to retrieve data from the Internet by storing frequently used information so it is more accessible to users. Companies use the products to try to ensure that their Web sites are available even at peak times, say, during online ticket sales. Springbank Networks, based in Palo Alto, Calif., researches and designs caching products.

title: G.M.'s New Chief Sticks to Company Plans
description: G. Richard Wagoner Jr., who became the youngest chief executive of General Motors last Thursday, said at the company's annual meeting here today that he planned to maintain the current business strategies and he expected that new truck models and an emphasis on Internet marketing would lift the G.M. market share.

title: European Domain Operators Refuse to Pay Bills
description: June 7, 2000

title: Cleaner Power in New York
description: The Pataki administration has given its blessing to a controversial gas-fired power plant just inland from the western shore of the Hudson River near the town of Athens in Green County, 120 miles north of New York City. The decision disappointed conservationists, who have fought the plant in part because it threatened to disfigure a landscape that had inspired some of the great paintings of the 19th-century Hudson River School. They argued, as did this page, that it should be located elsewhere.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN CLIMBS. The yen rose on expectations Japan's economic growth is picking up, raising speculation the Bank of Japan will lift interest rates. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.69 yen, down from 107.69 on Monday.

title: Burke Shoots 139
description: Mike Burke Jr. , the head pro at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J., shot a five-under-par 67 in the afternoon after a 72 in the morning for a 139 total that was the best score among the 21 players able to finish 36 holes in United States Open sectional qualifying at the Canoe Brook Country club in Summit, N.J., yesterday..

title: Unilever Says Purchase Fits Into Growth Strategy
description: Ever since it embarked on a new strategy in February to focus on its heavyweight brands like Ragu spaghetti sauce, Lipton tea and Dove soap, Unilever P.L.C., the British-Dutch consumer goods giant, has been on a buying spree in the United States, snapping up Ben & Jerry's Homemade and Slim-Fast Foods in a single day in April.

title: Microsoft Files Final Criticism of Government Breakup Plan
description: In a spirited final filing, Microsoft yesterday condemned the government's plan to split the company in two as ''a radical step'' that seemed to treat software as if it were pornography.

title: H.M.O.'s, Behaving Predictably
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain's Green Prince and His Family Differ on Altered Crops
description: Britain's royal family has fallen to feuding over a subject on which one would expect them to be solidly united: genetics.

description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Austin, Tex.

title: On the Web, As Elsewhere, Scientists Prove a Demanding Lot
description: LIFE science is a flourishing business on the Web. But the demands of scientists have made it an increasingly complicated business.

title: Three Roads in China: B2B, B2C and C2C
description: SOMEWHERE in the Turkish highlands this summer, a camper will bed for the night with a Chinese-made tent and sleeping bag, courtesy of a Turkish sporting goods wholesaler that bought hundreds over the Internet from a Chinese company earlier this year. It is the kind of transaction that many people hope is the beginning of a revolution for China's formidable economy.

title: Figuring Out Whether E-Mammon Can Fit in the Temple
description: ON the Web site of the East Liberty Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh, a visitor can see photographs of the historic church, check the schedule of potluck dinners, research the church's history, read recent sermons, connect with other members and even get directions to the church, known as the Cathedral of Hope.

title: Change Jobs Like Clothes? Click Here
description: LAST fall, Gage J. Fellows gamely tried to expand 1159.com, a ''best'' Web site about Denver nightclubs, into a national online travel and entertainment guide. To hire advertising sales representatives, he turned to a local recruiting agency and bought newspaper and radio advertisements. Applicants applied, all right; trouble was, most lacked basic computer skills.

title: San Jose Signs Sutter
description: The Sharks signed Coach Darryl Sutter to a new contract, five weeks after the team upset the St. Louis Blues in the first round of the playoffs.

title: Women's Global Views Examined by Survey
description: American women are more likely than men to frame their foreign policy concerns around global social issues like health, poverty and human rights, a new poll has found. The independent survey was released this week to coincide with a special General Assembly session on the progress of the world's women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBER, FREDA (''MRS. MURRAY'')
description: WERBER-Freda (''Mrs. Murray''). On June 4, 2000, in her 93rd year. Adoring and cherished wife for 70 years of Murray, z'l; loving and beloved mother of Judith Mandelbaum, z'l, and of Victor; devoted and dearly loved grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt, greataunt, cousin, and friend. A Very Special Lady. Contributions to Amit Women, 817 Broadway, NY 10003 will be deeply appreciated.

title: Sales? The Internet Will Handle That. Let's Talk Solutions.
description: CALL them ''vendors'' at your peril. Even references to working in ''product sales'' are met with tight-lipped grins.

title: The Backyard to the World
description: Florida mango season begins right now, and for mango lovers, even with the descent of inescapable heat and thick humidity, these are times of happy anticipation. Each month brings a new variety: the peach-flavored Van Dyke in mid-June; the luscious Kent in July; the huge, creamy Keitt in August.

title: INSIDE
description: SPECIAL TODAY

title: Where, Oh Where, Do All the Mangoes Go?
description: AS mango season heightens, chefs in New York are taking full advantage of the surfeit. Desserts are the obvious destination for sweet fruit, but mangoes also have such a complex, assertive flavor that they can hold their own next to chilies, herbs and other pungent ingredients.

title: A Crumber for Every Household
description: THE Internet has created a new shopping category: only on the Web. In other words, if you're in the market for some really oddball merchandise, don't head to the stores. Instead, sit at your terminal and click to a site like Tumbleweed Two Step (www.tumbleweedtwostep.com). Here you'll find tumbleweeds gathered from the Mojave Desert for $10 to $25 each, not including shipping.

title: It's a Whole New Lexicon
description: A FORMER professor of mine called the other day and asked if I'd speak to a group of graduating students about juggling life and work. It's been nearly 20 years since I was a graduating senior myself, and I certainly don't remember anyone talking to me then about life in the same sentence as work.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a wreath-laying ceremony in Kiev, Ukraine, where President Clinton honored people who died in a famine in 1932 and 1933, understated the number of victims. Western scholars put it at five million to eight million, not thousands.

title: F.B.I. Opens Investigation Of EBay Bids
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has opened an inquiry into whether several eBay users, including the Sacramento lawyer who almost sold a colorful abstract painting for $135,805 after putting it up for sale for 25 cents, committed fraud by bidding up the prices of one another's online auction offerings.

title: AT&T MOVE MEANS MILLIONS WILL FACE HIGHER PHONE BILL
description: With great fanfare last week, AT&T and the Federal Communications Commission announced that millions of telephone customers would see lower bills as the company passed on savings from a government-ordered reduction in the fees that long-distance companies pay to local phone companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCKS, MARGARET
description: LINCKS-Margaret. On June 4, 2000. Beloved wife of the late William. Aunt of Carol. Funeral Thursday, 9AM, from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Religious service Wednesday, 8PM. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. Visiting Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9.

title: If It's on Video, You Can Find It Someplace in Your Computer
description: PICK a movie, any movie -- not one with Julia Roberts but something out of the mainstream that you know you would have one chance in a thousand of finding in the average video store. Something like ''The Cranes Are Flying,'' Mikhail Kalatozov's acclaimed 1957 film about tangled love in wartime Russia. Or choose anything old or foreign, or obscure or rare -- D. W. Griffith's ''Female of the Species'' with Mary Pickford and Lillian Gish, ''The Communist Weapon of Allure'' or the western ''Rio Rattler.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Public Lives column yesterday about the Tony Awards misidentified the producers of the current revival of Cole Porter's ''Kiss Me, Kate'' in some copies. They were Roger Berlind and Roger Horchow, not Fran and Barry Weissler.

title: A Singer's Tormented Journey Into the Mind of George III
description: The American colonies were not all that George III lost during his long reign on the British throne. He also lost his mind. What this must have been like for him was the focus of an imaginative program that the conductor Jonathan Sheffer devised for the Eos Orchestra on Thursday night at the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

title: In Suffolk, Sheriff Pleads Not Guilty To Charges
description: The humiliated Suffolk County sheriff surrendered this morning in criminal court on a host of political corruption and abuse-of-power charges, including allegations that he and a former undersheriff pressured employees at the county jail into making campaign contributions in exchange for plum assignments.

title: Papers Reveal Bitter Battles Over Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: A House committee today disclosed scores of long-disputed internal government documents at the heart of a bitter debate over whether Attorney General Janet Reno should have sought an independent counsel to investigate accusations of Democratic fund-raising abuses in the 1996 campaign.

title: Food Industry Redraws the Borders in Its Landscape
description: With the $20.3 billion acquisition of Bestfoods by Unilever and the likely sale of Nabisco Holdings, the number of links in the food chain is dwindling.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: All's Fair in Love And Politics

title: Domino's Reaches Deal on Accusations of Bias
description: Moving to settle a string of racial bias complaints, Domino's Pizza said today that it had reached an agreement with the Justice Department to guarantee deliveries to all neighborhoods unless there was proven evidence that the area posed a threat to drivers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLONEY, (VALLONE), FRANK E., SR.
description: VALLONEY - (VALLONE) - Frank E., Sr. (fondly known as the Mayor of 231st St). On June 5, 2000, 80 years. Worked for Electro TypersUnion 100. Active for many years with the 50th Precinct-PAL and a member of the William E. Irwin American Legion Post. Beloved husband of the late Doris (nee Valvo), loving father of Joan Cybulski and the late Frank, Jr. Devoted grandfather of Donna Baraichi and Rose Cybulski. Great-grandfather of Rachael. Family will receive friends Wednesday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Bway at 232 St, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. John's Church (Kingsbridge) Thursday, 10:45 AM. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Yonkers, NY. Donations appreciated to the Rosary Hill Home 600 Linda Ave. Hawthorne, NY. 10532.

title: What's That Noise on the Internet? The Sound of Alliances Being Forged
description: EVERYONE'S a cousin in e-commerce.

title: Assessing the Online Exchanges: From One Expert, a Mixed Grade
description: THE bull market has not just been on the stock exchange but in exchanges themselves. The frenzy to find business-to-business uses of the Internet is prompting people to create online exchanges where companies will be able to trade everything from sheet steel to hotel sheets.

title: Space Mapping Affirms Theory Of the Universe
description: By measuring the distances to 100,000 galaxies scattered across billions of light-years of space, a robotic telescope in eastern Australia has produced the first detailed, large-scale map of the region of the universe inhabited by Earth and its own galaxy, the Milky Way.

title: Arabs and Israelis Will Reopen Talks in U.S.
description: Israeli and Palestinian negotiators will resume talks on a permanent peace accord next week in the Washington area, and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, will meet with President Clinton there next Wednesday, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today.

title: State Senate To Pass Bill On Hate Crime
description: After blocking it for more than a decade, the State Senate will pass a hate crimes bill on Wednesday, leaders said today, making it all but certain that some version of the bill will become law this year.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Dissent Fails to Halt Revamping of Russian Energy Concern
description: Anatoly Chubais, the head of Russia's national electric company, said today that he would go ahead with a plan to reorganize the company despite opposition from foreign investors who say the plan will destroy the value of their holdings and deprive them of control over assets.

title: Trinidad Fight Set
description: Felix Trinidad, armed with a new five-fight HBO deal, will fight Mamadou Thiam for the World Boxing Association superwelterweight title on July 22, with hopes of meeting Fernando Vargas on TVKO pay-per-view in the fall.

title: Mount Holyoke Drops SAT Requirement
description: At a time of increased reliance on standardized tests -- and mounting concern over their fairness -- Mount Holyoke College, the nation's oldest institution of higher learning for women, has decided to stop requiring applicants to submit College Board scores.

description: No ordinary mother, Rosie O'Donnell.

title: Under the Spell of the Turbine's Roar
description: THERE are many people who like speed, noise and power, who appreciate the serious engineering under the hood in the ''funny car'' events in drag racing and monster-truck rallies, who thrill to the whine of the turbines and flaming exhaust and the occasional guy-stuff explosions. But even among these power fans, Mark Nye and his home-built jet engines form a subculture.

title: Metro Business; New Rochester Flights
description: JetBlue Airways, a low-fare airline based in New York, has announced a schedule of flights between Rochester and Kennedy International Airport, with fares as low as $49 each way.

title: Open Sesame!
description: The Children's Television Workshop, which produces ''Sesame Street'' and ''Dragon Tales'' for PBS, is changing its name. From now on, it will be known as Sesame Workshop.

title: Putting a Face on Egypt, With Eyes That Almost Wink
description: STEINWAY STREET between 25th and 28th Avenues in Astoria, Queens, does not look, or smell, like a New York street. On warm evenings the air is flavored with sweet tobacco, as men, young and old, gather outside Middle Eastern cafes to smoke hookahs and drink tiny cups of thick coffee. Long robes and kaffiyehs are as common as Western dress. But perhaps the most unusual sight is the entrance to Mombar, a small Egyptian restaurant that opened about a month ago.

title: Shrinking World Means Big Gains for the Little Guys, Too
description: FOR directors of independent funeral homes, it means the chance to get the same discounts on coffins that the chains get. To the owner of five convenience stores in Mississippi, it opens doors to expansion. A private investigator near Cincinnati has found better prices on office supplies and T-shirts.

title: Stanley Cup Ratings
description: The Devils' 3-1 victory over Dallas in Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals Monday night generated a 3.3 Nielsen rating on ABC, the same rating Fox received last season for its second finals broadcast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHILL, HARRY
description: CHILL-Harry. Beloved husband of Muriel. Father of David and the late Jeffrey. Father-in-law of Andrea. Grandfather of Matthew. Brother of Ruth Liebross and the late Florence Baron.

description: On a late afternoon patrol in the foothills of Freetown, the young British soldiers went into a neighborhood of dilapidated clapboard houses, drawing greetings and waves from the locals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTENAU, GRACE, M.D.
description: ALTENAU-Grace, M.D. Her friends and colleagues at Lutheran Medical Center mourn the loss of Dr. Grace Altenau. Most recently an honorary member of our staff, Dr. Altenau began her affiliation with Lutheran Medical Center in 1936 when she served her internship and residency in Pediatrics at LMC. A graduate of NYU Medical School and board certified in Pediatrics for over 50 years, Dr. Altenau was one of the ''pioneer'' women physicians. She served on the faculty of SUNY Downstate and was Director of Pediatrics at Swedish Hospital. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family. Her friendship, loyalty and dedication will be missed by all of us. Steven W. Salvati, M.D., President Lutheran Medical Center Medical and Dental Staff Dominic J. Lodato, President Lutheran Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOLLUM, KATHARINE
description: McCOLLUM-Katharine. Died at home on Saturday, June 3, 2000, at age 76. She was a dear aunt to Judy and Peter Brase. Daughter of Peter C. Brase and Katharine Stark Brase of Little Neck. She served in the U.S. Army in World War II, graduated from Barnard College, and taught in the New York public school system. The Yankees have lost their most devoted fan.

title: Ordering Brides on the Web: Old Business, New Source
description: MEN with fantasies and women with hopes have always managed to connect. Now, sites that draw on those dreams have exploded across the Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESKY, KENNETH, M.D.
description: CHESKY-Kenneth, M.D. Prominent NY cardiologist on Monday, June 5, age 78. After graduating from Emory Medical School, Dr. Chesky served in the Navy for 3 years. When he returned from service he spent 2 years interning at the prestigious Boston City Hospital. Dr. Chesky moved to NY where he began his private practive through which he served and was affiliated with the staff and faculty of Mount Sinai Hospital for almost 40 years up to his retirement in 1986. Dr. Chesky is survived by his brother, Julius Chesky, nephews, Jeffrey, Norman and David Chesky, niece, Doralee Chesky and great nephew, Barry Chesky.

description: A group of investors headed by the Softbank Corporation has signed an agreement to buy the failed Nippon Credit Bank from the government.

description: When Dee Anderson Payne was hired to manage the Washington office of Bessemer Trust in 1985, it consisted, she later stated in court papers, of a folding chair, a telephone and an empty slate of clients for Bessemer's investment-advisory services.

Loving grandfather of Allison, Emily and Sarah Willis and Ashley and Katie Wray. Cherished son of Esther Willis. Dear brother of Guye, Uncle of Mike and Mark Willis and Karl and Mike Osis. title: Duck and Cover: Suburbs Treating Mosquito Like a New Public Enemy
description: Stephanie King's 5-year-old twins are no longer allowed to play outside at dusk in their neighborhood in Brewster, N.Y. Patricia Ahlqvist stretches mosquito netting over her 3-month-old's carriage each time she leaves her home in Tarrytown, N.Y., no matter the hour, and she forced her 4-year-old daughter's kiddie pool into early retirement.

title: Low-Key End on Both Sides As Corzine Gets Nomination
description: For those expecting caviar and lobster tails, the celebratory bash marking Jon S. Corzine's Senate primary victory tonight was something of a disappointment. Mr. Corzine, a Wall Street financier who poured a record amount of money into his campaign, did not hand out $100 bills at the door. There were no loot bags for departing revelers and the buffet tables were filled with fried shrimp, nachos and the usual assortment of catered finger foods.

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had ordered the police to review safety procedures on subway platforms after a rash of attempts to push people onto the tracks.

title: A Revolution in the Fish Industry That Hasn't Quite Taken Hold
description: THE business plan has not changed much in the nearly 30 years since Wright Gore Jr. began working for his family's shrimp supply company, Western Seafood. Shrimpers working the Gulf of Mexico sell their catch to Western, which processes and packages it. A broker for Western then solicits customers, mostly wholesalers from the Eastern seaboard, who, in turn, sell to restaurants, hotels and other retailers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIN, JOHN C.
description: OLIN-John C., 84, Professor Emeritus of History at Fordham University, died on June 6th in West Nyack, N.Y. Devoted husband of Marion A. description: Sybil Trent, a veteran of the golden age of radio and a star of the Saturday-morning children's radio show ''Let's Pretend,'' died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 73.

description: When President Clinton greeted the staff of the American Embassy in Lisbon last Thursday evening, he confessed that he had fallen in love with fado, the melancholic Portuguese music with words that yearn for a past that never was and may never be again.

description: Percent

So much has been accomplished, and there is still so far to go for the young dancers, students at the school, affiliated with New York City Ballet.

He was Alan Broadbent, not Mr. Haden.

title: A Promising Farm Tool, for Some
description: WHEN it was finally time to trade his old John Deere tractor for a newer model, Steve Lake, a 55-year-old farmer, went shopping on the Internet.

title: DEUTSCHE SELLS ALLIANZ SHARES
description: Europe's biggest bank, Deutsche Bank A.G., took another step toward unraveling itself from Germany Inc., selling about $2.4 billion worth of its shares in Allianz A.G., the Munich-based insurance conglomerate. Between them, Deutsche and Allianz have for decades been at the center of a web of German industrial cross-holdings that made the companies seem impregnable to outsiders. Deutsche sold some of its stake in Allianz last year, but the latest sale was bigger and the flood of shares knocked down the price of Allianz stock. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Corrections
description: The first article in this series, last Wednesday, about the chef Heston Blumenthal, misstated the temperature for a low-heat method of cooking lamb fillets. It is 80 to 85 degrees Celsius (about 176 to 185 degrees Fahrenheit), not 80 to 85 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, BRINK, ANNETTE
description: ROSS-BRINK-Annette, formerly of Manhasset, NY & Delray Beach, FL, passed away on June 6th, 2000. Pre-deceased by Alfred J. Ross and Frederick Brink. Loving mother of Richard (Anne), Alfred (Deirdre), Peter (Barbara), David, MaryLouise Irvine (Pat) and Donald (Katherine) and 16 grandchildren and 9 great-grandchildren. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Thursday Evening from 6-9pm. Funeral Mass on Friday 9:45am at St. Mary's RC Church, with interment to follow in Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY

title: With Special E-Fares, Online Bookings Soar
description: MOST United States airlines began selling tickets over the Internet in 1996, but it was a halfhearted effort because many airline officials viewed it as little more than the latest electronic plaything. Now the airlines are making up for lost time, going after potential passengers by adding more Web sites as well as forming partnerships with online retailers better known for selling electronic products or sporting goods than airline tickets.

title: Creating Ways to Cut the Delivery Time From Mouse to House
description: THE ordering may be express, but the delivery often seems Pony Express. That is shaping up as a central issue in the highly competitive world of online shopping, and it is spawning creative solutions for getting the goods to customers more quickly.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a federal judge's withdrawal from the coming trial of Wen Ho Lee, the scientist accused of mishandling nuclear weapons secrets, misstated the date of a hearing on defense motions for admission of classified information. It is next Monday; the hearing was not held yesterday.

title: Old-School Trainer Finds Winning Is Not Old Hat
description: It is not remotely related to Woody Stephens's five straight victories in the Belmont Stakes. In fact, it is not even a streak of any size yet. But Scotty Schulhofer is the only trainer who can make it two straight in the Belmont this Saturday, and he took the same rather unconventional route to get there both times. Going back a little farther, he would win the race for the third time in eight years if his 3-year-old colt Postponed turns the trick.

title: This Working Mom Played Bass for the Best of Them
description: DURING the late 1950's and all through the 60's in the hit factories of Los Angeles, where rock 'n' roll history was being made, giants strode into the recording studios and ruled the baby boomers' airwaves.

title: Indonesian Court Rules Time Magazine Did Not Libel Suharto
description: Dealing another blow to Indonesia's embattled former leader, Suharto, a court ruled today that Time magazine did not libel him in an article that said Mr. Suharto and his family had amassed a $15 billion fortune in his three decades in power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ROSE
description: SCHWARTZ-Rose, wife of David H. Schwartz and mother of Elliot and Judy Schwartz; Susan and Daniel Sklarin; and Donna and Robert Aschheim; sister of Ruth Weissberg; and Dovid Schisgal (Israel) passed away on June 5, 2000. She is also survived and mourned by her grandchildren, Rachel and Harris Lukashok and Jennifer Schwartz; Yigal, Tamara and Ely Sklarin; Meir, Cara, and Rebecca Aschheim. The employees and staff of ArtScroll Printing Corporation express their profound sympathy to the entire family on the passing of this exceptional woman, mother of our president, Elliot Schwartz. She was a true Woman of Valor and was beloved by all who came into contact with her. Her deeds of kindness were legendary and she leaves a deep void. May the Everpresent comfort the family among all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Employees and Staff of ArtScroll Printing Corporation

title: Banks Are Slow to Move Online, but So Are Their Customers
description: IN the early rounds of the online banking competition, the surprising outcome is that the big commercial banks have not been beaten to the punch by nimbler young challengers.

title: Rocker and Wohlers Pass in Night
description: The baseball paths of John Rocker and Mark Wohlers first crossed in May 1998. Wohlers, the Atlanta Braves' closer, went on the disabled list, and Rocker was recalled from Richmond to replace him on the roster. Three weeks later, Wohlers rejoined the Braves, Rocker remained and the two briefly were teammates. Two years later, they are opponents, pitching in the International League.

title: Reckonings; A Rent Affair
description: Economists who have ventured into the alleged real world often quote Princeton's Alan Blinder, who has formulated what he calls ''Murphy's Law of economic policy'': ''Economists have the least influence on policy where they know the most and are most agreed; they have the most influence on policy where they know the least and disagree most vehemently.'' It's flip and cynical, but it's true.

title: Reluctant Underwear Shopper Finds a Method That Clicks
description: I DON'T know about you, but I don't like to think much about underwear. I always found it disturbing when people said you had to have nice underthings on every day, in case you were hit by a bus and had to be taken to a hospital, where an utter stranger might witness your tattered skivvies.

title: The Net Is Calling Them Home, but Many More Are Needed
description: WHEN Xin Ye returned to Beijing after a 14-year absence to take a senior position at one of China's most popular Internet portals, Sohu, he left behind his wife, two daughters, a California lifestyle and a job prospect at a Silicon Valley start-up.

title: THE BOSS; Always Trying Harder
description: I was born in Trinidad, and my family migrated to Toronto when I was a baby. Soon afterward, my father divorced my mother, leaving her to care for my sister and me with welfare checks and her earnings as a part-time nurse. At 13, I started cleaning classrooms at my school to earn my own allowance.

description: Surrounded by a turquoise sea, lush emerald hills and the tropical trade winds that blow across their island nation, Fijians like to say their serenity matches the scenery.

title: Bobby Big Fish Gets Many Bites
description: Bobby Lienau, Bobby Big Fish to his friends, says more money will be spent this year sponsoring sport fishing than ever before. ''I think fishing is going nowhere but up,'' he said in a telephone interview.

title: HOSTILE OFFER EXTENDED
description: The Canadian oil and gas company Petrobank Energy and Resources Ltd. extended its hostile bid for Ranger Oil Ltd. by two weeks, to June 19, and said it was exploring ways to improve the terms of its $664 million offer. Petrobank said it would sell Ranger natural gas properties to the Alberta Energy Company for $177 million upon completion of the acquisition. In April, Ranger rejected Petrobank's offer as inadequate. Petrobank, Ranger and Alberta Energy are all based in Calgary, Alberta.

description: Portals Struggle to Convert Browsers to Shoppers

The agreement, with the LanPing Nonferrous Metals Company, is the first commercial venture of the Chinese government with a foreign mining company. title: THE CHEF; Wylie Dufresne

And rosemary and lamb are a natural combo. So, no single element in my lamb with fruit dressing is unusual, but the combination is: tender meat with sweet fruit, bitter favas, licorice-like fennel and piney rosemary.

title: CIRCUIT CITY SHARES PLUMMET ON PROFIT WARNING
description: Shares of Circuit City Group dove 24 percent yesterday after the company, the nation's second-largest retailer of appliances and consumer electronics, said that it expected lower profit margins and that earnings would fall short of analysts' expectations by about 4 cents a share for the first quarter. The company's stock fell $12.50 a share, to $39.625. The company, which ranks behind Best Buy in sales, said its consumer electronics business would post first-quarter earnings of about 23 cents a share.

title: Eminem Enters 'N Sync Turf
description: On his second album, ''The Marshall Mathers LP,'' the rapper Eminem makes fun of the boy band 'N Sync in at least four separate songs. But last week he entered the same pop league as 'N Sync when his second album sold more copies in its first week of release than any other act, with the sole exception of 'N Sync. ''The Marshall Mathers LP'' (Aftermath/Interscope) sold more than 1.7 million copies; 'N Sync moved 2.4 million copies of ''No Strings Attached'' when it was released in March, according to the Hartsdale, N.Y., music-tracking company Soundscan, which has been compiling the Billboard pop charts since 1991.

title: Designers Tiptoeing Onto the Internet, Clad Mostly in Accessories
description: DESIGNER fashion, unlike books or CD's, has not been an easy sell on the Web. For starters, there is the sizing and fit challenge -- how do you persuade consumers to buy high-end clothing without trying it on? There is the touch-and-feel problem -- how do you convey the look and texture of new fabrics and materials? Then there are limitations to graphic presentations, conflicts about distributing products and, beyond that, intangible issues like, how do you sell something as ephemeral as style?

title: WELCH ALLYN TO ACQUIRE PSC FOR $103 MILLION
description: PSC Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Hand Held Products, an affiliate of Welch Allyn Data Collection, for $8.45 a share in cash, a total of $103.1 million, in a deal that would combine two makers of bar-code scanning equipment. PSC's stock soared 32 percent, rising $1.9375 a share, to $8, in Nasdaq trading. PSC, which is based in Webster, N.Y., outside Rochester, had sales of $231.3 million last year. Welch Allyn Data Collection is owned by Welch Allyn Inc., which is based in Skaneateles Falls, N.Y., and is a privately held maker of medical testing devices.

title: TALKS ON DUTCH CABLE UNIT
description: A Dutch cable television company owned by France Telecom S.A., Casema, said it was in talks to buy the cable unit of Essent N.V., the biggest Dutch power supplier. Casema could sell shares, join with a United States cable company or get help from France Telecom to finance the purchase, which could cost about 5.4 billion guilders ($2.3 billion), the company said. The purchase would double Casema's share of the Dutch cable market to 42 percent and allow it to overtake United Pan-Europe Communications N.V. as the biggest Dutch provider.

title: The New Death Penalty Politics
description: The advent of modern DNA technology that can often prove with certainty the guilt or innocence of people convicted of serious crimes has heightened public concern about the fallibility of the criminal justice system, causing a dramatic shift in the nation's debate over capital punishment. Eight years ago Bill Clinton, then the governor of Arkansas, flew home in the midst of his presidential campaign to approve the execution of a man so brain-damaged that he saved the dessert from his final meal to eat later. It was considered good politics at that time to impose the maximum penalty on criminals. Last week, reflecting the new dynamic, Gov. George W. Bush postponed the execution of a convicted killer in Texas named Ricky Nolen McGinn to allow DNA testing the death-row inmate contends will establish his innocence.

title: Dim Sum Without Dialing
description: THE one major hassle in making pot-stickers is the dough. All it takes is flour and water, and you can knead it in a food processor, but there's a long resting period followed by the ultimate in tedium: rolling out several dozen two-inch circles, each taking a couple of minutes. Once you're finished you still face a half-hour or more of active labor to fill and cook them.

title: BANK NAMED AS SUSPECT
description: A long-simmering bank scandal in Indonesia has ensnared the country's top central banker. The government named the governor of Bank Indonesia, Syahril Sabirin, as a suspect in the Bank Bali affair. Mr. Sabirin was said to have attended meetings during which officials pressed executives at Bank Bali to funnel money into a company linked to the former ruling party in return for favorable treatment. Mr. Sabirin has denied wrongdoing. Setting up a showdown with Indonesia's president, Abdurrahman Wahid, Mr. Sabirin rejected Mr. Wahid's calls for his resignation. Mark Landler

title: G.E. AND CISCO FORM JOINT INTERNET VENTURE
description: The General Electric Company and Cisco Systems announced yesterday that they would form a joint venture, called GE Cisco Industrial Networks, to help manufacturers use Internet technology to ease communications between their factories and their offices. The venture, which will be based in Charlottesville, Va., will be led by a G.E. executive. It will offer a mix of services, including assessing customers' existing data systems, designing new ones around Internet technology, providing software and hardware, and managing the entire data system through outsourcing. G.E. said it expected the venture to realize $100 million in sales in three to five years. Claudia H. Deutsch

title: Our Towns; Going Forth, Once Again, As a Crusader

His was never the politics of sunny promises and pleasantries, and some political forecasters even imagined that bad skies were good news for the defeated governor's attempted comeback. After 16 campaigns in 31 years, Florio loyalists had weathered much worse.

title: A Prickly Rose Who Loved A Starry Prince; A Voice From the Past Upsets The Saint-Exupery Legend
description: Pioneering aviator, best-selling writer and romantic idol, Antoine de Saint-Exupery enjoyed a celebrity in his lifetime that was surpassed only by his fame after death. With his mysterious disappearance during a military reconnaissance flight over occupied France on July 31, 1944, and then the worldwide success of his final book, ''The Little Prince,'' he assumed the status of myth, one that has kept the French in thrall ever since.

title: VARIAN PLANS TO BUY IMPAC FOR ABOUT $135 MILLION
description: Varian Medical Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Impac Medical Systems Inc. for about $135 million in stock, joining Impac's medical information systems with Varian's equipment for treating cancer with radiation. Varian will issue about 3 million common shares and 300,000 options in return for all of Impac's common shares, preferred shares and options. Impac, based in Mountain View, Calif., expects sales of about $28 million for the fiscal year ending on Sept. 29. Shares of Varian, based in Palo Alto, Calif., fell 75 cents, to $41.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Crammed with colorful graphics and plain-talking superheroes speaking in bursts of text, comic books looked like Web sites in search of a Web.

title: Burke Qualifies For Open
description: Mike Burke Jr., the head pro at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J., will compete in his sixth United States Open next week at Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: A Rivalry Renewed For Bird and Johnson
description: Larry Bird did not want to create a fuss. He knew he was coming back to L.A. to face the Lakers in the playoffs for the first time since 1987, and he knew at some point this evening he and his rival in time, Magic Johnson, would embrace and share a nostalgic moment of trash talk.

title: Sweet Dreams in Narrow Spaces
description: WITH a little ingenuity, flexibility and the proper bed, no space is too small to be a guest bedroom. The right bed can be anything from a traditional army-style cot that stows in its own carry bag to a highly designed chrome chaise with a shiny nylon sleeping bag attached. Whether it's in-laws or friends who arrive for the weekend, any nook or corner can become host to a comfortable bed.

title: Lawsuit Accuses Fashion House of Running Sweatshops
description: A class-action lawsuit filed yesterday accuses one of New York's best-known fashion houses, Donna Karan, of running sweatshops that cheated workers out of millions of dollars in overtime pay.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM RISES. Palladium rose 3 percent, extending a two-week rally, on signs of limited supplies for automakers and other users. In New York, palladium for September delivery rose $18.85, to $640 an ounce.

title: KOREA TO MERGE TROUBLED BANKS
description: To speed up reforms within its troubled financial industry, the South Korean government plans to merge ailing banks that have been kept afloat with injections of taxpayers' money, the Financial Supervisory Commission said. ''Beginning in July, we will guide banks to restructure themselves, based on whether or not they have received public funds,'' said Jin Dong Soo, an official at the commission. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: O'Neal Ruins Pacers' Plans: He Runs Free In a Solo Show
description: Larry Bird decided before Game 1 that trying to stop Shaquille O'Neal outright was useless. So Bird, the coach of the Indiana Pacers, would concede points to O'Neal, the game's most awesome physical presence, and make the other Los Angeles Lakers beat his team -- a strategy employed often against Michael Jordan in the 1990's.

Playing himself, in a sly spoof of ''behind the scenes'' documentaries, he is the foil for Tom Crooze, his overeager stunt double, whom Ben Stiller portrays astutely, with grasping self-importance.

description: State Education Commissioner Richard P. Mills released a proposal yesterday intended to improve academic standards at vocational schools and make them attractive to students who would not otherwise go to four-year colleges.

description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright told Syrian and Egyptian officials today that the Clinton administration was willing to push once more for peace talks between Damascus and Israel, but that its main goal in its remaining months in office was a settlement between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: After a Rout, Still Fighting
description: With his final order yesterday in the Microsoft antitrust case, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said yes to the government one more time. He has agreed with the government, almost without qualification, on the facts of the case, on the law and now on the harsh remedy of splitting the company in two.

title: Some experts of spin offer advice to Microsoft on how to reach consumers' hearts and minds.
description: AS the Microsoft Corporation assesses the implications of the breakup ordered yesterday by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, the advice from professional communicators on how the company ought to handle the consequences is being offered almost as quickly as the ''I Love You'' computer worm infested e-mail in-boxes.

title: Budget Offers Perks to Boroughs Other Than Manhattan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council leaders joked this week about what to call them: the ''outer boroughs'' or the ''other boroughs''? But the reason for the bantering was no joke: the $37.6 billion budget approved this week includes an unusually large share of money and other perks for sections of the city outside Manhattan.

title: At Failing E-Stores It's Vulture Beware
description: I IMAGINE that some shoppers react sympathetically when a store goes out of business. My mother, for instance, still feels guilty about Bonwit Teller and wonders if her decision not to buy a certain red wool coat there one winter somehow contributed to the department store's demise. I agree it was a mistake to pass up the coat, because it looked so good with her hair.

description: When discussing last year's fight with Felix Trinidad, Oscar De La Hoya likes to refer to his defeat as that decision.

description: Two days after Indonesia's central bank governor was named as a suspect in a financial scandal, he and the government squared off today in a bitter showdown that could erode what little confidence investors have in this fragile country.

title: Yankees' New Weapon, The Stolen Base, Works
description: With his peripheral vision, Carl Pavano could see Yankees scurrying from corner to corner, but he could not catch them. The bases were infested with base-stealers, and the Montreal pitcher tried, stepping off the pitching rubber and threatening them. Sometimes he just held the ball and hoped they'd stop.

title: New Cable Channel Halts Production of 2 Programs
description: The new cable channel Oxygen announced yesterday that it was suspending production on two shows and would be laying off about 12 people, in a move that one executive said was a result of the programs' exceeding their production budgets.

description: GRAFF-Joseph. Jonathan Hall Condominium records with great sorrow the passing of our loyal friend and neighbor.

title: Living Large In Little Apple
description: A LOT of New Yorkers live in small spaces, some smaller than others. My own, for example, measures 250 square feet as the crow walks. Over time, I've become obsessed with making the most of it, getting up at odd hours to stack file cabinets and weed my belongings, even removing doors from hinges. Today, within easy reach, I also have a sofa, a desk, two chairs, three bureaus and an 18-pound cat named Gus, who takes up more than his fair share of the bed.

title: Thousands Compete at Once Across a Well-Wired World
description: There were two clear winners in the World Bridge Federation's Worldwide Bridge Contest last week, and many probable ones. In the first session, on Friday, 7,488 pairs played in 61 countries. In the second session, on Saturday, 5,304 pairs played in 48 countries.

title: 8 Companies Create an Internet Market for Supplies
description: Nortel Networks, I.B.M., Matsushita Electric Industrial and five other companies announced an Internet market for computer and telecommunications products today that they said could cut their supply costs by as much as 15 percent.

title: Fiji's Bigotry Of Domain
description: ''They are trying to steal our land.'' Such is the accusation made by a gang of usurpers against Fiji's Indian community in general and the deposed Indian-led government, whose ministers it now holds hostage, in particular. By one of the bitter ironies of the age of migration, the insistence of the gang's leader, the failed businessman George Speight, on the basic cultural importance of land is very easy for people of Indian origin to grasp. However, he gives the land what might be called racial characteristics, plainly assuming that it is, in its very nature, ethnically Fijian -- and so tips over into bigotry and folly.

title: Egyptian At Center On Rights Of Women
description: Five years after thousands of women converged on Beijing to draft what amounted to a bill of rights for women, government officials and women's organizations are huddled again in conference halls here, trying to turn those promises into concrete prescriptions for action.

title: 3 Are Shot in Restaurant
description: Three people were shot yesterday in a Brooklyn restaurant after an argument on the sidewalk spilled inside, the police said.

title: Reading Scores Improve Citywide; Still, Only 41% Meet Standards
description: Bolstering the encouraging results of recent state tests, the Board of Education reported yesterday that students in New York City performed significantly better this year on a citywide reading test. Still, only 40.8 percent met the rigorous new curriculum standards on which they were being tested, compared with 35.7 percent last year.

title: Frankel Says His Horse Is a Natural
description: Late last summer, when Juddmonte Farms' manager, Garrett O'Rourke, delivered the breeding operation's 2-year-olds to the trainer Bobby Frankel, he told Frankel that the dark brown son of A. P. Indy was his Kentucky Derby horse. The Brooklyn-born Frankel, a headstrong sort, was not so sure.

title: Leaders From Other Professions Reshape America's Schools, From Top to Bottom
description: Alan D. Bersin, superintendent of the San Diego schools, is talking tough with 35 student teachers: ''Our reading levels, by and large, are abysmal,'' he tells them. The dropout rate is huge, he says, and he has laid off 600 paraprofessionals because ''they have added virtually nothing to student achievement.''

title: Noble Ware With a Noble Name
description: In 1996, the siblings Mathilde and Alexandre Carron used a technique learned from their sculptor father to create quirky, mysterious-looking Astier de Villatte glazed earthenware with two friends. (Astier de Villatte was the Carrons' mother's noble family name.) Though mostly white, no two plates, bowls, pitchers or candlesticks are exactly the same. The line, including the $65 cup and saucer, above, is available in New York at ABC Carpet & Home, or from the company: 011-33-1-43-45-72-72.

title: Turmoil in Israel
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak's government was thrown into tumult when Parliament approved a preliminary bill to disperse and head toward new elections. The bill requires three more hearings to become law. But it could break up the ruling coalition and create a chaotic interlude at a diplomatically inopportune moment.

title: Williams's Career With Nets Is in Doubt
description: The smile, the jokes and the charitable spirit were all there, but beneath the joyous facade it was easy to see that Jayson Williams was troubled. While announcing at Riverfront Stadium today that his private foundation will hold a benefit softball game July 29, Williams, the Nets' fun-loving center, was struggling with the probability that his National Basketball Association career is over.

title: Apocalyptic Potboiler Is Publisher's Dream
description: The latest thriller in a hugely popular Christian fundamentalist series about the Apocalypse will enter the New York Times fiction best-seller list at No. 1 on Sunday, an unparalleled achievement for an evangelical novel.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about a debate in Borough Park, Brooklyn, over an eruv, a symbolic enclosure within which Orthodox Jews may carry objects without violating a Sabbath ban, misidentified a man in a cherry picker stringing a fishing line to expand the area. He asked not to be identified and was not Rabbi Moshe Unsdorfer, who favors the eruv.

title: A New Dog in Town, Steel and Sprouting
description: When it comes to public sculpture, Jeff Koons's giant topiaryesque ''Puppy'' is a rarity, a guaranteed crowd-pleaser with serious art credentials. A 1992 work, it has been seen in Germany, Spain and Australia and is now stationed in front of 30 Rockefeller Center until Sept. 5. Irresistibly cute, 43 feet high and quilted with flowers, it occupies the spot traditionally reserved for New York's most famous Christmas tree and easily holds down this patch of unusually fetishized turf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRGANG, FRANCES
description: IRGANG-Frances. On June 7, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Carl, loving mother of Jay and Joyce. Cherished grandmother of Mark (Orli). Great grandmother to Caren, Evan and Jordan. Dear sister of the late Charles and Leo Presser. Services Thursday, 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: LOVE BUG CHARGES DISMISSED
description: Citing lack of evidence, Philippine prosecutors dropped charges against a 23-year-old bank employee in connection with the destructive computer program that swept the Internet in self-propagating ''I Love You'' e-mail messages last month. Reonel Ramones, who lived in the apartment where investigators suspected the program originated, had been charged under a law prohibiting unauthorized use of passwords for credit cards or bank accounts. But it was another resident of the apartment, Onel de Guzman, 21, who said he might have inadvertently released the program, commonly called a virus or worm. Mr. de Guzman has not been charged. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: New Agency Posts For the Americas
description: Two agencies are creating posts to oversee operations in North America and Latin America.

title: F.D.A. Adds Hurdles in Approval of Abortion Pill
description: The long-running effort to bring the French abortion pill to women in this country has encountered yet another obstacle: a suggestion by the Food and Drug Administration that it may place tight restrictions on how the drug, RU-486, is distributed and who can prescribe it.

title: NEW SINGAPORE NEWSPAPERS
description: The company that publishes Singapore's largest English daily, Singapore Press Holdings, said it would start a second newspaper in September to take on new rivals as its industry monopoly ends. Singapore Press Holdings, which publishes The Straits Times and nine other newspapers in four languages, said the proposed paper would be called Streets. The company also plans to start another daily, called Project Eyeball, aimed at young professionals. Singapore said it would give the government-owned broadcaster, the Media Corporation of Singapore, a newspaper license for a free paper with a circulation of 200,000 to be distributed on public transportation.

title: When Mohammed Can't Get to the Museum
description: I WAS lucky enough to grow up in New York City, just a few blocks from Museum Mile. My art history classes included weekly visits to the Metropolitan Museum of Art; I learned about dinosaurs at the American Museum of Natural History. But while nothing can replace the experience of seeing a masterpiece up close, the Web means that museum education is no longer geographically restricted. Some of the world's most remarkable institutions have Web sites specifically designed for children and schools.

title: Grand Gestures in Tiny Spaces
description: IN the most ingenious small Manhattan apartments, designers and their clients become illusionists. They make beds disappear, tables double in height and televisions spin between two rooms at once.

title: Ex-Gov. Romer Embraces New Mission: Running Los Angeles Schools
description: Roy Romer is no stranger to politics. As governor of Colorado for 12 years, and then general chairman of the Democratic National Committee for two years, he has seen his share of infighting, bureaucracy and blood feuds.

title: Montana Voters Pick Candidates for Governor and Senate
description: With Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana barred by law from seeking a third consecutive term, his lieutenant governor, Judy Martz, and State Auditor Mark O'Keefe had little trouble winning their gubernatorial primaries on Tuesday to face each other in the November general election.

title: Shhhhhh: Alfonzo Is Stirring The Mets
description: For Edgardo Alfonzo, it was another typical game last night. He homered in the first inning to drive in the Mets' first run, tripled in the sixth to score the go-ahead run -- and somehow did nothing to draw attention to himself in an 11-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Prosecutors Describe Overdrafts by Pirro
description: Seeking to convince jurors that Albert J. Pirro Jr. deliberately tried to evade taxes, an agent for the Internal Revenue Service said today that Mr. Pirro's corporate accounts were overdrawn by up to $37,500 to pay for personal items, even though he had access to thousands of dollars in his personal account.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Judge Orders Breakup Of Microsoft Into 2 Units

title: Neither Notebook Nor Palm
description: SOMEHOW the niche between a palm-size organizer and a notebook has never been successfully colonized. Big companies are about to withdraw their bigger handheld entries from the market. I.B.M. withdrew months ago, and Hewlett-Packard will stop production of its larger handheld this month, although it will continue to produce its tiny handheld with non-touch-type keyboard, which has been selling well.

title: 2 Charged in $1.5 Million Mail Theft Scheme
description: A young couple used mail pilfered from thousands of homes in Queens and Long Island neighborhoods to steal more than $1.5 million from banks and credit card companies, prosecutors said yesterday. They called the crime one of the most brazen and methodical cases of identity theft they had seen.

title: A 'Guy With the Gold' Is Still Making Rules
description: IF you cut my veins, you'll get cement!'' booms Samuel J. LeFrak, the ubiquitous metropolitan builder, urban visionary (hey, no smirking; he's got knighthoods and honorary doctorates on deluxe business cards announcing him as Sir Samuel), and in his spare time, sugar daddy to the arts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, DEBORAH, M.
description: KING-Deborah, M. Died June 3 in E. Hampton. Cherished sister of Dorothy W. King, dearly loved cousin of Suzanne Gatehouse, beloved niece of Charles C. Bingham, Esq., and Father John K. Bingham, S.J.; aunt, cousin, friend and inspiration to all of her family, and countless friends, who adored her. Generous in her love for people and the earth, Debbie believed deeply in serving, and lived with abounding spirit. On Thursday, June 8, we will gather to celebrate Debbie with lunch at her home, 7 Hodder Avenue, the Springs, E. Hampton, from 12-3 PM, with viewing from 3-5 PM at the Williams Funeral Home, 99 Newtown Lane, E. Hampton, 631324-0433. In lieu of sending flowers, you may remember Debbie with a flowering perennial or evergreen in your garden or by making a donation to East Hampton Trails Preservation Society, PO Box 2144, Amagansett, NY 11930

title: Interest Is Added To Settlement
description: United States District Judge Victor Marrero ordered the Bear Stearns Companies to pay a Canadian client $52.5 million in interest on top of a Manhattan federal jury's $111.5 million award for losses suffered in an account handled by the securities firm in 1995 on currency future contracts.

title: Through Rose-Colored Glass
description: Paris shopfronts are becoming more design conscious. Future Systems, the avant-garde British architecture firm, laminated plastic film onto glass to add a rosy glow to the 19th-century stone facade of the recently opened Comme des Garcons perfume shop, at 23 Place du Marche-St.-Honore.

title: A Hot Dining Spot (With Art in the Basement)
description: Cross new design and stylish Parisians and what do you get? George, the latest restaurant opened by the Costes (pronounced coast) brothers, Jean-Louis and Gilbert. With seven places, they are building a see-and-be-seen empire in Paris. In a sure sign they've caught on, CD's of their D.J.'s ambient music are definite must-haves.

title: No, I'm Not Talking to You
description: IT was Thursday at rush hour on the street in front of Grand Central Terminal, and it was a cell phone circus.

title: Radio-Frequency Tags Could Pierce Some of the Fog of War
description: THE same kinds of tags that let cars move quickly past tollbooths may soon help the armed forces keep track of their vehicles, weapons and people.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the primary in New Jersey referred incorrectly to the rarity of a United States Senate race there without an incumbent. Bill Bradley chose not to seek re-election in 1996; Senator Frank R. Lautenberg's decision last year to step down at the end of his term was not the first such move in 18 years.

title: JamCam 3.0 and Jam-It For Pictures and Sound
description: As every parent finds out, children will abandon even the most elaborate and expensive toys to play with one of the following: an old camera, a tape recorder and the box the elaborate and expensive toy came in.

title: AN OLIVETTI MOVE ON BOND INTEREST
description: In an attempt to control its future borrowing costs, Olivetti plans to link the interest on 18 billion euros ($17 billion) of existing debt to credit ratings -- paying more if the ratings fall and less if they recover. Olivetti, which controls Telecom Italia through its Tecnost unit, would be the first borrower to link all of its existing bonds to credit ratings. They also would be the only bonds adjustable in both directions.

title: Speaking Volumes
description: The architect Peter Merino is one New Yorker snapping up vases by Marius Fernandez, a Marseilles artist. A 20-inch one is about $2,200; yard-high vases, above, are about $4,800, at Galerie Aittouares, 2 rue des Beaux-Arts; 011-33-1-40-51-87-46.

title: AIR CANADA STRIKE POSSIBLE
description: A strike by 2,200 pilots for Air Canada, which handles 80 percent of Canada's airline traffic, is possible by mid-June, after the pilot union's rejection of what the company called its final offer. But the union, the Air Canada Pilots Association, has not taken a strike vote, and a mediator assigned by the national government is still trying to bring the two sides to an agreement. The pilots, who have been without a contract since April 1, are seeking higher wages and pension benefits, and job protection during the integration of Air Canada with Canadian Airlines. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: IBM, Nortel, Toshiba, Others to Start Tech B-to-B Marketplace
description: June 7, 2000

title: INC.UBATOR CAPITAL BUYS THEMEWARE FOR $135 MILLION
description: Inc.ubator Capital Inc., a specialized Internet holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the ThemeWare Corporation, an Internet service provider, for $135 million in stock. Inc.ubator said it would also invest $5 million in cash in the next 12 months in ThemeWare, which is based in Newport Beach, Calif. In addition to providing Internet services for small-business owners, ThemeWare's key product is the Internet Tool Box, a multimedia kit that teaches the basics of access and use of the Internet. Shares of Inc.ubator, formerly known as Shanecy Inc., fell 37.5 cents, to $3.50 each, in trading over the counter.

title: Money Well Spent
description: In politics, as in life, money talks, and that makes Jon Corzine positively eloquent. To acquire New Jersey's Democratic nomination for the Senate, the former Wall Street whiz spent a record $32 million, give or take, but who's counting? Many have lamented this spending; a seat in Congress, they say, should not be bought. But was Mr. Corzine wrong to spend his millions? No, and here's why.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKMYER, ARNOLD A.

title: NATION'S LARGEST PREPAID PHONE CARD SUPPLIER IS SOLD
description: Star Telecommunications Inc. agreed yesterday to sell PT-1 Communications Inc., the nation's largest supplier of prepaid phone cards, to a subsidiary of the Counsel Corporation of Toronto, for $150 million. Counsel, which invests in pharmaceutical and technology companies, said the purchase of PT-1 provides it with a communications network in the United States. PT-1 has network switching operations in 30 major cities in the United States. Star Telecommunications, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., provides long-distance phone and Internet services worldwide. Star Telecommunications' stock rose 90.62 cents, to $3.34375 each, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KONIGSBERG, NATALIE
description: KONIGSBERG-Natalie. It's been one year without you. Your warmth, kindness and humor will live on forever. We miss you and love you. Fran, Marty, Jane, Don, Roz and Bob, Grandchildren and GreatGrandchildren

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MARY THORNTON
description: SMITH-Mary Thornton, 93, June 3 at home. At The Brearley School in NYC she acted as secretary and assistant to the head of the lower school for 48 years. She took an active interest in protecting the environment through many conservation organizations and was an advocate for endangered species. She is survived by a large family and devoted friends.

title: Gen. Thomas Kelly, 67, Dies; Pentagon Voice in Gulf War
description: Lt. Gen. Thomas W. Kelly, who was the voice and face of the Army for millions of Americans in daily news briefings on the Persian Gulf war, died on Tuesday at his home in Clifton, Va. He was 67.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The euro rose against the dollar on expectations the European Central Bank will raise interest rates today. In New York, the euro settled at 96.15 cents, up from 95.47 cents on Tuesday.

description: Holding his fingers just a fraction of an inch apart, David Duval described today how close he feels to playing his best golf.

title: Government of Israel Thrown Into Tumult by Vote in Parliament to Call New Elections
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak's government was thrown into tumult today when Parliament, by a substantial margin, approved a preliminary bill to disperse and head toward new elections.

title: Camcorders Allow a Steady Shot, Even Without a Steady Hand
description: ALTHOUGH jittery, frenetic images were the height of film artistry in the early 90's, it isn't a good technique for immortalizing your 10-year-old's first soccer goal on videotape. And therein lies a problem. As camcorders have become smaller and lighter, with greater zoom capabilities, they have magnified the operator's tiniest tremors. Even breathing can result in a jerky image.

title: Effort to Oust Republican Falls Short, But Not Far
description: Late Tuesday night, when she finally heard she had squeaked by her opponent in a hard-fought Republican primary, Representative Marge S. Roukema quoted her friend, the writer Mary Higgins Clark, who stood next to her on the podium as the congresswoman addressed her supporters.

title: Constant Connection In a Sea Of Choppy Currents
description: It was clear from the beginning of Greg Osby's set on Tuesday night at the Knitting Factory that he had whipped a new rhythm section into shape. Mr. Osby, the alto saxophonist, has been touring with Vashon Johnson and Derek Philips on bass and drums -- it's the fifth rhythm section New York audiences have seen in his band in four years -- and after about a dozen performances across the country they've achieved a particular rhythmic feel that seems to suit him. There's always a steady underlying pulse; Mr. Osby takes his tempos seriously. But the rhythm's emphases are jagged, and bass and drums keep up a flow of rhythmic ornamentation.

title: Support Sought On Reviving Spanish-Dutch Phone Merger
description: Juan Villalonga, the chairman of Telefonica, the Spanish telecommunications company, has been trying to rally support among company board members to revive merger talks with the Dutch telephone operator Royal KPN, executives close to Telefonica said today.

description: The centerpiece of the government's cure for the predatory, monopolistic, take-no-prisoners behavior that Microsoft was found to have embraced is to chop the company in two.

description: Dorrell Mainer and Kevin Rainey were eager to celebrate their wedding this Saturday in Brooklyn. They expected 150 friends and relatives, including Mr. Rainey's elderly mother from South Carolina.

description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Vice President Al Gore, the presumptive presidential nominees, declined to comment today on the court order to break Microsoft into two companies, but Congressional Republicans condemned the ruling.

Cherished grandmother of Kim, Jesse, Shayne, Kelly, Kimberly, Sasha, Amelia and Samuel. Great-grandmother of William. Dear sister of Mary Maimone. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, has prevented the issue from coming to a vote in the Assembly, where it appears to have enough votes to pass. Supporters say it bans a specific form of late-term abortion. Opponents say the measure improperly limits doctors' options.

Shares of Hanover fell 37.5 cents, to $57.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, and Stewart & Stevenson rose 37.5 cents, to $14.625, in Nasdaq trading. Both companies are based in Houston.

title: SUNGLASS HUT DOUBLES WATCH BUSINESS WITH ACQUISITION
description: Sunglass Hut International Inc. said yesterday that it had purchased Watch World International Inc., doubling the size of its stand-alone watch business. New York-based Watch World, a closely held national chain of 119 stores that also sells on the Internet, had about $42 million in sales in the year ended Jan. 29. The acquisition was completed June 1, said Sunglass Hut, which had sales of $635.6 million last year. The company put the price at $30 million in cash, stock and debt. Sunglass Hut, based in Coral Gables, Fla., has about 1,867 sites, including Watch Station stores and combination sunglass-and-watch stores.

title: HOLD THE PHONE
description: A new survey suggests that e-mail users tend to make fewer long-distance phone calls, but that doesn't mean that they are ready to abandon the telephone altogether. The study, published in the journal Communication Research, found that almost half of the 309 Columbus, Ohio, residents surveyed had used long-distance less after they began using personal e-mail, although they were not asked how much less. But the respondents still rated the telephone very high for socializing and as a way to express emotion, while e-mail was favored when there was a scheduling conflict or when a phone call would otherwise have to be made to a different time zone.

The phone maker Eastcom said it would develop mobile handsets and wireless phone equipment based on Qualcomm's technology. The contract could be worth several million dollars to Qualcomm. Qualcomm's bid to have its cell-phone technology, known as code division multiple access, used across China was set back when China's No. 2 phone company, the China United Telecommunications Corporation, said this week it would delay building such a network for two years. Shares of Qualcomm rose $5.8125 each, to $74.6875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Stern Justice for Microsoft
description: Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's order to split Microsoft into two independent companies -- one selling Windows, the other selling applications like Word and Excel -- is the proper remedy for repeated violations of the antitrust laws. title: New Jersey's Excessive Senate Race
description: At his victory celebration after Tuesday's election, Jon Corzine, New Jersey's new Democratic Senate nominee, made a promise that could be taken two ways. ''I want to invest in America,'' he told supporters. ''That's what this campaign is all about.'' What the former Wall Street financier meant was that he wanted to spend for better health care and schools, instead of cutting taxes. But Mr. Corzine had also just invested a stratospheric $35 million to win a primary, more than any other Senate candidate in American history. The price tag for this victory now stands as a distressing symbol of a political system so driven by money that a candidate must be either extremely wealthy or extremely beholden to contributors in order to win. Mr. Corzine and Representative Bob Franks, his Republican competitor for the general election, should now commit themselves to correcting the way money skews the nation's politics.

title: Tiffany Plans More Stores
description: Tiffany & Company said today that it would open three to five new stores yearly and could nearly double the number of its stores in the United States. Tiffany, the nation's No. 2 jewelry chain, could operate as many as 75 stores in the United States, up from 39, the chief financial officer, Jim Fernandez, said at a PaineWebber conference in New York. The company also plans to open two stores this year in Japan, adding to its 44 stores there. The retailer gets 28 percent of its total sales from Japan. Tiffany will also open stores in Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan, Mr. Fernandez said.

title: Chiron Stock Buyback

The buyback represents about 2.2 percent of the 180 million outstanding shares of Chiron, maker of the world's No. 2 selling multiple sclerosis drug, Betaseron. The repurchase plan follows an announcement in March that the company would repurchase five million shares. Shares of Chiron rose $1 each, to $43.0625.

title: Dining Chez Starck: Organic or Wicked
description: This city is a bit slow on the uptake when it comes to some trends -- especially health-conscious food. Philippe Starck took pity and opened his first Parisian restaurant, Bon. Classic steak frites is available, but so is sushi. There is a choice of settings as well: a sushi bar, an intimate dining room with comfy chairs, and a long, communal bar (left). Details like a tabletop lighted from within revealing a starry galaxy (above left) and metallic high stools make it undeniably Starck. The menu also has sections headed ''I Am Bad'' (red meat, sauces), ''Deluxe'' (delicacies like caviar) and ''Mother'' (comfort food). A gift shop stocks Mr. Starck's own organic pasta, his scary leggy juicer and other Starckabilia. Bon is at 25 rue de la Pompe; 011-33-1-40-72-70-00.

Philips declined to say why it was selling the stake in ASM, the world's fifth-largest maker of chip equipment, although analysts pointed out it needs cash for acquisitions and for a planned $1.6 billion share buyback. ASM's shares have risen fivefold and Philips's fourfold in the last 18 months.

The company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., owns and manages a fleet of 950 planes, providing a full range of aircraft financing products and services to 155 airlines in over 54 countries.

title: RUSSIA TAX REFORM ADVANCES
description: Russia's lower house of Parliament approved President Vladimir V. Putin's proposal to impose a flat income tax of 13 percent, providing the new president his first victory in economic reform. The rate will take effect on Jan. 1 and will replace the current three-tiered rate that requires the country's wealthiest to pay a 30 percent tax on income. The bill is expected to pass a final reading before Parliament breaks for the summer on July 11. Deputies have extended their session for two weeks to complete work on Mr. Putin's tax package, which would reduce the tax burden on business by about 20 percent. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORODY, TONY
description: GORODY - Tony (Antal) Sr. Passed away peacefully on June 6, 2000 in his home in Houston, Texas. Born in Budapest, Hungary in 1916, Tony's versatile piano artistry brought joy to many people throughout the world. A child prodigy, he toured Europe as a classical concert pianist. Subsequently, having falling in love with jazz, he toured with the W. Martiny and T. Brunner orchestras and performed as a solo pianist in many of the most popular night clubs in Hungary and Switzerald. He was recently honored by being included in a musical CD ROM Tribute, compiled by the Hungarian Foundation for Jazz Education and Research, for his contributions to jazz history. From 1952 to 1960, Tony lived in Havana, Cuba. There, he appeared as a guest on numerous television and radio shows, and was the featured artist of his own popular dining club, the Mes Amis (My Friends). After immigrating to the United States in 1960, Tony's popularity rose through his solo engagements at the Windsor Hotel, Montreal, The Pierre, Summit, Carlisle, Sherry Netherlands, and Park Lane Hotel (New York City), and other night clubs such as Gogi's and the House of Hungary. Starting in 1973, he maintained a sixteen year engagement at the Blue Room in the Warwick Hotel, Houston, Texas. We thank him for all the special moments he helped us bring in our lives through his dedicated artistry.There will be a musical tribute in his honor at a memorial service to be held Saturday, June 10, 2000 at 10am, Earthman Hunters Creek Chapel, 8303 Katy Freeway, Houston, Texas. Phone, 713-465-8900.

After the merger was scrapped, the company got a $15 million equity infusion from a Canadian investment dealer, the Canaccord Capital Corporation, and said it would cut operating costs by $40 million a year.
