title: GO.COM IS SELLING ULTRASEEK TO INKTOMI FOR $344 MILLION
description: Go.com, Walt Disney's Internet unit, agreed yesterday to sell Ultraseek, its corporate networking subsidiary, to the Inktomi Corporation for $344.7 million in cash and stock. The move to sell Ultraseek, which provides customizable search and navigation software to businesses, is part of Go.com's efforts to focus on consumers. The company, based in North Hollywood, Calif., acquired Ultraseek as part of its deal to buy Infoseek last year. Inktomi, based in Foster City, Calif., will pay $3.5 million in cash, and stock valued at $341.2 million. Inktomi's shares fell $2.9375, to $125.875, while Go.com rose 18.75 cents, to $12.50.

E4L Inc., a Los Angeles-based provider of direct-marketing services, is the largest stockholder of BuyItNow. PcWonders is a wholly owned subsidiary of eWonders.com, based in Whippany, N.J. The new business will retain the name BuyItNow. Under the agreement, BuyItNow received a two-thirds equity position in exchange for assets valued at about $250 million. PcWonders, an e-commerce company specializing in the sale of computer products and consumer electronics, received one-third equity in exchange for assets valued at about $100 million.

The spinoff will result in a ''new'' Fluor Corporation and the Massey Energy Company. Fluor's construction business generated revenue of $11.3 billion last year, while the coal business had revenue of $1.1 billion. Fluor shareholders at the time of the spinoff will retain their existing Fluor stock, which will become Massey Energy shares, and will also be issued one share in new Fluor stock. Shares of Fluor, based in Aliso Viejo, Calif., rose $3.1875, to $35.4375.

description: BLOOR-James, 92, died May 31st at Hilton Head Island, SC. He was born September 16, 1907 to Walter and Isabelle Bloor. He attended Barnard School for Boys and Rockland Academy. He was employed by Thompson-Starrett Co. and in 1932 he went to work for Chase National Bank, (Chase Manhattan Bank). During World War II, he served in the U.S. Navy. After the War, he returned to Chase where he stayed until 1955 when he left to become Executive Vice President of Central Savings Bank, (Apple Bank for Savings). He was named President in 1961 and retired as Chairman of the Board in 1972. Following retirement, he was a consultant for the National Bank of North America until 1974 when he was chosen by the Bankruptcy Court to act as Trustee of Investors Funding Corp. In addition, he served on the Board of Directors of Nyack Hospital, Empire National Bank, Sandoz Inc., Alico Financial Corp., Mercantile National Bank, The James T. Lee Foundation, Savings Bank Trust Co., Institutional Investors Mutual Fund, New York State Employees Retirement System, National Association of Savings Banks and Guardian Life Insurance Company. Mr. Bloor resided in Grandview-on-Hudson in Rockland County, New York. He was a Trustee of the Village, Mayor and Police Justice. In 1992, he moved to Hilton Head Island, SC. Survived by his wife, Florence; 3 children, James W. Bloor of Santa Ana, CA, Joan Faccioli of Hilton Head and Ann Gray of Eastham, MA; 8 grandchildren and 6 great-grandchildren. Memorial contributions to the Kerry Fund c/o Camp Ronald McDonald for Good Times, 1954 Cotner Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90025. Services were held on Hilton Head Island.

title: SOUTHERN IS BUYING FOUR PLANTS FROM POTOMAC
description: The Southern Company, the largest electricity producer in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy four power plants from the Potomac Electric Power Company, for $2.65 billion in cash. The plants, three in Maryland and one in Virginia, can produce 5,154 megawatts of electricity, enough to light more than five million homes. They will join a network stretching from California to Massachusetts. Southern, based in Atlanta, is buying and building plants across the United States to support its energy-trading business. Potomac Electric, based in Washington, is one of several utilities to abandon power production.

The companies are the Dashiell Corporation of Deer Park, Tex.; the Dacon Corporation of Lake Charles, La.; Michigan Trenching Service of Ypsilanti, Mich.; and VSI Group of Columbia, Md. Shares of Peco, which is merging with Unicom, the parent of Chicago's Commonwealth Edison, rose $1 each, to $42.8125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VISHNER, ESTHER DOBKIN.
description: VISHNER-Esther Dobkin. 90, formerly of the Bronx, died May 22 under care of friends in Oxnard, CA. Illness only deprived Esther of her independence in her last two months. Esther didn't have an easy life, but no one would have known it. Her infectious laughter and positive outlook were a gift to all. A love of ''good dark choclate'' and yellow roses evidenced the joy she took in simple pleasures. She presented her family with a steady stream of lovingly crafted knitted garments. Esther was born in Waterbury,CT, earned her AB degree from Hunter College, did allergy research at Mt. Sinai and Brooklyn Jewish Hospitals and was the first to publish the pollen count in the New York Times. Later she helped her brothers at Pioneer Fence Co. In 1948 she married the late Joseph Vishnevetsky (changed to Vishner). She was active in the PTAs of P.S. 94, J.H.S. 80, Sholem Aleichem Shul 21, served on Local School Board 10 and with Sholem Aleichem Folk Institute. In WWII she was a volunteer ''tracker'' of air traffic. She was a member of Workmen's Circle, National Yiddish Book Center and YIVO. Esther sang in the Kultur Gezelshaft Chorus and supported cultural, women's, social service, pacifist and environmental organizations. Daughter of the late Isaac and Jennie Dobkin, sister of the late Dr. Julius Dobkin, Solomon A. Dobkin and Abraham Dobkin, Esq., survived by sons Mayer Jacob Vishner, J. Marcus Newman (Nonnie Morris Vishner), Ira Vishner and wife Susan; brother Machbi Dobkin, sisters Hannah Doberne and Eva Dobkin; sistersin-law Lillian K. Dobkin, MarjorieHousepian Dobkin and Hedvig Suess; grandchildren Jess, Nathaniel and Polly Vishner; 13 nieces and nephews, 26 grandnieces and nephews. And many friends -generations of them. In accordance with Esther's wishes, there were no funeral services. In memoriam, plant a rosebush, eat choclate, or make donations to: YIVO, 15 W. 16th St., New York, NY 10011.

title: Ex-Trader Cleared of Charges
description: A judge cleared a former trader at the Bankers Trust New York Corporation today of unsafe banking charges that the Federal Reserve brought involving a sale of leveraged derivatives.

title: McCall Says Giuliani Administration Is Defying Court Order to Assist State Audits
description: The state comptroller said yesterday that the Giuliani administration was continuing to defy a court order to fully cooperate with state audits of city agencies.

title: Chicago Agencies Win Addy Awards
description: Two Chicago agencies have won top honors in the 32nd annual American Advertising Awards competition sponsored by the American Advertising Federation in Washington.

title: The Chillingly Fine Line Between Ecstasy and Grief
description: In the photograph you see a boy flying, head first, toward the ground, and another boy falling fast feet first. At first you hope the boys are alive, and then you hope they are dead. Finally you breathe a sigh of relief: both are alive and jumping. This may sound like a bizarre reaction to a picture of two boys bouncing exuberantly on a trampoline in South Africa against a blue sky filled with high-flying clouds. But if you saw the exhibition in which the photograph hangs, ''James Nachtwey: Testimony'' at the International Center of Photography, or Mr. Nachtwey's new book of photographs, ''Inferno'' (Phaidon, 2000), you might have the same response.

title: E.P.A., Citing Risks to Children, Signs Accord to Limit Insecticide
description: One of the most common ingredients in home, lawn and garden bug killers poses an unacceptable health risk, particularly to children, and by the end of the year will no longer be manufactured for that use, federal environmental officials announced yesterday.

title: Selling Books on the Street in a Quality-of-Life Town
description: The documentary ''Bookwars,'' a minor film about the book vendors who populate the streets of Manhattan, doesn't get into the wars until the last 20 minutes of the picture. Before that section, which deals with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's ''quality of life'' mission -- which, among other things, sought to clear Manhattan streets of vendors -- ''Bookwars'' is a slice of true life.

title: Drug Dealer Found Guilty in Murder of Child Witness
description: Issuing the first verdict in a case that outraged the public and prompted a swift strengthening of Connecticut's witness protection laws, a jury today convicted a drug dealer of ordering the murder of an 8-year-old boy last year to prevent the child from testifying against him as the state's key witness in another murder trial.

title: Resurrecting the Miner's World
description: ''The miners had a saying: 'If the timbers start talking, we start walking,' '' Joe Burke said, turning his head so that the thin beam from the lamp on his miner's helmet poked into the gloom, barely illuminating the stout wood columns that seemed to hold up the roof.

title: SOUTH AMERICAN PHONE VENTURE
description: Two North American telephone giants, Bell Canada International Inc. and Telefonos de Mexico S.A., have formed a new company with $3.5 billion in assets to expand in South America, primarily in broadband, mobile wireless and Internet services. Bell Canada International is a subsidiary of BCE Inc., which owns Canada's largest telephone company, and Telefonos is the biggest telephone company in Mexico. The new company will include Bell Canada's existing investments in Brazil, Columbia and Venezuela and the Brazilian holdings of Telefonos, plus $1.8 billion in cash. Timothy Pritchard

title: Protecting Public Spaces
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Companies Pick AG Worldwide
description: Three advertisers have named AG Worldwide in New York, part of the Draft Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle their accounts, with combined billings estimated at $54 million.

title: Into the Night, Endlessly Searching for the Perfect Rave
description: ''Who would want to go to a party that actually lets you know where it is?'' vents a very frustrated Neil (Jeff Witzke) in ''Groove,'' the shambling but mostly knowing and funny comedy from the director Greg Harrison. If you're nostalgic for the days of chasing around the city to find a gig and arriving just in time to see a pair of 16-year-olds earnestly discussing the merits of drum-and-bass versus jungle music, then ''Groove'' is the movie for you. And if you're not so inclined, the film's seductive lack of pretension will make a fan of you.

title: Metro Business; Morgan Stanley Looks to Jersey City
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is looking for office space in Jersey City, according to developers and real estate brokers.

title: Jack Kroll, 74; Editor and Critic Shaped Newsweek's Art Coverage
description: Jack Kroll, an editor, critic and writer for Newsweek magazine for more than 35 years, died yesterday in New York. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Residential Real Estate; Doctor's Office: Apartment Bargain
description: The classic sole-practitioner doctor's office, usually on the ground floor of a stately building, marked by a discreet plaque, has been acquiring a new use in recent years. Reflecting changes both in the medical world and the rising real estate market, many are being converted into apartments.

title: Agreement to Balance Budget Eludes Officials in Nassau
description: Despite negotiations that continued into the early morning hours, Nassau County officials failed to reach a final agreement today on $50 million in recurring spending cuts and new revenues needed to help balance this year's budget.

title: A Do-Gooder and a Victim Not Forgotten
description: DO-GOODERS tend to make for dull reading, so let's ignore Matt Foreman, the executive director of the Empire State Pride Agenda, for the moment, and zoom in on the dead man in his arms.

title: Court Orders Medicaid Care Despite Assets
description: New York's highest court ruled today that the state cannot refuse to provide medical coverage for people needing long-term institutional care in cases when their spouse refuses to turn the ailing person's assets over to the government.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Anchor Weighs In Over Microsoft

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 23 about the Republican primary in New Jersey for the seat held by Representative Marge S. Roukema misstated the criticism leveled at her by the Club for Growth, a conservative group based in Washington. (The error was repeated in an article in some copies on Wednesday.) While the organization has objected to Mrs. Roukema's moderate stands on welfare reform and tax issues, it has not criticized her for supporting abortion rights; it takes no position on social issues.

title: Ancient Pots As Storytellers
description: Just as medieval Christians learned their Bible by looking at stained glass windows and church sculptures, ancient Greeks had their mythology illustrated on painted pots.

title: Through the Looking Glass: Europe Raises Interest Rates
description: WHAT would the Federal Reserve do if American inflation was running about 2 percent a year and the unemployment rate was 9.6 percent? Would Alan Greenspan have the nerve to raise rates by half a percentage point?

title: BRITISH JOB CUTS ANNOUNCED
description: Britain's largest mail-order company, Great Universal Stores P.L.C., announced it would merge its home shopping unit with its catalog chain unit, Argos. The move is meant to cut costs and will result in the elimination of 800 jobs. Great Universal Stores is hoping to increase sales by using the Argos brand, which has a retail presence throughout Britain.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Shahzia Sikander
description: 'Acts of Balance'

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first and second days of Shavuot, the Jewish Feast of Weeks, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Future of Collector Cars: On the Auction Block, or Online?
description: THREE recent auctions here demonstrated that the collector-car market continues to gain strength. Yet the beneficiaries, the old-line auction companies that exhilarate crowds by sending multimillion-dollar Bugattis over the block, where they are subject to feverish bidding by celebrity collectors, are looking warily over their shoulders.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Wednesday about a drop in the stock of the Circuit City Group after it warned of falling profit margins misstated the company's expectations for its first quarter. Including its interest in the CarMax Group, Circuit City expects to exceed analysts' estimates by about a penny a share. It does not expect to miss forecasts by 4 cents a share.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN C.E.O. -- A special report.; Gore Dots the i's That Bush Leaves to Others
description: The vice president just was not satisfied. A team of graphic artists had labored to come up with a logo to emblazon on Al Gore's campaign buttons, bumper stickers and placards, but he felt they had failed to capture the right spirit. So he sketched an alternative, a swoosh and a star -- a simple, futuristic look with the words, ''Gore 2000.''

title: Big Carmakers Extend Benefits To Gay Couples
description: General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler division announced today that they would begin offering medical, dental and prescription drug benefits for same-sex partners of their 466,000 hourly and salaried employees in the United States, the largest move yet by corporate America to provide such benefits for gay and lesbian couples.

title: Terrorist Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Last Manager Set to Leave Soros Fund
description: The last of three top money managers announced his departure from the dwindling investment empire of George Soros yesterday. Scott Bessent, who oversees European investments for Soros Fund Management, said he would leave to start his own private investment group.

title: National Semiconductor's Fourth-Quarter Earnings Exceeded Expectations
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation reported fourth-quarter earnings today that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates as sales increased 22.5 percent. Executives raised their predictions for revenue growth in the next fiscal year to about 30 percent from 25 percent.

title: Mets at Yanks: A Lot of Shakin' Going On
description: There will be no angry men taking the field at Yankee Stadium tonight. The Mets and the Yankees don't harbor hatred, not in the way the Dodgers despised the Giants' Sal Maglie and Leo Durocher. The extra passion Derek Jeter and Mike Piazza and others will play with this weekend is not fueled by an inherited feud.

title: Round Trip Ends Orioles' Long Trip
description: The Orioles were tired of seeing Shea Stadium by last night. When their road trip was extended an extra day because of Tuesday's rainout, the Orioles spiraled into a traveling disaster. There were not enough rooms to accommodate the entire team so the Orioles flew to Baltimore after Wednesday night's game here, slept at home and then returned to New York yesterday afternoon.

title: The Stories Vs. the Steps
description: DANCE preceded drama in ancient days and the tension between the two forms is felt today in choreography. Ballet, more than modern dance, has seen the comeback of an old opera-house genre, the full-evening narrative spectacle. But plotless ballets, sometimes dramatic in an abstract way, continue to reign supreme among American choreographers.

title: A Vote Against Secret Spending
description: The 1996 Democratic fund-raising scandals introduced the notorious phrase ''soft money'' into everyday political discourse. The term applies to the huge, corrupting sums raised from corporations, unions and wealthy individuals for political parties outside federal limits. This year another gross abuse is spreading. Slush funds created under Section 527 of the tax code are starting to raise unregulated money without actually disclosing the donors. Yesterday evening, in a surprise victory for reform, the Senate voted for an amendment to close this new loophole and require disclosure. The measure still needs final Senate approval, and also passage by the House.

title: Gore Plans Tour on Prosperity Issues
description: Vice President Al Gore plans to kick off a new stage of his campaign next week, making a ''progress and prosperity'' tour devoted to the relatively new questions of how best to guide the nation in an era of budget surpluses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDEGGER, CECILIA
description: LANDEGGER-Cecilia. June 5, 2000. Beloved mother of Christine Mroczek, Cary Landegger, Claudia Malaya, Celia Landegger and the late Carl Michael Landegger. Grandmother of ten. Devoted sister of the late Elena Ugarte. She was the daughter of the late Joaquin Elizalde who was the Philippine ambassador to the United States and Foreign Secretary. She will be deeply missed. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street Monday, June 12, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, June 13, 10AM at the Church of the Epiphany, 239 E. 21 St, NYC. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Dorismonds Are Skeptical About Meeting With Mayor
description: The family of Patrick M. Dorismond said yesterday that they were ''weary'' of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent public condolences and complained that neither the mayor nor anyone on his staff had personally reached out to them since Mr. Dorismond was killed by the police in March.

title: Pacers Are Confident Despite Game 1 Misfire
description: Without fear or remorse, Reggie Miller fired shots until the bitter end Wednesday night, refusing to believe that they would not fall. Afterward, despite making an unfathomable 1-of-16 attempts, Miller issued a warning to the Los Angeles Lakers that was as outrageous as his performance.

title: A big new Internet services company is determined to make its entry with a splash.
description: THERE is a riddle that used to appear in magazines like Highlights for Children and Boys' Life, asking readers to name the only day of the year that can also be a sentence. The answer: March Fourth.

title: Faithful Homage (Crash! Kapow!)
description: Apparently because the rights to good films were unavailable, the producer Jerry Bruckheimer decided to remake the underwhelming auto theft spectacular ''Gone in 60 Seconds'' instead. By cranking up the action and adding a cast of magnetic, capable actors -- the Bruckheimer treatment -- he almost achieves alchemy. It's only gold-filled instead of pure gold, but that's quite an accomplishment. This new version is mindless hot-rodding fun, especially for those with a weakness for vintage cars hurtling down city streets, a group whose members include -- sigh -- me.

title: White House Reports Trouble Retrieving Messages
description: The White House, under pressure to produce thousands of lost e-mail messages sought by Congress, has informed a House committee that it cannot find any backup records for messages sent to or from Vice President Al Gore's office in 1998 and part of 1999.

title: NATIONAL CITY SAYS IT SOLD $2 BILLION IN STUDENT LOANS
description: The National City Corporation, Ohio's largest bank, said yesterday that it had sold $2 billion in student loans as part of a move to protect earnings from rising interest rates. The sale will result in a second-quarter pretax gain of $75 million. National City, which declined to identify the buyers, will use the proceeds to make new loans at higher rates. The company, based in Cleveland, also warned that some steps being considered to lower its financing costs might mean selling some of its investments, mostly bonds, at a loss.

title: Transfer of General at Site of Anti-Gay Killing Is Protested
description: The Army's decision to reassign the commander of Fort Campbell, Ky., where a gay soldier was beaten to death last year, is provoking criticism from members of Congress and gay-rights advocates who complain that an investigation of anti-gay harassment under his command has not yet been completed.

title: Leiter Views Rivalry From Both Sides Now
description: Al Leiter ducked beneath the streets to the subway station at 86th Street and Lexington Avenue last Tuesday, his two young daughters clutching each hand. The girls were going to watch their father do a television interview inside a subway car to promote the series between the Mets and the Yankees and then be treated to pizza.

title: What Say You, My Lords? You'd Rather Charleston?
description: For every man with his affects is born,

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Philadelphia; Wilton and Stamford, Conn.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Sharpening Their Wits And a Few Other Things
description: With flying knives, jagged bottles, snipping scissors and a chomping chopper, Penn & Teller are back on Broadway with a sharp show.

title: Albany Agrees On Plan to Aid Nassau County
description: After weeks of brinkmanship, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature have agreed to spend $105 million to bail out Nassau County and impose state oversight of county spending, in an effort to avert financial collapse in one of the nation's wealthiest regions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAUDERER, JEROME
description: ZAUDERER - Jerome. Lifelong resident of New York City, age 88. Father of Mark, father-in-law of Joan and grandfather of Daniel. Died June 6, 2000. Burial private. A memorial gathering will take place on a day to be announced.

title: Experts Praise Judge's Rulings On Microsoft
description: Legal experts gave the judge in the Microsoft case high marks yesterday for his handling of the case, saying he took some risks but grounded his ruling in fundamental principles governing fair competition.

title: Bush Proposes Restructured Budget Process And Other Policy Changes to End Gridlock
description: Criticizing Washington for what he termed ''too much needless division,'' Gov. George W. Bush proposed a wide-ranging overhaul of the federal budget process today in an effort to avoid the bitter annual standoffs between Congress and the president over taxes and spending.

title: Sports of The Times; McMullen's Last Hurrah Postponed
description: UP and down they skated, in and out they swooped. Another shot, another save.

title: Divining the Ways of God and Man: 10 Stories Rooted in Commandments
description: For Krzysztof Kieslowski, the great Polish filmmaker who died four years ago, the answers to our most troubling questions about the meaning of life and death and the existence of God can be intuited only from riddles, signs, portents, coincidences and sudden, odd strokes of fate. On entering Kieslowski's somber but far from depressing cinematic world, we find ourselves in a place where everything from household objects to chance encounters with strangers is charged with a mysterious gravity and enigmatic sense of connection. But as powerfully as his films portray human pain and longing, they also convey the preciousness of life with a conviction that few other filmmakers have succeeded in bringing to the screen.

title: Documentarians Become Talking Heads for a Change
description: ''The typewriter,'' goes a dated piece of verse by D. J. Enright, ''is creating a revolution in poetry.'' The digital video camera, we have been hearing lately, is having the same effect on filmmaking. Cheap, portable, easy to use, the new technology puts cinematic expression in reach of the masses. At a recent documentary festival, everyone I spoke to seemed to come up with the same analogy: the camera has become less like a printing press and more like a pencil, something you can grab hold of when the mood strikes, and use to transform your impressions into art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, CLARENCE HOLBROOK.
description: CARTER - Clarence Holbrook. Hirschl & Adler Galleries mourns the passing of a distinguished artist and fine human being. His career as both artist and teacher spanned 80 fruitful years. His unique personal vision was admired throughout the 20th Century. We shall miss him, and extend our sympathies to his family. Stuart P. Feld, M.P. Naud

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARM, MARY GAY.
description: HARM-Mary Gay. On June 5, 2000 at age 77. Dedicated social worker. Wife of the late Carl S. Harm. Sister of the late Inez Gay Johnson. Aunt to Marcia Johnson Alston, Gay Johnson McDougall and John A. Payton. Also survived by many loving cousins and other family members. Funeral services will be held Saturday, June 10 at 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Work Begins on Westin Hotel To the West of Times Square
description: Construction workers began building a soaring 45-story Westin hotel yesterday in a once forbidding area west of Times Square, at the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 43rd Street.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the ways in which New Yorkers make the most of small apartments misidentified a woman who grows hundreds of plants in a tiny space. She is Zabel Meshejian, not Doris Tobias.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEPLEMAN, JACK
description: STIEPLEMAN-Jack. On June 6, 2000. Of Delray Beach, Florida. Formerly of Kew Garden Hills, New York. Husband of the late Frieda. Loving father of Bernice Reiss, Susan Poirier and Edward Stiepleman. Brother of the late Willie and Ben. Grandfather and great-grandfather. Interment Delray Beach, Florida. The family requests that donations in his memory be made to: Hospice By The Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, Florida 33486.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Roads a Woman Can Take
description: To the Editor:

title: A Golfer Chugs Along, Carving Out a Living
description: John Maginnes, who is 163rd on the PGA Tour money list this year, is realistic about his standing on the tour.

title: Teenage Mother Accused of Throwing Baby in River Was Depressed, Lawyer Says
description: A lawyer for a 17-year-old mother charged with throwing her baby into the Passaic River Saturday night said today that she had been forced to leave home two years ago and was recently depressed and suffering from memory lapses.

title: Untrained but Inspired, Hands Dreamed in Stone
description: In 1941 Edward Weston photographed the grassy yard in Nashville where the sculptor William Edmondson (1874-1951) carved and displayed his work. Judging from the pictures, it was an enchanted ground.

title: CBS's 'Early Show' Draws Complaints, Not Crowds
description: When ''Today'' began broadcasting from a street-level studio in the early 1990's, using Rockefeller Plaza as its backdrop, it helped propel the show to first place in the ratings. The tactic was so successful that it was copied by ''Good Morning America,'' which opened a glass-walled studio in Times Square last year.

title: Calgary Journal; In the Catbird Seat (or the Hot Seat, Like Seattle?)
description: Playing on Americans' fear of the unknown, a Best Western Hotel television ad last winter showed business executives bucking an unpopular travel request down the corporate ladder. Finally, the request stopped at a hapless underling, standing wide-eyed by a photocopier as a colleague asked, ''Have you ever been to -- Calgary?''

title: Against All Odds, a Haven For the Youngest Refugees
description: The tiny village of Chabannes, in the Creuse region of central France, is a quiet, obscure place, one of those corners of rural Europe that seem strangely untouched by the modern world. But 60 years ago Chabannes confronted 20th-century European brutality at its worst, and responded with unusual courage and humanity. The village served as a haven for nearly 400 Jewish children -- most of them refugees from Germany and Austria -- whom its citizens protected from the Nazis and from the betrayal of their own collaborationist government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOHL, DAVID L.
description: WOHL-David L. June 9, 1955-Nov 18, 1994, ''Long ago what a time it was, a time of innocence and confidences I have prints of your memory thats all thats left.'' You are forever in my heart and soul. If only I could hold you in my arms and wish you a Happy 45th Birthday Sweet Boy. Love Mommy.

title: LIBERTY FINANCIAL SAYS IT IS HAVING TALKS WITH WANGER
description: Liberty Financial confirmed yesterday, without further comment, that it was holding discussions to acquire Wanger Asset Management, owner of the Acorn group of five mutual funds. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that Liberty had agreed to acquire Wanger for about $450 million, or about 6 percent of Wanger's $7.3 billion of assets under management. Liberty Financial, based in Boston, has $67 billion in assets and owns 95 mutual funds, including the Stein Roe and Newport Pacific Management groups. It is majority owned by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company. Liberty Financial's stock fell $1.25 a share, to $22.50.

title: Putin to Visit North Korea; U.S. ABM Plan May Be Target
description: President Vladimir V. Putin plans to visit North Korea next month, a move that underscores his active foreign policy and seems calculated to counter the Clinton administration's plan for a national missile defense.

title: Government Reports Decline in Import Prices
description: The prices businesses pay for imported goods, excluding petroleum, fell in May for the first time in almost a year, government figures showed today, suggesting that inexpensive imports are helping to keep inflation contained.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Making Books column yesterday, about leading authors and the sales shortfall of their recent novels, misidentified the work that made a one-week appearance on the New York Times best-seller list. As the article noted, it was ''Ravelstein,'' by Saul Bellow, not ''The Human Stain'' by Philip Roth.

title: A 'Full Monty,' Buffalo Style
description: Let the punning begin: ''The Full Monty'' is coming to Broadway.

title: Ties (and Bungee Cords) That Bind
description: More male eyes tear up in ''Pop and Me,'' a likable documentary about fathers and sons, than turn misty in ''Frequency,'' the macho tear-jerker about filial devotion that word of mouth has turned into a surprise hit. Could it be that the tough-but-tender ethos of Robert Bly's ''Iron John'' has trickled down into the cultural mainstream despite the buckets of glib derision heaped on the men's movement? The coincidence of these two male weepies suggests perhaps yes.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Judge Says Online Critic Has No Right to Hide
description: June 9, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, BLAIR
description: CLARK-Blair. The Hunter College community is deeply saddened by the passing of Blair Clark, Trustee of The Hunter College Foundation, a member of the Brookdale Board of Overseers and a friend of the College. He served as Co-Chair of The Committee for the Restoration of Roosevelt House and was deeply committed to its renewal. Mr. Clark was a retired journalist whose career spanned four decades. He was General Manager and Vice President for CBS News, France and New York, and editor of ''The Nation.'' We are proud of our association with Mr. Clark and shall miss him deeply. Our sincerest condolences are extended to his wife, children, and the entire family. David A. Caputo, President Hunter College CLARK-Blair. The Trustees of The Hunter College Foundation and members of The Committee for the Restoration of Roosevelt House are deeply saddened by the passing of their friend and fellow Trustee, Blair Clark. The restoration of Roosevelt House was a project close to his heart. He was an avid supporter of its renewal as a living tribute to the legacy of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt in New York City, and its place in Hunter's history. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife and family. Allan H. Kurtzman, Chairman Hunter College Foundation CLARK-L. Blair. The Club salutes its Senior Member L. Blair Clark, champion of the young, raconteur extraordinaire and splendid friend. Like his son Cameron, he was a virtuous man who passed ''mildy away''. Ours was no ''dull, sublunary lovers' love.'' Charles Kaiser, David White, Heyden White Rostow, And special guest Nancy B. Hector

title: TROY AGREES TO PAY $90 MILLION FOR CATSKILL FINANCIAL
description: The Troy Financial Corporation, the holding company of the 14-branch Troy Savings Bank, agreed yesterday to acquire the Catskill Financial Corporation for about $90 million in cash. Troy Financial agreed to pay $23 for each Catskill Financial share. The shares jumped $4.25 yesterday, or 24 percent, to $21.9375, while Troy Financial's slipped 6.25 cents, to $9.6875. Catskill Financial is the holding company of Catskill Savings Bank, which has $346 million in assets. The merger of Catskill Savings into Troy Savings will create a bank with assets of about $1.2 billion and 21 branches in upstate New York.

title: Democratic Party Asks Questions in Exchange for Free Internet Access
description: Democratic Party Asks Questions in Exchange for Free Internet Access

title: Corrections
description: Two picture credits with an article in Circuits yesterday about the use of cellular telephones in public were reversed. The photograph of Jon Geist was by Carol Halebian for The New York Times; the one below, of a young woman using a cell phone, was by Bridget Besaw Gorman for The New York Times.

title: Procter & Gamble Shake-Up Follows Poor Profit Outlook
description: The chief executive of Procter & Gamble, the consumer products giant, resigned yesterday as the company announced it would suffer another disappointing quarter and its stock price fell to less than half of what it was worth just four months ago.

title: EATING OUT
description: Near Lincoln Center

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Men with guns come and wreak havoc on a very regular basis. Those men cause more death by making people flee their homes than actually by shooting or slitting throats.''

title: Cox Radio Sets Deal for Atlanta Station
description: Cox Radio Inc., the fourth-largest United States radio company, said today that the Midwestern Broadcasting Company, owner of the Atlanta radio station WALR-FM, had accepted its offer to buy Midwestern for $280 million.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Green Mile

title: What About China?
description: In its eagerness to persuade Russia to accept deployment of a U.S. missile defense, the Clinton administration has all but ignored China, a nuclear power in its own right and an opponent of these systems.

title: Pet Shop Owners Are Accused Of Producing Fighting Birds
description: The owners of a Brooklyn pet shop were being held yesterday by police, accused of multiple felony counts for running a training and breeding center for cockfighting roosters in the basement of their business, the authorities said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Newspaper Chain on Block As Another Sells 38 Papers

title: New Duty for the Democrats' Main Money Man: Running the Convention
description: After a personal appeal by Vice President Al Gore, Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic Party's most prodigious fund-raiser, has agreed to serve as chairman of the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles, which has struggled to overcome fund-raising difficulties and bickering among its organizers.

title: Panama Still Failing to Stem Narcotics Traffic, U.S. Report Asserts
description: The Panamanian government has made little progress this year in its fight against drug trafficking and money laundering, according to a United States Customs intelligence report.

title: Attacking Hate Crimes
description: It has been a source of shame that year after year New York State has failed to enact a meaningful hate-crime law even as violence against gays and minority groups has become more common. More than 40 other states have approved some form of hate-crime legislation.

title: Behind a Solemn Rite for Obuchi, a Burst of Politicking
description: Japan's late prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, was remembered today in a solemn state service marked by emotional eulogies, cannonades, a parading honor guard in crisp white uniforms, and thousands of dark-suited mourners, including President Clinton.

title: Police Officer Faces Charges In Shooting of Bronx Teenager
description: An officer of the Police Department's Street Crime Unit is to surrender today to face charges in the on-duty shooting of a Bronx teenager more than a year ago, the Bronx district attorney's office said last night.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ADAPTEC, Milpitas, Calif., a designer of cards that speed computer communications, said it planned to make its software unit an independent company and make a public offering of shares for part of the unit.

description: Putin to Visit North Korea

description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Oxford-Cambridge Rivalry Is Complicated by Harvard
description: At a moment when scholarships and academic elitism are the hot-button topic in Britain's most august places of learning, enter Bill Gates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, JOSEPH
description: GROSSMAN-Joseph. June 8, 2000 Joseph Grossman of NYC, husband of Paula Rosoff Grossman. Father of Amy Breiger of Seattle, WA and Julie Grossman of Syracuse. Brother of William Grossman of Westport, CT and the late Rabbi Herman Grossman. Also survived by 3 grandchildren. Funeral services at Mishkan Israel Cemetery, Jewell St., New Haven, CT. SUNDAY morning at 11:00. Memorial contributions may be sent to the United Jewish Appeal of NY, 130 E. 59th St., NY, NY. A private period of mourning will be observed. For further information contact the Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, New Haven.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the Pataki administration's final approval for a single-unit power plant to be built in Athens, N.Y., misstated its size ranking. Experts say the Palo Verde nuclear plant in Arizona, which has three units, is the largest in the country, with a total capacity of 3,900 megawatts. The plant in Athens, with a capacity of 1,080 megawatts, is to be one of the largest in the United States fired by natural gas and one of the largest single-unit plants -- not the largest in the country.

title: Israeli Interests
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. Irreplaceable in our lives, forever in our hearts and minds. Much loved, deeply missed. Love, Harry

title: Earning A's in People Skills at Andover
description: Perhaps there have been other presidential candidates who have dressed in drag, flaunting their legs from beneath a (fairly short) white skirt. But George W. Bush is probably the only one who has done it in front of a camera.

title: Crestfallen, Devils Try to Regroup
description: The Devils' day began early this morning on the ice, playing sudden-death Stanley Cup hockey. After more than 106 minutes, including 46:21 of overtime, they lost Game 5 in stunning fashion, 1-0, to the Dallas Stars in a stirring match that ended at 1:11 a.m.

title: RUSSIA PHONE OFFERING
description: Russia's biggest mobile phone operator, Mobile TeleSystems, will offer shares at a price of $19 to $25 in its initial public offering in New York later this month. The offering, which will be the first by a Russian company since the country's financial collapse in 1998, will take place on June 30. The company expects to raise $265 million to $410 million in the sale. The proceeds will be spent on developing Russia's national mobile phone network. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: MODTECH TO BUY ITS COMPETITOR, MILLER BUILDING SYSTEMS
description: Modtech Holdings Inc. a maker of modular buildings and relocatable classrooms, agreed yesterday to buy its competitor Miller Building Systems Inc. for about $30 million in cash and assumed debt. Under the deal, Modtech will pay Miller Building shareholders $8.05 in cash for each outstanding share and assume outstanding Miller Building debt. Miller, based in Elkhart, Ind., posted 1999 net income of $2.5 million on sales of $65 million. Shares of Miller jumped $1.5625, to $7.50, while stock of Modtech, based in Perris, Calif., was unchanged at $11.625.

title: Bush Criticizes Gore Record On Trimming Bureaucracy
description: Gov. George W. Bush today assailed Vice President Al Gore's signature effort to streamline government, saying the Clinton administration had not reinvented the bureaucracy, but ''simply reshuffled it.''

title: Innovation Isn't The Microsoft Way
description: Bill Gates, protesting the government's antitrust initiatives against Microsoft, has asserted from the first that limiting the scope of his company's activities or breaking it up would stifle the innovation that helped Microsoft catalyze the information revolution into existence. The incongruity of this response to the Justice Department's pleadings and Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's decision is inescapable: Microsoft soared to its powerful heights on the backs of innovations that were largely the work of others.

title: ABC Made Most of Three Overtimes
description: ABC's marathon broadcast of Dallas's 1-0 three-overtime victory over the Devils in Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals on Thursday night offered a compelling reason for hockey being better in extra sessions than basketball: with no action-ending timeouts, there are no endless commercial breaks.

title: Cabdrivers Sue To End Policy On Suspensions
description: Three New York City taxi drivers filed a class-action lawsuit yesterday on behalf of the city's entire fleet of 41,000 yellow-cab drivers, saying that city officials should not be allowed to immediately revoke or suspend the licenses of cabbies who fail to pick up blacks or other members of minority groups.

title: JAPANESE BANK DEAL
description: Japan's fifth-largest lender, Sakura Bank Ltd., offered to buy a controlling stake in a small rival, Minato Bank Ltd., to strengthen its position in the country's second-largest metropolitan area. Sakura said it would buy as many as 142 million Minato shares for 240 yen each, or 34 billion yen ($325 million). The acquisition of the Kobe-based Minato will give Sakura about a fifth of deposits and a quarter of lending in Hyogo Prefecture, home to 5.5 million people.

title: Gore Praises Move to Aid Salmon Run
description: After an hourlong ride in a speedboat up the choppy Columbia River, Vice President Al Gore today announced President Clinton's designation of the Hanford Reach in south-central Washington, one of the most important salmon-spawning beds in the world, as a national monument.

title: Japanese Economy Rose 2.4% in Quarter
description: The Japanese economy rebounded in the first quarter of this year, reversing the course set in the previous six months. But economists said in appraising the data released today that the numbers did not necessarily signal a sustainable recovery and merely extended the pattern of alternating growth and contraction that has prevailed for many years in Japan, Asia's biggest economy.

title: E.D.S. Shares Skid 26 Percent On Company's Sales Warning
description: Shares of Electronic Data Systems tumbled 26 percent today after it said second-quarter sales would be less than expected.

title: Investigation Finds No Plot In Killing Of Dr. King
description: After an 18-month investigation, the Justice Department concluded today that there was no evidence to support recent assertions of a plot to assassinate the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and recommended no further inquiry in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNETT, MARY
description: BURNETT-Mary (nee Connolly) on June 7, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Loving mother of Timothy, Kieran, Joseph, Maura and the late Christopher. Dear sister of Anne, Joan, and the late Joseph and Kevin. Cherished Grandmother of Daniel, Alina, and Emma. Friends may call at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Ave, New Hyde Park, NY, Sat 7-9:30pm, Sun 2-5 & 79:30pm. Funeral Mass Monday 11AM at Notre Dame RC Church in New Hyde Park. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Access to RU-486
description: RU-486, the French abortion pill, has long offered the promise of better access to safe abortions for women in this country. But that promise has gone unfulfilled because of political controversies surrounding abortion and earlier difficulties in finding a suitable manufacturer. Now come troubling reports that the Food and Drug Administration, as it moves toward final approval of the drug it pronounced safe and effective in 1996, is considering unreasonable restrictions on the distribution of RU-486 that would virtually eliminate its chief value.

title: Fatal Fall Onto Rail Track
description: A man was electrocuted last night in Penn Station after he tumbled from a train platform onto a set of tracks, fire officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACE, DR. WILLIAM
description: PACE-Dr. William. (nee Wulf Peisachowitz.) Passed away June 8, 2000. Born in Shavl, Lithuania in 1902, he was a very prominent physician in Prague. When Hitler arrived, he continued his practice in Shavl. He is a survivor of the Shavl ghetto and of Dachau Lager 10, during which time he is credited with saving numerous lives, repeatedly placing his own at risk. After liberation he helped the allies conquer the typhoid epidemic in Dachau and directed the Jewish Hospital in Munich. He continued his practice in New York, affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital until his retirement. He is survived by his niece, Dr. Bella Pace of Scarsdale, NY and his nephew Dr. Ben Pace of East Hills, NY. Funeral services will be held Sunday, 2:15 at ''The Riverside'' Memorial Chapel at Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENTON, SINGER, MARIANNE
description: BENTON-SINGER-Marianne. On June 8th. Loving wife of Richard. Mother of Jason Zeif and Kate Singer. Friends may call at the Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Rd., Pleasantville, NY., Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral services Monday 10AM, Church of St. John and St. Mary, Chappaqua, NY. Her courage, wit and beauty inspired all who knew her.

title: Famine in North Korea Creates Steady Human Flow Into China
description: Each spring, when the food runs out, the Parks leave their 11-year-old son with neighbors in North Hamgyong Province in North Korea, say they are going to the hospital, and then trudge eight hours along the railroad tracks to China in search of food and cash.

title: Barak Facing Old Dilemma
description: This week the Israeli Parliament engaged in primal scream therapy for a hundred frustrations, some deep-seated, some petty.

title: Op-Art
Jacob Lawrence Is Dead at 82; Vivid Painter Who Chronicled Odyssey of Black Americans
description: Jacob Lawrence, one of America's leading modern figurative painters and, from the beginning of his career in the 1930's, among the most impassioned visual chroniclers of the African-American experience, died yesterday at his home in Seattle after a long illness. He was 82.

title: George Segal, Pop Sculptor, Dies at 75; Molded Plaster People of a Ghostly Angst
description: George Segal, whose rough-surfaced casts of actual people brought a new, often eerie realism to postwar sculpture and made him one of the most quietly influential artists of his time, died yesterday at his home in South Brunswick, N.J. He was 75 years old and had lived in South Brunswick for 60 years.

title: Nary a Hint of Anxiety In an Organized Obbligato
description: The trombonist Roswell Rudd is one of jazz's tricksters. Now 64, he is a New Englander whose career has linked New Orleans (his formal background in Dixieland bands, his rowdy but organized obbligato style) and New York's East Village (his early-60's involvement in what was called the ''new thing,'' with urgent, iconoclastic players like Archie Shepp and Milford Graves). He has been important in the revival of the works of Herbie Nichols, one of the great composers of jazz and a mentor during his younger days. He knows how to use rock and roll musicians perfectly, without condescension or groveling. And he's the kind of guy who writes bossa novas about his dog.

title: Court Orders Parole for Officers' Killer, Held for 36 Years
description: In a rare judicial step, a New Jersey appeals panel today ordered the parole of a 62-year-old convict who has been imprisoned since 1964 for pistol-whipping and fatally shooting two Lodi police officers in a highway bar.

title: Lewis Rejoins the Ravens and Speaks of Ordeal
description: He said he was exhausted and angry. He did not want to talk anymore about his four-month ordeal that began with him facing murder charges in Atlanta and ended this week with his being put on 12 months of probation. Ray Lewis did talk, though, at a news conference today at the Baltimore Ravens' offices. He talked about the past and the future in an attempt for closure.

title: Tsakane Journal; Apartheid Still Burdens A Girl Who Didn't Fit
description: For years, the country girl wished she could wiggle out of her skin and shed her color like the molting snakes that rustled through the green fields. It was the 1960's, and she was the daughter of white Afrikaners who proudly supported the government's brutal system of apartheid and racial segregation.

title: As Zedillo Meets Clinton, U.S. Praises Vote Process
description: Three weeks before Mexicans go to the polls in their most tightly contested presidential race ever, President Clinton warmly received his Mexican counterpart, President Ernesto Zedillo, today, and White House officials expressed confidence in the integrity of the electoral process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLOCK, JOHN L.
description: POLLOCK-John L. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of John L. Pollock, a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: GAO Warns Online Investors
description: GAO Warns Online Investors

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Saturday about the Labor Department's employment report for May misstated the period for a forecast of economic growth made by Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting firm in St. Louis, and misstated the recency of the forecast. And a correction in this space on Tuesday omitted a clarification of the recency. The firm predicted a decline in growth from 4.5 percent in the second quarter to around 3 percent in the second half of the year, not the second quarter. The forecast was the firm's existing one -- not revised as a result of May's employment data.

title: Penicheiro Dominates The Liberty
description: When the Liberty players missed their shots, and that was with stunning frequency last night at Madison Square Garden, Sacramento sent the rebounds directly to point guard Ticha Penicheiro. From there, Penicheiro only accelerated, starting the fast break every time down court with such urgency, it was as if she were entering the autobahn.

title: Lazio Selects Forbes Veteran as Senate Campaign Manager
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio has appointed a veteran strategist for conservative causes to run his campaign for the Senate, campaign officials said yesterday.

title: A Pianist Conducts a Guided Tour Along a Secret Route
description: Marilyn Crispell's piano playing has changed quite a bit since she first appeared in the early 80's. For the most part she has moved in the direction of romanticism and greater structure, and she seems to keep the stations of that journey within herself.

title: Politics Slow Shaky Revival In Indonesia
description: This is a jumpy place at the best of times, so when the earth started shaking last Sunday before midnight, the locals took no chances. Dozens of people fled their high-rise apartments, as windows rattled and water sloshed out of pools.

title: Mutiny Emphatically Ends the MetroStars' Winning Streak
description: When the final whistle blew tonight, the MetroStars stood in their positions for a moment, then walked slowly from the field. The game had never really been in question, as the Tampa Bay Mutiny dominated the action for a 3-0 victory at Giants Stadium, but it was more than just this game that the MetroStars were thinking about.

title: Frederic Dard:Shunned by Critics, Loved by Readers as San-Antonio : A Conjurer With French Language
description: PARIS  Frederic Dard's death this week ended the long, extraordinary career of a man better known as San-Antonio, the swashbuckling, skirt-chasing police commissioner who was the hero (and apocryphal "author") of hundreds of Mr. Dard's books.

title: Creature Comforts For Party Animals
description: Don Henley assumed an unusual stance for a rock star during his show on Thursday at Radio City Music Hall. For much of the performance this singer and songwriter stood with an almost military erectness, his feet aligned and his chest puffed.

title: Pacers Hack the Shaq, but They're the Ones Left Hurting
description: Kobe Bryant was helped from the court, his left ankle swollen. Shaquille O'Neal pushed line drives toward the rim, his free-throw woes building with each successive misfire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COULOUCOUNDIS, ANTHONY
description: COULOUCOUNDIS-Anthony G. On June 8, 2000. Beloved husband of Marina and the late Marion. Cherished father of Roxann Couloucoundis Goldberg, Georgette Parry and the late Anthony Coucloucoundis, II. Father-in-law of Craig and Jeff. Devoted grandfather of Kaitlin, Anthony, William and Nicholas Parry and Marion Goldberg. Dearest brother of Martis and Effie Culucundis and Nina Culucundis. Beloved uncle and cousin of many. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Monday, 6-8PM. Funeral service Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 343 E. 74 St, Tuesday, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Anthony G. Couloucoundis, II Memorial Fund, c/o Allen Stevenson School, 132 E. 78 St, NY NY 10021 attn Ms. Linda Ellenberg.

title: Toward Cleaner Campaigns; Fattening Albany's Cats
description: Contributors planning to send a check to their New York State legislators should now consider this: Their money could be going to feed the office cat, as it did in one state senator's case last year. Or maybe $2,000 would pay another senator's country club dues. The list of ways legislators have spent their campaign bank accounts, now appearing on the Board of Elections Web site, also runs to restaurants or luxury sport utility vehicles or box seats at the Saratoga races.

title: Belmont's Biggest Question: Which Also-Ran Won't Be?
description: On the eve of the 132nd Belmont Stakes, the trainer of the longest shot in the field, the colt Hugh Hefner at 50-1, looked over the 11 horses entered and said rather hopefully, ''I don't think there are any superstars in there.''

title: The Big City; High Notes At the Home Of the C Note
description: THERE comes a moment in every diva's life when Europe's opera houses do not satisfy. It is no longer enough to have triumphed at the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden or at the State Opera House in Vienna. The audiences in Paris bore her. She is not even thrilled by the cheers from the notoriously difficult Milanese at La Scala.

title: Economy May Have a Soft Spot; Swelling Trade Gap Worries Some Experts and Policy Makers
description: If this bionic economy has a soft underbelly, it may be trade.

title: FORMER G.M. EXECUTIVE SOUGHT
description: The United States Justice Department formally petitioned Spain to extradite Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua to stand trial in the United States on charges of industrial espionage. Mr. Lopez left the Opel subsidiary of General Motors in Germany to go to Volkswagen in 1992, and General Motors accused him of stealing vast quantities of documents -- many later shredded -- when he left. Volkswagen pushed out Mr. Lopez in late 1996 and in 1997 settled lawsuits with General Motors. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Governor? Party Chairman? He's Not Seen Anything Yet
description: SHORTLY after he decided this week to accept the offer to become superintendent of the Los Angeles Unified School District, Roy Romer called his oldest child, Mark, 47, to deliver the news. Mark wasted no time telling his 71-year-old father, a former three-term Democratic governor of Colorado, ''You need counseling.''

title: Religion Journal; A Tibetan Buddhist Leader Is Making a Rare Visit
description: By now, many Americans can claim at least a passing familiarity with the 14th Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual and political leader of Tibet. He was well enough known, for example, to have drawn an audience in the tens of thousands for a public teaching he gave in Central Park last August. And, perhaps more to the point, he has had a book, ''The Art of Happiness'' (Riverhead), on the best-seller lists for well over a year.

title: Security Council Extends Oil-for-Food Program Allowing Iraq to Import Necessities
description: With Iraqi profits from oil sales now at record-high levels, the Security Council has extended the ''oil-for-food'' program for another six months to allow the imports of food, medicine and other civilian necessities.

title: Avoiding Child Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Dead Birds Are a Portent Of Return of West Nile Virus
description: Three crows found dead -- two in New York State and one in New Jersey -- were confirmed yesterday as this year's first known victims of the West Nile virus, the mosquito-borne disease that killed seven people in New York City last year, health officials said.

title: Officer Charged With Misdemeanor Assault in Shooting of Teenager
description: A police officer in the Street Crime Unit was charged with misdemeanor assault yesterday in the shooting of an unarmed Bronx teenager last year. The boy's mother said the charge should have been more serious, and police union officials said there should have been no charges at all.

title: Swashbuckling Anarchists Try to Take the $; Out of Cyberspace
description: There was some perverse pleasure to be had last month as the heavy metal band Metallica sued the Web company Napster for copyright infringement. Here is a band that invokes the hounds of hell and mocks gentility with shrieking sarcasm, suddenly championing bourgeois values by insisting on royalty payments. And here are legions of college students supposedly championing Metallican values -- undermining corporate greed, attacking propriety -- when what they are really after in downloading songs from Napster is free music.

title: A Painful Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: First Piazza Slams Clemens, and Then the Fans Do
description: Roger Clemens stepped off the mound in the sixth inning of last night's game at Yankee Stadium and walked steadily into a head wind of boos, the tempest of Yankee fans raging over his horrible performance against the Mets. Never accelerating his amble, Clemens crossed the first-base line, the discontent growing louder, reaching a high pitch before he disappeared into the dugout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAPER, DOROTHY S.
description: DRAPER-Dorothy S. Died peacefully in her sleep at Beth Israel Hospital on the morning of June 9, 2000. She will be missed terribly by all those who survived her: her son, Roger; her sister, Ruth Samberg; her brother-in-law, Mike Samberg; her niece and her nephew-in-law, Eslee Samberg and Eric Marcus; her nephew and her niece-in-law, Mark and Marcee Samberg; and Ran Kohn and her many, many other friends. Services Sunday, June 11th, 2 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Teenage Gunman Critically Injures 2 in Bronx
description: A teenage boy opened fire with a handgun last night in the basketball court of a South Bronx housing development, critically wounding a 12-year-old boy and a 22-year-old man and sending dozens of police officers in bulletproof vests and helicopters on a manhunt, police officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, AARON
description: FINKELSTEIN-Aaron. West End Temple, Neponsit, New York mourns the death of an esteemed member and offers deepest sympathy to his wife, Harriet and family.

title: 9 Horses Die in Fire In Brooklyn Stable
description: At least nine horses died last night when a fire broke out in a Brooklyn stable, fire officials said.

title: East Harlem Shopping Center Snagged Over Financing of Garage
description: It was supposed to bring Manhattan its first Costco and Home Depot superstores and add more than a thousand jobs in East Harlem. But now, plans to build a shopping center along Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive have run into a serious snag because no financing has been found for the $30 million garage that is needed to make the project work, officials said this week.

title: In Connecticut, Cases Multiply Against Police
description: In New Haven, a state grand jury is investigating whether two top police detectives concealed evidence in a 1996 murder case. In Hartford, federal officials have indicted six current or former police officers accused of forcing prostitutes to have sex with them. This spring, two officers in New Milford were convicted of manslaughter in two separate killings.

title: HOUSE APPROVES A BILL TO REPEAL THE ESTATE TAX
description: The House voted today to repeal the federal estate tax, drawing a veto threat from President Clinton even as Democrats joined Republicans in recognizing the issue's political potency.

title: Off the Train, Onto the Block; Auction House to Put Vintage Graffiti on Sale
description: It is a memento from Eddie Rodriguez's past and, in a way, the city's -- a 30-foot-wide canvas that he and some friends painted when they were teenagers in the 1970's. It was a wall-filler in his apartment in the 1980's and a garage-filler after he rolled it up and moved to New Jersey in the 1990's.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday about wavelike hills on the Sun misstated their height. It is about 300 feet, not yards.

title: Dot-Com Volunteer Finds Happiness
description: I'm one of the 140 employees laid off this week by APBNews.com, a news Web site that covered crime and justice. Like everything in the somewhat crazed atmosphere of an online news site, the scene of our firing felt somewhat unreal.

title: A War Over Rent, on Two Coasts
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPEAN GROWTH
description: Europe provided fresh evidence of renewed economic growth, as the European Union reported that the 15-nation group had expanded by about 0.7 percent in the first quarter and exports surged 3.2 percent. The growth was essentially identical in the 11-nation group that has adopted the euro as a common currency. Germany, which accounts for one-third of the euro-zone economy, reported a big jump in industrial production on Thursday and unemployment has dropped for eight consecutive months. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Juniors Take a Loss and Then Nearly a Title
description: The best performance ever by a junior team occurred this week at the International Team Trials in Memphis, where a group of world-class players were fighting for the right to represent the United States in the world championships in Maastricht, the Netherlands, in August.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURMAN, MARY H.
description: FURMAN-Mary H. Of Chatham, NJ on June 7, 2000. Devoted daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Hartung. Beloved wife of the late Earle L. Furman, DDS. Survived by three loving children and their spouses: Marilyn F. and Thomas D. O'Donnell of New York, NY; Richard E. and Carolyn W. Furman of Hickory, NC; and Robert J. and Joan P. Furman of Montvale, NJ. Proud grandmother of Julia, Holly and Christie. Friends may call at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St. (Rt. 124), Chatham, NJ on Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian burial will be held at St. Patrick's Church, Chatham on Saturday, June 10, 2000, at 2:30 PM. The family would appreciate contributions in her memory to the Sarah Ward Nursery, 27 Jay St., Newark, NJ 07103.

title: Columbia Pictures Has New President
description: Columbia Pictures has named Peter Schlessel, who was most recently executive vice president of its Screen Gems and Columbia-TriStar divisions, as the studio's new president of production. The promotion makes him second in command to Columbia's chairwoman, Amy Pascal.

title: Corrections
description: The My Job column on the Workplace page on May 31 about Sam Brown, a horse trainer and riding instructor, omitted the identity of his employers. They are the Montclair Riding Academy in New Jersey and Cedar Lane Stables in Brooklyn.

title: LIBERTY MEDIA GROUP TO ACQUIRE SOUNDELUX BUSINESSES
description: Liberty Media Group agreed yesterday to acquire the post- production and sound business of SounDelux Entertainment Group for $90 million in cash in a deal that replaces one reached last summer. In July 1999 Liberty Media said it would buy a controlling stake in the privately held SounDelux, a Hollywood-based provider of services to the entertainment industry, for stock then valued at $70.3 million. That transaction included SounDelux's location-based entertainment and theater design businesses, which it will retain under the new agreement. Liberty Media, based in Englewood, Colo., is a unit of the AT&T Corporation that trades as a tracking stock for AT&T interests in video programming, communications, technology and Internet businesses.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday by Jeff Greenfield incorrectly identified Adlai Stevenson's running mate in the 1952 presidential election; it was John Sparkman, not Estes Kefauver. The article also misspelled the last name of Henry Clay's running mate in the 1844 presidential election; it is Frelinghuysen, not Freylinghausen.

title: NORTH KOREAN BUSINESS RISKS
description: South Korea's government plans to propose that Pyongyang sign a set of agreements to minimize risks faced by businesses seeking to enter North Korea, according to Lee Ki Ho, the top economic adviser to South Korea's president. Through the proposed agreement, the South Korean government seeks to secure a legal framework to protect investments in the North, while preventing double taxation, and to develop a concerted plan to deal with labor disputes. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: DOMINION RESOURCES SELLS BRITISH POWER UNIT STAKE
description: Dominion Resources Inc., an integrated electric power and natural gas company in Richmond, Va., said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 80 percent stake in the British company Corby Power Ltd. to PowerGen P.L.C. for about $80 million. Dominion said the sale of Corby is part of its strategy of selling noncore assets and focusing on energy markets in the Midwest, Northeast and mid-Atlantic regions of the United States. Shares of Dominion Resources Inc. were up 75 cents at $44.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: House Approves Measure To Repeal Inheritance Tax

title: A Campaign Finance Muddle
description: The House rejected a new disclosure rule, though it plans to revisit the issue. In any case, the measure did not seem to suggest movement on the issue of ''soft money.'' Article and news analysis, Page A11.

title: Drugmaker Wins a Round In Patent Case With Rival
description: Transkaryotic Therapies Inc. won a round in its patent fight with the biotechnology giant Amgen Inc. yesterday when a judge ruled that Transkaryotic did not infringe on one of Amgen's patents covering its best- selling drug.

title: Artists Jacob Lawrence And George Segal Die
description: The art world lost two American originals yesterday, the painter Jacob Lawrence and the sculptor George Segal. Mr. Lawrence, who died at 82, was one of the nation's leading figural painters and a vivid chronicler of the African-American experience. Starting with satirical studies of Harlem street life, he deployed a pared-down, Cubist-inflected style that never lost contact with social reality. Mr. Segal, who died at 75, was best known for full-body plaster casts of real, seemingly ordinary people that conveyed a ghostly sense of the spiritual desolation of modern man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, ALFRED
description: MARKOWITZ-Alfred, MD. Beloved husband of Sydell, devoted father of Dr. Arlene, Dr. David, Dr. Marian Haber, and Amy Rosen. Loving brother of Doris, beloved grandfather of nine. Services 12:30PM, Sunday, Plaza Memmorial Chapel, 91St & Amsterdam Ave. Contributions to the Alfred M. Markowitz Endowment Fund For Scholars, Dept. of Surgery, Columbia University-Millstein Hospital Building, 7th Flr, NY, NY 10032.

title: Brazil Grants Some Legal Recognition to Same-Sex Couples
description: In an action that gay groups describe as the first of its sort in Latin America, the Brazilian government has extended de facto legal recognition to same-sex relationships by granting such couples the right to inherit each other's pension and social security benefits.

title: Studies Thaw The Exploits Of Undercover Cold Warriors
description: In the years since the breakup of the Soviet Union and the opening of its secret files, much has been learned about the accomplishments of Soviet spies in the United States, particularly in the 1930's and 40's. The still-accumulating evidence has silenced some of the truest believers in the innocence of the likes of Alger Hiss and Julius Rosenberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHFIELD, LOUISE M.
description: HIRSHFIELD-Louise M. 81. On June 7, 2000. Survived by daughter and son-in-law Barbara and Glen Thomas of Binghamton, grandson Jason Thomas, nephews Thomas and Walter May. Graveside services will be held Sundy 1PM at the Salem Field cemetery. Memorial contributions to the Temple Concord Youth Fund, 9 Riverside Drive, Binghamton, NY 13905.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, ROSALIND BLUM
description: SCHULMAN-Rosalind Blum, of New York City, age 90, passed away peacefully in her sleep on June 9, 2000. Beloved mother of Susan Linda Schulman and the late Donald M. Schulman, devoted grandmother of Robin Schulman Torriero, loving great-grandmother of Jenifer, Lisa and Jessica, and adored wife of the late Saul T. Schulman. A distinguished child psychologist, she established The Psychological Testing Center in New York City in 1941, and for more than 60 years found great joy in guiding parents and children to the best school for their needs and abilities. She received her B.A. and M.A. in Clinical Psychology from Teachers College, Columbia University, where she taught courses in tests and measurements for many years. She created the original admission program for Hunter College Elementary School and was consulting psychologist for many private schools, including the Professional Children's School, St. David's and St. Hilda's and St. Hughes. She was extremely instrumental in the creation of the Rodeph Sholom Nursery School and later the Day School, and was the pro bono school psychologist for both schools for many years. She continued in private practice until her death. She was a member of the American Psychological Assoc., NY State Psychological Assoc., NY Society of Clinical Psychologists and the American Assoc. of Counseling and Development. She was a NY state certified psychologist and held a Diplomate in School Psychology. She is survived by her daughter, granddaughter, greatgranddaughters, thousands of families she helped and many, many friends. Visiting Saturday 79PM and Sunday 2-4PM. Service Monday, June 12th, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Followed by interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: ADC IN $200 MILLION DEAL FOR CENTIGRAM

Centigram's stock was up $2.75 a share, to $24.75, in Nasdaq trading. Centigram, which is based in San Jose, Calif., had $39.3 million in revenue in the six months that ended on April 29. ADC, based in Minneapolis, develops systems that make voice, data and video signals move faster. ADC had $1.3 billion in sales in the six months that ended on April 30. The economy's inflation rate in the first five months of the year was an annualized 3.4 percent. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

The measure would require disclosure of donors to political slush funds operating under Section 527 of the federal tax code. These tax-exempt funds, created in some cases by members of Congress, have begun raising money from secret sources and running ads promoting or criticizing candidates.

title: Tech 2010: #19 Words to Live By; The Document That Can't Be Forged
description: When Joshua Smith looks at a piece of paper very, very closely, he sees a fingerprint. Smith, who works at a start-up company called the Escher Group, has found that every square centimeter of paper contains a unique pattern of fiber hills and fiber valleys. This square centimeter, he notes, can serve as verifiable proof that the paper -- and thus whatever is written on it -- is the original. Even a perfect photocopy can't capture the texture of the original paper, because the copy is a different piece of paper.

title: NO RIFLE TEAM
description: Scarsdale High School decided last week that it would disband its rifle team. Team members objected, saying the team teaches gun safety. ''It gave the student who is not 6-foot-3 and 200 pounds a chance to participate in a competitive sport,'' said Michael V. McGill, the district superintendent. But, he added, officials decided to disband the team after a bomb scare at the school last year and incidents like the Columbine massacre. Still, he said, the decision was less of a security decision than one of policy. ''We're not afraid our kids will do anything like that,'' he said, ''but it's an issue of what kind of stance does the school have against firearms and youth, and is it still appropriate for us, in the current climate, to have a rifle team? We concluded that this is no longer something that should be sponsored by the school.'' COREY KILGANNON

title: Tech 2010: #22 Heal Thyself; The Severed Limb That Regrows Itself
description: In the future, as today, a newt will lose a power struggle with a predator -- a lizard, say. The lizard will make off with a newt leg, but the rest of the newt will stay behind. There's a bit of blood, but belly to the ground, the newt will retreat to a damp spot under a rock. Several weeks will pass, during which the newt will make its living barely hindered by an incrementally growing stump. In six weeks, the lizard conflict will be nothing but a bad memory: the newt will be walking and swimming with a new limb indistinguishable from the original.

title: E-ZPASS CUTBACK
description: E-ZPass will not be available on every lane of the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway, as originally planned. Last week the Turnpike Authority, which is in charge of E-ZPass installation in the state, announced that 60 lanes on the turnpike and 40 lanes on the parkway will never get E-Z Pass capability, because of escalating costs. The first phase of the work, which will place E-ZPass on 163 of the parkway's 344 lanes and 160 of the turnpike's lanes, is set to be finished in September, pushed back from this month. description: GROUNDEDTake ''neurons,'' add an ''rf'' (for radio frequency) and you've got Motorola's Neurfons project, which aims to embed tiny radio systems in common consumer goods and industrial materials. One possible scenario: silicon chips with moisture sensors and radio transceivers are mixed with fertilizer and scattered throughout a vineyard, say. Each chip measures the moisture in its area and then, powered by heat from the soil, transmits data to a neighboring chip. Eventually, data are collected at the edge of the field by a radio in the sprinkler system. A precise map of water levels throughout the field is produced, making extremely sensitive crop husbandry possible.
