title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDER, SAMUEL LAMIE M.D.
description: FEDER-Samuel Lamie M.D., 84, of Lenox, a renowned psychiatrist, died Sunday, June 4, at his home. Born in Philadelphia, PA on August 12, 1915, the son of Max and Fannie Feder, he attended schools there and received his Bachelor's degree, Magna Cum Laude, from Harvard College in 1937 where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He earned his Medical Degree from Harvard Medical School in 1941 where he was elected to Alpha Omega Alpha Society. He was a VA Fellow in Psychiatry at New York University School of Medicine from 1949-51 and earned a Certificate in Psychoanalytic Medicine at Columbia University in 1955. He became a certified Psychiatrist with the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology in 1957. He was also certified with the American Psychoanalytic Association. During WWII, Dr. Feder was a Major in the Army Medical Corps, serving as Chief of Medicine at a station hospital from 1942-1946 in the Pacific. From 194649 he was a Pathology Fellow and Medical and Radiology resident at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City. From 1949-51 he was Psychiatry Fellow at Bellevue Hospital in New York. He was a department director and lecturer throughout his career at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, Columbia University, Mt. Sinai Hospital and Emory University School of Medicine. He was Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College from 1975-86 and during that time was Clinical Director of the Westchester Division of New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center. Dr. Feder was Acting Medical Director of the Westchester Division of New York Hospital where he was later Associate Medical Director and Senior Psychiatrist, retiring in 1986. Dr. Feder was on many Psychiatric related committees and professional organizations. He authored many papers including ''Psychological Consideration in Care of Patients with Cancer'' (1966) and ''Observation on Patients with Malignant Disease'' (1965). He also co-authored a book, ''Shame and the Development of Autonomy''. Other activities included teaching and clinical supervision in many areas of hospital and ambulatory psychiatry, psychosomatic medicine, liaison psychiatry, psychopharmacology, curriculum development, resident training, undergraduate training, and psychoanalysis. He is survived by his wife Marie, his son, Michael, and daughters Constance Williams and Elizabeth Barrell, his son-in-law Sankey Williams and his daughter-in-law Barbara Manocherian. He is also survived by seven grandchildren, and his sisters Sylvia Kohn and Mathilda Brailove. Services will be private. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Tech 2010: #03 Imbue Your Hue; The Makeup That Changes Your Identity
description: People are willing to put up with almost anything to make themselves a different color. In order to get a bit darker, we're happy to lounge in claustrophobic boxes irradiating ourselves with carcinogenic light or liberally apply self-tanners that oxidize our epidermis like the flesh of a peeled apple. We strip off layers of skin with chemicals to make ourselves lighter, shoot lasers at our dark patches and spread thick ''blending'' makeup over our white spots. Dr. James Nordlund, an expert on the human pigmentary system, offers this explanation: ''People are weird.'' And he thinks we haven't yet begun to plumb the depths of our strange desires. Wait 10 or 15 years, he says, when we might walk into the drugstore, buy a cream that's able to flip our pigmenting mechanism on or off and get as dark or light as we want.

title: Conservation, Far From Home
description: A few weeks ago, the Nature Conservancy announced that it would spend $37 million to buy a remote Pacific atoll from a Honolulu family that had owned it for 80 years. The atoll, Palmyra, seemed an uninviting place, 1,052 miles from Hawaii and largely inaccessible except by small plane. With 15 feet of rainfall a year, Palmyra has only 680 habitable acres at high tide. But the conservancy decided to make the atoll the single most costly purchase in its 49-year history for all the reasons that conservation groups do these things. Palmyra not only is one of the most pristine places left in the tropical Pacific. It also shelters the world's largest land invertebrate, the coconut crab, nourishes tropical trees that have vanished elsewhere and, at a time when most of the world's coral reefs are under siege, encompasses 15,512 acres of healthy reefs with an astonishing variety of aquatic life.

At the same time, they appear to have disproportionately shouldered the stresses brought by a total change of life style.

Amid lush tropical foliage, viewers glimpse isolated, partly clothed figures, often faceless, usually female. Or are they participating in a clandestine sexual encounter with a partner just off-camera? In some of the images, gorgeous exotic flowers emerge from the figures' pulled-down panties as though they had been placed there as part of some bizarre ritual.

Aromatherapy enthusiasts will, no doubt, embrace a shirt that can respond to stress signals by circulating calming vanilla scents or emit energy-boosting geranium spritzes during interminable afternoon meetings.

title: Tech 2010: #13 Feel Secure; The Detective That Every Jury Believes

The tools are not only rudimentary; they also can't even be used without contaminating or destroying some of the evidence at a crime scene. Five years ago, the defense team in the O. J. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOULTON, WILLIAM G.
description: MOULTON-William G. Renowned Professor and Linguistics Scholar. William G. Moulton of Exeter, NH and Quonochontaug, RI died on Friday, June 2 after a long illness. He was 86. Prof. Moulton was an internationally known linguistics scholar, specializing in Germanic languages. Born in Providence, RI, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Princeton in 1935. After teaching at Yale, where he received his Ph.D in 1941, he went to Cornell from 1947 to 1960, and returned to Princeton to teach until he retired in 1979. Middlebury College and the University of Munich awarded him honorary degrees.Prof. Moulton was awarded a Fulbright and two Guggenheim Fellowships. Author of several books and multiple articles, active in the Linguistics Society of America and the Center for Applied Linguistics, he was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. During WWII as a captain in the army he wrote the army language series SPOKEN GERMAN with his wife Jenni, to teach German to American servicemen. As an American, his structural understanding of Germanic languages, from Old and Middle High German to modern day Swiss German, made him unique. His linguistic gift was to make complicated work simple and bring a light touch to serious studies. Prof. Moulton is survived by his wife of 62 years, Jenni Moulton, their daughters Elizabeth Farnham of Exeter, NH, Susan Moultan of Winchester, MA, four grandchildren and his brother David. A memorial service will be held June 16 at Riverwoods in Exeter, NH.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Thoughts of Another Life
description: The characters in Joan Silber's first collection of short stories, IN MY OTHER LIFE (Sarabande, cloth, $21.95; paper, $13.95), are almost all New Yorkers, but not the self-absorbed, ambitious, cell-phone-toting kind. These are plain-spoken middle-aged people, just trying to get by, who imagine themselves better off in another life. In this life, they are drug counselors, bartenders, video store managers and real estate agents; never married, working on second marriages, trying to raise children. They don't consider themselves failures, but realize they might be seen that way. In ''Bobby Jackson,'' the 40-ish narrator looks back on his youth as a bartender, when he experimented with heroin and felt ''drowned in love'' with a waitress named Nancy. That he survived those reckless years is not alarming, just true. ''I was not afraid to die,'' he says plainly. ''I had the dreamy curiosity about death that small children have.'' Now, in the calm of middle age, he is someone ''who takes great private pleasure in things around me. On some days my own apartment seems like a vale of peace and light.'' There's a lot to be said for holding on to what you've got, Silber tells us. In ''Lake Natasink,'' an unconventional relationship is portrayed with quiet honesty and humor. Patty and her lover Charlotte are moving upstate with their newly adopted baby, and tension arises over the transition. Tired of arguing, ''They sit down quietly. They watch the news.'' Silber, the author of two previous novels, treats dysfunction a bit more gently than Lorrie Moore, with whom she shares a marvelous, perspicacious wit. Her characters struggle to keep going, however slowly, without losing their dignity. If they lack fulfillment, memories of old longings seem to suffice. These elegant and wise stories pay tribute to ordinary urban heroes -- people who have lived long enough to know that when misfortune shows up, there's no need to make a fuss. Carmela Ciuraru

The purchases, of land that absorb water during heavy rains, much of which would otherwise be developed, follow 15 years of deliberation over proposals, including one to build a $1.8 billion tunnel to divert flood waters to Newark Bay. The Federal government will finance 75 percent of the purchases and the state the rest.

title: QUICK BITE/Newark; Hungry as a (Newark) Bear
description: The logo for Newark's minor league team is a bear with a baseball in its mouth. On my first trip to see the Newark Bears at Riverfront Stadium, I hoped to find something a bit more appetizing. Stadium food has come a long way from the old standby, a hot dog and a beer. To a traditionalist, diverse delicacies are as unwelcome as the designated hitter. At no point in ''Take Me Out to the Ballgame'' will you hear, ''Buy me some tofu and fish tacos.'' But as baseball competes for America's entertainment dollar, we see more variety, appealing to the appetites of everyone in your family (unless your cousin is the maitre d'hotel at Le Cirque).

At the same time, the students, the engine for action on diversity at most colleges, are making finer and finer distinctions among themselves. It is a generation that defines itself more by its differences than its similarities.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-11-00: Counter Culture; Dot-communist Manifesto
description: A sharp, unexpected twang of conscience hit me the other day. It occurred as I was merrily downloading the umpteenth Pet Shop Boys B side from another Napster user's hard drive. Was this theft? Nobody, I rationalized, was going to be without the Extended Rollo Mix of ''New York City Boy'' because of my actions. All Napster is, after all, is a huge database of MP3 files, a musical commune dreamed up by a college-freshman geek. And sharing a database isn't theft. If you agree to join the Napster ''community,'' you agree to share every MP3 you have with any other Napsterite who is online at the same time you are. It's worth the tiny loss of privacy, because what you get in return is access to more free music than anyone could listen to in a lifetime.

title: Tech 2010: #31 Healthy Living; The Doctor That Floats in Your Bloodstream
description: Imagine you have a heart attack at lunch. Then imagine this: coursing through your capillaries, injected soon after you began to feel chest pain, are countless minuscule cylinders packed with pressurized oxygen, designed to mimic the function of red blood cells (the scale is inconceivably tiny: more than a billion of these ''respirocytes'' could fit inside a single grain of rice). Aboard each artificial red blood cell is a fantastically small computer that guides the respirocyte and tells it when to deliver oxygen to your distressed cells. Instead of collapsing ashen-faced into the arms of an E.R. tech, you finish your lunch, pay your tab and calmly drive to your doctor's office for a follow-up.

Its split-second determination that a piece of food tastes good or bad is a reasonable indication of whether it contains stuff your body needs, like the protein in a big, juicy steak, or stuff that it does not, like the sodium hypochlorite in a spoonful of Drano. Your tongue is not always right -- many things that don't taste good are good for you. But what it lacks in accuracy, it makes up for in speed.

title: From Polynesia, Artwork Fit For Warriors
description: CURATORS, collectors and dealers of tribal art converged last month on Sotheby's in New York to view, gossip about and bid small fortunes for two 19th-century Polynesian rarities: a brilliantly colored Hawaiian feather cape and a curious Austral Islands necklace of whalebone, ivory and human hair. Their obscure histories (they were unknown to scholars until the sale was announced in January) and their freshly restored condition made them hot topics of discussion in tribal art, a field considered one of the most rumor-ridden in today's art market. Such concerns notwithstanding, the objects brought record prices for Polynesian art.

description: For the past four years, a group of writers and researchers has compiled the Dead Media Project, an online archive of obsolete technology started by two science-fiction writers, Richard Kadrey and Bruce Sterling. ''The future arrives through novelty,'' Sterling says. ''We recognize a new period by its technical accomplishments. But the character of everyday life is also influenced by the absence of things.'' Kadrey adds: ''We're probably generating more dead media than at any other moment in history. This is the golden age of cool junk. To understand this is to think differently about where we are and where we're going.'' Herewith, a brief sampling of the working list.

title: BRIEFING: EDUCATION; RUTGERS DRUG ARRESTS
description: Rutgers University's New Brunswick campus had the second highest number of drug arrests among the nation's largest colleges in 1998, according to a survey by the Chronicle of Higher Education. The survey included data from 481 four-year institutions with enrollments of 5,000 or more. The University of California at Berkeley had the most drug arrests, with 280 for the year, and Rutgers came in second with 138 reported drug arrests. There were 358 alcohol-related arrests in Rutgers that year, which did not land it in the top five in that category. According to a statement released by Anthony Murphy, chief of the Rutgers University Police Department, 63 of the drug arrests took place in neighborhoods near the campus that Rutgers officers also patrol.

title: Tech 2010: #08 Sunny Deals; The Mall Where Every Price Is Negotiable
description: It's the day before Christmas, I'm in the middle of my holiday shopping and I'm parched. Looking down at my hand-held mallbot, I notice that McDonald's is offering 16 ounces of Diet Coke at 89 cents, but my bot, whom I call Marty, would fry his silicon if I paid retail. He's a little Palm Pilot-looking gizmo and he can keep track of the price fluctuations of every item in the mall through his little infrared window, and he can haggle them down if I let him. He signals that Diet Rite has tumbled to about two pennies an ounce over at Subway. That means that the teenagers who work as food-court arbitrageurs will be selling Diet Rite to the people in the McDonald's line. I figure Mickey D.'s is going to have to discount deep at the register, so I put in an offer for 63 cents a cup and let the market come to me. I could hold out until after the lunch rush, when prices usually drop 15 percent, but I'm thirsty now. Besides, I want to be back at Macy's in half an hour. It has been oversupplied with my favorite brand of cologne all day, and with the Christmas shopping season over in just a few hours, there are signs of panic sweeping across the store's entire male-fragrance sector.

Yet those who do know her are drawn to her, as proven by the large and enthusiastic audience at her ''80th Year Retrospective'' -- she doesn't turn 80 until July 13 -- last weekend at the Cowell Theater here.

title: Finding New Audiences For Alienation
description: IF the death of celebrated artists is often followed by diminished interest in their work, Samuel Beckett has been luckier than most. He did not have to wait a generation for a admirer to find him a new public. In Michael Colgan, the artistic director of Dublin's Gate Theater, he had a ready apostle. Indeed, a Beckett revival was already in the works even before the Irish-born playwright died at 83 in Paris in 1989.

As they slipped copies of the tape, called Videograf 2000, into cardboard covers, a knock sounded at the door.

title: Tech 2010: #32 Everlasting; The Genius Who Sticks Around Forever
description: They say that wisdom accumulates, that perhaps it is not subject to the same ticktock corrosion that renders bones frail and hair thin. They say it is our one real treasure, this thing to be passed on, generation to generation, to grant us a stay against a dark, dim future. And so we have Greek lectures transcribed by diligent pupils; sketches by Leonardo; a collection of Gertrude Stein's writing; the fireside scratch of a chatty F.D.R.; a cinematic tour of Stephen Hawking's universe; and now, at this great, late date, we have Timothy Leary charting his last days just a mouse-click away. But what we don't have is the people themselves; we don't have their consciousnesses, and that is the real loss. And, if you believe the believers, that is all about to change.

title: CAMDEN PROSECUTOR REPLACED
description: In the first move made since the state took over the financial operations of Camden last month, Municipal Prosecutor Patricia Bowen Atkins was fired last week after the discovery in her office of uncashed checks and unfilled requests for trial information dating from late 1998, as well as three months of unopened mail. On May 10 the state took over the financial operation of the city because of gross fiscal mismanagement. The situation in Ms. Atkins's office was uncovered after a city police officer refused a request to shred documents from the office, according to Lee Solomon, Camden County prosecutor. KAREN DeMASTERS

description: SANDRA LEVINSON, the director of the Center for Cuban Studies in Manhattan, was exhilarated as she stepped into the elevator of her hotel here one afternoon in February. Luis Rodriguez Ricardo, a young naive artist, had finished the painting he had promised Ms. Levinson to illustrate a brochure for a tour sponsored by the center. She balanced the work, ''The Arrival,'' a jubilant view of the Santiago de Cuba harbor in full fete, on her hip, moving aside as a French group entered.

Call him Captain Dad, Mark Messiah, the Frozen Chosen, but as the grandstand Beast knows, only he can justify its cry, ''We want cup!''

description: In response to the popularity of mountain biking, the county has opened a network of trails at Sprain Ridge Park in Yonkers. Five miles will be marked according to proficiency, so beginners can practice on some trails and progress to others. Sprain Ridge is the county's third park designated for mountain bicycling. Blue Mountain Reservation in Peekskill has trails for all levels of ability, while Graham Hills Park in Pleasantville is geared toward more experienced cyclists. ELSA BRENNER

description: Two renovations have brought a bold postmodern twist to New Orleans's upscale hotel scene, where furnishings tend to be antique, real or fake, fabrics are often flowery, and charm has long been mandatory.

title: At AT&T, Memories Of a Similar Air of Denial
description: COMPARISONS can be overdrawn between the proposed breakup of Microsoft and the dismemberment almost 20 years ago of AT&T. But veterans of the Bell System's split see at least one clear parallel: the sense of denial within AT&T was as strong then as it appears to be at Microsoft now.

title: One More Kiss Goodbye
description: It might seem silly that four men in heavy theatrical makeup, old enough to cash in on their A.A.R.P. discounts, are running around a concert stage. In black leather tight enough to reveal paunches, they make sexual innuendo and indulge in campy pyrotechnics. This is the Kiss Farewell Tour, coming to the Blockbuster Sony Entertainment Center in Camden on Friday and the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford on June 27.

title: POSTINGS: 13 Companies Form a Consortium; Uniting to Tap The Internet
description: In a joint effort to use the power of the Internet, 13 large commercial property companies have agreed to form an organization called the Office Technology Consortium. The companies, which own or manage over 400 million square feet of space, say they want to use the scale of their operations as well as Internet technologies to improve business processes and industry service standards.

title: Working Out Beyond the Limitations of Age
description: GOING to a gym when your figure is not quite svelte isn't easy. For those who are obese, elderly, sedentary or have chronic health conditions like asthma, walking the treadmill at a snail's pace or struggling to lift a five-pound weight can seem downright humiliating. And without monitoring, it may not even be safe.

title: Once a Tar Heel . . .
description: Tony Earley doesn't live in North Carolina anymore, but the only real blot on what he calls his ''impeccable North Carolina credentials'' is that ''by military accident'' he was born in Texas and lived there for the first year and a half of his life.

title: Robert Altman's Decade of Astonishments
description: ROBERT ALTMAN turned 75 this past February, and he is working still. He has never won an Oscar, or had anything like an honorary statuette for his career. No Irving Thalberg award has come his way. Yet he has been nominated as best director four times, for ''M*A*S*H,'' ''Nashville,'' ''Short Cuts'' and ''The Player.'' I am sympathetic to all four pictures, but if they rate a nomination, what are we going to do about such unequivocally great works as ''The Long Goodbye,'' ''McCabe and Mrs. Miller'' and ''3 Women''?

title: Of Rather and the Rugrats
description: Dan Rather is one of the last of the great, booming, authoritative voices in network journalism. He is TV news straight, no chaser. Warm and cuddly he is not. The Rugrats, however, are. These animated brats, with their own cartoon show on Viacom's Nickelodeon channel, are as devilish as they are cute.

title: Residents Gaze Longingly At Parks Across the Border
description: At a meeting of Democratic Assembly members in Albany last month, Assemblywoman Audrey I. Pheffer interrupted a discussion about a $100 million bailout for Nassau County to raise an old complaint. Nassau County residents can use city parks in Queens, she said, but Queens residents cannot use county parks.

title: Border-Hopping In Basque Country
description: THERE was nothing remotely spooky about the sparkling August day on which my husband, G. J., and I checked into El Emperador, a parador in the Basque town of Hondarribia in northern Spain. Even the severe 16th-century stone facade of this former castle-fortress seemed welcoming and golden, washed as it was by the afternoon sun. Nonetheless, near the end of our stay we were told about Celedonio, the parador's resident phantom. The congenial apparition is a nobleman who is thought to have once lived in what is now one of Spain's most popular historic hotels. Neither G. J. nor I made his acquaintance during our four-day stay, but many other guests have, said the parador's director, Pilar de Miguel Hernando, who has herself seen him four times. Celedonio is a good ghost, she claimed, a smiling figure who usually appears in January and February, the parador's quietest months.

title: Eviction Specialist: 'This Is Not Easy'
description: One cool day this spring, Jose Reyes, Placido Cruz, Mark Hubbard and Melvin Rivera started their morning in Bayside, Queens. They parked their truck outside a residential building at 10 a.m., took the elevator to the fifth floor and knocked on an apartment door. This was not a typical assignment. These men work for Traffic Moving Systems, which specializes in moving evicted tenants out of their homes. The Yonkers company, founded by Bob Sardina in 1989, is frequently called on by landlords.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, JACOB
description: LAWRENCE-Jacob. Age 82. Born Atlantic City, NJ 1917. Died peacefully at his home in Seattle, WA June 9, 2000. Survived by his beloved wife of 59 years Gwendolyn Knight. Jacob Lawrence was a gracious and generous man of enormous talent and integrity who remained true to his unique artistic vision for over 60 years. His devotion to teaching and encouragement of younger artists was unparalleled. His humanistic approach to life and art was an inspiration to all who knew him. We will treasure and honor our memories of his inestimable friendship. Memorial Service in New York to be announced. Donations in lieu of Flowers to Jacob and Gwendolyn Lawrence Foundation, 300 Commercial Street, Boston, MA 02109. Bridget Moore, Edward DeLuca and the staff of DC Moore Gallery

title: The Past, Neatly Packaged
description: HEAD northeast in Newfoundland along the Bonavista Peninsula until the rough road ends and the cold ocean begins, and you'll find a bronze statue of a man clothed in pouffy Renaissance garb overlooking tumultuous seas. The landscape has a distinctly edge-of-the-known-world feel to it: icebergs float offshore like errant mountaintops, humpback whales feed and breach, and puffins dart along the ocean surface to and from their island colony just around the point.

But this year, the 34th annual festival, which opens next Saturday will have 90 performers on five stages, including Dar Williams, Holly Near, Janis Ian, Pete Seeger, Vance Gilbert, Josh White Jr. and the Children's Gospel Choir of Peekskill.

title: Helping Ad Icons Grow Up
description: FOR more than a hundred years, thirsty consumers who didn't even know her name have recognized Psyche the nymph as the symbol of White Rock soda. Now, however, slumping sales and a younger target audience have prompted White Rock to give its fragile, bare-breasted bottle girl a bolder look. The company is favoring a Psyche depicted only in outline with a few deft brush strokes, and who is neither crouched on a rock nor gazing into a pool.

title: Uggams as Callas In 'Master Class'
description: THINK Maria Callas, ascending to the pinnacle of fame and fashion, her every calculated scene, on or offstage, a photo-op. Then came the fatal descent of her career and of her life. Tosca, in her death leap from a parapet atop the Castel Sant'Angelo, is a symbol of the Callas impulse to self-destruct.

Douglas Eisele of Caracas, Venezuela, and David T. Eisele of Paris, TX. Also survived by great-nieces and great-nephews. Notice of memorial service later.

title: Hafez al-Assad, Who Turned Syria Into a Power in the Middle East, Dies at 69
description: Hafez al-Assad, the air force officer who ruled Syria for three decades, transforming a Middle East backwater into an introverted regional power that endured as the center of unbending Arab hostility toward Israel, died yesterday in Damascus. He was 69.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-11-00: Phenomenon; Canceled Flight
description: A stunning array of technological innovations has been woven into the day-to-day fabric of early-21st-century life: clothing made from recycled plastic Coke bottles; phones that run on high-frequency microwave radiation; snack-food science capable of containing such unruly forms as s'mores and peanut butter and jelly within the confines of a toaster pastry. Yet for some of us, such marvels are slim compensation for the unrealized possibilities of another device, one promised throughout childhood and never delivered. Where are our jetpacks?

title: Pacers Look to Home Floor and to Absence of Bryant
description: It is the most celebrated new arena in the National Basketball Association, a tribute to a time when players took set shots and wore canvas sneakers. It is part museum, part coliseum and a lot of magic for the Indiana Pacers.

description: Bashar al-Assad, the presumptive new president of Syria, has waited in the wings of power for six years, nurturing a reputation as an accessible and progressive man who wants to satisfy the yearning of many Syrians to be part of the modern world.

title: Walking the Williamsburg
description: EVERY New York tourist attraction has a hipper alter ego. For Shakespeare in the Park, there's Shakespeare in the Parking Lot; for P.S. 1, there's P.S. 122; for the Rainbow Room, there's the view from your accountant's 49th-floor window.

title: Habitats/100 John Street in the Financial District; 3 Dot-Com Partners Find 4-Story House in the Sky
description: ALL those baby boomers who envy the wealth of the young Internet moguls can take solace, at least, in this: the dot-commers may live in fabulous places, but they often work so hard they have little time to exploit the opportunities for fun their good fortune presents.

title: Tech 2010: #29 Wait No More; The Elevator You Never Have to Wait For
description: No more staring at closed elevator doors, repeatedly pressing a call button in frustration. No more standing at the rear of the car, willing the elevator to make it to your floor without another God-forsaken stop. No more traveling dumbly up and down, a modern-day Babbitt in a tin can in its dark and solitary shaft.

title: The Republicans Are Coming, The Republicans Are Coming,; For the State's Rank-and-File, It's Spit and Polish
description: KATHY ROACH practices her best handshake and smile in a simple exercise she and 25 other eager participants act out during an orientation session for the ''Philadelphia Friends,'' a select corps of volunteers who have agreed to be on call 24 hours a day when Republicans converge on Philadelphia next month for its quadrennial national convention.

title: Author, Doctor and, Now, Educator
description: FOR every student who has ever sat in school and thought, ''Someday, when I run the place . . . '' Dr. Eve Rice's recent election to the Byram Hills school board may offer hope.

title: EXTENDED INSPECTION DEADLINE
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency last week granted the Division of Motor Vehicles another extension of the deadline -- to Aug. 1 -- for getting the enhanced emissions tests in place at all motor vehicle inspection stations, said Mary Mears, an E.P.A. spokeswoman. A few of the stations that have only one or two lanes still cannot perform the enhanced emissions tests. The state said it needed the delay beyond the original June 30 deadline to set up an appointment system at those stations to avoid long lines for the enhanced tests.

title: Microsoft's Future
description: Executives at Microsoft say they have not yet discussed how to carry out a judge's order to split the company. But consultants warn that Microsoft runs risks if it fails to lay plans quickly.

In disk-golf parlance, I faced a dogleg right to a Pole Hole nearly 180 feet away and to the left, tucked behind a distant copse.

description: What man wouldn't want the gift of never having to ask for directions? Red Maps' Essential Guides for Urban Explorers offer sleek, high-design maps with detailed information on museums, architecture, shops, theaters and hotels. Beginning two years ago with a shopping guide to SoHo, Red Maps recently added two more maps of New York (Midtown and all of Manhattan), as well as guides to Los Angeles, San Francisco, Washington and Las Vegas.

description: Q Does a co-op board have the right to limit the percent of financing that buyers of sponsor units are allowed to obtain? . . . Lewis Hadow, the Bronx.

title: Making Sure There's No Paper Trail
description: LES CHEIKIN owes his business, in large part, to a 1988 Supreme Court ruling that anything put in the trash in a public area can be taken and read by anyone. The rise in corporate espionage has also been good for his business.

title: Feminism in Art, With Respect
description: MIRIAM SCHAPIRO has no trouble with labels. Being called a feminist artist is something she accepts, even relishes.

title: Pets Flying as Cargo, Not Checked as Luggage
description: SEVERAL major airlines announced rules last month restricting pets traveling as passengers' checked luggage in the baggage compartments of planes, at least during the summer. But industry sources say that seasonal embargoes are just the beginning and that airlines are soon likely to require that pets going by air be handled by commercial shippers, a more expensive proposition for the owners. A medium-size dog traveling as luggage may cost $50 one way; shipped professionally, with someone charged with going to retrieve the kennel if the weather turns bad or the flight is canceled, the cost may be $700.

title: Anna Sosenko, 90, Producer, Songwriter and Stars' Friend
description: Anna Sosenko, the songwriter who wrote ''Darling, Je Vous Aime Beaucoup,'' the manager of Hildegarde -- the legendary cabaret personality who made the song famous -- and the impresario of stage specials that featured such performers as Mary Martin and Ethel Merman, died Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

title: Test Scores Are Up. From This We Can Conclude that the schools are doing:
description: In this era of standardized student testing, it has become an all-too-familiar ritual in New York City and across the country: the leader of the school system calls a news conference and holds a wedding or a funeral, crowing if scores are up, grieving and accepting blame if they are down.

title: Black Magic
description: The Fly-Truffler By Gustaf Sobin. 155 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: Bookend; The Prophecy of Hester Prynne
description: Reading ''The Scarlet Letter'' again, I imagine Hester Prynne as she steps out of the Boston jail. She carries her out-of-wedlock baby in her arms but does not hide the ''A'' she wears on her breast. Her crime, though it will never be named in the book by more than an initial, is placed on exhibition. Yet she has converted the letter into her own statement by fantastic flourishes of gold embroidery. She is a mystery beyond the reach not only of her fellow Bostonians but also of the reader. To the end of her story she will be someone whose final meaning is as obscure as her reasons for blazoning the letter so that it looks like a badge of honor while it reinforces her condemnation.

title: NEW TRAIN SERVICE
description: The Metro-North Railroad is adding 18 weekday trains, more service in the Bronx and two new stations, Wassaic and Tenmile River, beginning July 9. On the Hudson line, two new morning departures from Tarrytown, at 6:54 a.m. and 7:12 a.m., have been scheduled. In Cortlandt, the 7:46 a.m. express from the Croton-Harmon train station will originate at Cortlandt at 7:37 a.m. And to meet rider requests for more express service to and from Irvington, Ardsley, Dobbs Ferry and Hastings-on-Hudson, new peak time expresses are being introduced. On the New Haven line, there is new, off-peak weekday inbound service from Harrison and a summer Friday-only express to New Haven. ELSA BRENNER

title: Casting Sculpture That Can Land in Front Yards
description: FOR the last 18 years, Argos Art Foundry in Brewster has been casting fine-art sculpture. Of the thousands of pieces cast at the foundry each year, the bulk of it goes to galleries or commercial installations around the world, but about 20 percent goes directly into private homes.

title: South Africa In Quandary: Should Gays Donate Blood?
description: Endowed with a bill of rights that is one of the world's most expansive and beset by an AIDS crisis that is one of world's worst, South Africa finds itself trying to reconcile the two in the face of a challenge to its practice of disqualifying gay men from giving blood.

description: There was no Triple Crown hanging in the balance. There was no showdown between the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winners. But a large, high-spirited crowd of 67,810 braved a muggy day for the 132nd running of the Belmont Stakes yesterday, as well as a rich, competitive undercard of stakes races.

description: A PUBLIC debate Monday on the health effects of low-level radiation at Brookhaven National Laboratory raised a common issue: that the data on which most radiation health studies are based may be fundamentally flawed.

title: In Bathroom Graffiti, More Than a Good Time
description: Help-wanted ads are freighted with economic significance far out of proportion to their humble dimensions. Economists put rulers to them to measure economic health. Newspapers depend on them for a big part of their profits. Pundits use their migration to Web sites to ring the papers' death knell.

title: Jill Simpson, Jonathan Owens
description: Jill Astrid Simpson, the daughter of Joyce Shallis of Milford, Conn., and Allan Claude Simpson of Long Island City, Queens, is to be married today to Jonathan James Owens, the son of Caroline and James Rigueur Owens Jr. of Westport, Conn. The Rev. William Simpson, a United Methodist minister and an uncle of the bride, officiated at the Unitarian Church in Westport.

title: Don't Tell
description: To the Editor: About ''One Traveler's Credo: Don't Tell, Don't Ask'' by Robert Packard (April 2), Mr. Packard's advice to check your travel monologue at the door was sage and well founded. Trip tales with visuals rank right up there with stories of grandchildren and hospital stays with H.M.O. complications. It is difficult, when trapped with a ''reliving the harrowing-experience-at-30,000-feet'' ex-vacationer not to utter ''Next time buy a one-way ticket!''

title: Tech 2010: #02 The Plush Life; The Lawn That Never Needs Mowing
description: Measured in raw acreage, grass is the country's largest single crop; more than that, it gives shape and meaning to the weekend for millions of Americans. But within just a few years, powerful growth-regulating chemicals now available only to professional groundskeepers will put a picture-perfect lawn within easy reach of even the laziest Joe Mow. And that's just the beginning.

title: Rescuing a Romantic Epic From Obscurity
description: THE ranks of the great film directors are short on Keatses and Shelleys, young artists cut off in their prime, leaving behind a handful of great works that suggest what might have been. But one who qualifies is Jean Vigo, the French director who died of tuberculosis at age 29 in 1934. Vigo completed just four films (two of them brief, avant-garde documentaries) before his death, but his two dramatic features, ''Zero de Conduite'' (1933) and ''L'Atalante'' (1934) possess an originality and a depth of emotion that have earned him a well-deserved spot in the pantheon.

title: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Church
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gift to the Wealthiest
description: Seldom have so many voted for a gargantuan tax cut for so few. The House voted overwhelmingly Friday, 279 to 136, to repeal the federal estate tax -- a tax so focused on the rich that it hits only about 2 percent of all estates. Sponsors claimed to be acting on behalf of families who inherit a family farm or business only to find that they are forced to sell the property to pay the ''death tax.'' But among the estates that are now subject to taxation, only about 3 percent are farms or family businesses, and there are better ways to get relief to them.

title: Straight to the Heart Of Value Investing
description: Warren Buffett is not a man given to emotional displays. But he appeared genuinely moved recently when Barbara Dodd Anderson, the daughter of David Dodd, co-author with Benjamin Graham of ''Securities Analysis,'' presented him with her father's own copy of the first edition, with his annotations. This landmark 1930's book on value investing has been the basis for Mr. Buffett's strategy.

title: Will a Onetime Jazz Mecca Make Room for a Pancake House?
description: In 1925, when Ed Smalls opened Smalls's Paradise, a nighclub for black and white patrons that offered jazz, Chinese food and waitresses on roller skates, it was quickly called ''the hottest spot in Harlem.''

title: June 4-10; Shorter Lives for Americans
description: By most demographic estimates, an American born in the last year or two should live, on average, to nearly 77. But the World Health Organization, using a new calculation, has lowered the figure for ''healthy life expectency'' to 70 because of the risks faced by Americans, particularly men -- smoking and violence are high on the list. BARBARA CROSSETTE

title: Yankees Expected to Sign Gooden
description: Dwight Gooden has already been traded by the Astros and released by the Tampa Bay Devil Rays this season, but the Yankees have seen enough to want him. They are expected to announce today that they are signing the 35-year-old Gooden to a minor league contract.

description: Harvard's men's heavyweight varsity won the 135th rowing of its tradition-steeped race with Yale, beating the Elis in the four-mile upstream Thames River course in Gales Ferry, Conn., by two and a half boat lengths.

description: International Business Machines Corporation and nine companies have created e2open.com -- a global business-to-business e-marketplace for the computer, electronics and telecommunications industries. The other companies are Hitachi, LG Electronics, Matsushita Electric (Panasonic), Nortel Networks, Seagate Technology, Solectron, Toshiba, Ariba and i2.

title: Creating Dance Music Worth Sitting Through
description: ONE of my favorite records last year was an album that virtually nobody in the United States has heard and one that will be difficult for most people to find there. It's called ''Stadtansichten,'' a various-artists compilation on the Berlin-based MFS label. It's an album of what could be called electronic dance music, a genre the music industry in America has saddled with the unfortunate moniker of electronica in an effort to get people to buy it without thinking of words like disco or techno, which seem to have an unfortunate effect in the marketplace.

title: Yeshivas of Traditional Orthodoxy Flourishing
description: Down a narrow lane near the western outskirts of this city, wood-framed country houses and arching trees impart a rural feel, giving no hint that nearby is a place where a special kind of intellectual intensity rules the day.

title: Rumba, the Heartbeat of Cuban Music
description: IMAGINE a Grammy Awards show in which every musical segment before the grand finale was devoted to field hollers: century-old songs that hark back directly to African music. Audiences would be startled, wondering why anything so antique was on the air; recording companies would chafe because they'd want to promote more current styles. But when Cuba's annual awards for recordings, the Cubadisco prizes, were given out on May 24 at the Teatro Nacional here, there were roars of applause for group after group playing rumba, the style at the deepest roots of Cuban music.

title: Tech 2010: #28 Working It Out; The Company Where Everybody's a Temp
description: A company in Valencia, Calif., called 3D Systems makes a startlingly futuristic contraption that might best be described as a three-dimensional fax machine. Instead of spitting out a mere piece of paper, it produces an actual object. A ThermoJet office printer, working from a digital blueprint, squirts out precise drops of hot plastic to make the proper shape. The resulting object can be anything, a blender, say, or a cell phone, and ready in just hours. Sadly, you won't be able to make a milkshake with that blender or place a call on the phone, but the 3-D fax machine is prized by companies that do a lot of industrial design. It enables a group of people, spread out anywhere on the planet, to collaborate in a way that only recently would have required them to be in the same place.

title: Tech 2010: #17 Top Secet; The Code That Can't be Broken
description: The technology that will cashier the linguists, mathematicians and hackers who have traditionally devoted themselves to breaking codes comes with a cool name: quantum cryptography. Ordinary cryptographic systems rely on scrambling messages so thoroughly that only a recipient with a code key can unscramble them. Quantum cryptography uses random codes lacking in any pattern that might offer clues to a code breaker. More important, it allows the parties transmitting the code to send it without the fear that it might be intercepted without their knowledge. The result? Unprecedented secrecy and security -- two commodities that are increasingly rare in a world dominated by the free flow of information. For futurists, the development of quantum cryptography is a kind of cosmic victory for personal privacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNSHINE, NATHAN
description: SUNSHINE-Nathan. Of East Chester, NY. Retired President of Adler Shoe Shops, Inc. Beloved father of Laura. Dear brother of Milton. Services Sunday 11:30 AM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY.

title: On a Mission to Cuba, Bearing Balanchine
description: PLEASE don't laugh,'' says Lourdes Lopez, a former principal dancer of New York City Ballet, ''but I had a sort of second coming.'' Ms. Lopez, who left her native Cuba when she was one year old, is describing her first trip back here in 1997, at the age of 39. ''For the first time I felt like I belonged somewhere.''

title: On Foot, From Village to Village, on Galicia's Coast
description: I HOPPED on the bus with the sign that said ''End of the World Transport,'' and soon was speeding down the road toward the Coast of Death. In the Galician language, both the name of the bus company (Transportes Finisterre) and my destination (Costa da Morte) sounded far less apocalyptic. Still, the translations reminded me that the country I was about to traverse on foot, the rocky, sea-swept corner of northwestern Spain called Galicia, was considered by medieval Europeans to be the limits of the known universe, home to powerful unseen spirits.

title: Somewhere Between Big Bird and Buffy

title: Kathleen Busch, Ethan Luce
description: Kathleen Maura Busch, a college administrator, and Ethan Craig Luce, a radar engineer, were married on Cape Cod yesterday. Msgr. Aloysius J. Busch, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Joan of Arc Church in Orleans, Mass.

title: Tech 2010: #23 The Winner Within; The Coach Who Will Put You in The Zone
description: A sprinter crouches in the starting blocks, body and mind quiet, thoughts focused: 100 meters of dash for an Olympic gold medal ahead. Two lanes away, legs twitching, eyes darting, vagrant notions race through the mind of another competitor: a sore ankle, potential fame, bad breakfast; relax, says his inner voice, growing desperate, come on, come on, come on. For an elite athlete, trying to concentrate in the moment of greatest stress, finding the focus and groove known as the zone can mean the difference between first place and fourth, a smiling face on a Wheaties box and abiding regret.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, HENRY DR
description: GREENE-Henry Dr. Renaissance man thrived unchallenge. Hank Green (Dr. Henry Greene), internationally known artist and performer, died of prostate cancer. He served with distinction during WWII as Commander of an LCT landing craft. Hank earned a doctorate in education and served as assistant principal at Tilden High School for 36 years. He was truly a renaissance man. He was a highly acclaimed square dance caller, professional singer and band leader. Hank was also a published poet, artist and sculptor, whose works were displayed for years in well known art galleries. He was an outstanding athlete, excelling at basketball, baseball and tennis and rode a unique ''Side By Side'' bicycle with his wife Charlotte throughout Europe. Most recently, Hank achieved success as a professional magician performing on such prestigious cruise lines as the QEII. Hank is survived by Charlotte, his wife of 58 years, and two sons, Gregory Greene and Dr. Richard Greene. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to a research foundation dedicated to the treatment and eventual cure of prostate cancer-addressed to: Dr. Cy Stein, Columbia University, 630 W. 168 St, New York, NY 10032

title: Our Crowd
description: I WONDER whether the chef at Cortina Ristorante has spring fever. Or perhaps the manager is more interested in the live music than the service. Because something doesn't seem to be right here. The place just does not live up to the glowing reviews I've read. The atmosphere is not that of an elegant Italian dining room but rather a baroque hotel lobby in Florida. The servers were forgetful yet unrepentant, often insisting that each plate be finished -- plates piled high with food made by chefs I wish I could call innovative.

title: Texas Lawyer's Death Row Record a Concern
description: On death row at the Terrell unit of the Texas state prison in Livingston, an hour's drive north of here, inmates and death penalty lawyers refer sardonically to a place they call the Mock Wing. This metaphorical prison enclave has housed at least a dozen death row inmates, some already executed, others awaiting their final punishment, who shared the same lawyer, Ronald G. Mock.

title: Freedy Johnston at Maxwell's
description: Freedy Johnston possesses exceptional ingenuity for composing austere pop songs and has been compared with Elvis Costello and Bob Dylan. His 1992 album ''You Can Fly'' and 1994's ''This Perfect World'' captivated listeners with complex fatalistic narratives and abstruse melodies. His more recent sound, as demonstrated on ''Blue Days, Black Nights'' has headed toward the Jackson Brown-James Taylor school of laid-back singer-songwriter fare.

title: At Yale, Three Small Exhibitions With Larger Thoughts in Mind
description: THREE small shows at the Yale Art Gallery in New Haven have a larger import than their compactness would indicate. They make their points concisely, but precisely and suggestively, and thereby stimulate big thoughts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, LOUIS ISAAC
description: KANE-Louis Isaac. On Friday, June 9, of Boston and Ogunquit, ME. Husband of Katharine D. Kane. Father of Dr. Holliday Kane Rayfield and her husband Rick Rayfield, Jenny Kane and Joseph Daniels Kane. Grandfather of Sophie Alexander Rayfield. Son of George E. Kane of Boston and the late Sally (Smith) Kane. Nephew of the late Charles E. Smith. Brother of Ann Kane Collier and her husband Marvin Collier of Boston. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. He received the A.B. from Harvard College 1953 and completed service in the U.S. Marine Corps as a Captain in 1959. Mr. Kane was Chairman of Au Bon Pain Corp., Co-chairman of the Harvard College Fund and recently received the Harvard Medal. Past Chairman of the West End Boys & Girls Club and Trustee of Bentley College. Shiva at his home at 20 River Rd., Ogunquit, ME (207-646-7471) on Sunday, 7-9 PM, and continuing Monday through Thursday, 1-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Remembrances may be made to the West End House, 105 Allston St., Allston, MA 02134, Ogunquit Museum of American Art, Ogunquit, ME 03907 or Harvard College, c/o Harvard College Fund, 124 Mt. Auburn St., Cambridge, MA 02138. For information, the Levine Chapels, Brookline.

Others, like fans of the British band the Cure, like to wallow in misery, at home and in stadiums. Well, New Jersey Goths can rejoice, or to be precise, they can find something less horrible than daily existence to look forward to, because Robert Smith and his Cure are coming to the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel at 8 p.m. Friday and the Blockbuster Sony Entertainment Center in Camden at 8 p.m. next Sunday.

title: Shut Air-Conditioner, Get Thanks From LIPA

title: Tech 2010: #05 The Morning Glide; The Jet That Sees the Runway
description: The problem with the Concorde is that its pilots need a window to take off and to land. Enabling pilots to see is what results in that heavy, drooping nose, and the nose is what makes the Concorde a somewhat sluggish supersonic plane.

title: June 4-10; Perot May Not Run
description: In his quest for the Reform Party's presidential nomination, Patrick J. Buchanan got a major lift when a spokesman for Ross Perot, the party's founder and two-time nominee, said Mr. Perot had all but decided not to seek the nomination this year. That's bad news for Mr. Buchanan's opponents, who fear he will impose his conservative social views on a party that has taken no official position on such issues. John Hagelin of the Natural Law Party, which favors across-the-board government reform, is preparing to fight Mr. Buchanan for the nomination. MICHAEL JANOFSKY

title: Gutters: There's a Type to Suit You
description: GUTTERS are an important part of any house. They capture rainwater running down from the roof and they route it through the downspouts away from the house. This helps to keep basements and crawl spaces dry, prevent topsoil erosion and shield windows and doors from water penetration.

description: There is the well-known sociological phe nomenon known as Nimby not in my backyard. But in this era of otherwise conspicuous prosperity, this is a tale of a lesser-known impulse -- not on your front lawn.

description: LIKE ''cabriolet'' and ''sedan,'' the word ''limousine'' was passed on from carriage makers. Once a carriage with a roof projecting over the chauffeur's seat, it came to mean a long car carrying a V.I.P.

title: The Summer House, Reinvented in England
description: Anyone who wants to find out what a sitooterie is should head for Belsay Hall in northeast England this summer. Scattered around the 30-acre landscaped garden of this grand house built in Greek revival style by Sir Charles Monck in 1817 are 12 sitooteries, the Scottish colloquialism for a structure to sit ''oot'' in. Twelve leading architects, including Sir Norman Foster, Claudio Silverstrin and Julian Opie, have designed contemporary interpretations of the traditional summer house and pavilion, which will be exhibited through Sept. 30 at Belsay Hall in Northumberland.

title: A Movie Wardrobe for Streetwise Pops
description: Golf sweaters? Rep ties? As John Shaft, the detective hero in John Singleton's coming remake of ''Shaft'' might say, shut your mouth! For fathers with serious style, Giorgio Armani has designed a line of clothing based on the ''Shaft'' wardrobe created for the movie's star, Samuel L. Jackson. Urban and streetwise, the line includes the signature three-quarter-length Shaft leather jacket ($1,298), with raw-cut edges and unfinished seams. There are also turtlenecks and sexy knits ($228 for each), and even black leather pants ($698). While the look may be a bit of a departure from the traditional Father's Day fare, every man deserves a little sartorial adventure. After all, Dad's the original cat who won't cop out when there's danger all about. At Emporio Armani, (877) 736-7674.

title: Tech 2010: #26 Heaven Sent; The Dead Celebrity Who Comes Back to Life
description: Peter Riva is the grandson of Marlene Dietrich, and he is determined to see her reborn. He talks about a day when a ''Dietrich in a tube'' will be commercially available, when she can star as a Parisian femme fatale who scorns Humphrey Bogart and sends him lovelorn to Morocco. She would have wanted it that way, he says: ''When the first talkie came along, she was determined to be in it. When the makeup came, she adapted instantly. When she lived in Paris as an older woman, she went through five VCR's because the standard kept improving. This is somebody who didn't have an aversion to new technology.''

title: Online Company Moves Headquarters to Valhalla
description: TradeOut.com, an online marketplace for excess inventory, is less than two years old, but it has already outgrown its headquarters in Ardsley and is moving to offices three times as large in Valhalla. The company, formed in 1998, has 220 employees, of whom 150 will move to the new offices this summer.

title: They'll Call This One The Overtime Series
description: Just three days ago, this season's Stanley Cup finals seemed likely to be remembered as another ho-hum series that failed to live up to the hype.

title: In Central Park, Another Sleepy Delta Day in June
description: Sandra Bloodworth had arranged a vase of silk magnolia blooms on top of the table covered with a red-and-white checkered cloth. The food was kept hot in carefully wrapped pots, though the day was so uncharitably warm (too warm, in fact, for wearing lipstick, a fact that most of the ladies present chose to disregard) that the pots needed no help staying as cozy as a Mississippi weevil in a boll at the height of August.

title: Pouring New Money in Old Bottles
description: In California, the cost of the cultiest wines has gone way up, but the cost of your friends' admiration may be going even higher. The Napa Valley Wine Auction raised a record $9.5 million for local charities last weekend, nearly double the $5.5 million last year. One bidder, Chase Bailey, a retired Cisco Systems executive, paid $500,000 for a six-liter bottle of 1992 Screaming Eagle Cabernet Sauvignon -- a single-bottle record, according to Fritz Hatton of Christie's, the auctioneer. For five lots, Mr. Bailey paid more than $1.7 million.

title: Helping Pets of Abused
description: The town animal shelter in Huntington announced a program this week aimed at protecting the pets of victims of domestic abuse while the victims seek long-term housing for themselves.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-11-00; The Size Of Things To Come
description: It's all about the hand, the current love affair with gadgets. It may seem, at first glance, that it has to do with brushed aluminum, the alluring surface du jour. Or perhaps speed or power. But you can't actually feel the wind in your hair when a processor is ''blazingly fast.'' No, these qualities may fuel the new economy, but they're not responsible for that peculiar, lustful yearning one feels for the latest cell phone or personal digital assistant, or P.D.A., an abbreviation previously reserved for ''public display of affection.''

title: A Tossed Salad of Music on the Beach
description: NO ONE can accuse Kay Seelig of running a one-dimensional show. The seventh annual Beach Fest, the summer beach season entertainment opener for Atlantic City is, if nothing else, a well-wrought model of inconsistency.

title: Tech 2010: #16 No-Sweat Equities; The Day Trader That Puts Your Mind at Ease
description: I am a great trader, though you wouldn't necessarily know it by my recent account statements. A lover of underdogs, I trade what are known on Wall Street as dead cats -- stocks that have fallen precipitously. There are two prominent theories about dead cats. The first is that if you throw one out the window, it will bounce, and you can play that bounce. The second, more widely held, is that a dead cat is a sure-fire way of parting a fool and his money. I, however, have a foolproof method for calibrating the extent to which a dead cat will bounce. And if my shares have a way, from time to time, of getting sold at prices lower than where I bought them, that doesn't mean I made a bad trade. I just made a losing trade. It happens. All the time. If that's hard for you to deal with, just imagine how I feel: a great trader who hemorrhaged money in history's longest bull market. In the not-too-distant future, however, I won't have to feel so bad so often, because there will be a machine trading for me, as me, like me. No more fear, greed and ego for me. Just a simulating algorithm of me. Ivan Trader, a remorseless machine.

description: To the Editor:

title: Holmes's City
description: To the Editor: Reading ''Deducing Holmes's City'' (April 2) was enjoyable. Any Sherlock enthusiast may deduce that there is scarcely an area in London where one cannot recall some part of the great detective's adventures.

title: Just Call It Hoofing
description: It's difficult to describe what you'll see if you attend ''Dancing With Horses,'' an unusual presentation next Saturday at 8 p.m. at Garret Mountain Park's equestrian center. Easier, perhaps, to describe it by not describing it.

title: Another Country
description: VERTIGO By W. G. Sebald. Translated by Michael Hulse. Illustrated. 263 pp. New York: New Directions. $23.95.

title: Champagne in Spirit, Too
description: The French think Champagne on Bastille Day. Americans don't on the Fourth of July. But proper celebration of Independence Day requires more than Bud Light or its sparkling-wine equivalent, Korbel.

title: Born Of Bonsai, It Got Really Big
description: HENRY SCHANNEN happily concedes that he had an advantage when he began creating his rhododendron display garden five years ago. While such a garden normally takes a decade to establish, Mr. Schannen, a market research executive, did it in only 18 months. He now has what experts have called one of the most diverse rhododendron collections in the country.

title: Visiting Anew, Remembering Things Past
description: A REVIEWER'S lot is not always a happy one. A terrific restaurant is discovered, praised and then kissed good-bye, usually forever. Another awaits. Five years ago, I swooned over Villa Doria in Bellmore. Now, with the arrival of new owners, chef and staff, another visit was called for.

title: Polgar Tops an Elite Field With a Last-Round Victory
description: Judit Polgar of Hungary surpassed a former world champion, Anatoly Karpov, and the current International Chess Federation champion, Aleksandr Khalifman, both of Russia, in winning the Japfa Classic International Tournament in Denpasar, Bali, Indonesia, recently.

title: From Deep Silence to Birdsong and Car Horns
description: DONNA MARIE GEFFEN never told her husband to turn down the television or yelled at her children for making too much noise. Neither has she played her favorite song over and over again, or paused to listen to the birds outside her window.

title: SOAPBOX; Sign Here
description: I'VE had more than 500 poems published. Of course, they've been mostly in obscure publications, and by the time I ticked them all off to you they would have disappeared from view. I write a weekly column for our local newspaper, but based on the feedback (none), I wonder if anyone is reading it. Occasionally I get an honorable mention or even a first prize in the New York Magazine Competition and someone might tell me, ''Hey, I saw your limerick in The New Yorker.'' O.K., it's not a limerick (not usually) and, it's not the The New Yorker.

description: The Boomer

title: The World: Small Islands, Big Trouble; Looking for Paradise? Keep Looking
description: LT. JOE CABLE and Bloody Mary knew the score. Not even a South Pacific paradise like the fictional one created by Rodgers and Hammerstein is spared the ugly things in life like racial intolerance and war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, DAVID W.
description: COHN-David W. June 6, 2000 at age 94. Beloved husband of Emmy-Lou for 64 years. Dearest and cherished father of Suzanne C. Simon and her husband David and the late Cecile Cohn. Loving grandfather of Deborah Wasser and her partner Susan Vaughan, David Wasser, Deirdre and Alex Silberman, and Keira and Julian Safir. Great-grandfather of Max, Savannah and Jack. He was a loving, kind and sweet man who will be missed by both his family and friends. Funeral private.

title: Blow, Blow, Thou Energy-Producing Wind
description: HISTORIC windmills are not an unusual sight on the East End, but three new ones using the latest technology may soon rise on Montauk's ocean bluffs -- and may even power the Montauk Lighthouse.

title: Bus Link to Yosemite Reduces Car Traffic
description: In an effort to reduce the number of cars in Yosemite, a public bus system is now making scheduled runs into the national park from three surrounding counties.

title: Record Labels Are Hearing an Angry Song
description: AS a rock star and actress, Courtney Love knows how to grab the spotlight. At a new-media conference last month in Manhattan's SoHo, she delivered her keynote address in 70's-style hip huggers and angrily shouted at paparazzi who were blinding her with their camera flashes.

description: ARIA LAMS was matter of fact about her illness. ''I've been sick since I was a little girl,'' she told her first-grade classmates last fall. ''I had lost my hair. But now I'm better.''

title: Gayle Farbman, Michael Wasserman
description: Gayle Michelle Farbman and Michael David Wasserman were married last evening at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, N.Y. Rabbi Paula Winnig of Temple Sinai of Long Island in Lawrence, N.Y., officiated.

title: Eileen Grady, Andrew Vermilye
description: Eileen Patricia Grady and Andrew Riker Vermilye were married yesterday by Elizabeth O. Parker, a nondenominational minister, at the Chevy Chase (Md.) Club.

description: Each spring for the last 20 years, Nestor Rantas has traveled to the Bronx from Juana Diaz, P.R., to sell hats, T-shirts, key chains and anything else bearing the colors or name of his native land.

title: Loggers Look at a Tree and See a Boat
description: CONNECTICUT'S 570 licensed loggers are an independent lot, mostly hewing an unseen living in one- or two-man bands from the forests that dot the two northern corners of the state. But the 70 million board feet of timber they harvest each year is thought by the state to contribute about $414 million to the economy, in large part because the state still holds many stands of prime hardwoods that are valued throughout the world.

title: Green Calls for More Trains To Ease Subway Crowding
description: New York City's public advocate, Mark Green, responding to a call by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for improved safety procedures on subway platforms, said yesterday that the best safety measure would be more frequent service. More trains, he said, would prevent overcrowding in subway stations.

title: When the Reality Is Inside the Body
description: PERHAPS the trend began years ago with Mutual of Omaha's ''Wild Kingdom,'' which each week gave viewers a fly-in-the-Sahara view of such animal behavior as lions ripping gazelles to shreds.

title: Long Hot Summer, Short Hot Pants
description: I WAS amused -- you might be, too -- by the news that many designers have included hot pants in their last two collections, in other words, as part of the selection that is in stores now and will be again in late August and September. Ralph Lauren is making them in glen plaid; Stella McCartney is making them for Chloe in frayed white denim with a white lacy ruffle. Dolce & Gabbana expressed themselves in vinyl and chains; Richard Tyler, in a rather soignee sea-green knit. Not to mention the ones by Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton, or Donatella Versace for both her Versace and her Versus collections, or those made by Randolph Duke, Bottega Veneta, Emporio Armani or Betsey Johnson.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-11-00: The Ethicist; School Ties
description: I volunteered to work on a directory of local private schools because it might give our 4-year-old daughter an edge when she applies to private school next fall. A friend argued that this was wrong: most parents were denied this opportunity because they either didn't know about it or didn't have time to volunteer; in other words, it smacked of exclusion. Was she right? -- Anonymous, California

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHBERGER, FRITZ, DR
description: ROTHBERGER-Fritz, Dr. 97, Wolfville, Nova Scotia, Canada. Died May 30, 2000. Born in Vienna, Austria, he was a son of the late Henry and Ella (Burchardt) Rothberger. He was a retired professor of mathematics. Dr. Rothberger led a distinguished academic career at Acadia University and at the University of New Brunswick, Laval and Windsor. He was an internationally known mathematician and an oustanding teacher, who instilled a love for mathematics in numerous young people. In 1977 a symposium was held in his honor at the University of Toronto. He is survived by his cousin Bertha L. Gutmann of Caldwell, NJ and her family. Burial in Gaspereau Cemetery. Donations to Acadia University, Wolfville, The Wolfville Elms Rest Home or the charity of choice.

title: A Web Site Tracks Airport Conditions
description: Part of the Federal Aviation Administration's effort to reduce air traffic delays this summer is to do a better job of putting together a picture of air traffic delays around the country and sharing it with its own personnel, the airlines and anyone else who needs to know.

title: Artists Pro and Con With a New Generation of Swindles
description: WITH crime down, the streets of New York are safer than they have been in years. And to the casual eye, it may seem as if the city's fraud artists, who traditionally choose the warmer months in which to ply their trade, have all but disappeared from the streets.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about refinancing car loans misstated some aspects of a five-year, $38,000 loan at 10 percent interest. After making payments for one year, the borrower would owe $31,833 principal on the loan, not $38,736. An average of 39 percent of the first-year payment amount, not a majority, is applied to interest on such a loan.

title: Kermit Roosevelt, Leader of C.I.A. Coup in Iran, Dies at 84
description: Kermit Roosevelt, who was a member of the famous American political family but who made his contributions to the nation in the shadowy world of spy craft, died Thursday at a retirement community in Cockeysville, Md., near Baltimore. He was 84.

title: Talking to the Streets for Art
description: TRAFFIC will come to a halt for a mile along on Fifth Avenue Tuesday evening as nine museums take to the streets for the 22nd annual Museum Mile Festival (part of last year's is shown above). The action will take place from 82nd to 104th Street. For the first time, several of the museums will offer outdoor art activities, including chalk art and seven-foot pieces of chalk for families to play with. Twentieth-century New York will be celebrated in an event called Mapping Memories, and outside the National Academy of Design, children 9 to 12 will be shown how to sketch a live model. Musicians will perform in front of the museums.

title: Not Your Toddler's Apple Cider
description: NOW and again, Larrie Laird leads visitors back beyond his family's plant to a building where 55-gallon oak casks rise from floor to ceiling. Here they lie, biding their time, resting, waiting, aging.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, MYLES LOWELL
description: LIPTON-Myles Lowell. On June 6th, 2000. Resided in St. Louis, MO. Beloved husband of Christina. Cherished son of Constance Deener and the late Saul Lipton. Dear nephew of Norman Berke. Services Sunday, June 11th, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYRON, JOSHUA
description: MYRON-Joshua. Beloved husband of the late Sybil Myron. Cherished and devoted father of Naomi Scheuer. Loving grandfather of Marc Lubin, Eve Lubin, Abigail Scheuer and their spouses Robin Lubin, C.R. Jeffs and Ateatema. Passed on after 102 years spanning three centuries on two continents. Born in Rishon le Zion in todays Israel, he spent a lifetime of commitment to Israel and Jewish causes serving with heroism in the Jewish Legion during World War I. In 1920 he came to America to study, then married and became a pharmacist. Residing in Suffern, NY since 1938, he will be greatly missed by his family and his community. Services will be held at 12:30 on Sunday, June 11, at Congregation Sons of Israel, at 34 Montebello Road in Suffern. In lieu of flowers contributions in his honor may be sent to Congregation Sons of Israel.

title: Elizabeth Johnson and Josh Epstein
description: ON the eastern end of Long Island, this is the month of strawberries, June bugs that buzz against the screen doors like beepers gone haywire, and brides. At this time of year, if you see an enormous number of cars parked outside a house and people running frantically down the driveway, it's either a yard sale or a wedding.

title: POSTINGS: Former Warehouse Being Converted at 169 Hudson Street; From Bridge Cables To 12 TriBeCa Condos
description: In its previous incarnation the building at 169 Hudson Street was a decidedly unglamorous warehouse where cables and other materials used in the construction of bridges were kept by the John A. Roebling Steel Corporation, whose namesake founder designed the Brooklyn Bridge. Now the building, between Laight and Vestry Streets in TriBeCa, is being transformed into a luxury 12-unit condominium with such amenities as a temperature-controlled wine cellar and tasting room.

title: Rights Gains Are Preserved At U.N. Forum On Women
description: Five years after a watershed conference held in Beijing articulated and affirmed what more than 180 nations could agree were the universal rights of women, a weeklong follow-up meeting ended yesterday at the United Nations with no significant victories for opponents who have tried to reverse those gains.

title: From 60's Hijinks to Hollywood Ending
description: THE year was 1968. It was a time of teenage rebellion, sexual revolution and protest. So when Jane Shmerler and John Masius were suspended from Scarsdale High School, what was their crime?
