description: Ultima Thule

title: Claims on Property Reclaimed by Nature
description: Set atop a hill in the exclusive Newstead section, overlooking this township's quaint downtown and much of Essex County and New York City beyond, is a 30-acre quarry that resembles a vast, overgrown crater stretching a quarter-mile across. Jagged man-made cliffs rise about 60 feet above a small stream that feeds a shallow pond.

title: Roundabout Way to Childhood Dream
description: IN the late 1980's, when Jeff Cohen was a student at Oceanside High School, he gave up guitar lessons for basketball games and track meets. Nowadays, his priorities have switched and the hurdles he is conquering are musical.

title: Mourning a Fatally Girdled Tree as It Twists in the Wind
description: In mid-April, a 20-year-old pear tree at Ninth Avenue and Gansevoort Street was stripped of its bark, leaving a three-foot-wide ring completely bare.

title: Gently Tie That Tomato
description: Mulch and stake tomatoes for better disease control. Use soft ties, wrapping them loosely in a figure eight around the stake or trellis and the plants.

title: New Yorker's Disappearance in Jamaica Baffles Police and Family
description: By the time Claudia Kirschhoch set foot in Jamaica, she had lived in France for a year and had taken a handful of language courses. She worked as an editor for the Frommer's travel guide series and pored over maps with an intense curiosity.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Little Whitman, a Little Isaiah
description: With her signature spiky haircut and fiddle at the ready, the performance artist Laurie Anderson has been a darling of the downtown art scene for three decades. The art critic RoseLee Goldberg has written a thoughtful, if at times too adulatory, overview of Anderson's multimedia career. This handsomely produced LAURIE ANDERSON (Abrams, $39.95) covers her early sculptures and sketches, art-rock records like her pop hit ''O Superman,'' quirky inventions and grandly scaled electronic operas like ''Home of the Brave'' and her latest, ''Songs and Stories From Moby-Dick.'' Anderson trained as a classical violinist with the Chicago Youth Symphony, studied art at Columbia University and actually did walk away from an airplane crash, as recounted in her song ''The Language of the Future.'' Her experimental work has been influenced by the Fluxus performance artists, as well as by John Cage, Philip Glass and William S. Burroughs, but Goldberg presumptuously links her to Whitman, Melville and the prophet Isaiah. Although Goldberg assumes the reader is familiar with performance art, her descriptions of Anderson's pieces are vivid and illuminating, and she shows the seamless continuity of Anderson's daily life, dreams and work. Eric P. Nash

title: June 4-10; Discrimination on Wall Street
description: Even Wall Street traders who make $1 million a year can be victims of sex discrimination in the workplace, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission declared after taking up a complaint against Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. Paving the way for lawsuits, the commission said the firm had discriminated against women who worked in its institutional stocks division and had retaliated against a trader, Allison K. Schieffelin, for complaining publicly. The firm denied the charges. PATRICK McGEEHAN

title: Don't Tell
description: To the Editor: The lengthy recounting of other people's travels -- not, of course, our own -- is indeed boring and superfluous. But there's a better way of doing it: writing it all down.

title: The Nation; The Kind of Face-Off in Which Looks Can Kill
description: HIS bloody, unappetizing lip notwithstanding, Representative Rick Lazio's entry into the New York Senate race generated a basketful of valentines in newspapers and magazines describing his pleasing suburban patina as a big political asset. Not too many articles said the same thing about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the unadulterated 50's guy whom Mr. Lazio replaced. Meanwhile the opponent of these Senate candidates past and present, Hillary Rodham Clinton, was acclaimed last year in Esquire magazine for her ''sexy'' mouth -- sexy being an adjective that is normally problematic for female politicians.

title: Julia Weil, Jeffrey Lazarus
description: Julia Yve Weil, the daughter of Shelia and Wayne Weil of Rutherford, N.J., and Jeffrey Todd Lazarus, a son of Arlene and Steven Lazarus of Glencoe, Ill., are to be married tonight at Wave Hill in the Bronx. Judge Loretta A. Preska of the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York is to officiate.

title: School by School, the Fourth-Grade Reading Scores
description: In this years assessment of the reading skills of fourth graders across New York State, the percentage of pupils in Westchester passing the test rose 12 points from last year, to 73.1 percent.

title: A Grammy for Indians
description: The board of trustees of the Recording Academy announced last week that American Indians would be represented in the Grammys.

title: Crime
description: No wonder the Roman Catholic church in Rocksburg, Pa., is called Mother of Sorrows -- someone has to cry for the suffering souls in the depressed mill town where K. C. Constantine sets his blue-collar crime novels. GRIEVANCE (Mysterious Press/Warner, $23.95) picks up the never-ending narrative of Rocksburg's decline with the murder of J. D. Lyon, C.E.O. of the local steel outfit that pulled up stakes and relocated to Brazil, tossing this company town into an economic sinkhole. Ruggiero (Rugs) Carlucci, the young police sergeant who recently took over the peacekeeping chores in this ruefully honest series, does his best to conduct a fair investigation. But he is driven to distraction by his mother's deteriorating mental state, and his work ethic is compromised by his compassion for the families whose lives were so casually destroyed by the murdered man.

title: Another Setback For Supermarket in Hastings
description: ShopRite's five-year effort to open a supermarket in Hastings-on-Hudson experienced another setback when Justice Peter M. Leavitt of State Supreme Court in White Plains upheld the village Planning Board's rejection of the store plans.

title: Let's Make a Deal
description: THE WHITE SHARKS

title: Tech 2010: #06 The Morning Glide; The Train You're Never Late For
description: Doug Malewicki envisions a future full of unusual things. Like a way of liberating American cities from their clogged-artery highways using a lacework of elevated rails that would carry thousands of commuters in individual pods coasting silently above the sidewalks at 100 miles per hour. Like a 40-foot-high robotic dinosaur that eats cars and spits fire to thrill crowds of carnival spectators. Malewicki has already designed the latter, but while his Robosaurus will be chewing Chevy Novas throughout the land this summer, the only way to see his magnetic-levitation-powered SkyTran is to pore over the snappy retrofuturistic illustrations on its Web site (www.skytran.net). Malewicki and the rest of his team at Skytran Inc. -- a half-dozen staff members scattered from Raleigh, N.C., to Seattle -- are fully convinced that once a full-size prototype is up and running, it's only a theoretical hop, step and jump to the day when the beleaguered American worker will walk to his local pod station (at a shopping mall on Main Street), wave a personal ID in front of a sensor and be whisked away in his fiberglass cocoon. Picture the offspring of a Newark Airport monorail and a Killington chairlift, and you can envision SkyTran's commuting machine: no straphanging with strangers, no carpooling with verbose neighbors. Just a personal zoom with a view.

title: A Tour of Tours Of New York
description: NEW YORK CITY'S struggle with New York Apple Tours since a pedestrian was killed May 22 by a company bus whose driver was not properly licensed has put the city's tourism infrastructure in a bad light.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, KATHERINE (NEE KOLODNY)
description: KRAMER-Katherine (nee Kolodny), 76, died on June 9, after a brief illness. Born in New York, and long residing in Oakdale, she was a dedicated and skilled social worker. Beloved wife of the late poet Aaron Kramer, mother of Carol of Tucson and Laura of Montclair, and grandmother of Nora and Joanna Gordon, she was a woman of enormous integrity, and will be greatly missed.

Bachelder III, head of a Manhattan law firm that bears his name, may deserve a share of the credit, or the blame.

The Rev. Dr. Timothy Ives, a Congregational minister, officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The Rev. Young Kil Moon, a Methodist minister, took part in the ceremony.

description: On approximately 299 and two-thirds of its 300 islands, there are no indications that Fiji is in turmoil, with rebels occupying Parliament and holding three dozen hostages who include the elected prime minister, much of his Cabinet and the daughter of the country's president.

description: EVEN for seasoned tree experts like Lou Sebesta, an urban forester who has seen many champions, the 125-year-old flowering dogwood in Carmel is a wonder.

description: Bronwyn Anne Langhorne Jonker, the daughter of Mary and A. Daniel Jonker of Roxbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Matthew Thomas Prohaska, the son of Donna and Thomas M. Prohaska of Amherst, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Robert P. Clements officiated at Christ Episcopal Church in Roxbury, with the Rev. Dr. Florence W. Pert, a minister of the Reformed Church of America, taking part.

description: Anne Frances Collins, a daughter of Dr. Mary H. Collins and Dr. John J. Collins Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married yesterday to Frank Henry Goodyear III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodyear Jr. of Phoenix. The Rev. Thomas J. Hogan, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul in Wellesley, Mass. Robert S. Hurlbut Jr., an Episcopal lay reader, took part in the ceremony.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; The Other Retirement Planning
description: NO one warned me about the actual day when I would retire. Sure, I had read a surfeit of information about retirement, but it focused only on financial planning and activity planning -- things like travel, golf, volunteer work, and how not to get into your spouse's space. None of it talked about how to get through that final day at a job you had loved for decades.

title: Commendable Pulls an Upset In a Depleted Belmont Stakes
description: While the spirits of the missing superstars Fusaichi Pegasus and Red Bullet were hanging over the homestretch, the 132nd Belmont Stakes was run yesterday with a cast of 11 horses of far less magnitude. And the one who got there first was one of the least likely: Commendable, 17th in the Kentucky Derby, without a victory in six races since his debut last August at Del Mar and an 18-1 long shot in the Belmont.

title: For Today, Call Him 007
description: The legendary James Bond toy car -- the classic boy toy of the mid-1960's -- has been reintroduced by the British manufacturer Hamleys of London. Available as a limited edition in the original Aston Martin model ($59.99, gold-plated collector's edition only) or a white Lotus Esprit model ($49.99; both available at www.Hamleys.com), the cars come with ejector seat, pop-up bullet shield and James Bond figure inside, providing hours of amusement and opportunity to make vroom-vroom noises for fathers and sons alike. And if Dad bursts out crying because he's lost his mini-Bond in the first minutes of playing, never fear: extra replacement figures -- Oddjob, Jaws or 007 himself -- are included.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOGASHI, TOM
description: TOGASHI-Tom. Pioneering Japanese TV journalist, loved and admired by colleagues, friends and family, died at home in New York City on June 4, 2000, of lung cancer at age 63. A fisherman's son from Northern Japan, he earned a law degree from Chuo University in Tokyo and was awarded a law scholarship from the University of Kansas in Lawrence in 1959. At a time when young Japanese rarely left their homeland, he explored every part of the country he loved and eventually became an American citizen. During the turbulent 60's he took part in almost every major event, became a wellknown figure in the East Village, working with LaMama and other groups. He then went on to make award-winning documentaries for Japanese and American public television. His passionate interest in astronomy was reflected in an impressive International NHK-TV Galactic Odyssey series. In 1996 he received a Media Achievement Award from the International Society for the Study of Dissociation for his sensitive TV portrayal of multiple personality disorder. His beaming smile and integrity won the hearts of all who loved and worked with him-whose personal and professional lives he so deeply touched. He will be remembered for his compassion... his playful wit and intellectual curiosity...for his loyalty, tolerance of others, and unwavering decency...and for the courage with which he faced his final challenge. His life was shorter than it might have been, but as rich and full as it could have been. He is survived by his wife, Bess Heitner; his brother, Hitoshi, in New York City; and his mother, Kikumi and family in Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, ALFRED M., M. D.
description: MARKOWITZ-Alfred M., M. D. The Department of Surgery of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and New YorkPresbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend and collegue, Dr. Alfred Markowitz. Dr. Markowitz, who was Professor Emeritus of Clinical Surgery at the time of his death, served the medical center with distinction for nearly half a century as an educator, clinician, and researcher. He was particularly known for his teaching of medical students and training of surgical residents, and was considered one of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center's most respected practitioners. He was much loved and will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Markowitz family.

title: Syria After Hafez al-Assad
description: Hafez al-Assad has been a fixture of Syrian politics and diplomacy for so long that it is hard to imagine the Middle East without him. In 30 years of rule, he transformed Syria from a coup-prone pawn of stronger Arab states into a formidable regional power. His Soviet-equipped forces slashed across the Golan Heights and menaced Israel's survival in the early days of the 1973 war and have progressively taken over Lebanon since 1976. His fixation with reclaiming every inch of the Golan made him the last of Israel's Arab neighbors to resist a negotiated peace. His successor should shed this costly policy of confrontation and begin integrating Syria's closed and backward society into the 21st-century world.

title: Let Artistic Gray Areas Be, as Long as Truth Is Out

Definitions mean boundaries, and all of these terms make clear that the boundaries we once knew are disappearing. At most we have borders now, meant to be crossed, redrawn or erased.

title: April Tool Orders Fell

April orders from United States companies for domestic and foreign-produced machine tools fell to $450 million from a revised $577 million in March, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said. Tool orders were higher in the first four months of this year than the same period last year. Orders rose 9 percent through April, to $1.87 billion.

title: Trapped in the Nuclear Math

title: How to Move the Schools

The system has a long way to go to reach this goal. But as the school year draws to a close, New York City's schools are showing indisputable signs of improvement as measured by state and local reading tests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, ROSALIND BLUM
description: SCHULMAN-Rosalind Blum, of New York City, age 90, passed away peacefully in her sleep on June 9, 2000. Beloved mother of Susan Linda Schulman and the late Donald M. Schulman, devoted grandmother of Robin Schulman Torriero, loving great-grandmother of Jenifer, Lisa and Jessica, and adored wife of the late Saul T. Schulman. A distinguished child psychologist, she established The Psychological Testing Center in New York City in 1941, and for more than 60 years found great joy in guiding parents and children to the best school for their needs and abilities. She received her B.A. and M.A. in Clinical Psychology from Teachers College, Columbia University, where she taught courses in tests and measurements for many years. She created the original admission program for Hunter College Elementary School and was consulting psychologist for many private schools, including The Professional Children's School, St. David's, and St. Hilda's and St. Hughes. She was extremely instrumental in the creation in the Rodeph Sholom Nursery School and later the Day School, and was the pro bono school psychologist for both schools for many years. She continued in private practice until her death. She was a member of the American Psychological Assoc., NY State Psychological Assoc., NY Society of Clinical Psychologists and the American Assoc. of Counseling and Development. She was a NY State Certified Psychologist and held a Diplomat in School Psychology. She is survived by her daughter, granddaughter, great-granddaughter, thousands of families she helped and many, many friends. Service Monday, June 12th, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSEN, SYLVIA
description: GERSEN-Sylvia on June 11, 2000. We shared a life for over 50 years. Reaching the Millennium as she attained the age of 90 was an unexpected bonus. The oft repeated characterization of a gallant dispute with cancer was literally true in her case. We even spent the night before her brain surgery at the ballet, putting a period to a lifelong passion for music and the dance. Straightforward, unduly modest, unaware of the extent of her talents and the generosity of her spirit, without pretense or display, a lady of grace, elegance and gentility, she merited and to an extent unrecognized by her, achieved the respect, admiration and love of those who knew her best. Nothing became her life as much as the way she met her death. She leaves a desperately bereaved husband whose life she guided and immeasurably enriched, nieces Marilyn Gans, Betty Katsner and Peggy Clark who were especially dear to her, Betty Lenson, the widow of her beloved younger brother Martin, grandnieces of whom she was fond, and a host of friends & acquaintances. Burial was private. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 15, 2000, 3:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York.

title: TIME WARNER TELECOM CANCELS PURCHASE OF GST
description: Time Warner Telecom Inc., a provider of telephone and Internet service to businesses, canceled its planned $450 million purchase of GST Telecommunications Inc., which is in bankruptcy proceedings. Time Warner Telecom, which is 48 percent owned by the No. 1 United States cable television operator, Time Warner Inc., said it could not reach favorable terms on a final agreement with GST and its creditors. Instead of selling to Time Warner Telecom, GST said it would ask a federal court in Delaware to let it sell most of its assets at auction. GST filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Wilmington, Del., on May 17, citing high debt and insufficient cash flow. GST, based in Vancouver, Wash., provides voice, Internet and data services in Western states.

You can see it still in the dark shirts and ties of Regis Philbin's ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' wardrobe, which might as well have been pinched from the closet of Tommaso Buscetta, a Sicilian Mafioso who inspired a men's wear collection by Dolce & Gabbana. Until a decade back, a gangster was a guy who suited up for business. For fashion purposes, at least, he was probably of European ancestry and white.

title: LIBERTY FINANCIAL TO BUY WANGER ASSET MANAGEMENT
description: The Liberty Financial Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Wanger Asset Management L.P., the investment company that runs the Acorn mutual funds, for $280 million, plus an additional $170 million over the next five years depending on Wanger's financial performance. Liberty Financial, which is based in Boston, disclosed last week that it was in talks with Wanger, which specializes in small companies and international stock mutual funds. Wanger has $8.8 billion in assets under management. Liberty Financial, an asset management company, has more than $67 billion in assets under management. It is 71 percent owned by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company.

title: The Two Koreas, Talking
description: This week's meetings between South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, and North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, mark an encouraging change in the relationship between the two Koreas. In the 55 years since the Korean Peninsula was divided after World War II, the North has directed invasion, infiltration and terrorism against the South and both sides have employed vitriolic propaganda against each other. Now, for the first time, the top leaders on each side are getting together to discuss mutual concerns like economic cooperation and family reunification.

title: Oracular And Talky, An 'Electra' By a Greek
description: The Greek composer Mikis Theodorakis is best known in the United States as a composer of music for film soundtracks, most notably ''Zorba the Greek,'' ''Serpico'' and ''Z.'' But his name regularly crops up in other contexts as well. Having studied composition in Paris with Messiaen and had an early hit with a ballet, ''Antigone,'' he became disillusioned with what he regarded as the limitations of the classical music world and became captivated by the idea of combining high and low art. He began writing art songs with bouzouki accompaniments, as well as overtly popular songs, some of which found a life in translation outside Greece.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENTON, JOHN H.
description: BENTON-John H. Educational film executive and a magazine publisher passed away at home in Los Angeles, California, on 16 February 2000 at the age of 57. Born in Chicago, Illinois, John was reared in Southport, Connecticut and Phoenix, Arizona. He was a graduate of Deerfield Academy, Yale University and King's College, Cambridge University. He worked with UNESCO in Paris prior to joining Encyclopaedia Britannica, of which his father, Senator William Benton was publisher. In 1973 he became Chairman of The Board of Britannica's Educational Film Subidiary. A race car participant and enthusiast, he also published Racecar Magazine. After relocating to California in the late 1970's, he deepened his lifelong relationship with Taliesin and served on The Board of The Frank Lloyd Wright Building Conservancy. He is survived by his children, William Worth Benton and Lillian Hemingway Benton as well as a sister, Helen B. Boley and a brother, Charles Benton. His sister, Louise H. Benton Wagner, predeceased him.

title: Revealing the Dark Side Of the Doll Coppelia

George Balanchine and Alexandra Danilova based their staging of this 19th-century frolic, set to lilting music by Delibes, on the version in which Danilova became one of the great interpreters of the role of Swanilda. But the City Ballet version has darker undertones that are closer to the story by E.T.A. Hoffmann from which the scenario is drawn.

title: PERKINELMER BUYING NEN LIFE SCIENCES FOR $400 MILLION
description: PerkinElmer Inc., a distributor of genetic-analysis tools, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Nen Life Sciences for $400 million in cash to become one of the top global providers of drug-discovery instruments. PerkinElmer is buying Nen, a maker of drug-discovery devices, from an investment group led by Genstar Capital L.L.C. Nen Life is expected to have $125 million in revenue this year. Shares of PerkinElmer, which is based in Wellesley, Mass., fell $3.25 each, to $57.6875. PerkinElmer is the name adopted by EG&G Inc. last October, after buying the former Perkin-Elmer Corporation's analytical instrument unit for $425 million in cash and debt. The former Perkin-Elmer is now the PE Corporation.

We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Helen, their children and family. The Museum's long relationship with George includes a retrospective of his work in 1998, and wonderful works in the Museum's collection. His world-renowned sculpture, ''Holocaust'', is on view in the Museum's permanent exhibition galleries. Since its acquisition in the early 1980s, our visitors have been drawn to this work as a Holocaust memorial within the Museum, and it is a centerpiece for education programs. title: UPDATE; Mr. Mom Dies, Leaving Hatchlings
description: With one week to go before egg-hatching time, Mr. Mom, the pride of the Long Beach Aquarium of the Pacific, was set to become the first captive weedy sea dragon in the United States to give birth successfully. Sea dragons always breed through the male, but rarely in captivity, and Mr. Mom's resilient nature had raised hopes that he would quash the belief that these delicate fish could never reproduce before human eyes.

title: ENGAGE WILL BUY MEDIABRIDGE TECHNOLOGIES
description: Engage Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the privately held MediaBridge Technologies Inc. for $268.3 million in stock. Engage said it would issue 14.5 million shares for the transaction. Engage makes systems that track customers' online buying habits. It is owned by CMGI Inc., a company in Andover, Mass., that invests in Internet businesses. Engage is also based in Andover. MediaBridge, based in Acton, Mass., develops software for marketing aimed at specific groups.

title: Corrections

Though both were pioneering researchers, they were not the first to describe the animals' lives in the wild. Earlier scholars included George Schaller and Robert M. Yerkes. title: CORNING SHARES RISE ON REVISED EARNINGS FORECAST
description: The shares of Corning Inc. climbed 8 percent yesterday after the company, the world's biggest maker of fiber optic cable, said it expected to report second-quarter earnings well above estimates. The company, based in Corning, N.Y., said it expected to post earnings before special items of 78 cents to 80 cents a share, topping analysts' estimates of 69 cents. The projected earnings represent growth of about 50 percent over a year earlier. Corning said it continued to experience strong demand for its optical fiber and cable, photonic modules and components, and flat-panel glass products. The company also lifted its forecast for growth in full-year earnings to 45 percent from 35 percent. Corning's shares rose $18.50 each, to $230.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOYES, FREDERICK
description: NOYES-Frederick. June 10, 2000, of heart failure. Born September 25, 1912, Colebrook, N.H. He graduated from MIT in architecture, 1936. Served in the U.S. Army as a Major, WWII. As a Project Designer at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, he was instrumental in the design of Lever House, the city's first ''glass box'' office building. Later his established his own busy and varied practice. In retirement he was active in architectural preservation and in MIT alumni activities. He belonged to several NGOs at the U.N., the Shanghai Tiffin Club and Goodland Country Club. For years he enjoyed singing in his church choirs and was a member of the Canterbury Choral Society. His ''Central Park office'' was a favorite spot. An energetic, creative, and highly original man, he'll be fondly and vividly remembered by his many friends. He is survived by his brother and sister-in-law Irving and Katherine Noyes; his halfbrother and sister-in-law Bernerd and Hannah Burbank; his sons Jonathan, David and Peter and their wives; his grandchildren Jennifer, Jonathan, Lee, and Jonathan; his loving nieces and nephews and his friend Caroline Helmuth. Memorial service at St. James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave (71 St), June 24th at 10:00AM.

title: STATION CASINOS TO ACQUIRE SANTE FE HOTEL AND CASINO

Station Casinos also agreed to lend as much as $36 million to Santa Fe Gaming's Pioneer Hotel Inc. unit. The loan will be credited against the sale price. Shares of Station Casinos fell 43.75 cents, to $27.1875. Santa Fe Gaming rose 81.25 cents, to $2.0625.

title: AOL DEAL WITH BRAZIL BANK
description: One of Brazil's largest banks, Banco Itau, acquired 12 percent of America Online Latin America as part of a strategic effort by the Internet provider to expand throughout the country. AOL Latin America will provide limited free access to Itau's 700,000 clients that use online banking, with the potential of expanding to all of the bank's more than seven million clients in Brazil. Itau is the last of Brazil's large banks to offer free Internet access to its clients for home banking. AOL Latin America plans to make a $575 million initial public offering later this year. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODDARD, RUTH R.
description: GODDARD-Ruth R. The American Jewish Committee bids a sorrowful farewell to an extraordinary woman who graced our organization with her generosity, elegance, friendship and vitality for more than half a century. Ruth served as Chair of our Women's Campaign Board and, in 1968, became the first woman elected to serve as an AJC National Vice President. Most recently, she was Honorary Chair of The Women's Campaign Board and Honorary National Vice President. A woman well ahead of her time, Ruth combined a successful and varied business career with active leadership in a host of philanthropic and civic agencies devoted to the the arts, health care and education. Particularly close to her heart was the well-being of the Jewish community, to which she devoted much of her time and energy. In 1996, AJC was proud to pay tribute to Ruth at a gala dinner held in honor of her 95th birthday. Ruth was a trendsetter and a uniquely energetic individual, whose legacy of public service, humanitarianism and Jewish committment we will long treasure. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Exec. Director Jack Lapin, Chair, Board of Governors Shulamith Bahat, Assoc Exec Dir

title: G.M. PLACES $5.6 BILLION OF STOCK IN EMPLOYEE PLANS
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had contributed 60.5 million shares of G.M. Class H common stock, valued at about $5.6 billion, to employee benefit plans. The company transmitted 53.6 million shares to its United States hourly rate employees pension plan and 6.9 million shares to its welfare benefit trust, a voluntary employees' health-care and life insurance benefit trust. The contributions are part of the company's plan to restructure its economic interest in its Hughes Electronics unit, G.M.'s wholly owned subsidiary that makes satellite TV systems. The move will reduce G.M.'s annual pension and retirement benefit expenses and improve operating earnings.

In its relentlessly biological mind, what we think of as civilization is portrayed as a fragile membrane that barely prevents us from acting on our most brutal instincts.

title: ILLUMINET ACQUIRES NATIONAL TELEMANAGEMENT FOR STOCK
description: The telephone services company Illuminet Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held National Telemanagement Corporation for $83.9 million in stock, plus the assumption of $3.9 million in debt. Illuminet's services include routing phone calls and allowing phone companies to offer caller ID and cell phone roaming services. National Telemanagement, based in Dallas, develops technology that lets phone companies keep track of customers' phone use. The company had $16.1 million in revenue last year. Illuminet, of Olympia, Wash., had $100.6 million in revenue last year. Its stock was up 87.5 cents, to $43.375, up 87.5 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGE, ARTHUR P.
description: SAGE-Arthur P. Born November 20, 1940. Husband of Earline Sage, step-father of Dr. Nicole Alford of Maryland and Robert Alford of Brooklyn. Son of Faye Sage of Forest Hills. Senior Grievance Advocate of Teamster Local 237. Founding member, past President and 1995 Man of the Year of Civil Service Bar Association. Member of B'Nai Brith. Attended NYU at age 15. Graduated with BA and JD. Former Assistant to the General Counsel of HRA. Loved the arts, opera afficionado, and Shakespeare buff. Tennis fan. He celebrated life. Viewing June 14 at the Riverside Chapel, 180 W 76 St, 6-9pm. Services Thursday, June 15 at 11:30am, Riverside Chapel.

title: Ever Tried Popping Ice Cream? It's Easier Now
description: Ice-cream lovers can be an impatient lot, in a hurry to get the sweet stuff into a dish or cone. Oxo's new scoop makes the job easier: when the lever on the handle is pressed, the ice cream pops right out of the brushed-stainless-steel bowl. As on all Oxo kitchen tools, the handle is cushioned. The scoop is $11.50 at Broadway Panhandler, 477 Broome Street (Greene Street), and other housewares stores.

title: Reckonings; Death and Taxes
description: The distribution of wealth does not look like the ''bell curve'' beloved of statisticians. Instead it is best described by a ''power law,'' a sort of elongated ski slope. Power-law distributions, unlike bell curves, have a lot of their mass far out in the right tail -- which means, in this particular case, that a large share of the total wealth is held by a small number of families.

title: Pink (Well, Rose) Is for Guys
description: MILLIONS of fathers may stifle yawns this Sunday as they receive bottles of Scotch, Cognac and other predictable gifts, the beverage equivalents of ties and after-shave. But here's a chance to cross everybody up and reward Dad with something unexpected: a bottle of rose.

title: SYKES SELLS EMPLOYEE BENEFITS UNIT IN RESTRUCTURING
description: Sykes Enterprises, which runs customer-support centers for Microsoft and other companies, is selling its employee-benefits unit for $165.5 million in cash to a closely held investment company. Sykes also said its second-quarter earnings would not meet analysts' forecasts. The company said it was selling its SHPS unit to Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe as part of a reorganization that will include some office closings and the firing of an unspecified number of workers. Sykes said it expected a gain of $68.7 million, or $1.60 a share, from the sale. Shares of Sykes fell $3.75 each, to $16.625.

A few serious margin calls could change that very quickly; the markup is four and five times what the winemaker sells it for, so there is a lot of fat in that price to be trimmed. But if the stock market doesn't crash, collectors will be eager to shell out $10,000 or so for one of the 2,200 cases made.

title: BROADCOM AGREES TO ACQUIRE INNOVENT FOR $438 MILLION
description: A maker of broadband chips, the Broadcom Corporation, agreed yesterday to buy Innovent Systems Inc., a manufacturer of integrated circuits for short-range wireless communications, for around $438 million in stock, based on Monday's closing prices. Broadcom, which makes integrated circuits that speed broadband communications, said it would issue three million shares of its Class A common stock in exchange for Innovent. Shares of Broadcom, based in Irvine, Calif., rose $5.6875, to $152.375. Innovent's Blutonium family of chips are used for high-performance short-range wireless communications in hand-held devices and personal computers.

Mr. Goodby confirmed a report of the shift this week in Advertising Age. Mr. Simpson, 40, is a partner and creative director, and Mr. Venables, 34, is associate partner and creative director.

title: Murder in a Small Town. Or Is It a Savage Jungle?
description: If it's possible for a film to convey a physical sensation of the world that is more intense than everyday life, Bruno Dumont's flawed masterpiece, ''Humanite,'' does a disquietingly good job. The raw sensory effect this transfixing movie produces might almost be described as psychedelic. Surrendering to its vision feels a little like being exposed to the sun after losing a layer of skin. In its relentlessly biological mind, what we think of as civilization is portrayed as a fragile membrane that barely prevents us from acting on our most brutal instincts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEEBER, MARION
description: WEEBER-Marion. New York industrial designer of silverware and jewelry, died June 12, 2000 of a heart attack at Bellvue Hospital at the age of 94. She was trained at The Arts Students League of New York, where she became a Life Member, Honorary Member of The American Federation of Arts, and President of her Manhattan design firm, Marion Weeber, Inc., for fifty years, contributing awardwinning design to leading American manufacturers and importers. Her inventions, designs, paintings and drawings are in museums and private collections. She is survived by two stepchildren and their families, and was the widow of the late Paul N. Welsh, advertising executive. Her father was the late Christian F. Weeber, pioneer automotive and aeronautic inventor, of Albany, NY. Visitation Wednesday 7-9 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, then on Thursday 4-8 at The Frederick Funeral Home, 633 Central Avenue, Albany, NY. Services 11:30 Friday, with burial to follow. in Albany Rural Cemetery.

title: A Growing Gender Gap (and It's Not What You Think)
description: In the last two decades, women have made significant inroads in male-dominated professions. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, in 1983 only 7 percent of dentists were women. Today, 17 percent are. In 1983, 15 percent of lawyers were women. Now, 29 percent are. Even police officers and security guards have an increased representation of women -- 21 percent versus 13 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, FRANCES
description: BRODY-Frances. Of Scotch Plains, NJ and Delray Beach, FL, passed peacefully in her sleep on Tuesday morning, June 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Herbert Brody, co-founder of Pathmark Supermarkets, adored mother and mother-in-law of Susanne Brody, & Gary Cohen, Wendy & Gordon Keil, Patti and Daniel Lehrhoff, Andrew & Tracey Brody. Loving grandmother of Adam, Sarah, Heather, and Noah Keil, Danielle, Michelle and Haley Rosengarten, Corey, Amanda, Nicole, Benjamin, Jessie, and Michael Lehrhoff, and Marcia Brody. A woman of valor who lived her life in the service of her family, her friends and her community. She had been actively involved in The Herb and Frances Brody Center for Food Sciences at Hebrew University of Israel, Hadassah Hospital, Israel Bonds, UJA, ADL, Alyn Hospital, Newark Beth Israel Hospital, Temple Emanu-El in Westfield, New Jersey, and The YMHA's of New Jersey was tireless. For over 70 years, she dedicated herself to a life of tzedakah and righteousness. The world is a better place because of her, she is loved and will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, June 14, 2000, at 11:30 A.M. at Temple Emanu-El, East Broad Street, Westfield, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to The Hebrew University, Herb and Frances Brody College of Agriculture, 11 East 69th Street, New York, New York 10022.

title: Not Quite a Jazz Festival
description: Friday night's show at Aaron Davis Hall -- which brought together within one extraordinary band the pianist Andrew Hill, the saxophonist Jackie McLean, the vibraphonist Bobby Hutcherson, the drummer Billy Higgins and the bassist Scott Colley -- was a one-time corral of great musicians that had ''jazz festival'' written all over it: it takes curatorial motivation to make this happen. And though it could have been produced by any of New York's three major jazz festivals and attracted an audience anywhere from the Lower East Side to Carnegie Hall to Harlem (where it did in fact happen), it wasn't a festival concert at all but part of Aaron Davis Hall's independently produced jazz series.

title: Poached Chicken Takes Flight
description: ROY IP, who owns Le Petit Cafe in Branford, Conn., grew up eating chicken poached in soy sauce in Hong Kong, and it is still an important part of his home repertory because it is so easy and delicious. In less than half an hour on the stove, the bird takes on dark, rich flavors from not just soy sauce but also ginger, scallions, star anise and an unusually fragrant wine. It's the antithesis of the usual poached chicken, in which all the bird's flavor leaches into the cooking liquid. Instead, the meat takes on a powerfully complex taste from the seasonings.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES AGREES TO PURCHASE AIR BAG MAKER
description: Harvard Industries, a maker of vehicle door frames and interior parts, agreed yesterday to buy Breed Technologies Inc. in a bid to take the company, which makes air bags, out of bankruptcy. The purchase, which is subject to bankruptcy court approval, calls for Harvard to assume about $300 million of Breed's debt. It will also pay about $220 million in cash and notes to creditors. Breed creditors would get about 45 percent of the equity of the combined company. Breed, once the third-largest maker of air bags, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in September. The combined company would have about $1.7 billion in annual sales.

title: A Homey Pit Stop, Hard by I-95

But interstate travel is no picnic; for years, we survived on a convenience diet of hamburgers and gasoline fumes. And then we discovered the boxed lunches at Sally Bell's Kitchen, halfway between the two cities.

title: Brazil's Rural Violence
description: This month in the Brazilian state of Para, the wealthy and influential rancher Jeronimo Alves Amorim received a 19-year prison term for ordering the murder of a rural union leader, Expedito Ribeiro de Souza, nine years ago. More than 1,000 activists for the landless such as Mr. Ribeiro de Souza have been killed in Brazil in the last 10 years. Only a handful of the murderers have been tried, virtually all of them low-level hired triggermen. The conviction and sentencing of the powerful Mr. Amorim is one of several recent setbacks for Brazil's ranchers, whose drive for land is furthering the destruction of the Amazon and condemning peasants to lives of destitution.

title: The Outrage in Central Park
description: New Yorkers were rightfully outraged when they learned that a roving mob of young men assaulted several women in Central Park early Sunday evening, just after the annual Puerto Rican National Day parade. A televised videotape that showed the mob reveling in these savage attacks was horrifying enough. But the rampage took on an even more disturbing cast when victims charged that police officers whom they had approached to report the attacks did nothing -- at a time when swift intervention might have prevented further assaults. Besides bringing the assailants to justice, the Police Department needs to determine as swiftly as possible which officers performed honorably and which did not. It must punish any who violated the public trust by ignoring pleas for help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKERSON, JAMES
description: WILKERSON-James (Joe) Platt, died on June 8, at his home, Dover House, Chipping Camden, Gloucester, England. He was 85 years old. He died from complications caused by cancer of the spine. A graduate of Amherst College in 1937, he joined the Young & Rubicam advertising agency, where he advanced to head one of its largest clients, General Foods. In 1959, he became Senior Vice President and Director, Y&R Europe and Managing Director of the agency's London office. After leaving Young & Rubicam as an Executive Vice President in 1968, he served on the board of Marsteller Advertising and Burson-Marsteller, Public Relations and took an active role in its European advertising operation. He was also a sheep farmer and tree planter at his former home, Admington Hall in Warwickshire. He was President of the International Wine and Food Society. He is survived by his wife, Audrey (Potter); three daughters, Ann Olson, from Olive Hill, Kentucky, Cathy Wilkerson, from Brooklyn, NY, and Robin Wilkerson from Lincoln, Mass., and four grandchildren. Memorial donations to your local community hospice.

Apache plans to acquire Permian Basin and South Texas properties that have a daily production of about 40 million cubic feet of natural gas and 4,000 barrels of liquid hydrocarbons. The properties have proven reserves of about 502 billion cubic feet of gas equivalent. Shares of Apache rose $2.125, to $58.9375 each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE RUSSOW, AUDREY THRASHER
description: de RUSSOW-Audrey Thrasher. Formerly of Old Field, NY died Friday, June 9 in Denver, CO. She was 78. Born June 24, 1921 in NYC she was the only child of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Leslie Thrasher (Janet van H. Jackson). Her father, Leslie, was a well known artist and illustrator during the 1920's and 30's, best known for his covers for Liberty Magazine and the Saturday Evening Post. She attended Spence in NYC and Baldwin outside of Philadelphia. Among Mrs. de Russow's many interests were charitable work, gardening, animals, traveling and a wide circle of friends. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Wolfgang and Janet von Russow, and her granddaughters, Alexandra and Catherine of Denver, CO.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Phillips Exeter Academy's decision to let gay and lesbian couples serve as dormitory parents misstated the academy's age ranking among prep schools. Exeter, chartered in 1781, is not the country's oldest. According to the National Association of Independent Schools, the oldest is Collegiate School in New York City, founded in 1628. Governor Dummer Academy in Byfield, Mass., founded in 1763, is the nation's oldest boarding school.

title: Frederic Cassidy, 92, Expert on American Folk Language, Dies

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
Liberty, Round 2
description: Drivers on Wilshire Boulevard are doing double takes as a wall keeps changing its image. For Memorial Day last year, Mike McNeilly started to paint a 12-story Statue of Liberty on the Westwood Medical Building, in an area where zoning prohibits commercial billboards. It was meant to honor war veterans, the artist said, but after a city councilman took action, work was suspended and the matter ended up in court. Not that Mr. McNeilly waited around for a ruling. After painting the word ''censored'' over the half-finished work, he returned in time for Memorial Day last month with a second take, right, on Liberty.

title: CLINTON LAWYERS GIVE A GO-AHEAD TO MISSILE SHIELD
description: Administration lawyers have advised President Clinton that, in their view, he could begin building the first piece of a national missile defense system without violating a 1972 arms control treaty with Russia, senior officials said.

title: Defenseless in the Park
description: A few weeks ago, I was chased by a group of young men in broad daylight on my way to Prospect Park in Brooklyn. It was a Sunday afternoon, and I was headed to the park to go jogging. I'd just reached the corner of Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, a busy street, when shouts and catcalls made me turn around. About 10 men were coming at me, one spraying toward my face with fluorescent canned string.

title: NORTEL NETWORKS WILL ACQUIRE EPICON FOR $275 MILLION

Epicon, based in Chelmsford, Mass., makes software that allows clients to install, manage and update software on thousands of desktop computers from a central server. The company, which was founded in 1997, has 60 employees. Shares of Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, rose $1.3125, to $64.5625 each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Lost at Los Alamos
description: The security failures at the Los Alamos National Laboratory have been appalling. Two computer hard drives containing sensitive nuclear weapons data have disappeared from its vault, and officials do not know whether they were misplaced, stolen or accidentally destroyed. To make matters worse, employees who first noticed the loss failed to inform their superiors for three weeks while trying in vain to find the highly secret material. Secretary of Energy Bill Richardson, who quieted earlier controversies over security lapses with assertions that he would not tolerate more failures, has a lot to answer for in this case. Clearly, he has not done enough to solve security problems at the nuclear weapons laboratories.

title: At ArtMuseum.net, Project Explores Fusion Of Art and Technology

In ''Multimedia: From Wagner to Virtual Reality,'' a history project installed this week on Intel's ArtMuseum.net site, Mr. Packer argues that the Internet's multimedia capabilities have descended from the fusion of the arts envisioned by Richard Wagner, the 19th-century composer of opera's ''Ring'' cycle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALTON, CATHERINE J.
description: DALTON-Catherine J. Dr. Catherine J. Dalton, 83, died at home June 9, after a long illness. Born August 7, 1916 in Brooklyn, NY, Dr. Dalton graduated from NY Medical College in 1948. Following residency training, she was on the attending radiology staff at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital for 5 years. From 1956-1965, she headed the x-ray department at the NY Infirmary. She then became director of the radiology department at what was then Doctors' Hospital (now Beth Israel North), remaining there until her retirement in 1981. Since 1963, Dr. Dalton had owned a summer home on Block Island and after her retirement, chose to spend 6 months there each year. She leaves two sisters, Mrs. Anthony Petrone of Rockville Center, NY and Mrs. Matthew Doherty of Afton, NY, as well as 20 nieces and nephews. A memorial Mass was celebrated at St. Agnes' Cathedral in Rockville Center on Monday, June 12. The family asks that remembrances be sent to The Block Island Conservancy or Habitat for Humanity.

She is survived by one niece and two nephews. Visiting will be Thursday from 2 to 4. Funeral service Thursday, 3:30 PM at the funeral home. Burial Friday, 1 PM at the Evergreen Cemetery in Brooklyn. For further information contact Anderson & Campbell Funeral Home, Whiting, New Jersey, 732-350-5700.

title: The Vigilance That Can't Let Up
description: The outrageous and violent behavior of a large gang of young men who were totally out of control in Central Park on Sunday was a troubling reminder of the bad old days that most New Yorkers, myself included, had felt were behind us. It seems inconceivable that over two dozen women could have been assaulted in broad daylight. Fear is now consuming the public -- a fear that was compounded by a weekend that also saw seven homicides and 28 shootings in the city.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Cutback
description: The Kaiser Aluminum Corporation, the third-largest United States aluminum maker, said today that it would dismiss 400 temporary employees at smelting plants in Tacoma and Mead, Wash., as it temporarily cuts capacity because of high power costs. The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, a unit of Houston-based Kaiser, also said it had sold back 100 megawatts of power that it has under contract through June 30, 2001.

title: Coals to Newcastle
description: Sunny Los Angeles may sound like the last place to pay for a tan, but in fact, tanning parlors here can be high art, as the Swiss-born architect Frank Escher and his Sri Lankan partner, Ravi GuneWardena, demonstrated with this, their second Electric Sun Salon. Rising to the challenge, they came up with a serenely minimal space whose decorative effect comes from the play of light. A pink glow from installed lights mingles with a turquoise wash cast by the tanning beds. The high-gloss look is finished off with red vinyl seats, a glass counter and a shiny gray-white floor. The salon, shown, just opened at 14364 Ventura Boulevard, Sherman Oaks; (818) 784-8834.

title: Out West, Giving the Musical Some Pop
description: The Broadway musical, ever in search of the shows that will expand its traditional audience into hipper or younger (or both) sectors of the populace, pushed forward this past season with ''Contact,'' ''James Joyce's 'The Dead' '' and ''The Wild Party,'' all of which offered innovation in form or tone. Now in Southern California, three nascent works are trying to lure new (and old) theatergoers by energizing the traditional form with the force of pop culture in general and rock 'n' roll in particular. They vary in their achievement, but they all project at least one welcome idea: the world of pop is stageable, a tap-worthy vein of material.

title: PMC-SIERRA BUYS THE REST OF MALLEABLE FOR $229 MILLION
description: PMC-Sierra Inc., a designer of computer chips for communications and networking equipment, agreed yesterday to buy the remainder of Malleable Technologies for $229.3 million in stock. PMC-Sierra will pay 1.25 million shares for the 85 percent of closely held Malleable it does not already own. The 40 employees of Malleable, which is based in San Jose, Calif., will join PMC-Sierra's office in Silicon Valley. This is PMC-Sierra's fourth acquisition this year. Malleable's chips are adept at transmitting voice traffic as chunks of data. Shares of PMC-Sierra, which is based in Burnaby, British Columbia, fell $6.25, to $183.4375 each, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Bryant Feasts, Especially In Clutch
description: He started tentatively, moving gingerly, though without a limp. Kobe Bryant was back in the lineup for the Los Angeles Lakers tonight, but he was not quite himself. He did not have his typical lift on jump shots and was unable to shoot comfortably over Indiana's Mark Jackson. His forays to the basket were few as he settled on the perimeter.

title: Booming Atlanta Saps Water as Drought Wilts Georgia
description: Just after dawn they emerge onto their pillowy meadows of fescue and bluegrass, some with hoses and some with mighty irrigation systems, each squeezing out every last legal drop of water before the 10 a.m. cutoff arrives with its water police, tattling neighbors and dark civic guilt.

title: Queens Sophomore Wins the 200
description: Yendy Gilchrist, a sophomore at Beach Channel High School in Queens, won the 200-meter dash in 25.85 seconds and was second in the 100 meters at the 16th annual Eastern States girls championships yesterday at Mitchel Field in Garden City, N.Y.

title: KODAK PLANS TO EXPAND ITS STOCK REPURCHASE PROGRAM
description: Citing expectations of higher revenue and reduced spending, the Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would accelerate its stock repurchase program, buying as much as $1.2 billion in stock by the end of the year. Robert Brust, chief financial officer, said the Rochester-based company would buy back $9 million to $10 million worth of shares a day, starting today. That is up sharply from the current daily average of about $1 million. Last year, Kodak bought back about $925 million of its stock under a repurchasing program announced in April 1999. Shares of Kodak rose $1.50 yesterday, to $60.25 each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: This Way In (or Out)
description: Ever wondered where interior designers and the house-proud in Los Angeles shop? At boutiques on La Brea and Beverly Boulevards and on Melrose Avenue (Skank World and Modernica, to name two), in the workrooms of furniture designers like Gregg Fleishman (above, outside his studio in Culver City) and at flea markets. That's the latest from Michael Webb, author of ''Architecture & Design LA'' (The Understanding Business, $14), whose third edition is subtitled ''Selective Guide to the Best Buildings, Interiors, Design Resources and Arts Facilities in Southern California.'' What is ''out,'' Mr. Webb? Most showrooms at the Pacific Design Center (though Knoll, Snaidero and Dakota Jackson make the cut) and chain stores like Ikea. The 88-page guidebook's design and building supplies source list is a useful addition to an opinionated tour of the best architecture in Los Angeles; (510) 649-3730.

title: Knitting Factory Goes Hollywood
description: Let's begin with a generalization: the main difference between going to a concert in Manhattan or in Hollywood is the intent. In Manhattan, most people go to a concert because the act is good or interesting or has been recommended by a trustworthy source. In Hollywood, most people seem to be attending shows because the acts are on the pop charts, seeking to land on the pop charts or predicted to make the pop charts. Or they buy tickets (more accurately, land on the guest list) because the performers are acquaintances of a friend or in business with a friend.

title: Heaven Can't Wait
description: Religious patronage of architecture is alive in Garden Grove, Calif., where the religious broadcaster Dr. Robert H. Schuller (inset), 73, oversees a 38-acre homage to design. His latest project, a $20 million visitors center he likes to call the International Center for Possibility Thinking (drawing, above), is being built beside Philip Johnson's Crystal Cathedral (1981) and Richard Neutra's Tower of Hope (1968). Dr. Schuller, whose program, ''Hour of Power,'' attracts millions of viewers, bought and bulldozed 38 private residences to make room for the center, designed by Richard Meier. How did a pastor become the Lorenzo de' Medici of American architecture -- or, as he put it, ''hooked on architecture of the highest league''? ''Architecture should not only be elegant but also eloquent,'' Dr. Schuller said. ''People come onto our property and say what a wonderful feeling this is.''

title: A New Magazine Celebrates The Guy Called Dad
description: IT is an axiom in the publishing business that when a demographic group is ready, its magazine will appear. It happened with Rolling Stone, it happened with Maxim, it happened with Bassmaster and Jane, and now it is happening with Dads. For the first time in history, a lifestyle magazine aimed exclusively at men who are parents -- that is, men whose male, non-gender-neutral parenthood techniques form an integral component of their personalities -- has arrived. The only question to ask Dads Media L.L.C., the publisher, is, what took you so long?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUANG, JOHN
description: HUANG-John. It is with great sorrow that we mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, John Huang. John was a credit to both the medical profession and the legal profession. His insight and analytical skills will sorely be missed. Most cherished of all, however, was his friendship and loyalty and it is in that regard that we are left with a void that will be filled with memories. In all facets of life, he has left an indelible mark. His legacy will surely live on in the hearts of those he touched and in his caring and devoted wife Mabel and two sons, Michael and David, of whom he was tremendously proud. We were honored to have spent this time with you and our prayers go out to you and your family until we meet again. Roy F. Scaffidi, Esq.

title: Korean Reconciliation
description: This week's first encounter between the leaders of North and South Korea did not end tensions in one of the most volatile corners of the world, but it did begin to overcome the enmity of a half-century. The Clinton administration rightly seeks to reinforce the gains by lifting many sanctions against Pyongyang. The North-South meetings unfolded in a surprisingly cordial atmosphere, and yesterday's joint declaration, though vaguely worded, contained just about all that could be realistically hoped for from this initial meeting. President Kim Dae Jung returns to South Korea with his stature enhanced. North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, shed some of his reputation for reclusiveness and mystery.

description: A group that includes the Carlisle Companies of Syracuse and Caik Holding, agreed to buy Icopal, a Danish maker of building materials, for 4 billion kroner ($520 million), beating a bid from Trelleborg A.B. of Sweden. Caik is offering 435 kroner a share. It has already acquired more than half of Icopal, which earlier rejected Trelleborg's bid of 420 kroner a share.

description: The police released photographs of seven young men yesterday who were caught on amateur videotapes taken Sunday in Central Park during a wild melee in which at least two dozen women were sexually abused after the National Puerto Rican Day Parade.

description: Prosecutors have charged dozens of people with using stock manipulation, fraud and violence to steal from thousands of investors across the country in a scheme that federal authorities are calling one of organized crime's most aggressive forays into the stock market.

description: In the stretch at the International Team Trials in Memphis, which ended Monday night after nine days, the cognoscenti were confused. ''It's over,'' they said. ''No, it's not.'' ''Yes, it is.''

title: Will Chairs Fly on the Web, or Just Fold?
description: A YEAR ago, the idea of selling furniture on the Internet seemed a stroke of genius. What could be cooler than clicking up a couch? Over a dozen Web sites sprang into action, all promising to take the schlep out of shopping and the fear out of fabric selection. After all, the furnishings industry was huge, with more than $190 billion in sales in 1999, by the estimate of the Bureau of Economic Analysis. Moreover, there weren't a lot of household names dominating the marketplace. The gold rush was on.

Still, she was stunned the evening that a group of rowdy Verdi listeners started flinging food from their perches on the Rumsey Playfield and briefly shut down a performance of the New York Grand Opera.

title: NEW ROLE FOR FORMER CANADIAN LEADER
description: Brian Mulroney, 61, left, who was prime minister of Canada from 1984 to 1993 and is the chairman of the Sun Media Corporation, has temporarily become its chief executive after the surprise resignation of Paul Godfrey. Mr. Mulroney was president of the Iron Ore Company of Canada before he was elected leader of the Progressive Conservative Party in 1983. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

Stokes, Martha E. van Nierop and Jean E. Urban and ten grandchildren. Memorial service at St. Barnabas Church, Greenwich, CT on Friday, June 16, 2000 at 11:00 AM. Interment private.

title: It's Where The Twine Meets
description: Andy Hackman and Kathy Guild, co-owners of the Outside furniture store, recently came across a surprisingly comfortable iron and twine garden chair with a fruit shape and unknown provenance. They recast it as the curvy Pear chair, using the same materials. The chair feels like a taut hammock and is made to order for $700, from Outside, 442 North La Brea Avenue, Los Angeles; (323) 934-1254.

title: TWO LAUNDRY DETERGENT BUSINESSES FORM PARTNERSHIP
description: The Church & Dwight Company, the Princeton, N.J., maker of Arm & Hammer baking soda, agreed yesterday to combine its laundry detergent business with USA Detergents Inc. of North Brunswick, N.J., to cut costs and improve its supply chain. Church & Dwight bought a 10 percent stake in USA Detergents for $10 million and has an option to buy another 5 percent later. Church & Dwight would get 55 percent to 65 percent of the profit. The new partnership, named Armus L.L.C., would include Church & Dwight's Arm & Hammer detergents and USA Detergent's Xtra detergents and Nice 'N Fluffy fabric softeners. Armus will have more than $400 million in annual sales and about 10 percent market share by volume, Church & Dwight said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an agreement with the musicians' union permitting the distribution of classical music over the Internet referred incorrectly to orchestral recordings conducted by Sir Georg Solti and Fritz Reiner. Both were most closely associated with the Chicago Symphony; neither recorded with the Boston, Cleveland or Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: Lunch Spots Mirror Changes in Brooklyn Court's Mood
description: The elders of Court Street still talk fondly of the days when the biggest difference between the good guys and the bad guys was a government pension, when guys from opposite sides of the law were hardly averse to hoisting a few together on quiet afternoons or even elbowing up to the same lunch counter.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Irish tenor Frank Patterson on Tuesday misspelled the names of three singers with whom he recorded a compilation of Handel arias and Hugo Wolf songs. The three were Hermann Prey (not Herman), Elly Ameling (not Ely) and Jose Carreras (not Carerras).

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Phillips Exeter Academy's decision to let gay and lesbian couples serve as dormitory parents misstated the academy's age ranking among prep schools. Exeter, chartered in 1781, is not the country's oldest. According to the National Association of Independent Schools, the oldest is Collegiate School in New York City, founded in 1628. Governor Dummer Academy in Byfield, Mass., founded in 1763, is the nation's oldest boarding school.

description: Everybody has a breaking point, Chuck Knoblauch said last month after his throwing jitters resurfaced, and the Yankees' second baseman apparently reached his after his problems erupted worse than ever last night. After throwing away three balls in the first six innings of last night's 12-3 loss to the Chicago White Sox, Knoblauch left the game. Then he left Yankee Stadium as well, walking out in his street clothes while the game was in progress.

The elevator operator has already developed a fluent line of snappy patter, and he needs it, because time hangs heavy during the ascent. Visually, however, there's a big payoff when the doors finally open. AZ (pronounced like the two letters) is a real eyeful, with a peaked skylight that opens in fair weather and closes at the first spattering of rain.

title: A Landscape of Wide-Eyed Wonder as a Political Storm Gathers Overhead
description: It sometimes seems as if the film industries of a peaceful, prosperous, and more or less united Europe have staked their survival on recreating the strife, misery and division of the European past. In recent years, the political catastrophes that convulsed the continent in the middle decades of the 20th century have become fodder for costume drama, as horror gives way to sentimentality.

title: A Son of Chicago -- William Michael Daley
description: To some, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley is as affable, self-effacing and disarmingly smooth as any top-drawer lobbyist in this town. To others, he is the perfect child of Chicago's gritty machine politics: brass-knuckles tough, vindictive and, at times, searingly blunt.

description: PIORE-Nora Kahn. The faculty, students, alumni and staff of Columbia's Mailman School of Public Health mourn the passing of its esteemed faculty member, Nora Kahn Piore. A professor of public health economics from 1972 to 1982, she enjoyed a varied career that spanned fifty years working on issues related to health insurance, health economics and policy analysis for New York City's Commissioners of Health, Hospitals and Welfare. To her children, grandchildren and sister, we extend deepest sympathy. Allan Rosenfield, MD Dean

description: American trade restrictions on imported steel have cost customers in this country as much as $150 billion in the last three decades, a new study sponsored by foreign steel producers asserts.

description: It has been a place of advantage all season long, a place where hardly anyone wins besides the Indiana Pacers. So how odd it would be for the Los Angeles Lakers to hug and dance while wearing championship caps amid the throwback features of Conseco Fieldhouse.

title: A Dazzling Flash, Reflected at Last Upon History
description: Modernism may or may not be over, but that hasn't kept historians from adding names to its roster. With more and more names from more parts of the world, it is at last being defined as a multinational, multicultural phenomenon, which it always was.

title: Efficiency on Wheels; U.S. Auto Industry Is Catching Up With the Japanese
description: The Ford Taurus factory in Atlanta has no air-conditioning to ward off the sweltering heat of the Georgia summer. Its scuffed concrete floors and sooty ceiling beams hold the grit of 53 years of car-building. On the assembly line, orange robots weld car roofs and sides and, farther down, hundreds of men and women install the cars' interiors. To all appearances, it is an utterly ordinary car factory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, ALFRED., M.D.
description: MARKOWITZ-Alfred., M.D. The Faculty and Staff of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Alfred Markowitz. Dr. Markowitz served the medical center for nearly half a century, contributing greatly to medical education, research and practice. He was an outstanding educator, clinician and researcher who will be particularly remembered by the countless medical students and surgical residents he trained. Dr. Markowitz was Professor Emeritus of Clinical Surgery at the time of his death. He will be missed and his memory cherished. We extend our deepest sympathy to the Markowitz family. Thomas Q. Morris, M.D. Interim Dean for Clinical and Educational Affairs. Columbia Univ. College of Physicians & Surgeons David I. Hirsh, PHD, Interim Dean for Research, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons.

title: Oh, It's Not What It Used to Be
description: The Bowery is nobody's idea of paradise. But when the aging buildings and their fire escapes shimmer in the morning light, it's a place of urban beauty, alluring like an Edward Hopper painting. Its flat facades, with their mismatched colors and styles and uneven heights, create an eclectic backdrop for a glimpse of what the city might have been like the last time the century turned. The Bowery deserves better than its skid row connotations.

title: West Nile Test May Set Off City Spraying
description: New York City health officials said yesterday that they were preparing to spray insecticide over a broad swath of Corona, Queens, next week after blood tests showed that a chicken in the area had been infected with the West Nile virus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, CLAIRE G.,
description: BERNSTEIN-Claire G., 92, on June 14, 2000. Daughter of the late Anna and Leon Gilbson, sister of Helen Trager, wife of the late Leo Bernstein and widow of Joseph Steinberger. She is remembered by her children, grandchildren and niece. Contributions in Claire's name may be made to the Henry Ittelson Center, Riverdale.

title: DEAL FOR RUSSIAN CIGARETTE MAKER
description: Expanding into a market with a population of heavy smokers, the British concern Gallaher Group will buy the Russian cigarette maker Liggett-Ducat for $390.5 million. The deal gives Gallaher the biggest share of a market where an estimated 260 billion cigarettes were smoked last year. Gallaher will acquire the company, with assets including a new factory in Moscow and distribution operations from the Vector Group of the United States. Liggett-Ducat, which had sales of $92.5 million last year, is Russia's biggest seller, with 50 percent of the market for cheap cigarettes and 17 percent of the market over all. Sabrina Tavernise

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about chicken exports to India misstated the prices at which Perdue Farms estimated that it could sell chicken legs there. Assuming a 35 percent tariff, the company said, it could charge one-third to one-half less than local merchants, not a third to a half of local prices.

description: Sweet and Lowdown

title: To a Quaint Fishing Port Came a Jazzy City Boy, Lured by the Light
description: At first look, the quaint fishing port of Gloucester, Mass., seems an unlikely hangout for the jazzy city painter Stuart Davis (1894-1964). But Davis loved the place, with its sea-brightened light, its rocky coast, its maritime activity and its art colony goings-on. Besides Davis, these attributes lured well-known painters over the years, including Winslow Homer, William Morris Hunt and Frank Duveneck in the late 19th century, and Edward Hopper, John Sloan, Childe Hassam, William Glackens and Milton Avery in the 20th.

title: Drought Bakes Much of South, Periling Crops
description: The pond on Dave Barry's farm, once six feet deep, has dried to a mud puddle, surrounded by ominous purple flowers atop alfalfa that is blooming far too soon.

title: Deputy Likely to Take Daley's Place
description: President Clinton is likely to name Robert L. Mallett, the deputy commerce secretary, to replace William M. Daley as acting secretary as a result of the announcement that Mr. Daley would lead the Gore campaign, an administration official said tonight.

title: Up a Lazy Canal, Alone in a Kayak
description: ''You look pretty,'' the little girl said as my yellow kayak glided past. At first -- tired, sweaty, sunburned -- I thought I hadn't heard right.

title: Pardon for the Pope's Attacker
description: The pardon of Mehmet Ali Agca, would-be assassin of Pope John Paul II, is a reminder that cold-war mysteries may still lie buried in the archives of the former Soviet Union and the East bloc. Mr. Agca shot the pope at his weekly general audience in St. Peter's Square on May 13, 1981. John Paul was wounded in his hand and stomach, and required two operations and four and a half months of convalescence. Whether Mr. Agca acted alone or at the bidding of the K.G.B. and the Bulgarian secret service, or was backed by the Gray Wolves, a right-wing Turkish terror group to which he belonged, is still unknown.

title: COTELLIGENT SAYS IT IS SELLING STAFFING UNIT TO COMSYS
description: Cotelligent Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its staffing unit to the privately held Comsys Information Technology Services for about $121 million plus assumed debt of $10 million. Comsys, based in Houston, provides information technology to large and midsize corporations in 30 offices across the United States. Cotelligent, based in San Francisco, provides information technology consulting and outsourcing services, as well as Web site design and electronic commerce development. It had revenue of $338.8 million in the year that ended March 31. Cotelligent shares were unchanged yesterday at $5.50.

title: LUCENT SAYS IT WILL BE PRIMARY SUPPLIER FOR VERIZON
description: Lucent Technologies, the phone equipment maker, said yesterday that it would be the main supplier of network equipment to the Verizon Wireless venture in an agreement valued at as much as $1.5 billion. Verizon, the United States wireless venture of Bell Atlantic and Vodafone AirTouch, and Lucent announced a letter of intent and said they expected to sign a contract this year. The equipment would allow Verizon, the largest United States wireless carrier, to increase its coverage and capacity and help it offer high-speed Internet and other data and voice services. Cellular companies like Verizon are hoping Internet access will encourage customers to use their phones more.

title: With Visions of Bonanza, Gore Will Offer $500 Billion in Tax Cuts
description: Expecting a shower of gold at the end of the month when new budget surplus estimates are released, Vice President Al Gore said today that he would offer Americans $500 billion in tax cuts over 10 years.

title: No Fluff, No Gimmickry In These Searing Stories
description: In discussions of popular culture nowadays, few words are more crassly degraded than reality, as in the ''reality programming'' that is a hot new television trend. The misapplication of the word to categorize gimmicky televised pseudo-events is all the more distressing when such sensationalist fluff is compared with the best documentary and fiction films to be seen each year at the Human Rights Watch Film Festival. This reality is the genuine article.

description: On a foggy opening day of the United States Open, Tiger Woods was crystal clear about his intentions.

description: When Ruby Sprott read an advertisement last fall announcing plans for new two- and three-family houses in central Harlem for people with annual incomes of $50,000 to $70,950, she saw it as an opportunity to make the leap from a 12-year renter to a homeowner in the neighborhood.

title: Ruth R. Goddard, 98; Led Many Charities
description: Ruth R. Goddard, a leader of the American Jewish Committee for more than 50 years who was also active in many other philanthropies in New York, died Tuesday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 98.

description: In the legal equivalent of a bench-clearing brawl, closing arguments in the tax-fraud trial of Albert J. Pirro Jr. ended chaotically this afternoon after the prosecution suggested that Mr. Pirro lusted for money in much the way it said President Richard M. Nixon had lusted for power.

title: Mr. Putin and the Plutocrats
description: The shape of Vladimir Putin's presidency could well be determined by the unfolding clash between the Russian leader and the small group of business titans who control much of their nation's wealth. Certainly, Mr. Putin faces no more difficult task than determining how to curb their political and economic influence without trampling on Russia's newly found freedoms. His government has not made a promising start by arresting Vladimir Gusinsky, an oligarch who owns Russia's only independent television network and some of its most fearless newspapers and magazines. Mr. Putin seemed to acknowledge as much yesterday when he called the arrest ''excessive.''

description: It's been on and off more times than Dame Edna's wig, but the long-awaited production of ''The Unexpected Man,'' by Yasmina Reza, who won a Tony Award for ''Art,'' is apparently coming to fruition, and with an impressive cast to boot.

title: Verily, He Talks the Talk
description: Across the bloody fields of Scotland, in the land where the stage smoke swirls and the synthesizers scream like banshees, strides a faceless figure in black, thudding along in thick, corpse-kicking boots. Who is this masked man, speaking so portentously about how ''foul and fair'' his day has been? At last he raises the gleaming vizard of his helmet and there, behold, is a most familiar wide-browed visage: hey, it's one of America's most popular television stars, and, boy, does he look as if he means business.

title: BRAZIL TRADE DATA STRENGTHENS
description: The broadest measure of Brazilian trade showed the lowest deficit in three months in May, reflecting the strength of Brazilian export growth. The deficit, which narrowed to $1.62 billion from $3.08 billion in April, also reflected a drop in interest payments on government bonds. Rising confidence in the Brazilian economy also led to an increase in direct investment in Brazil by multinational companies, to $1.77 billion from $1.36 billion in April. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: City Tax Cuts Still Possible, Giuliani Says
