title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: SAINT ETIENNE: ''Sound of Water'' (Sub Pop). ''Sail away, sail away,'' Sarah Cracknell of Saint Etienne coos in ''How We Used to Live,'' the nine-minute mini-suite that sums up ''Sound of Water'' as it drifts between distant, unhappy memories and persistent hope. For a decade, Saint Etienne has been leavening pop songs with dance-club rhythms, coolly observing how far astray passion and ambition can lead. The band's fifth unified album, ''Sound of Water,'' floats above the fray; its songs yearn for escape and sanctuary. Saint Etienne collaborated with the minimalist German electronic group To Rococo Rot and with Sean O'Hagan, the Beach Boys idolator from the High Llamas. The few uptempo songs are skeletal and abstracted, transparently displaying their underlying patterns of clicks and blips and nonsense pop syllables, while the ballads sway between two chords like Brian Wilson in a hammock. Saint Etienne remains fascinated with pop construction, but has moved past cleverness and easy ironies. Its songs are no longer puzzles; they're atmospheric, self-contained worlds. JON PARELES

The deal would allow E*Trade to build a cross-border electronic trading network and receive revenue from Versus trades. E*Trade now gets licensing revenue from Versus, which handles 13 percent of the trading volume on the Toronto Stock Exchange. E*Trade, based in Menlo Park, Calif., had revenue of $621.4 million last year. Its stock rose 50 cents, to $17.125.

In Act I the Polonaise music for aristocrats goes to jolly peasants, and Prince Siegfried is pictured as a wallflower.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Saturday about the cancellation of a United States tour, including a concert at Radio City Music Hall, by Kazem el-Saher, a pop singer originally from Iraq, misstated the reason. United States visas were delayed for the Iraqi band members, but not for Mr. el-Saher, who has Canadian citizenship and does not need a visa.

title: EMMIS IS BUYING 2 RADIO STATIONS FROM CLEAR CHANNEL
description: Emmis Communications said yesterday that it would buy two radio stations for $108 million. Emmis, based in Indianapolis, said it would buy the stations -- KKFR-FM in Phoenix and KXPK-FM in Denver -- from Clear Channel Communications, which is acquiring AMFM Inc. Emmis, which owns radio and television stations as well as print magazines, has said it wants to quadruple the size of its radio business in the 30 biggest United States markets and plans to become more of a pure radio company by separating the slower-growth television stations from the rest of its holdings. The shares of Emmis jumped $4.625 each, or 13.8 percent, to $38.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: GEORGIA JOINS TRADE GROUP
description: The former Soviet republic of Georgia has officially become the 137th member of the World Trade Organization. It is the fourth former republic to gain membership, joining Kyrgyzstan, Latvia and Estonia. The country first applied to join in 1996 and was approved for membership last October. When Georgia's Parliament failed to ratify its membership accord before January, the deadline was extended. About 30 other countries, notably China and Russia, are waiting to join the global trade group, which sets rules for international commerce. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Germany's Pledge to Close Nuclear Plants: That's Green Power
description: The government decision to close the 19 nuclear power plants in Germany over the next 20 years reflects the power of the environmentalist movement in a country where the trauma of war has imbued the term ''nuclear'' with a powerful negative resonance.

title: He's an Engineering Major, Kinda Cute but Um, Like, a Real Control Freak
description: If you're still disconsolate over the demise of ''Beverly Hills 90210,'' then ''Boys and Girls'' may be the movie for you. I don't mean the early, cheesy Shannen Doherty ''90210,'' mind you, or the sleazy, soap-operatic Dylan-in-distress middle years. What this feeble, harmless romantic comedy calls to mind is an extra-long episode from one of the show's interminable final seasons, in which the cast seemed to change every week and nobody could remember if Donna was still a virgin or not, because nobody -- not the audience, not the writers, not even the long-suffering David -- cared.

title: WITH RATES UP, WACHOVIA ISSUES PROFIT WARNING
description: The Wachovia Corporation, a Southeast regional bank, warned yesterday that it was unlikely to meet analyst expectations for the second quarter and for the year as rising interest rates cut into its income from loans and from its capital markets, mortgage and investment businesses. Wachovia shares plunged $13.125, almost 19 percent, to $57.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., said the shortfall could be attributed to ''the dampening of activity in market-sensitive'' businesses like capital markets, mortgages and investments. Wachovia also warned that it would increase its provision for future loan losses by $200 million. Wachovia did not disclose how much earnings would be reduced.

title: Detectives Hope Basement Holds Clue to Etan Patz
description: On a spring day 21 years ago, 6-year-old Etan Patz left his family's SoHo loft to walk to his school bus alone for the first time, and vanished without a trace. Over the years, his unsolved disappearance haunted investigators and came to symbolize the agonies of families with children missing in America.

title: With Accord Set, Ethiopia and Eritrea Pause in Fighting
description: Fighting between Ethiopian and Eritrean soldiers paused today as ministers from both nations prepared to sign a preliminary cease-fire on Sunday that would involve yet another role for United Nations peacekeepers in a conflict in Africa.

description: Chuck Knoblauch was infected with throwing jitters two years ago and, for two years, he instinctively played through them, always coming back in spite of all the attention they attracted.

description: John Taylor was watching the basketball finals at his barber shop at an apartment complex in the Rockaways on Wednesday when newscasters interrupted the game to report that the police were releasing the photographs of seven men sought in Sunday's melee in Central Park, his family said.

title: The Page Floats, Transformed
description: Apart from the luster of borrowed seriousness, what literature most often provides the movies is access to a deep and self-replenishing reservoir of stories. Film and the novel are cousins not far removed, and the DNA they share is narrative. But their narrative codes -- owing partly to obvious differences of media, partly to their divergent histories -- have grown further and further apart. After several generations of fervid experimentation, the flouting of storytelling norms has become, among ambitious fiction writers, a convention in itself.

title: Israeli Shots Disrupt U.N. Team in Lebanon
description: The United Nations is hoping to finish up the job of verifying that Israel has withdrawn from southern Lebanon, but its work was frustrated today when Israeli soldiers fired shots near a United Nations team visiting one of the last remaining unchecked border sites.

title: A Resemblance? It's Only Natural
description: In ''Sunshine,'' the family saga by the Hungarian filmmaker Istvan Szabo that opened in New York last Friday, the actresses Jennifer Ehle and Rosemary Harris play the same character at two different stages in her life. Ms. Ehle is the young, rebellious Valerie Sonnenschein, who marries her cousin Ignatz (Ralph Fiennes) in the twilight years of the Austro-Hungarian Empire; Ms. Harris is the mature Valerie, who survives both the death camps of World War II and the Stalinist repression of the 1950's.

title: Moldova on the Brink /Sliding Deeper Into Poverty : A Post-Communist Nation Loses Its Way
description: MOLDOVA, a former Soviet republic that is ranked as one of the poorest nations in Europeburdened by economic stagnation, corruption and organized crime  is struggling to halt a slide into even deeper poverty. The government of Moldova, a largely agricultural rolling steppe between Romania and Ukraine, has warned that the republic is undergoing "one of the most difficult periods in its history" and could slip into the ranks of the "second or third layer" of the world's nations.

title: Divining the Big Event: A Ray of Hope, at Least
description: The agreement signed at the summit meeting in Pyongyang on Wednesday, just days shy of the 50th anniversary of the start of the Korean War, was brimming with words that heralded the arrival of peace. Yet the two countries are still technically at war, and no one wants to raise the question of who would govern a unified nation.

title: MERITOR TO LAY OFF 500 AND TAKE $26 MILLION CHARGE
description: Meritor Automotive, a maker of automotive systems and components, said yesterday that it planned to lay off 500 workers and eliminate excess manufacturing capacity in Europe as part of a reorganization that will reduce costs by $21 million a year before taxes. A Meritor spokeswoman said the layoffs would be worldwide and affect all segments of the company, which employs 19,000 people. The company, based in Troy, Mich., said the actions would result in a pretax charge of $26 million.

title: Corzine, Criticized on Spending, Cuts Staff
description: Stung by criticism of his record-breaking spending in the Senate primary, Jon S. Corzine has laid off most of his campaign workers and dropped several consultants.

title: Circuit Board Expansion
description: Jabil Circuit Inc., a maker of printed circuit boards, said today that it would expand a plant in Idaho, doubling its manufacturing space there and adding as many as 700 jobs over the next few years. The company, whose products include digital displays for vehicle dashboards, circuits for remote keyless entry systems and personal computer motherboards, will add 98,000 square feet to its 170,000-square-foot manufacturing and office site in Meridian, a suburb of Boise. Jabil is currently expanding many plants and adding new ones around the world as the demand for electronics equipment increases.

title: Lazio Earned Profit On Stock in a Firm Run by Contributors
description: When Rick A. Lazio entered Congress in 1993, he had an unremarkable portfolio of personal investments. With mutual funds, municipal bonds and a blue-chip stock or two, Mr. Lazio had salted away his money in the kind of assets that countless other middle-class suburbanites have embraced.

title: RANGER ACCEPTS SWEETER BID
description: Two months after putting itself up for sale, Ranger Oil Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, accepted a takeover offer worth about $748 million from a local rival, Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. The offer tops a hostile bid worth about $680 million made April 6 by Petrobank Energy and Resources Ltd., also of Calgary. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DERLAN INDUSTRIES, Toronto, named David Williamson, president and chief operating officer, to the post of chief executive. He succeeds Dermot Coughlan, who is retiring.

title: SWISS RAISE RATES
description: Acting to contain inflation in Switzerland's expanding economy, the Swiss National Bank raised its benchmark interest rate by a greater-than-expected 50 basis points, or half a percentage point. The increase puts the bank's benchmark three-month rate target range at 3 percent to 4 percent. Economists had expected a quarter-point increase. Switzerland's economy is growing at the fastest pace since 1989, fueled by booming exports. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: District Attorney Finds No Case in Fatal Police Shooting of an Unarmed Drug Suspect
description: After a three-month investigation into the fatal shooting of an unarmed drug suspect by a police officer, the Bronx district attorney's office has ordered the case closed, concluding that the officer's gun discharged accidentally during a struggle with the suspect.

title: BRITISH STORES TO CLOSE
description: A privately held Dutch clothing retailer, C&A, said it was pulling out of Britain after 78 years, closing all 113 stores and cutting 4,800 jobs because of slumping profit and sales. Its British business posted total losses of $:250 million ($377 million) over the last five years, C&A said. Most of the British outlets will close at the end of this year.

title: Russell Redux: A Private Man Bursts Back Into the Public Eye
description: Suddenly, Bill Russell is back in public, emerging from his quiet life on Mercer Island, Wash., as the white-bearded icon of teamwork.

title: Public Interests; Other People's Election
description: It's hard to feel unloved in the middle of a big election year. Al Gore wants your vote so badly he'll come to your house and spend the afternoon telling you about the Industrial Revolution -- if you'll only ask. George W. Bush has probably already memorized your kids' ages, and given you a nickname.

This movie twists on perceptions of what is happening, starting when Fleming (Hugo Weaving) is rousted out of his dozing as his shabby one-room apartment is invaded by the police. It is not a terribly difficult movie to figure out, but it is quite diverting.

description: The Czech central bank seized control of the country's third-largest bank, Investicni a Postovni Banka, after days of panic among its customers and a run on the bank's deposits over fears that it lacked enough money to cover bad loans. The new administrator arrived at the bank accompanied by a dozen armed members of a special police unit. The Finance Ministry said the bank had suffered ''serious liquidity problems'' and that once it is stable again, would probably be sold within two years. Investicni a Postovni Banka has $8.3 billion in assets and three million personal savings accounts. Ladka Bauerova

Rambus rose $19.3125 a share, to $76, in trading of more than 64 million shares. The company's computer-memory technology helps speed personal computers and other devices by taking full advantage of faster processors from chip makers like the Intel Corporation. Toshiba's agreement to license more of Rambus's designs could increase the company's sales.

title: Homage to a Songwriter Who Made It Look Easy

If his songwriting lacked a personal stamp as distinctive as Lorenz Hart's, Oscar Hammerstein's or Cole Porter's, he melded aspects of their voices (Hart's urbane wit, Hammerstein's formal grandeur and Porter's verbal dexterity) into a flowery cosmopolitan diction that embodied a romantic 1950's ideal of aristocratic style.

description: FEDER-Samuel Lamie, MD. The Department of Psychiatry of Weill Medical College of Cornell University, New York-Presbyterian Hospital, notes with sorrow the passing on June 6 at his home in Lenox, MA of Dr. Lamie Feder, esteemed colleague, mentor and friend. Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College from 1975 until his retirement in 1986, Dr. Feder served as Clinical Director, as Acting Medical Director, and later as Associate Medical Director and Senior Psychiatrist at the Westchester Division of the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center. Faculty and staff who were privileged to work with Lamie extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Marie and to his children and grandchildren. Jack D. Barchas, MD, Psychiatrist-in-Chief Philip J. Wilner, MD, Medical Director Virginia L. Susman, MD, Associate Medical Director

Mr. Springsteen is The Boss, a pillar of humanity in rock. Ms. Schlessinger is merely bossy -- a mean-spirited ''doctor'' (in physiology, not psychology) who dispenses authoritarian advice to pathetic lonelyhearts desperate enough to seek family counseling from a call-in radio show.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM HAS REJECTED A BUYOUT OFFER
description: The International Aluminum Corporation, a maker of windows and doors, has received and rejected a $72.4 million buyout offer from a shareholder, the Columbia Ventures Corporation, saying the company was not for sale. Columbia Ventures, a closely held aluminum fabricator in Vancouver, Wash., offered $18.25 a share for International Aluminum, according to a regulatory filing made on Thursday. The offer was 22 percent more than Wednesday's closing share price. Columbia and its owner, Kenneth D. Peterson Jr., together own about 312,000 shares, or a 7.3 percent stake in International Aluminum, which is based in Monterey Park, Calif. Shares of International Aluminum rose $1.3125 each yesterday, to $16.375, on the Big Board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUANG, JOHN
description: HUANG-John. It is with great sorrow that we mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, John Huang. John was a credit to both the medical profession and the legal profession. His insight and analytical skills will sorely be missed. Most cherished of all, however, was his friendship and loyalty and it is in that regard that we are left with a void that will be filled with memories. In all facets of life, he has left an indelible mark. His legacy will surely live on in the hearts of those he touched and in his caring and devoted wife Mabel and two sons, Michael and David, of whom he was tremendously proud. We were honored to have spent this time with you and our prayers go out to you and your family until we meet again. Roy F. Scaffidi, Esq.

title: Africa's Swelling Refugee Crisis
description: The recent fighting between Ethiopia and Eritrea and the war in Sierra Leone are adding to Africa's outcast multitudes. Refugees and the internally displaced -- those who flee their homes without crossing borders -- are among the saddest byproducts of the continent's wars. Africa has more than 3 million refugees and some 15 million internally displaced, a much higher number than 10 years ago. These outcasts are straining the resources of their host communities and the good will of donors, and yet there is no end to the stream of people fleeing for their lives.

title: CDC ASSET MANAGEMENT AGREES TO BUY NVEST
description: The investment management company Nvest L.P. agreed yesterday to be acquired by CDC Asset Management for $40 a share, or $700 million. CDC will also assume $1.5 billion of debt. CDC is the investment management arm of Caisse des Depots of France. Nvest shares shot up 88 percent, rising $17.625, to $37.625, on the Big Board. Also, MetLife Inc., the second-largest life insurer in the United States, will gain about $858 million from the sale of its 48 percent stake in Nvest. MetLife, which is based New York, has held a stake in Nvest since 1996. Boston-based Nvest, formerly the New England Investment Companies, is made up of 11 investment firms and 6 investment sales and consulting firms.

title: MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL SETS SALE OF 10 HOTELS
description: Marriott International Inc., the world's top lodging company, said yesterday that it had sold 10 hotels to the real estate investment trust company Hospitality Properties Trust for $145 million. Hospitality Properties, based in Newtown, Mass., will lease the hotels to a unit of the Crestline Capital Corporation for a minimum of $15.6 million, while a subsidiary of Marriott will manage these hotels through 2015. The 10 hotels contain 1,420 rooms and are in eight states: two in Arizona, two in California, and one each in Georgia, Massachusetts, Nevada, Tennessee, Texas and West Virginia. Crestline Capital, which leases 116 hotels and subleases 71 from Marriott, was spun off by Marriott, which is based in Bethesda, Md., when it became a real estate investment trust in 1998.

title: Jules Feiffer, at 71, Slows Down to a Gallop
description: Jules Feiffer's moody modern dancer, the comic strip figure who has leaped and stretched interpretively to spring, summer, autumn and winter for over 40 years, is finally hanging up her tights. description: The trustee brought in to reverse the slide of the city's largest janitors' union announced this week that he would run for the union's presidency, after recommending that the parent union end the trusteeship.

title: WORK PLACE MATERNITY RIGHTS PACT
description: A pact was adopted by the International Labor Organization to upgrade a 1952 treaty that strengthens the rights of women workers. The agreement extends maternity leave from 12 to 14 weeks, guarantees women the right to the same jobs after their leaves, bars pregnancy tests for job applicants and strengthens provisions for breast feeding. title: MILD CANADIAN INFLATION
description: Canada's inflation rate rose slightly in May to an annual rate of 2.4 percent, up from 2.1 percent in April, but comfortably below the 3 percent pace in March. The latest increase in the Consumer Price Index was less than economists had predicted and was again pushed higher mainly by the cost of gasoline. Excluding energy, core inflation in May was 1.3 percent. The modest pace suggests further interest rate increases by the Bank of Canada will only match those imposed by the Federal Reserve Board in the United States.

title: Corrections

He is Kamel Morjane, not Kamal Moranje. The article also misstated Congo's size ranking in Africa in some copies. It is not the largest country; Sudan is.

description: SCHNELLER-Arthur, M.D., 95, June 15, 2000, in West Palm Beach, Fl. Survived by his beloved daughters Joan (Joseph) Pomeranz & Jean (Arnold) Levine, 11 adored grandchildren, 10 great grandchildren & his devoted brother Dr. Leo Schneller. Extraordinarily devoted family doctor in Astoria, Long Island from 1929-1974, interupted only to serve as Commander in the United States Navy during World War II where he was one of the first doctors ashore during the Normandy invasion. He was the first lot doctor at Paramount's Astoria Studios. Services at Schwartz Bros. Funeral Chapel, Queens Boulevard., Forest Hills, June 18 at 10:00 AM. Contributions can be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407. For info., Riverside Gordon, Fla.

title: Microsoft Accuses Its Rivals Of Garbage-Can Tactics
description: Microsoft accused its rivals today of masterminding an attempt to buy trash generated by a Microsoft-backed lobbying organization, apparently hoping the trash would yield valuable information on the company.

description: The independent counsel who has been investigating the Clintons on several fronts is expected to file his final report next week with a special judicial panel on what role Hillary Rodham Clinton played in the firing of seven longtime employees in the White House travel office.

title: Tiger Compound Showdown Nears
description: To get to the thickly forested preserve where Joan Byron-Marasek keeps 24 tigers, you have to go past the Six Flags Outlet Mall just off Interstate 195, and through a busy intersection with three gas stations and a Methodist church. If you come across a new development of large, expensive homes, you've gone a bit too far.

title: F.C.C. Approves Phone Deal
description: The F.C.C. approved the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE, creating a company that will control a third of the nation's local telephone market and 25 million cell phones in 40 states. Page C1.

title: When Being a Father Exacted a Price
description: My father died 10 years ago, around Father's Day, in southern China, without my being there to kowtow and bid him goodbye. I had been living in the United States for five years and had just gotten my law degree from Columbia and was preparing for the bar exam. My family didn't tell me until after the exams were over. When I learned of his death, I collapsed in my sister's arms and cried the whole night. For the next few months, I stumbled around the streets of New York in silent mourning. At 28, I felt like a miserable orphan.

description: Despite a sharp slowdown in domestic stock and bond markets, Lehman Brothers Holdings reported yesterday that its fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 15 percent from a year earlier, though they were 33 percent lower than in the previous quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCSWEENEY, EDWARD F.
description: McSWEENEY-Edward F. III. ''Dooley.'' It should warm your eternal spirit to know that whenever two of your 250 nearest and dearest friends gather, ''Dooley stories'' punctuate the conversation and you and the enduring value of your friendship are inevitably the subject of the first and last toast. Nine years later, babycakes, you are loved all the more for all the right reasons. See ya. Your pal, JPK. McSWEENEY-Edward F. III (Dooley). Our accounting teacher at Brooklyn College urged us all to ''go out there and make a difference.'' I never knew how big a difference one could make until I started to re-assess the long-term impact of our friend ''Dooley''. The number of people who came to know each other through him; the number of consummated transactions in which he played some introductory role; the number of growing businesses whose financial success originated with ''Dooley's'' efforts could together fund the budget of the state of California. Although ''Dooley'' did not get to see many of the fruits of his often brilliant and always generous efforts, his extraordinarily broad circle of friends certainly did. That is not such a bad legacy. Next year we will gather on the occasion of the 10th anniversary of your passing to again celebrate the importance of your life to us. Stanley Goldstei

title: The Russians Are Coming
description: James Billington, the Librarian of Congress and a historian of Russian culture, has come up with a simple but effective way of advancing democracy in Russia. Borrowing a page from the Marshall Plan, which brought young German politicians to the United States after World War II, Mr. Billington has devised a program that gives thousands of Russian civic leaders a chance to see the American political and economic system at work. With $10 million from Congress last summer, and a similar amount this year, the Russian Leadership Program offers Russians -- many under 40 years old -- a brief but intense encounter with a noisy, often messy but remarkably open form of governance.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on June 6 about Ukraine's announcement that it will close the Chernobyl nuclear power plant by Dec. 15 referred incorrectly to the number of deaths and illnesses caused by the accident there in 1986. The Nuclear Energy Agency of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report that 31 people died in the first weeks after the accident. Other estimates of deaths ultimately caused by the accident range from dozens to tens of thousands; estimates of illnesses range from hundreds to tens of thousands. It has not been established that the accident caused untold thousands of deaths and illnesses.

Schuyler, Henry and Betsy, Ted and Joanna, Sam and Caroline, Miles and Jennie.

description: The United States Civil Rights Commission today called on New York City to create a mechanism for the appointment of independent prosecutors to investigate serious accusations of police misconduct.

title: CONVERTIBLE CURRENCY FOR CHINA?
description: China's chief central banker said the country had put full convertibility of the country's currency back on the agenda after having suspended such plans during the Asian economic crisis two years ago. ''With China's World Trade Organization entry, we will gradually push forward the process of capital account convertibility,'' said Dai Xianglong, governor of the People's Bank of China, according to the state-run China Daily. The country has long planned to make its currency, known as the renminbi, or people's money, fully convertible. Craig S. Smith

title: WILINK.COM TO ADD KNUTSFORD GROUP OF BRITAIN
description: WILink.com, a privately held financial information services company based in Richmond, Va., agreed yesterday to be acquired by the British investment company Knutsford Group P.L.C. in a deal worth $83.3 million, which includes stock, cash and notes. Knutsford is offering WILink shareholders a choice of one of four packages, each with a different portion of stock, cash and notes. The combined company will be renamed WILink.com P.L.C. It will offer investment services to individual investors online. WILink is the parent company of World Investor Link Inc. in Richmond and World Investor Link Ltd. in Britain.

It didn't matter whether he was singing hard-core honky-tonk or mellifluous soft pop like ''Danny Boy,'' with the 10-piece string section he had hired bowing along. title: COVAD COMMUNICATIONS IN STOCK PURCHASE OF BLUESTAR
description: Covad Communications Group Inc., an Internet service provider, said yesterday that it would acquire the privately held Bluestar Communications Inc. for $202 million in stock. Both companies provide high-speed Internet access over the copper wires used by phone companies, known as digital subscriber lines. Covad's stock plunged $6.81, or 27 percent, to $18.4375, in Nasdaq trading. The stock has fallen about 70 percent since March. Covad, based in Santa Clara, Calif., provides Internet services to corporate customers, while Bluestar, based in Nashville, provides Internet access in small cities and rural areas in the Southeast.

title: Beliefs; In an Islamic nation strained by many tensions, Indonesia's president is a champion of pluralism.
description: Among religious leaders, President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia stands out, but not simply because he has repeatedly called for a respectful dialogue among faiths and has decried any appeal to religion as a justification for violence.

title: OFFER FOR CEMENT COMPANY
description: A big Swiss cement maker, Holderbank Financiere Glarus, joined with a Portuguese rival to make an unsolicited bid of 4 billion euros ($3.7 billion) for Cimpor-Cimentos de Portugal SGPS. Holderbank and Semapa-Sociedade de Investimento e Gestao SGPS bid 20.5 euros a share in cash for Cimpor-Cimentos, Portugal's top cement maker, and they will assume 1.2 billion euros in debt. The offer is contingent on Portugal's selling its 12.7 percent stake in Cimpor, something the government has said it will not do.

title: MISSION ORCHARD TRUST TO ACQUIRE PACIFIC GATEWAY

The closely held Mission Orchard is an affiliate of Integrated Capital Associates, a private investment firm based in San Francisco. Pacific Gateway is a San Francisco-based real estate development company and the owner of 20 office buildings in the Bay area, as well as buildings in Arizona and Florida. Pacific Gateway's shares rose 12 percent, gaining $1.3125, to $11.9375, on the Amex.

description: The notion of a citizen's arrest is something of a joke these days -- ridiculed, when mentioned at all. But the very real threat of a parking summons issued by someone like the man next door is rattling motorists here is like something out of Kafka.

title: An Inconvenient Woman
description: I was appalled by the extreme prejudice shown toward Barry Winchell by his ''friends.'' I was also amazed at how much excessive drinking was tolerated by the military. It sounded to me as if alcohol abuse was as much to blame for the murder as was hatred of gays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLONTZ, ROBERT
description: ROLONTZ-Robert. 79. Died June 14, 2000 from complications after 22 years of Parkinson's Disease. Producer of Mickey and Sylvia's hit recording ''Love is Strange.'' Author of the book ''How to Get Your Song Recorded.'' Conceived the idea for the platinum record. Creator of the Ralph J. Gleason Music Book Award. Survived by wife/best friend, Susan; adored children, daughter Lee, son Morgan; sister Lela; loved grandchildren, Madeleine and Pauline. A memorial service will be held in mid July. Donations may be made to Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Chelsea Piers, Suite 303, Pier 62, NYC 10011.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If somebody asked me, 'What did you learn?' I'd probably say, 'Well, I learned to put up scaffolding.' But in fact, I was learning other lessons. There are some life experiences that go unlearned if you take the professional track all your life.''

title: Testing Pizzas' Pizazz As Maker Hits Market
description: PHILLY cheese steak. Thai chicken with roasted peanuts and ginger sauce.

title: Innovators Looking to London
description: Chicago's financial exchanges may have spread the notion of hedging by buying futures on stocks, bonds and currency, but two men who helped pave the way for all this in the 1980's are now turning to London to promote further innovations. They are Richard L. Sandor, the former Berkeley economics professor who helped introduce financial futures at the Chicago Board of Trade, and Leslie Rosenthal, the exchange's former chairman. They said they were behind the recent announcement that Battery Ventures, a venture capital fund, and the Blackstone Group would invest $91 million for nearly 40 percent stake in the London International Financial Futures Exchange, or Liffe.

title: Williams's Huge Day Can't Stem A Meltdown
description: Jake Westbrook walked from the bullpen into the steamy fishbowl of Yankee Stadium for his first major league start. He was already mopping his drenched forehead with a towel and choking back his nerves.

title: Orchestra Wins Award For 'Adventurous' Project
description: WHY not, the Westchester Philharmonic thought, when planning its education program, ''Exploring New Worlds: Music of the Americas''? Inspired by the centennial celebrations for Aaron Copland, the orchestra decided to invite a young American composer to write a piece for its series of spring school concerts at the Performing Arts Center in Purchase. And then a novel idea took hold: why not have the 7,800 Westchester schoolchildren who take part in the education program choose the composer themselves?

title: What Can (and Did) Go Wrong on Concert Stage
description: LOOKING back at the classical music season, it becomes clear that New Jersey and New York energize each other's concert scenes -- sometimes by tripping each other up. Concerts can be exciting beyond their musical programs: sheer quantity of offerings exposes them to those mischances pretentiously called acts of God.

title: Weekend Gathering of the Vibes
description: SINCE the funk band Deep Banana Blackout plays more than 200 dates a year outside its home state of Connecticut, performing at the Gathering of the Vibes next weekend will be sort of a busman's holiday. The annual celebration of music, arts, crafts and family fun takes place Friday through Sunday at Seaside Park in Bridgeport.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. Daddy dear, our 8th Father's Day without you. We miss you, your love, your wisdom. Our link to you will never be broken. Irik and Jaar-mel

title: Fixing the Blame for Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Scandal Involving Earthquake Victims Hits California Insurance Commissioner's Office
description: The office of California's insurance commissioner has been hit by a scandal that threatens to cost him his job and the tottering California Republican Party some of its hopes for rejuvenation in the 2000 election.

title: The Cuban Missile Crisis, Angioplasty and Other Show Stoppers
description: MOMENTS of truth,'' Bill Lockwood calls them -- the times when things don't go quite according to plan. In the presenting business they are frequent, as small as a broken guitar string, as large as a missed flight or a curtain-time illness. Even with 40 years' experience, they never go away; at best, they become tempered with a bit of perspective.

title: Children's Books
description: The Raft

title: Q & A
description: Diamond Hunt

title: The Nation; Money Changes Everything
description: AN almost surreal sense of good fortune suffuses the carnival that is the American economy these days. And that, paradoxically, is proving to be a challenge to politicians, who are having trouble finding their footing in a climate where prosperity seems a given and the biggest issue is not too little money but too much of it.

title: The Double-Life Crusade
description: As usual, Andrew Sullivan's argument contains a germ of truth; and as usual, Sullivan can't find it. The so-called life-life position may be internally consistent, but until its proponents embrace a woman's right to choose family planning -- yes, birth control -- instead of working, as so many anti-choicers do, to prevent access to this information, the pro-life argument will remain sanctimonious, hypocritical and specious.

title: The Electronic Fishbowl
description: No one halfway familiar with the Dutch will be surprised to read that they have managed to raise the level of voyeurism to new heights through national TV and the Internet (Marshall Sella, May 21). Take it from an ex-Dutchman: it's a centuries-old streak in the national culture. Have a look at the old burgher homes lining the canals in The Hague or Amsterdam and marvel at the enormous first-story windows, reaching down almost to pavement level. In an often gloomy climate, they had to be big, and curtains would defeat the idea. So passers-by can watch your TV if they like. Now look up to the higher stories and note the little mirrors outside many of the windows called (what else?) spionnetjes (little spies). You might even catch the reflection of a person watching whatever might be going on in the street.

title: 'Missile' Wins Stephen Foster
description: The 3-year-old class may still be searching for a leader as racing nears midseason, but the senior class found one yesterday when Golden Missile went wire to wire on a sloppy track and won the $750,000 Stephen Foster Handicap at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky.

title: Fixing the Blame for Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Love Of the Arts
description: Museums, dance studios and Outward Bound all benefit.

title: Overhauling Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: When One Household Has Two Political Agendas
description: LESLIE WIESENFELDER and his wife, Phyllis, are not what you would call big donors to political campaigns -- certainly not the kind of fat cats singled out by reformers for contributing to a debasement of the democratic process.

title: 90's Hipsters Dial Up the Past With an 80's Plaything
description: THE Roland MC-505 Groovebox, a small programmable synthesizer, is an impressive musical plaything. It has been called a ''band in a box''; it is also a nostalgia machine, capable of producing a wild variety of vintage keyboard sounds, as well as the trademark thuds and thumps of some of the most popular rhythm machines of all time, including Roland's 303 bass synthesizer and its 808 and 909 beat boxes.

title: June 11-17; Death Penalty Appeals
description: When Illinois declared a moratorium on executions recently, after 13 condemned men were found innocent, some death-penalty supporters called the state an aberration. It isn't. A new study found that nationwide, two-thirds of death-penalty convictions over two decades were overturned on appeal, with 7 percent of the condemned later found not guilty. And, typically, the appeals process takes nine years. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Hot Seat Awaits New Chief At P.& G.
description: IT'S hard to turn a Ford into a Ferrari.

title: Small Jeweler to Close After 35 Years in Business
description: After 35 years at the corner of Eighth Avenue and 15th Street, a small shop, Flanzer Jewelers, is closing on or about Friday, depending on how long it takes for the store's supply of merchandise to run out.

title: Loews Chooses Its Site
description: AFTER months of indecision, Loews Cineplex Theaters will open a new multiplex in White Plains as originally planned -- and not in a $100 million waterfront development in Port Chester -- White Plains officials said this week.

title: For Fed Rate Increases, A Pause That's Expected
description: What a difference a month can make. According to a survey last week, there was not a single economist at any major bond firm that expected the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates this month.

title: Lies, Damned Lies and Tastings
description: THE rising tide of year-round visitors to East End wineries crests in the warm-weather months. A comparable heightening in attention over the last decade suggests that the press is taking producers more seriously too.

title: High-End Rentals on the Rise in Downtown Seattle
description: AFFLUENT workers willing to pay thousands of dollars for monthly rent have created a brisk high-end apartment market downtown, a turnaround from the mid-1990's, when few people wanted to live in the business district, anchor retailers were leaving and planners feared the city center was becoming blighted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROST, SYLVIA
description: FROST-Sylvia. On June 16, 2000. Wife of the late A. Harold Frost. Cherished mother of Patricia Siders. Sister of Leonard Susseles and the late Harriett Trepner. Loving grandmother of Dale and Jan. Proud great-grandmother of Jake, Max and Olivia. Services private.

title: Walter Poenisch, 86, Swimmer Who Covered Record Distances
description: Walter Poenisch, a retired cookie baker and marathon swimmer who observed his 65th birthday by becoming the first man to swim from Havana to the Florida Keys -- a feat not universally recognized -- died on June 6 at his home in suburban Columbus, Ohio. He was 86.

title: Lower Morale, Yes. But Apathy?; Police Say They Are Diligent as Ever, and the Numbers Agree
description: The murder rate is up 6 percent. The Wendy's killings and a spate of livery-cab driver murders have revived a long-dormant image of a dangerous New York. And here and there, when New Yorkers talk about crime and remember the bad old days, many have come to assume that a police force tired of pay disparity, relentless pressure to produce and public second-guessing has grown sluggish.

title: Cool Britannia
description: To the Editor: I wholeheartedly agree on changing London. I worked at the American Embassy from 1951 to 1953, at the beginning of the second Elizabethan age. London was still very grim, food was rationed, building sites were empty and the winter air was thick with fog.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUSE, KAREN E.
description: HOUSE-Karen E. June 12, 2000. Daughter of Reese M. and Sally (Brooks) House. Sister of M. Kelly House. She is also survived by her father's partner Ted Guthrie. Residence: NYC and formerly of Boston and Portland, OR. A celebration of her life will be held Tuesday at 7 PM, in the Great Hall of Beneficient Congregational Church, Providence, RI. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Karen House Memorial Fund, c/ o Western Massachusetts Sacred Harp Convention, Box 38, Northampton, MA 01016.

title: Mulligan Stew
description: To the Editor:

title: An Idea of Architecture; an Architecture of Ideas
description: ARCHITECTS are Freudian figures in a Marxian landscape. This was one clear message that emerged from the final ANY conference, a three-day architectural talent fest held earlier this month at the Guggenheim Museum. To get their work done, architects must operate in an environment increasingly ruled by market values. And this Darwinian backdrop heightens the peculiarities of the creative life. Architects, many of the best ones, are isolated individuals who are driven to construct social spaces. Their work displays the public virtues of their personal defects.

title: The Lost Joys of Family Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Join the Club (if They'll Let You in): The State's Golf History
description: NEW JERSEY has a long and storied golf history. In fact, it holds the keepers of American golf history, the United States Golf Association's Museum and Library in Far Hills.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Page 5 of the Book Review today about ''Bee Season'' misstates the surname of the author at two points. She is Myla Goldberg, as noted in the remaining references, not Goldman.

title: For These Bondholders, It Was Close, but No Goal
description: It was a last-minute letdown for holders of U. C. Sampdoria bonds.

title: The Nation: The Immigration Debate; Full Employment Opens the Door
description: JUST a few years ago, lawmakers were in full cry about the supposed dangers of immigration -- from crime to welfare cheats to lost jobs.

title: Sure Hands on Drawbridge? Yeah, Sure
description: People usually send letters to the editor when they want to complain.

title: June 11-17; More Growing Pains for the Gore Campaign
description: Change is something Vice President Al Gore is not afraid of. Particularly when it involves his campaign.

title: Sort of Like Woodstock but . . .
description: The K-Rock Dysfunctional Family Picnic is not a Jerry Springer day in the park. Sponsored by K-Rock radio (92.3 FM), this annual event is louder, more aggressive and, depending on taste, perhaps more musical. A hard-core Woodstock, the concert brings together some of the best hard rock, punk and metal bands in an ear-splitting, mosh-pit-filled day of fun.

title: The Nation; For Activists, Nailing Theses to Their Party's Doors
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom holds that party platforms are only slightly less archaic than torchlight parades on election eve -- a grab bag of dogma for true believers at a time when nearly every candidate wants to run as a centrist, wooing the swing voters of the suburbs.

title: A Restaurant by the Sea Means Seafood
description: SUN, sand and seafood mean summer on Long Island. For nearly 40 years, Steve's Pier One has been part of that good-times equation. Generations have flocked to the Bayville beach-side landmark to savor lobsters, enjoy spectacular sunsets on the Sound and gawk at the marine memorabilia. The place oozes with stuffed fish, ship's lamps, anchors and ship's models.

title: We've Got An I.P.O. You Can't Refuse
description: TO: Members of the Commission

title: Film Intersections
description: To the Editor: As a native New Yorker, I'm fascinated by the way so many public intersections are not only private landmarks that note significant phases of my own life but have also, courtesy of Hollywood, burned themselves into the collective cultural consciousness. So I particularly enjoyed Anita Gates's ''Bright Lights, Big City . . . Action!'' (May 14) and her efforts to catalog New York scenes that have resonated with many otherwise unrelated people well beyond the city limits.

title: Bush, Harvard Business School And the Makings of a President
description: ON their first day at Harvard Business School, a dean told the students of the class of 1975 that what they would learn there would prepare them less for the job they would take immediately after graduation than the job they would have in 25 years.

title: Pact Ends County And City Taxi Wars
description: THE taxi wars are finally over.

title: Shaken and Stirred
description: LONG BRANCH is one of those shore towns, like Atlantic City and Asbury Park, that are all too well known for having seen better days. A fabulous resort in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, visited by no fewer than seven presidents, it faded fast after World War II and in recent years has struggled to keep breathing.

title: Resolute Artists Who Learned to Endure
description: SUSAN JAFFE, the luminous classical ballerina with the flashing emerald eyes, gets straight to the point. ''It's neat that I've lasted this long,'' she says with a broad smile.

title: With a Bulldozer, Making 18 Holes of Art And Protecting Nature
description: ERIC BERGSTOL brought his golf cart to a screeching stop and uncurled the lanky frame that at one time had him touring South America as a semiprofessional basketball player.

title: The View From/Monroe; Forget Mario Andretti, It's Racing Al Dente
description: ONE week before the Great Pasta Race at Stepney Elementary School, Samantha Chirunomula recognized an engineering glitch. Two rotelle wheels on her flat-bed lasagna car would not spin on their bamboo axles.

title: Birding at the End Of Nature
description: When I was a freshman at Randolph-Macon Women's College in Lynchburg, Va., I had an English professor who was an avid birder. He described the mating dance of the woodcock just as Jonathan Rosen (May 21) did, and I was a convert. It was easy to find a fabulous array of birds in the Blue Ridge Mountains and the James River wetlands.

title: The Farms and Fields Beckon
description: STRAWBERRY fields can be found in every county in Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROAMAN, ALAN
description: ROAMAN-Alan. Alan, you were a wonderful brother and brother-inlaw, and your special warmth and affection endeared you to your niece and nephews, grand nieces and grand nephew. Barbara and Richard Roaman Lisa Roaman Fox, Laura, Mark and Eric Roaman Emily, Danny and Sandy

title: Carolyn Willis, Louis Schwartz
description: Carolyn Willis and Louis Schwartz are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Dennis Ross at the Manhattan Penthouse. .

title: Elizabeth Wohlken, Christopher Rugaber
description: Elizabeth Jane Wohlken, the daughter of Francine Lucas of Seattle and Norman J. Wohlken of Sea Ranch, Calif., was married yesterday to Christopher Sanford Rugaber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Rugaber of Roanoke, Va. The Rev. Penelope M. Bridges performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va.

title: Janitors Relive Story of Their Struggle
description: What kind of movie premiere is held in midafternoon, without a foot of red carpet in sight and with most of the audience wearing the same outfit? A premiere that knows its target audience, most of whom had to get to work by 5:30.

title: June 11-17; Pardon for Papal Gunman
description: Ceding to Vatican wishes, the Italian government pardoned Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish gunman who tried to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981. The pardon, which came during a Holy Year of the Roman Catholic Church, did not set Mr. Agca free. Mr. Agca, who was forgiven long ago by the pope, was extradited to Turkey, where he faces an eight-year sentence for the 1979 murder of a Turkish journalist. ALESSANDRA STANLEY

title: The Guru of Small Things
description: So it turns out that Hillary Rodham Clinton is as voracious a listener as her husband. On tour in New York, she has displayed an intense style all her own, her brow knitted, her head nodding metronomically. Her statewide ''listening tour'' was not just an act -- she remembers what she heard, and she recycles the good bits.

title: The Double-Life Crusade
description: Sullivan misses an important distinction between capital punishment and abortion: if the state outlaws capital punishment, there will be no more executions. But if the state outlaws abortion, there will continue to be abortions, more hideous and perhaps even more numerous than those that now occur. I oppose capital punishment. I support legal abortion, not because I rejoice in abortions but because experience tells us that the alternative to legal abortion is much worse.

title: All Pirro, All the Time
description: MANY years ago, when they first started talking about 500 channels of cable television, the idea seemed to be about bringing the wonders of the world into every living room -- news from Argentina! British rugby and soccer! Nobel laureates opining on abstruse topics of great sociological import! Television was going to be transformed from the vast wasteland to an electronic Eden.

title: BRIEFING: LEGISLATION; ECSTASY PROPOSAL
description: Governor Whitman proposed legislation last week that would strengthen criminal penalties on dealers of the drug Ecstasy, putting putting it on the same level as hard-core drugs like cocaine and heroin. Under the proposed regulations, selling 500 hundred pills of Ecstasy, popular among young people, or more would be a first-degree crime, with a possible 10- to 20-year sentence. Possessing 50 pills or more would be a second-degree crime with a 5-to 10-year sentence. Possessing fewer than 50 pills would remain a third-degree offense. Currently, possessing any amount is a third-degree crime and rarely results in imprisonment. KUSHANAVA CHOUDHURY

title: Margaret Brennan, William Cobb
description: Margaret Graham Brennan and William Lyman Cobb Jr. were married yesterday at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Gilbert performed the ceremony.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-18-00: Wedding List; Marriage a la Modem
description: When Newt Gingrich marries Callista Bisek in Virginia on Aug. 18 (his third marriage, her first), the ceremony will be invitation-only. But any well-wisher with a modem can visit the happy couple's gift registry, at the Web sites of Macy's and Williams-Sonoma. (Gingrich is no longer subject to Congressional ethics rules, so there's no need for restraint.) The list, excerpted below, offers certain clues about the life these two may lead. They'll do a lot of celebrating: a dozen $99 beer steins are registered, as are a dozen claret glasses, Champagne flutes, liqueur glasses, etc., etc. Their dinners will be elegant but not fussy -- the cutlery is stainless steel, and the china is all dishwasher safe -- and may well include lasagna, casseroles, spaghetti, tarts or brownies. As for the king-size Ralph Lauren bed linens? It's best not to speculate. ''Neither I nor Newt comments on his private life,'' says Mike Shields, his spokesman. ''Sorry.''

title: Who Pays the Bills?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Guard Unit Adds Dimension to a Peacekeeper Role
description: When hunters came across the wreckage of an aircraft on a remote mountainside in April, Capt. David B. Webb of the 49th Armored Division of the Texas National Guard volunteered to join an Air Force team sent to figure out whose plane it might be.

title: Marie Herb, William Henning
description: Marie Herb and William Hughes Henning were married yesterday at the Massachusetts Maritime Academy in Buzzards Bay, Mass. Jeannette T. Normandin, who was appointed a Massachusetts civil marriage celebrant for the day, officiated.

title: A Season of Sound and Fury, Signifying Plenty
description: ANTONY SHER is the first to acknowledge that the majority of ''Macbeth'' productions don't work, almost as if the supernatural component to Shakespeare's play were casting a hex on it in performance. Added to that was his first exposure to the text, as a schoolboy in his native South Africa, where, the actor said, ''It was taught appallingly, so I had no real experience of it.''

title: The Double-Life Crusade
description: Several months ago, I watched George W. Bush, John McCain and Alan Keyes debate on TV. I shook my head in disbelief as all of them, but especially Keyes, defended the life of the unborn child and then turned around and supported the death penalty. Keyes's conviction for the death penalty didn't make sense after his extremely passionate argument for life. I didn't get it. And then, as I read Sullivan's article, I felt that I could breathe again. Thank you for putting into words my exact sentiments.

title: Message Was Received By Surging MetroStars
description: The message had been pounded into the MetroStars during practice, that after a lackluster effort a week ago they were still readying for their biggest game of the year and had much to play for. And if the words of Octavio Zambrano did not get through, the elbow that Tab Ramos took just minutes into today's game from Leonel Alvarez relayed the message again that this game was important.

title: The Man Who Quit 'Blue,' Still Making a Comeback
description: Six years ago, David Caruso left ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' in a highly-publicized bid for movie stardom. But Mr. Caruso, who had co-starred with Dennis Franz on the acclaimed police drama on ABC for a bit more than a year, fell on his face.

title: POSTINGS: Soon to Go Up Between 91st and 92nd Streets; A New Condo on Second Avenue
description: Chartwell House, a new 34-story limestone and red-brick condominium with many studio and one-bedroom apartments, is soon to rise at 1760 Second Avenue, between 91st and 92nd Streets. Completion is scheduled for summer 2001.

title: Taking On 7-Eleven In Holmdel
description: At a busy crossroads here, four townships meet. So does the New School of Monmouth County. Now, much to the consternation of parents and teachers at the tiny red Cape Cod-style school building, a new 7-Eleven convenience store looms.

title: Montreal
description: Every summer, after the steel bonds of winter fall away, Montrealers leap forth for an outdoor season of street festivals, cafe-hopping, bicycling along canals or simply strolling streets imbued with the history of a city founded in 1642.

title: Another Branch of the Family
description: THE VARIETY OF LIFE

title: One More Time: Round 2 in the Fight for School Budgets
description: AS another school year winds down, most school districts shift from academic pressures to carefree thoughts of summer vacation.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-18-00: The Ethicist; Blood Work
description: I am a physician in a trauma center that does not check accident victims for alcohol and drugs. If a driver were intoxicated, insurance would not cover medical costs. However, not knowing blood- alcohol levels may have adverse medical consequences. Should we check even if it means added financial burdens, suboptimal care or exposure to criminal charges? -- Anonymous, New York

title: Rules on Taking a Roommate
description: Q The lease of the rent-stabilized apartment that I reside in is in my name and my spouse's name. We are now separated and I am planning to have a roommate to share the rent. Am I jeopardizing my lease? Also, where can I find more information about the rules and regulations of rent stabilization? . . . Terry Mune, Manhattan.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE SECRET LIVES OF WORDS

title: A Musical Voyage To Lost Worlds
description: AND now to western Formosa and a song for the gathering of tea,'' intones a calm, sonorous voice during a typically arcane, hourlong installment of ''The Secret Museum of the Air,'' which may just be the most singular world music show on radio.

title: June 11-17; The Boss Stirs the Pot
description: New York City police union leaders urged their members to boycott concerts by Bruce Springsteen, who has begun performing a new song about the shooting of Amadou Diallo, the unarmed immigrant from Guinea who died in a hail of police gunfire last year. Ignoring the criticism, Mr. Springsteen performed the song, ''American Skin,'' at Madison Square Garden, where he began by singing the words ''41 shots'' nine times.

title: The World: The Trouble With Democracy; NATO's Friends Can't Win Every Vote
description: TO hear some in NATO talk, Montenegro is the unsinkable aircraft carrier in the West's unfinished war against Yugoslavia's president, Slobodan Milosevic. But last week, the carrier took a few shells from Montenegro's voters, a sizable minority of whom want to remain inside Yugoslavia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, PAULINE
description: WOLFSON-Pauline. On June 17. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Devoted mother of Ruth Ellen and Michael (Linda). Loving grandmother of Cheryl, Lisa, David, Adam, Dean, Laurie and Nicole. Services Monday, 11 AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Demand for Fencing Is Born From Two Mothers' Sorrow
description: With the stinging clarity of broken glass, Hilda Cuesta remembers the night the police came to tell her that her 21-year-old son, Daniel, had been killed trying to cross the Bruckner Expressway. It was Christmas Day.

title: New York, Brick by Brick
description: IN Borges's story ''The Aleph,'' the narrator opens the trapdoor of a cellar to find himself staring at ''millions of acts both delightful and awful,'' all of which simultaneously ''occupied the same point in space.'' So a newcomer might feel, arriving in New York City for the first time.

title: The World; If You Want Opposition, Just Crush an Opponent
description: BY any standard measure of democracy, Russia now more than ever desperately needs a credible political opposition. But until last week, President Vladimir V. Putin didn't really have any -- not in the Parliament, not in the regions, not among top business leaders, and certainly not among a population that, more than anything, wants someone to put their unruly society in order.

title: 2 Long Islanders Get MacArthurs
description: Carl Safina, a marine biologist from Islip, and Laura Otis, a Hofstra University English professor who explores connections between different ways of learning, were among 25 recipients of this year's MacArthur Fellowships.

title: PARTY DIFFERENCES ON DRUG BENEFITS CONTINUE TO GROW
description: With the House about to begin two weeks of intense debate over competing proposals to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare, the differences between President Clinton and Republicans in Congress are widening by the day.

title: Some Musings On Topics of the Day
description: What's in a pool for me? I was fortunate enough to be born and raised in Irvington. I learned how to swim in the Hudson and earned some of my money for college life guarding at ''the beach.'' It was back then, some 25-plus years ago that the community began talking about a village/community pool. All I can think of now when the topic arises with such heated debate is, How many people have lost out because of other people tripping on their power? Some people think that blight is huge houses, huge vehicles and huge egos.

title: Political Memo; Strategists See the New Economy in a New Light
description: Eight years after the Clinton campaign adopted ''It's the economy, stupid,'' as its mantra, the presidential race of 2000 has raised an intriguing question: has the new economy changed some of the old rules of politics?

title: A Little Start-Up Gets a Big Push
description: THERE is little unusual about a pair of ambitious students trying to start their own Internet business these days. Relatively few of them, however, have access to anything that resembles the Harvard Business School network of 37,000 living, schmoozing alumni.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the building at 130 West 57th Street, misstated the floor on which the artist Childe Hassam had a studio. It was the 13th, not the 9th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRITT, WILBUR M.
description: MERRITT-Wilbur M. On June 15, 2000 of Plandome, NY. Husband of the late Helen. Father of John C. Merritt. Grandfather of Gregg Merritt and Andrea Chambers. Great-grandfather of Elizabeth Chambers. Father-in-law of Janet Merritt. Memorial service at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset on Tuesday, 1 PM. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: An Inconvenient Woman
description: I admire Calpernia Addams's bravery and hope she yet finds the kind of happiness that Barry Winchell's tragic death cut short. I can never understand why we must force others into our categories. I was struck by Barry's easy acceptance of himself and Calpernia and the readiness with which ''It's O.K.'' came to his lips -- and perhaps contributed to his death.

title: To Avoid Nasty Repairmen Call an Architect
description: To the Editor:

title: Oh, What a Fine Plot We Hatched. (And Here's What to Do the Next Time).
description: WHEN the Central Intelligence Agency helped overthrow Mohammed Mossadegh as Iran's prime minister in 1953, ensuring another 25 years of rule for Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, the C.I.A. was already figuring that its first effort to topple a foreign government would not be its last.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE

title: Losing Ground Against Microbes
description: Among the many things people in industrialized countries today take for granted is that we will not die of a sore throat or infected scratch from a rosebush. Effective protection provided by antibiotics, anti-malarials and other microbe-killers was not available 50 years ago, and a new report from the World Health Organization warns that if we continue current practices, such protection will not be available 50 years from now. Almost every major infectious disease is becoming resistant to available medicine, and scientists are not developing new medicines fast enough to keep up. The W.H.O. warns that we cannot count on new drugs being developed, and so must preserve the currently available antimicrobials by ending our misuse of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFALLO, RICHARD
description: DUFALLO - Richard. One of America's leading exponents of twentieth-century music, Richard Dufallo died June 16, 2000, of cancer. During his career, he conducted more than 80 major orchestras and festivals in the U.S., Canada, and twelve European countries and premiered a host of major works by acclaimed American and European composers. Former assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic, Maestro Dufallo worked closely with Leonard Bernstein from 1965 to 1975. During this time, he made his opera debut with the New York City Opera and succeeded Darius Milhaud as artistic director of the Conference on Contemporary Music at the Aspen Festival in Colorado. American symphony orchestras that performed under his baton include the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Philadelphia Orchestra, and Buffalo Philharmonic, with which he enjoyed a three-year association as assistant conductor. Maestro Dufallo conducted more than 25 world premieres, including Stockhausen's ''Carre'' in London, The Hague and Paris; Jacob Druckman's ''Lamia'' with the Berlin Philharmonic, and Sir Peter Maxwell Davis' opera ''The Lighthouse'' at the Edinburgh Festival. Other European performances include Robert Beaser's ''Piano Concerto'' with the Philharmonique de Monte Carlo with his wife, Steinway Artist Pamela Mia Paul, the Rome premiere of Elliott Carter's ''A Mirror on Which to Dwell,'' the world premiere of ''Trance Formations'' by Robert Zuidam at Amsterdam's Concertgebouw, and the Polish premiere of Bruce MacCombie's ''Chelsea Tango.'' Named permanent guest conductor of the Gelders Orchestra in Holland, Maestro Dufallo made his European debut in 1970 in Paris with the Orchestra Telephonique Francais. Other major European orchestras that have performed undehis baton include the Concertgebouw Orchestra, Rotterdam Philharmonic, Berlin Philharmonic, London Symphony and Royal Philharmonic. Equally at home with Mozart and Mahler, Dufallo's programming frequently included works by Bernstein, Aaron Copland, George Gershwin, Charles Ives, and Igor Stravinsky. In February 2000, Maestro Dufallo conducted the Dutch Radio Symphony as part of a 26-hr. series, ''Of Beauty and Consolation,'' which was taped by VPRO Dutch television and broadcast in Europe in April. The two-and-one-half-hour performance (with no intermission) included original text (by the conductor), which he spoke between each piece. Other recent appearances include tours with the Netherlands Wind Ensemble, a tour of Holland and Belgium with the Dutch Radio Philharmonic, the world premiere of ''The Food of Love'' by Peter Schat with the Noord Nederlands Orkest, and debuts with the Orkest van het Oosten (1997-98), and Israel Sinfonietta and Limburg Symphony Orchestra (1998-99). His internationally acclaimed publication, ''Trackings: Composers Speak with Richard Dufallo'' (Oxford University Press), includes conversations with twenty-six of the world's leading composers. Maestro Dufallo has been recorded on Sony, Composer's Voice, CRI American Masters, Fontec Records, Channel Crossings, and Globe. A native of Whiting, Indiana, Maestro Dufallo was born Jan. 30, 1933. He is survived by his wife, pianist Pamela Mia Paul, sons Basil Dufallo, a classics scholar, of Seattle, and Cornelius Dufallo, a violinist in the Flux Quartet, of New York; daughter Rene Kirby of Los Angeles, and a sister, Kathryn Traczyk of East Chicago, Indiana. No service is planned. Memorials may be made to the Richard Dufallo Scholarship Fund, University of North Texas, P.O. Box 311367, Denton, Texas 76203. For more information, contact Pati Haworth at 940382-5962.

My oh so handsome, smart, funny, beloved best friend. I await you at the door and run to answer your phone call. I still can't believe it. My need to see you, talk to you & touch you is overwhelming. My darling, my precious, my excellent strong man. I will miss you and love you forever. Your Sooky

title: The Re-education of Anchee Min
description: At 6 o'clock on a Sunday morning, the San Bernadino Freeway heading east from Los Angeles toward the San Gabriel Mountains is deserted, and the strip malls and subdivisions that sprawl along the hillsides are still blanketed in the gray sleepiness of night. But I am very much awake, thanks to jet lag and my anxious anticipation of the six-mile pre-breakfast hike to which the writer Anchee Min has summoned me.

title: Assad's Son Gets Syrian Party's Blessing
description: Syria's Baath Party, the structural support beneath the 30-year rule of the late Hafez al-Assad, gathered today to pledge allegiance to his 34-year-old son, Bashar, and to vest him formally with the political authority he had quietly exercised from the shadows in the last two years of his father's illness.

title: Basketball Star Now Faces College Recruiters' Phone Blitz
description: HE has handled the full-court press, the game-on-the-line final shot and even the college recruiting-letter blitz.

title: NEWARK CENSUS
description: The director of the United States Census Burea, Kenneth Prewitt, paid a visit last week to the hundreds of frustrated workers at the Newark census office. Dr. Prewitt urged them to make a final push to count the people in the city who have been missed so far. By last week, 97.5 percent of the nation had returned census questionnaires or been visited by a census worker, while the rate in Newark was only about 82 percent, among the lowest among big cities. The workers have until mid-July to complete the count. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: From Nooks to a Courtyard in Bronxville
description: IT is easy to whip up enthusiasm for Scarborough Fair. The many small dining spaces make eating here seem like a private affair, from the patio and glittery little bar at the entry to the cozy nooks of the main room to the flower-decked, vest-pocket courtyard, reminiscent of the half-hidden back gardens one glimpses from the side streets in Italy.

title: 2 Cellos Shine in Caramoor Opening
description: THE Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah opens its eight-week season next Saturday with the cellist Yo-Yo Ma performing with the Orchestra of St. Luke's, conducted by the festival's artistic adviser, Peter Oundjian.

title: Bottom of 9th in Some Vacant Lots As Plan Threatens Youth Baseball
description: As a boy, Victor Cox used to leave his apartment on 100th Street in East Harlem and play sandlot baseball in the vacant lot across the street. It wasn't ideal.

title: Food; Sweet and Lowdown
description: In a society that prides itself on change, it's a little embarrassing to consider the fate of sweet marjoram. A case of mistaken identity dating back to the classification of plants pushed origanum majorana into the oregano family, where it has languished for nearly 250 years. Slightly suspect as bitter and aggressive, marjoram has been relegated -- as most oregano is -- to red sauce and pizza. What a paradox!

title: The Might and Mystery Of a Woman Scorned
description: BY studying pantomime in her native city of Prague, Lenka Pichlikova skirted the language barrier that would hinder her acting career once she immigrated to the United States. Now, 20 years later, though she speaks fluent English, she still prefers storytelling through mime and dance.

title: A Japanese Artist Recalls the 60's: Dots, and Lots of 'em
description: DOTS, dots, dots and dots . . . and then more dots. That's what's in store for viewers of the 66 paintings on paper by the Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama spread chockablock around a single room at the Art Museum, Princeton University: a relentless, restless sea of spots of saturated color, sometimes gathered into circular or columnar configurations against black backgrounds, sometimes spread broadcast across the entire sheet.

title: Steak House Occupies Former B. Smith Space
description: Taking the place of the former B. Smith's soul-food restaurant space in the theater district is Jack Rose, which opened May 15 at 771 Eighth Avenue, at the corner of 47th Street. The restaurant is named after a man who, according to legend, was a Hell's Kitchen gangster back in the 1910's who inspired a drink of the same name. Its combination of applejack, lemon juice and grenadine has been reworked by the restaurant to be a little easier on the throat.

title: Pacers Are Alive and Putting On Their Spin
description: The game was in the vault an hour before. Reggie Miller had pulled the pin on his last 3-pointer, and Jalen Rose had peeled and sliced a defense purported to be the league's most stingy.

title: The Actor
description: ''My hair has become my signature,'' said Andre Royo, an actor, who describes his head of matted tufts as ''in between the Afro and the dreads.'' But his trademark is not singular. Lenny Kravitz and Marcy Grey, both singers, as well as Method Man, the rap performer, have started sporting the same kinky look. Mr. Royo, who had favored his hair short, with a square cut in the back, thinks the hairdo makes him appear ''menacing and cool.'' That may be why he was cast as a villain in John Singleton's version of ''Shaft,'' which opened on Friday.

title: Swinging Chandeliers
description: It has taken a while, but big earrings are really big now, especially chandeliers -- beaded three-inch pendants studded with rhinestones and other bits of costume bijoux. At last October's European collections, Michelle Kessler, Vogue's accessories director, broke the code of minimalism when she wore a pair of R. J. Graziano's chandelier earrings against her long, straight hair. Soon, they dangled in November Vogue and January Allure. Despite these glossy endorsements, big didn't excite retailers. ''None of the stores picked them up because of the whole minimalism thing,'' Wendy Converse, sales manager at R. J. Graziano, said. ''They have just come around to realizing that big is the thing.''

title: A Method Of Cutting Estate Taxes
description: ALTHOUGH the House of Representatives voted this month to kill the federal tax now imposed on estates that exceed $675,000, the promise of a presidential veto has left tax planners with ample incentive to continue advising clients about how to reduce taxes on assets they will ultimately pass to their heirs.

description: MUSIC can make age meaningless, as the five-year-old New Jersey Intergenerational Orchestra has shown.

title: Jones's Mediocre Jumping Gives Competitors Hope
description: Marion Jones turned on her computer this morning and learned the surprising news that Jackie Joyner-Kersee, two years retired, had entered the long jump at next month's United States Olympic track and field trials. Then Jones jumped at a Grand Prix meet here and gave the 38-year-old Joyner-Kersee no reason to believe that a comeback would be ill advised.

title: From Tagliarini to the Bikini
description: Malia Mills, 33, founded Malia Mills Swimwear in 1992 while she was a waitress. Her suits, which sell for about $150 apiece, are among the best-selling swimwear lines at Saks Fifth Avenue, Barneys and Bloomingdale's stores across the country. Part of the line's appeal is that the Malia Mills catalog features civilian models with the figure problems of average women, not swimsuit models with perfect physiques.

title: CHAPPAQUA: BOND VOTE
description: Voters in Chappaqua narrowly approved a $56.8 million bond act Tuesday to build a middle school and renovate three other schools. The measure, approved 2,318 to 2,205, will raise school taxes roughly 6 percent. The new school is to open in September of 2002 and will be the second middle school in Chappaqua. The bond money will also pay for an expansion of Horace Greeley High School and renovations at Roaring Brook Elementary School and Bell Middle School. AL BAKER

description: INTERNATIONAL 3-11

title: The Nation: State Insecurity; The Trials of Secret Science
description: SCIENTISTS talk for a living. If this comes as a surprise, consider that all the experiments and deep thinking of scientific research take place in what amounts to a global sandbox overrun by extremely bright toddlers. Incessant communication is how they get their work done, and passing the secret of how to build the tallest sand castle to half a dozen of them -- say, those on one side of a line in the sand marked United States of America -- guarantees that the entire sandbox will look like downtown Manhattan in about five minutes.

description: Q: Back in 1972, you argued in a case that the actor Lee Marvin's girlfriend of six years deserved half of his $3.6 million in assets. How did you become the father of palimony?

title: Where the Gods Are Neighbors
description: THE first time I was in the Peloponnesus, it was midwinter, and out of the low fog that was everywhere goatherds seemed to appear and dissolve as if in a Theo Angelopoulos film. The narrow roads etched into the mountainside threatened to fall off into clouds. At every switchback turn, a small, mailbox-like shrine with faded icon, biscuits and half-empty bottle of Fanta seemed placed to ensure safe passage.

title: Learning to Fly Without Fear
description: BY my watch, it took six minutes from the time I entered Molly Jong-Fast's book party at the Harmonie Club for sour grapes to sprout. A young man, bound for law school, announced that he would rather publish a novel, too. ''If it were this easy for me, I would write,'' he said churlishly, taking in the photographers snapping shots of Ms. Jong-Fast with her mother, the novelist Erica Jong, hovering and smiling nearby.

title: Free Concert in Hoboken
description: Jill Sobule, singer-songwriter, had a big problem in 1995. She had a hit record, the amiably innocent, homoerotic ''I Kissed a Girl.'' She became a one-hit wonder. At least to those who never took the time to listen to her subsequent recordings.

title: POUND RIDGE: POND CLEANUP
description: The Pound Ridge Town Pond will be cleaned to prevent future problems under an agreement approved by the Board of Legislators. The two-acre pond has had excessive sediment and algae. County Executive Andrew J. Spano called the cleanup ''a demonstration project,'' and said he hoped other local governments would follow suit. The project will be financed with $67,500 in federal funds, with the town supplying labor and maintenance. The county will put plants around the pond in the spring.

title: Ahmad Jamal in Cape May
description: Improvisation is one of the cornerstones of jazz and the pianist Ahmad Jamal has been surprising audiences with his originality ever since he burst on the scene with the 1953 release of ''Ahmad Jamal at the Pershing.'' His restless virtuosity keeps audiences glued to the ivories as he jumps between musical themes and counterthemes and flits between dynamics and tempo. One minute he is pounding away, and the next he will be silent. And he is known for dramatic silences as he vaults from scales to chords, from traditional to bop.
