description: THE big question that dominated the annual awards dinner of the Council of Fashion Designers of America on Thursday night at Lincoln Center was not who would win -- would Oscar prevail over Helmut, thus winning one for Park Avenue, Swifty's and taupe double-faced suits? -- but whether everyone would be home by 11 p.m.

title: Family-Run, and Deft Hand in the Kitchen
description: MARRA'S, in Glen Cove, is a marvel. It offers chewy olive and tomato rolls and homemade sun-dried tomato pesto to new arrivals. There is a bottle of very good garlic- and rosemary-flavored virgin olive oil on every table and glasses of water come with lemon slices discretely perched on their rims. Yet, despite touches of a sort usually encountered at luxury restaurants, nothing on the menu costs more than $10.

title: Rowing 120 Miles Into AARP Sunset
description: Bill Lenderking, a big old guy, 6 feet 4 inches tall, 66 years old, sits on his big old porch, stretching out his knobby old legs, sipping a beer. Finally, he says: ''It's not like it's some real adventure. I'm not risking my life.''

title: The Rare Crossover With Many Rewards
description: AFTER successfully combining the jazz saxophonist Jan Garbarek with the Hilliard Ensemble, an early-music outfit, ECM Records now sets its discipline-crossing sights on music of the great Elizabethan lute-song composer John Dowland. The project began as a conventional Dowland recital by John Potter, a tenor who has sung in the Hilliard Ensemble, Electric Phoenix and Red Byrd; and Stephen Stubbs, the lutenist and director of the group Tragicomedia.

title: Mapping One's Past as Personal Prologue
description: ABOUT 20 people were hunched over tables at the Museum Mile street fair on Fifth Avenue Tuesday evening, colored markers in hand, writing notations on a map, like seafarers planning a journey. But they were headed toward the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGER, JOSEPH
description: SAGER-Joseph. On June 15, 2000, in Plantation, FL, age 92. Beloved father of Marilyn. Devoted brother of the late Rose Berman and Jack Sager. Cherished uncle, great-uncle, cousin, honorary grandfather and friend. A New Yorker for his first 72 years, he graduated from Fordham University Pharmacy School in 1927, and late served as president of his condo association. His great warmth, smile and humor will be sorely missed. Services Monday, June 19, 10 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: June 11-17; Runway Danger Is Seen
description: In a study of runway safety, the National Transportation Safety Board cited an increased risk of on-the-ground collisions, and an increase in the number of times that planes or trucks blunder onto active runways. The Federal Aviation Administration has plans for a computer system to provide warnings, but it is 10 years behind schedule and the board said it was insufficient anyway. The board proposed procedural changes as a short-term fix, but said those changes might worsen airport congestion. MATTHEW L. WALD

title: An Undervalued American Classic
description: FORTY years ago, Billy Wilder's ''Apartment'' and Alfred Hitchcock's ''Psycho'' opened in New York the same week -- the kind of double whammy that reminds us we now live in impoverished times. The films have nothing in common except that each has a lonely bachelor with a unique approach to ensuring a female guest stays over a little longer -- and each has terrific bathroom scenes. In ''Psycho,'' Norman Bates goes to one of his motel rooms dressed as his mom and stabs the heroine to death in the shower. In ''The Apartment,'' the lowly insurance clerk C. C. Baxter (Jack Lemmon) removes the blade from his safety razor lest the suicidal elevator operator Fran Kubelik (Shirley MacLaine) should try to slash her wrists; he later scrapes his lathered jaw with the bladeless razor -- we can see the gag coming and are glad when it arrives.

title: A Peek at Your Credit Scorecard

title: And Now, a Word From Outer Space
description: Art movements are almost always named by critics or historians after the fact. But on a recent evening at the Gagosian Gallery on West 24th Street, Miltos Manetas, who creates computer paintings, staged ''Project: ?Word,'' a happening in the form of a news conference to introduce a term for today's contemporary art and style. ''Neen'' describes visual culture inspired by or based on computer technology, including fine art, Web design and video games, as well as by any number of things sleek, portable and plastic. ''No one knows exactly what it refers to,'' said Steven Pinker, a professor of psychology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and one of five speakers on a panel at the event, which drew some 350 people in the world of art. ''But it's a synonym for cool.''

He leaves his grandson Bruce, his nephews and neices Lawrence and Janet Mayer, Shelley and Tonie Blackler, his sister-in-law Corinne Melkin and his nephew Stephen Melkin. description: FRESH AIR FIEND

title: Music As Muse For Art
description: AS the quirky tones of a jazz trio resonated, Emily Tanner, 17, of Centerport picked at the large chunk of clay on the sculpture stand in front of her. She scratched out a skyscraper, hewed an old man's face, then rotated the mound to the other side to carve out a pregnant woman holding a baby. ''It's like the blurbs of ink with the psychiatrist,'' Emily said, chiseling fastidiously with a plastic tool as the improvised strains of world music being played in the center of the art studio became more strident. ''I'm just looking and seeing what I see. Tonight it's a little more risky. I wanted to do something I wasn't as comfortable with.''

title: By the Sea in Santa Monica, It's Back to Basics
description: UNLIKE Brentwood, Bel Air and other swank western suburbs of Los Angeles, Santa Monica has a real downtown and a slew of restaurants, none of which, fortunately, is known for its stargazing. Some focus more on food than atmosphere, and some the other way around; a few succeed at both.

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; Down Home Barbecue, If Home is Mongolia
description: History tell us that Genghis Khan's Mongolian hordes swept out of the Gobi desert in the 13th century, their sights set on Europe. Now comes a restaurant that suggests that far from dreaming of domination, all the dust-coated horsemen really wanted to do was teach the West to do barbecue right. At Gobi Grill, Mongolian barbecue is the main attraction. At the end of a busy day in the desert, say legends posted here, Genghis's men used their razor-sharp weapons to carve up local game and vegetables, which they grilled on their shields. The tradition lives on in the form of the tava, a flat, round skillet perfect for grilling meals. Diners here assemble their own, plucking thinly shaved meats like lamb, chicken, beef and seafood from a cart, tossing in a variety of fresh vegetables, and ladling on one of four sauces and assorted condiments. Garlic water, anyone? Next, you slip your bowl into the kitchen through a slot beneath a glass window, a chef heaps your selections onto a smoking skillet and cooks it with the aid of elongated chopsticks as you watch. Who knew such a simple ritual could be so fascinating? And, for that matter, who knew you could grill Asian noodles? Later, diners cradling their steaming bowls hurry back to their seats to feast under a tentlike structure called a ger. The cost is $12.95, and yes, you can go back for more, though I've never gotten past my second bowl. Meals fit for a conqueror can be filling. JOSEPH D'AGNESE

The novel, narrated in the hard-boiled style of 50's pulps, is the story of a Los Angeles used-car salesman named Richard Hudson whose attempt to redeem his meaningless life by making a movie ends in betrayal and violence when his partner and the studio boss conclude that the film is too disturbing for public consumption. To Mr. Devor, the book suggested a unique opportunity for a fresh take on film noir: a caper film in which the prize is intellectual property, and a violent rampage is justified on the grounds of artistic integrity.

The New Grove Dictionary of Opera, published in 1992, credited the score to Benedikt Schack and Franz Xaver Gerl, noting that one comic duet, with a soprano part for a character who can no longer speak but only meows like a cat, was orchestrated ''and perhaps partly composed'' by Mozart.

Joan was an active volunteer for over 25 years with the Denver Art Museum and also worked with Catholic Charities' Emergency Assistance Center. She graduated from the University of Colorado with an honors degree in History. Her interests included needle point, antiques, gourmet cooking and studying art history. Joan is survived by her husband, two daughters; Lisa K. Smith of Denver, Colorado and Krista M. Smith of Los Angeles, California, one son; Stephen P. title: The Hawk Is a Lady

But the person inside the sometimes uncomfortably warm costume next school year will be Sarah Brennan of Point Pleasant Beach, the first woman Hawk since the mascot made its debut in 1956. Ms. Brennan will be a senior next year, and by virtue of being the Hawk, she will receive a full scholarship worth $16,000, said Larry Dougherty, assistant athletic director for media relations. But the fact that Ms. Brennan is a woman never entered into the competition, which is stiff. ''Once you get all the gear on, you can't tell anyway,'' said Ms. Brennan. ''I could just be a short guy for all anyone knows.'' KAREN DeMASTERS

Yet, I couldn't help laughing when he told Sara Davidson that ''pot works faster'' than meditation in achieving ''soul perspective.'' Immediate gratification has been criticized as an American malaise, marked by selfishness, impatience and immaturity. I wonder if Ram Dass feels that living closer to one's death -- with less time to spare -- exempts those seeking awareness from the effort and discipline he once apparently endorsed. His remark also reminded me of the contradictions that Zen teachers sometimes throw at their students to keep them off-balance.

title: Express to the Highlands
description: THE Highlands of Scotland are split by a long geological fault line, the Great Glen, which slants across the country from sea to sea, and is mostly filled with fresh water. Loch Ness lies near the middle. The region's turbulent past can be read in the names of three towns along the Glen: Fort George in the northeast, Fort Augustus in the center, and Fort William in the southwest.

description: Robert Mackey's Lives column (May 21) was the most absurd thing you've published in many years. If India is an undercover investigator, what are you doing publishing her photograph as well as her alias? The whole thing reads like the plot of a lowbrow television movie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, GRETA
description: KAUFMAN-Greta. Died May 30, 2000 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Howard. Adored, cherished and devoted mother of Laurie. Dear sister of Harold Hoffman. Always a New Yorker in heart and spirit. A unique personality, she will be remembered for her indomitable will in facing life's challenges, and her endearing loyalty and strength of character. Three kisses mommie.

title: A 1920's Estate Garden Is Carefully Restored
description: THE Antiquarian and Landmarks Society of Hartford was not at all surprised a decade ago when it acquired a beautifully preserved 18th-century estate in northwestern Connecticut. The Bethlehem summer home for a wealthy New York family, it was called ''The Hay'' by its last mistress, Caroline Woolsey Ferriday, who had made her intended bequest well known before she died in 1990.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, PAUL WALDO
description: SCHWARTZ-Paul Waldo. Age 61, of Cambridge, MA. Died June 8. Writer, painter, photographer, Harvard graduate, man of letters, mystical thinker, bon vivant. We will miss you. Your New York Friends

title: Turn Of the Century
description: The new PBS mini-series ''1900 House,'' which started last week, follows a modern British family that has agreed to spend three months living in a London townhouse that has been carefully de-modernized -- electric wiring stripped out and gas lighting put back into service, plumbing degraded back to Victorian standards and so on. I was worried about the concept: would it turn out to be exploitation TV with a highbrow veneer, sort of ''Survivor'' meets ''Upstairs, Downstairs''? But the first episode, about the preparation of the house and the selection of the family, was terrific, prompting some serious thoughts about the nature and measurement of economic progress.

title: The Southwest
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to see the photograph of Will Tsosie in ''Under the Arizona Sun'' (April 23). He served as our guide on the Navajo reservation portion of a trip to the Southwest. We got to eat his aunt's Navajo cooking and visit another aunt's sheep farm. He is knowledgeable, hospitable and charming. A highlight of the trip was sitting on a rim of Canyon de Chelly, above Spider Woman Rock, and hearing Mr. Tsosie sing the traditional chants connected with Spider Woman, who is part of the Navajo creation story.

title: Children's Books; A Mighty Big Splash
description: In August 1926, fighting rain, high winds and 20-foot waves, Gertrude Ederle became the first woman to swim the English Channel. Ederle, just 19, already held three Olympic medals and had set 29 American and world records. Her time for the channel, 14 hours 31 minutes, beat the men's record by nearly two hours and remained the women's record for 35 years.

title: Footlights; Round Ends, Excitement Continues
description: Arthur Aitkens did not reach the second round two weeks ago in the Van Cliburn Foundation's Second International Piano Competition for Outstanding Amateurs in Fort Worth, Tex. Still, the retired corporate lawyer said that just being there through the first round was reward enough.

description: SAY this about brand-name value investors: There seem to be fewer of them of late.

title: Yonkers School Board Fires Superintendent
description: Inserting more tumult into a long-troubled school district, the Yonkers school board fired the schools superintendent Friday night after he battled the mayor's attempts to get the city out from under a court order to desegregate its schools.

title: CHILD ABUSE GRANTS
description: The Dutchess and Putnam Departments of Social Services will receive $44,678 and $60,000, respectively, from the state as part of $1.8 million program to improve the investigation of child abuse cases and help children who are victims of abuse. Westchester was not among the 25 grants announced. An additonal $300,000 has been allocated for local or regional child fatality review teams. In the garden behind his Chelsea apartment is the sign that used to hang over the club's door: a curly-haired figure with a tambourine halo, along with a disco whistle and an amyl nitrate popper dangling below. A friend salvaged it from a garbage heap after the club closed.

title: OSSINING: OFFICERS CLEARED
description: A federal investigation has exonerated three white Ossining police officers in the July 1998 shooting death of Chris Malone, a 24-year-old black man. The investigation cleared the officers, Raymond DeBenedictis, Richard Damiano and Daniel Slater, of criminal wrongdoing. After reports that Mr. Malone had fired a gun, the officers chased and caught him, shooting him after the suspect pointed a handgun at them. Federal officials said the investigation failed to establish beyond a reasonable doubt that the officers had used unreasonable force. ELSA BRENNER

title: At U.N., Serving Iran's Food To Eager if Ignorant Diners
description: THE SETTING -- The bustling, steamy kitchen of the United Nations Delegates Dining Room, where a dozen people were taking a behind-the-scenes cooking class, part of a series sponsored by the New School University that brings students to top eating spots. This month, the United Nations is celebrating the food of Iran, so chickpea fritters, savory shish kebabs and Persian baklava swimming in rosewater were all on the menu. It was the first time, according to the United Nations, that the Islamic government of Iran has sponsored any official event outside the country.

Among the boats competing for top prizes were such modern thoroughbreds as Larry Ellison's Sayonara, Jim Dolan's Sagamore and George Coumantaros's Boomerang.

title: Style; The Buckaroo Stops Here
description: For seven years, the Cowboy Poetry and Music Festival has descended on a motion picture studio in Santa Clarita, Calif., called the Melody Ranch, once owned by the singing cowboy Gene Autry. Musicians, wranglers, tradesmen and enthusiasts eager to download the 90's -- the 1890's -- assemble in all their overwrought finery. Performers celebrate in verse and ballad those pioneers who fought their way west after the Civil War, men who spat around campfires and discussed iambic pentameter. Well, maybe not. Still, a cowboy poetry festival? Is this oxymoronic? Or a regional curiosity, like those Renaissance fairs we have upstate? Either way, style's the main draw.

title: As Murder Rates Edge Up, Concern, but Few Answers
description: With the number of homicides in some of the nation's big cities rising in 1999 and the first five months of 2000, after eight years of sharp drops, concern is rising among law enforcement officials and criminologists about whether the decline in violent crime has finally come to an end.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Summer Window Into New World Beyond Imagining

title: June 11-17; Legal Victory for Nixon
description: Six years after his death, former President Richard M. Nixon scored a legal victory. The Justice Department agreed to pay Nixon's estate $18 million for White House papers, tapes and photographs seized by Congress after his resignation in 1974. Nixon's contention that the documents were his personal property was backed by an appeals court, but critics accused his heirs of profiting from public papers that implicated the president in obstruction of justice and other crimes. CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS

title: New Occupants At Alex and Henry's

At least, that's what the founders of the three major music festivals on the South Fork hope as the season gets under way tomorrow with Pianofest opening its 12th year of presenting advanced piano students in weekly ''concerts with commentary.''

title: Frozen Switches
description: To the Editor: I was pleased to see that Amtrak is installing modern safety devices in ''Faster Amtrak Trains, Fancier Safeguards'' by Matthew L. Wald (May 21).

title: Sports of The Times; No. 8 Is This Open's Most Precise Hole
description: FROM the tee down near the rocks of Carmel Bay, you can't see the chasm. All you see is the grassy horizon of the fairway with the dazzling expanse of Carmel's crescent beach to the right. Beyond the fairway at the edge of the chasm, out there about 260 yards, shaggy grass surrounds two small signs.

With fewer Americans enlisting in the armed services today, and with fewer Americans having been personally touched by the tragedy of war, it seems that you might have chosen to remind your readers of the holiday's significance by honoring the young men and women who have fallen victim to the misfortunes of combat and perhaps saved this worthwhile yet extremely controversial subject for another weekend.

title: The Challenges of Abundance
description: A deadly familiarity has crept into the debate between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush. Last week, as Mr. Gore embarked on a new series of ''prosperity and progress'' speeches, Mr. Bush immediately derided his efforts as ''Al Gore's 'I Invented Prosperity' Tour.'' Underneath the surface of such exchanges, however, the political terrain may be undergoing some redefinition. For the first time in decades, a presidential race is occurring at a time of economic abundance and budget surpluses. These unusual circumstances are testing the creativity of both major candidates.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Revising Lives
description: In computer software terminology, the ''version 2.0'' of a program is generally the first major revision to the original product, where old mistakes are fixed and new features are added. As one might guess from the title, Caroline Preston's warm and engaging second novel, LUCY CROCKER 2.0 (Scribner, $23), is about a woman's decision to revise her own life. Part midlife catharsis, part wilderness adventure story, the book also brings a human touch to the world of computers. Lucy is a painter and former librarian living in Massachusetts, and she is married to Ed, a software company president; they have teenage twin sons who started their own computer consulting business while in fourth grade. Asked to produce paintings and puzzles for a sequel to a computer fantasy game she had designed, Lucy procrastinates until Ed, goaded by Ingrid, his company's publicity director, fires her from the project. After she discovers that Ed and Ingrid are engaging in after-work activities of their own (often involving huckleberry massage oil), and catches her sons surfing for porn on the Internet, Lucy is prompted to action. She signs up her protesting twins for a rigorous canoe trip, and then she takes off on a sojourn of her own to her family's old cabin in the Wisconsin woods. Although the book's plot can be predictable in places, Preston gives us strong, complex characters who each end up striving to correct the bugs and glitches plaguing their lives. J. D. Biersdorfer

title: Science Fiction
description: The prologue to EVOLUTION'S DARLING (Four Walls Eight Windows, paper, $15.95), by Scott Westerfeld, is breathtaking. Rathere, the 14-year-old daughter of a space-roving journalist, has trouble getting her father's attention. Her constant companion is an Artificial Intelligence (A.I.) with so much computing capacity that it can pilot a starship, baby-sit for Rathere and ponder the mysteries of the universe at the same time. The danger, for Rathere's financially strapped father, is that the A.I. will raise its ''Turing Quotient'' to 1.0, which would make it, in the eyes of the law, an independent person rather than a useful piece of property. Realizing that his daughter's relationship with the A.I. is driving the machine toward sentience, the father separates them. Rathere fights back in the only way she can. To nudge the A.I. over the threshold to personhood, she makes love to it -- in a scene of eerie beauty that begins with the words, ''It's me, darling.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNAPP, LUCILLE GALE
description: KNAPP-Lucille Gale. Died peacefully in her home at Wolsey Farm, Mt. Kisco, NY, on June 16, 2000, at the age of 94. This extraordinary woman was an avid supporter of the arts and had a great love for music. Her style, spirit and love for life will be greatly missed by her family and friends. Mrs. Knapp was the beloved wife of the late Sanford R. Knapp. She was the President of Taylor-Knapp Company which mined silver and manganese in Philipsburg, MT. She also established the William and L. R. Gale Community Foundation and Galeton Foundation to benefit the citizens of Galeton, PA, and she cherished her summer home in Buck Hill, PA. Mrs. Knapp had been a resident of Riverdale, NY, where she was a lifelong member of the Riverdale Yacht Club. She is survived by her sister-in-law Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Knapp of Irvington, NY, her nieces Katharine K. Sherwood of South Salem, NY, and Carolyn K. Cullins of Burlington, VT, and great-niece Sarah G. Cullins and great-nephews Duncan R. Sherwood and Carter M. Sherwood. The memorial service will be held on June 29, 2000, at 11 AM, at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. Matthew's Church or the Galeton Foundation.

title: Raising the Stakes In Punk Rock
description: TWO Sundays ago, some 10,000 people gathered in Dolores Park in the Mission District here for Soupstock 2000, a day of music celebrating the 20th anniversary of Food Not Bombs. With chapters around the country and overseas, the anarchist collective was founded to fight militarism; more recently, in San Francisco, the group has organized tenants to oppose gentrification and often clashed with police over unauthorized, on-the-street food distribution to homeless people. But this was a sunny day. The riotously tattooed crowd was very young, no one was hungry (''Have you had any of the food?'' asked an announcer from the stage; ''It's free; everything here today is free''), and Sleater-Kinney, a three-woman punk band founded in Olympia, Wash., in 1994, was out of place.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-18-00: Salient Facts; What Would Cows Think?
description: Each of us consumed 24 gallons of the stuff last year (down from 29 gallons in 1975), but milk's share of stomach -- industry-speak for beverage market share -- is only 12 percent, less than half that of carbonated soft drinks. We drink nearly as much beer and coffee as milk, and if current trends continue, we could soon be drinking more bottled water than milk too. So the question for the industry, according to Rachel Kaldor of the Dairy Institute of California, is ''How do you make milk cool?'' In the past few years, the answer has been marketing. Tap Britney Spears as the newest mustache model and sponsor her current tour. But now a new answer has arisen: make milk that tastes like something else.

These are excellent films by first-rank directors, but what made them so soul-satisfying was a quality of intimacy, palpable and immediate. It becomes a privileged state, beyond voyeurism to a kind of collaboration, a sense that the director is disclosing subtle secrets, or trying to -- about behavior, about life, or simply about the possibilities of perception itself -- and that your ability to see is as important as the filmmaker's ability to show.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; America's Satanic Mills
description: Social documentary photography was still new when Lewis W. Hine began photographing child laborers at the beginning of the 20th century. Between 1906 and 1918, working as an investigative photographer for a humanitarian organization, the National Child Labor Committee, he documented children toiling in mines, mills, fish canneries, factories and on the streets. Buoyed by his belief in the power of pictures to change public opinion, Hine was indefatigable. He could also be shrewd, claiming to be a Bible salesman to gain entry into factories where he was otherwise unwanted, or memorizing the height of his coat buttons to compute the heights of the children he photographed. His social realism was in tune with the muckraking tenor of his times, Vicki Goldberg writes in her insightful introduction to LEWIS W. HINE: Children at Work (Prestel, $39.95), a selection of more than 90 of Hine's finest photographs. If their frankly prosaic character renders pronouncements about the excellence of individual pictures difficult to make, she observes, there is less question about the force and power of the totality of his work. Aesthetics were not what Hine's work was about; it was social change that he sought. Truths were revealed in the details: the scabbed bare feet of a small girl in a cotton mill, the hugeness of a bundle of newspaper compared with the diminutive arm of the 8-year-old newsboy who clutches it. If some of the shock of these images escape us now, it is only because the camera has made us witnesses to far worse atrocities in the intervening years. But nothing takes away from the pioneering quality of Hine's achievement. Andrea Barnet

title: Gauging the Effect Of Drug Warnings
description: Consumers who said they would not take a drug because of the information about side effects offered in advertisements said they were influenced more by such information in television commercials than by comparable information in magazine ads, according to a study released on Thursday by the Time Inc., at the third annual Health Summit Breakfast in New York. The breakfast was organized by two magazines owned by Time: Time and Health.

description: CONVERTING the loose change on the bedroom dresser into ''real money'' is probably on the bottom of most people's ''to do'' lists, right up there with organizing the sock drawer.

title: One Review Ends, And Another Begins
description: The Florida Department of Health in Tallahassee, Fla., retained Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, as the agency of record for its antitobacco campaign. Billings were estimated at $19 million for the 18-month contract. The decision came after a four-month review that had been narrowed to Crispin Porter and an agency that withdrew, Siboney U.S.A in Miami, part of True North Communications. Crispin Porter said it planned to continue with its ''truth'' campaign.

title: First Lady Attacks Lazio For Missing Vote in House

title: Internet Exchanges Create Opportunities for Small Businesses : For Little Guys, a More Level Playing Field
description: INDIVIDUALLY, small businesses may seem like small potatoes, but as a whole, they are increasingly seen as a big deal when it comes to business-to-business transactions on the Internet. A myriad of dot-com companies are developing marketplaces and services to give small businesses the same opportunities available to corporations like the Big Three automakers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLIAR, JOAN
description: STOLIAR-Joan. On June 18, 2000, a woman of rare talents and unique dignity, understanding and warmth. She gave unsparingly of herself until her long-term bout with cancer took her suddenly and peacefully with her loved ones by her side. An award winning book designer and avid fly fisher, she devoted her later years to helping impaired and elderly attain good fishing and getting school children from New York City and upstate New York to understand more about the environment and clean water by raising trout in their classrooms. She is survived by her adoring husband of 47 years, Arthur, her devoted children, Lee Stoliar Dufresne of Charlotteville, NY, and Evan Stoliar of New York City, beloved grandchild Abby Dufresne, and treasured sister, Dr. Virginia Stein of Somerville, NJ. Funeral service Tuesday, June 20, at 1:15 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St, NYC (212) 362-6600. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to a charity of your choice in Joan's name.

description: Aiming directly at the voters in the center, Republicans turned their first official platform meeting today into a showcase for the party's ideas on education, Medicare and Social Security.

title: The Times Is Expected to Sign An Accord on a New Building
description: The New York Times is expected to sign an agreement this week with state and city officials to build a 40-story headquarters on Eighth Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets, according to executives involved in the talks.

title: Pacino, Burstyn and Keitel To Lead the Actors Studio
description: The Actors Studio, the legendary theater workshop, has named Al Pacino, Ellen Burstyn and Harvey Keitel -- three members of its board -- as co-presidents. They will replace Arthur Penn, who is leaving to serve as executive producer of the television series ''Law and Order'' but who will continue as president emeritus. Estelle Parsons will stay on as artistic director.

title: Jeffrey Willick, 40, Astrophysicist and Professor
description: Dr. Jeffrey A. Willick, an assistant professor at Stanford University and an astrophysicist intrigued with cosmology and the motion of galaxies, was killed Sunday afternoon in Englewood, N.J., when a sports car crashed into a coffee shop and hit him, the authorities said. He was 40.

title: The Dutch Seek to Legalize Long-Tolerated Euthanasia
description: When surgery showed that Dr. Henk Laane's 77-year-old patient, a woman who had been in his care for more than a decade, was riddled with cancer, she immediately asked him to help her die.

title: Trade Winds Are Blowing For Yankees Despite Rout
description: The Yankees were 20-8 on May 7, steadily building their lead in the American League East, playing at a pace that would have them chasing all the records they set in 1998. But the Yankees have gone 15-21 since, including a 22-1 rout of the Boston Red Sox tonight in the opener of a four-game series. Regardless of how they do in this series, which comes on the heels of a four-game losing streak, they are ready to make changes.

title: Basketball Loudly and Furiously Takes Over, on the Stage and in a Fan's Life
description: You'll need a high decibel tolerance to enjoy ''Joe Fearless (A Fan Dance),'' and it will help if you're a sports nut, but this comedy about one man's lunatic obsession with basketball, ebulliently written by Liz Tuccillo and staged by Craig Carlisle at the edge of hysteria, is a true original. If your imagination has ever put you on the floor of Madison Square Garden with the galloping herds of the National Basketball Association thundering around you, get a ticket. It's probably the first theatrical production ever staged with a foul-shooting contest for the audience at intermission.

title: U.S. and China Agree on Steps To Fight Drugs
description: The United States and China agreed today to step up cooperation in the fight against illegal drugs, especially heroin and methamphetamine. The two drugs have emerged as scourges in both countries and throughout much of Asia.

title: Brisk Rhythms for Songs of Slave Drivers and Sadness
description: African slaves brought the gift of syncopation to Peru, putting rhythmic crosscurrents behind the symmetrical melodies of Spanish and Native American songs. Susana Baca, who has spent much of her career collecting and preserving Afro-Peruvian songs, has decided not to isolate Peru's music from its kin across the hemisphere. On Wednesday night she opened a three-night engagement at Joe's Pub with guest musicians from New York -- John Medeski on keyboards and Marc Ribot and David Byrne on guitars -- sitting in with her Peruvian band.

title: Bodies of 58 Asians in Dover: An 'Evil Trade in People'
description: British customs officers searching a consignment of imported tomatoes aboard a Dutch truck in this Channel port early today were horrified to find the bodies of 58 Asian men and women inside the dark, airless space.

description: Like a pilot at his controls, Stefen Fangmeier sat at the video console in a darkened meeting room at Industrial Light and Magic, a pioneer in the business of creating special effects for movies. Arrayed behind him on four rows of ratty couches and metal chairs were a dozen or so computer animators and engineers.

title: H&R Block Hires Campbell Mithun
description: H&R Block in Kansas City, Mo., said yesterday that it had named Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle creative duties for its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $100 million. That assignment had been handled since 1996 by the Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, which decided against taking part in a review that began in late March.

title: Cendant Says Accounting Firm Knew of Fraudulent Practices
description: The Cendant Corporation contended in a court filing yesterday that the accounting firm Ernst & Young knew of widespread fraud at CUC International, a predecessor to Cendant, by 1997 and chose to help the fraud along rather than expose it. Ernst & Young immediately responded by attributing the fraud in part to Cendant's current chief executive, Henry R. Silverman.

title: Colombia Oil Discovery
description: Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd. said testing of a well in Colombia confirmed the discovery of about 1.4 billion barrels of oil, at least 20 percent of which can be profitably extracted. Alberto Calderon, the president of Empresa Colombiana de Petroleos, the Colombian state oil company, said the find should increase the likelihood that Colombia would remain self-sufficient in oil after 2004, when its existing reserves are expected to dry up. The find of the Guando field is the biggest in Colombia after BP Amoco's Cusiana and Cupiagua fields and Occidental Petroleum's Cano Limon field, the Colombian company said.

title: A Safer Retirement Plan
description: Vice President Al Gore has learned from his boss. With Clintonesque strokes he has put together a retirement plan that extracts the best part of Gov. George W. Bush's proposal, leaving the governor to defend the unpopular parts, such as the likely need to cut promised Social Security benefits.

title: ROYAL BANK ACQUISITION
description: Canada's largest bank, Royal Bank of Canada, has agreed to buy the Liberty Life Insurance Company and the Liberty Insurance Services Corporation, two subsidiaries of the Liberty Corporation of Greenville, S.C., for $650 million. The two insurance companies have 1,500 employees and agents, and manage $2 billion of assets. John Cleghorn, chairman and chief executive of Royal Bank, said the purchase provided ''excellent opportunities for cross-selling with our retail operations in the United States,'' which include banking and investor services. Although Royal Bank's insurance subsidiary has been growing steadily in Canada, domestic banking regulations do not permit insurance to be sold through bank branches. The Liberty Corporation said it agreed to buy Civic Communications, a television broadcaster based in Jackson, Miss., for $204 million. Timothy Pritchard

title: Bittersweet Day at Seagram

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KABAT, ELVIN A.
description: KABAT-Elvin A. Ph.D. The Faculty and Staff of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons mourn the loss of our distinguished friend and colleague, Dr. Elvin Kabat. Dr. Kabat's long career with Columbia University began as an Assistant Professor of Bacteriology in 1946. An immunochemist, biochemist and educator, he served Columbia for more than half a century, becoming Higgins Professor Emeritus in 1985. One of the founders of the field of immunochemistry, Dr. Kabat received the National Medal of Science, the nation's highest award for scientific achievement, from President Bush in 1991. His accomplishments are illustrated in his vast list of publications, which total more than 400 and have been distributed throughout the world. Dr. Kabat was universally admired and venerated by generations of students, colleagues and staff. He will be greatly missed and his memory cherished. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Sally, and his sons. Thomas Q. Morris, M.D. Interim Dean for Clinical and Educational Affairs, Columbia Univ. College of Physicians & Surgeons David I. Hirsh, PhD, Interim Dean for Research, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, HOWARD
description: ROSEN-Howard, M.D. The Members of The NYU-Hospital For Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Dr. Howard Rosen. Dr. Rosen was a graduate of HJD's Orthopaedic Residency Program and continued to serve as a valued and honored member of the department for more than 48 years. He was an outstanding educator of residents and a world-reknown orthopaedic surgeon. Dr. Rosen was a remarkable man and a true contributor to the field of orthopaedic surgery. He leaves a grieving hospital community and a profound void at HJD, since his many years of dedicated work at the hospital have touched the lives of countless people during his tenure. We grieve his passing as we celebrate his exemplary life and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Connie, their daughters, Terry and Eileen, and to the entire family. Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D., Chairman, NYU-Hospital For Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery William Jaffe, M.D., Vice-Chairman NYU-Hospital For Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery

title: Front Row

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, ELEANOR
description: GOLDBERGER-Eleanor. We celebrate the life and mourn the death of Eleanor Goldberger, 73, of Spring Hill, FL, who peacefully passed away Thursday, June 15, 2000. Devoted wife of Joseph Fainstein, beloved mother of Genie and Dianne and cherished grandmother of Mindy and Carrie; adored friend of many. Donations may be made to Hernando Pasco Hospice, Spring Hill, FL.34606

title: Student Prayers Must Be Private, Court Reaffirms
description: Strongly reaffirming its earlier decisions against officially sponsored prayer in public schools, the Supreme Court ruled today that prayers led by students at high school football games are no exception: as officially sanctioned acts at events that students feel great social pressure to attend, they are unconstitutional.

title: FRENCH COMPANY AGREES TO A DEAL TO  BUY  SEAGRAM
description: The Seagram Company, the spirits and entertainment company that includes such legendary names as Absolut vodka, Universal Studios and Polygram Records, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to be acquired for about $34 billion in stock by Vivendi S.A., a French water utility that is transforming itself into a telecommunications and entertainment giant.

title: These Views From Russia Look a Lot Like Home
description: Competition in the commercial spy business's outer-space satellite imagery sector is heating up as Russia enters the fray. A sample photo, showing New York harbor, with an inset showing City Hall, was taken in 1994 by a Russian military spy satellite hundreds of miles up and was just made available commercially in the United States by Central Trading Systems, in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Lawmakers Reach Compromise on Pesticide Notification Bill
description: Republican and Democratic leaders in the Legislature announced today that they had reached agreement on legislation that would allow county governments to mandate that people be notified when pesticides were going to be applied near their homes.

title: Pacers Display Their Valor in Bird's Final Series
description: The Indiana Pacers were not supposed to make it this difficult. Their starting point guard is slow, their top center can't rebound, they were from the second-class Eastern Conference. Compassionate observers were hoping that the Pacers would not embarrass themselves in the National Basketball Association finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, ISFRIED
description: STRAUSS-Isfried. We mourn the passing of the husband of our esteemed member Erica Strauss and the father of our esteemed members Melvin and Ronald Strauss and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ABRAHAM
description: COHEN-Abraham. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood and Men's Club, mourn the passing of our esteemed member, the beloved husband of our devoted member, Vera Cohen. We extend heartfelt sympathy to all the members ofthe bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

description: Following is a transcript of Archbishop Edward M. Egan's homily yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral, as recorded by The New York Times:

description: It's 8 a.m., and Diane Ruggiero is seated in a super-trendy patio restaurant in a hotel on Sunset Boulevard. Despite the early hour, most of the handful of diners are wearing dark glasses, dressed in black and keeping their cell phones handy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNITZER, ALBERT R.
description: SNITZER-Albert R. ''Allie'', CLU, ChFC, of Murray Hill, New Jersey on June 14, 2000. Husband of Leah Goldberg Snitzer. Father of John R. of Murray Hill, New Jersey and Mrs. Cathy Kneese of Chatham, New Jersey. Father-in-law of Kenneth Kneese. Also survived by 2 grandchildren, Tamara and Sean Kneese. A Memorial Service was held at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham, New Jersey on Saturday, June 17. Those who wish may contribute in his memory to the University of Virginia Fund, PO Box 3446, Dept. of Latin, Greek and Archaeology, Charlottesville, Virgina, 22903.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLICK, JEFFREY ALAN
description: WILLICK-Jeffrey Alan, age 40. Beloved father, husband, son, brother and uncle, friend and teacher to many. Victim of a tragic accident. Professor of Astrophysics at Stamford University. Devoted husband of Ellen Schneider, M.D. Adoring father of Jason, Emily and baby girl due in September. Beloved son of Nancy and Martin S. Willick of Teaneck, NJ. Cherished brother of Gary, Stuart and Jennifer Eden, Karen and Billy Burke. Services Wednesday, June 21st, at 11:30 AM, at ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' Hackensack. Memorial service in Palo Alto, CA; date to be announced.

title: Guggenheim In Pact With Hermitage
description: Two art institutions with visions of expansion but strikingly different economic positions -- the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia -- have reached an agreement to share their collections, organize joint exhibitions and help each other develop a worldwide network of museums.

title: A Million Parents Lost Medicaid, Study Says
description: Nearly a million low-income parents have lost Medicaid coverage and have probably become uninsured since Congress and the states began overhauling the nation's welfare programs in 1996, a consumer group said in a new study today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: JOSEPH STEVENS & CO., New York, named Jeff Lederer, a consultant to the company, to the post of president. He succeeds Steven Markowitz, who remains chairman.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the arts pages yesterday included an outdated reference to PeripheRock, an event in France's annual Music Festival. The event, originally scheduled for tomorrow on the road that circles Paris, has been canceled.

title: A Shampoo That Highlights Head Lice
description: A pediatrician at Yale says he has developed an improved technique for detecting lice eggs, known as nits, raising hope for the day when parents will not have to spend long hours delousing their children -- only to find that a few missed eggs forces them to begin all over again.

title: Novel Rockets Speed Dreams of Sending People to Mars
description: A new type of rocket engine under development could halve the travel time between Earth and Mars -- should NASA ever decide to send astronauts there.

title: Sotheby's Biggest Shareholder Still Criticizes Board Makeup
description: The Baron Capital Group, a New York mutual fund that is the largest outside shareholder of Sotheby's, filed a notice with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday saying that it continues to believe that electing the son of the former chairman and some of his friends to the board would present a conflict of interest.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: A Man in the News article on Friday about Commerce Secretary William M. Daley misidentified the Chicago high school that he attended. (The error also appeared in a profile of Mr. Daley on Dec. 14, 1996.) It was St. Ignatius High School, now called St. Ignatius College Prep, not De La Salle High School.

title: Pepsi Plans to Offer a Competitor to Sprite
description: PepsiCo Inc., the world's No. 2 soft drink maker, will sell a new lemon-lime flavored soft drink by year-end to compete with the Coca-Cola Company's fast-growing Sprite.

title: It Takes Two to Tango, And More to Jazz It Up
description: Jazz and tango have parallel histories. Both came out of the slums and the underworld, were denounced as salacious and were then embraced as dance music. Both moved from clubs to concert halls, evolving into more ambitious forms. Both conjure romance, exhilaration and tension; both use improvisation. Yet they are as different as Argentina and the United States. Tango has a European formality and a sense of tragedy; jazz prefers openness and a sense of humor, the underlying optimism that lets the blues transcend hard times. Still, it was inevitable that jazz and tango would meet, as they did in the jazz festival concert on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Justices Overturn a State Law on Myanmar
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously struck down a Massachusetts law aimed at boycotting companies that do business in Myanmar, ruling that crucial differences between the state law and existing federal sanctions ''compromise the very capacity of the president to speak for the nation with one voice in dealing with other governments.''

title: Blattner Brunner Acquires EPB Unit
description: Blattner Brunner in Pittsburgh said yesterday that it had acquired Egan/St. James in Pittsburgh from EPB Communications in New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: New Jersey Will Have to Raise Gas Tax to Pay for Projects, Policy Group Says
description: New Jersey is going to have to raise the state gas tax by at least a nickel to pay for $3.7 billion in road and public transportation projects over the next four years, a study by a liberal policy organization predicted today.

title: Testaverde on the Mend
description: Vinny Testaverde is in the ninth month of rehabilitation from an Achilles' tendon injury that normally takes 8 to 12 months to heal. He said yesterday that he was ''not quite 100 percent,'' but thought he would be close by opening day.

title: Fighting Fog
description: Q.: How do antifogging treatments for mirrors and eyeglasses work?

title: Little Ears And Big Elephants
description: There is both a place and a need for children's works in the classical music repertory, but few composers have turned their hand to the task and of those that have, few have done it successfully. Success, of course, is in the ear of the beholder, but one criterion is that the work can sit comfortably beside the concert works in the composer's catalog, as Prokofiev's ''Peter and the Wolf,'' Saint-Saens's ''Carnival of the Animals,'' Britten's ''Young People's Guide to the Orchestra'' and Poulenc's ''Histoire de Babar'' do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, LEONARD
description: HOCHBERG-Leonard . It is with great sorrow that the Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Leonard Hochberg, brother of Irwin Hochberg, former chairman of the board and longtime supporter of UJA-Federation and many other Jewish causes. Our deepest sympathies go to Irwin, his wife, Rita, and the rest of the family. May all who benefited from Leonard's kindness and wisdom be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: U.S. Clears Pfizer Deal for Warner-Lambert
description: Clearing the way for a merger that would make Pfizer Inc. the world's biggest pharmaceutical company, the Federal Trade Commission approved its combination with the Warner-Lambert Company yesterday on condition that the companies shed businesses in four categories.

title: Appeals Court Plans Fast-Paced Schedule for Review of the Microsoft Case
description: A federal appeals court stepped forcefully into the Microsoft antitrust case today, dismissing a government argument that it lacked jurisdiction and setting a fast-paced schedule for reviewing Microsoft's request that the judges block a lower-court order restricting its conduct.

title: HEINZ IS SELLING U.S. CAN-MAKING OPERATIONS
description: The H. J. Heinz Company agreed to sell its can-making operations in the United States, American Samoa and Puerto Rico to the closely held Impress Metal Packaging Holdingsfor an undisclosed price. Impress, based in Amsterdam, will supply metal cans to Heinz's North American seafood and pet-products plants for 10 years. Heinz, based in Pittsburgh, makes a wide variety of food products. It has been closing plants to focus on new products.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: LUCENT AGREES TO ACQUIRE HERRMANN TECHNOLOGY
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the privately held Herrmann Technology Inc. for $438 million in stock to get more optical networking technology. Lucent, which is based in Murray Hill, N.J., issued 7.3 million shares for Herrmann and may issue another 675,000 shares, worth $40 million, if Herrmann meets certain performance-based goals. Herrmann, which is based in Dallas, makes devices that allow large amounts of data to travel over a fiber optic network. Lucent said it planned to keep Herrmann's 65 employees in Dallas. Shares of Lucent, which had $38.3 billion in revenue last year, were up 68.75 cnets, to $60.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Beyond Ireland to a Wider Yet Often Bleak World
description: A stone's throw from Davy Byrne's pub, where fans of James Joyce celebrated ''Ulysses'' on Friday night, St. Anne's Church was packed straight up to the organ pipes with more than 700 people waiting to hear Irish authors read from their work at the Dublin Writers' Festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRIER, EUGENE
description: CARRIER-Eugene. Former Manager of the New York Times Technical Support Department. Passed away on Friday, June 16 in Cape Coral, Florida. He is survived by his wife Denise, a brother Bobbie, daughters Christie Tine and Dawn Murray Schnauder and son David. Five grandchildren Kevin, Nicholas, Samantha, Alicia and Gene. Memorial service 10AM Tuesday, June 20 at St. Andrew Catholic Church in Cape Coral. The family has asked that in lieu of flowers donations be sent to The Gift of Life of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in New York.

title: Piazza Hits Hard by Keeping It Simple
description: When he is at the plate, Mike Piazza gives himself instant feedback. He processes the pitches he sees and the way his swing feels. Beyond that, he keeps it simple. There is too much analysis of hitting, Piazza believes, and he does not need it.

description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Los Angeles and Cupertino, Calif.

description: The audit was routine, but the findings were chaotic.

title: Political Memo; Mrs. Clinton Finds Specter Of Gingrich Has Faded
description: In the space of a few days last week, in speeches and television advertisements, Hillary Rodham Clinton assailed Representative Rick A. Lazio as a friend to the gun lobby, a foe of abortion rights, and hostile to women, children and families, by virtue of some of the votes he has cast in Congress. But there was one thing notably missing from the first lady's broad and calculated barrage on her new opponent in the race for the United States Senate: any mention of Newt Gingrich.

title: Nortel-Hewlett Venture
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company agreed to create devices and services jointly for wireless-Internet access, the companies said today. Nortel, a telephone equipment maker, also said it would add 2,000 high-technology jobs in Europe as it built new wireless centers in Spain and Germany and Internet laboratories in Norway and Sweden. Nortel and Hewlett-Packard will use Nortel's wireless network equipment and Hewlett-Packard's computing technology to make high-speed Internet products. They will focus on wireless, electronic-commerce services and software.

title: U.S. Declares 'Rogue Nations' Are Now 'States of Concern'
description: After years of directing sanctions and suspicion toward defiant governments from North Korea to Iran, the Clinton administration abruptly declared today that ''rogue nations'' no longer exist.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The delivery of a pregame prayer has the improper effect of coercing those present to participate in an act of religious worship.''

title: DISPUTE OVER RESTRUCTURING
description: A struggle over Russia's most actively traded company, Unified Energy Systems, intensified after the company said it would present a reorganization plan to the government tomorrow, despite criticism of the plan from foreign investors. The plan, which calls for splitting off regional power plants and generators from the parent company, has been widely opposed by foreign investors who say it will destroy the value of their holdings. Sabrina Tavernise

title: MacTavish Offered The Top Spot
description: The Edmonton Oilers offered their coaching job to Craig MacTavish, who was an assistant with the team last season, a team spokesman said.

No Trace of Anti-Hollywood Bias in French Purchase of Universal
description: Even in a city that is used to being looked down on, there has been something particularly galling about the way the French have long regarded Hollywood. That makes it all the more provocative that the latest foreign company to buy a major movie studio has been Vivendi S.A., a French media giant.

title: Federal Law on Hate Crimes Is Scheduled for Vote in the Senate
description: Senators of both parties condemned crimes based on race, sex or sexual orientation as a dishonor to the nation today in an emotional prelude to a vote scheduled for Tuesday on creating a federal hate crimes statute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, LESTER
description: SCHWARTZ-Lester. Died on June 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Mara, devoted father of Ralph, Victoria, Ted, Nancy and brother of Martin. Adoring grandfather of Elana, Jonathan and Jack. A dedicated psychoanalyst, deeply devoted to his patients, family and friends. Services-The SAJ, 15 W. 86th St., June 20, 9:30 AM. Donations-The New York Psychoanalytic Institute.

title: Banknorth to Buy Insurer
description: Banknorth Group Inc., the largest bank by deposit share in Maine and New Hampshire, agreed today to buy the closely held Palmer Goodell Insurance Agency Inc. to sell more financial products to bank customers in Massachusetts. Palmer Goodell, based in Springfield, Mass., specializes in employee payroll deduction programs and disability management services for schools and nonprofit groups. It has annual revenue of more than $75 million. Terms were not disclosed. Peoples Heritage Financial Group Inc. acquired Banknorth, of Burlington, Vt., in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, PAULINE
description: ROSE-Pauline. Widow of Bennett Rose, devoted mother of Peter Rose, Judy and Michael Margulies, doting grandmother of Arthur and David Margulies and Jennifer Ginsberg, loving and adored aunt and friend, died in her 91st year. She was a role model for several generations of admirers. Always gracious and with impressive dignity and bearing, she expressed her caring quietly and in a nonjudgmental manner. She enriched everyone who knew her. Family, lifelong friends and strangers came away knowing they were touched by rare beauty and gentleness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLIAR, JOAN
description: STOLIAR-Joan. The Board of Directors of Theodore Gordon Flyfishers deeply mourns the passing of longtime Board member Joan Stoliar. Joan was the lightning rod and driving force behind TGF's Trout in the Classroom Program, which brought an awareness of the importance of a healthy aquatic environment to both New York City and New York State schoolchildren. Her guiding hand and generous heart will be missed by her schools of children and schools of fish. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband and champion, Arthur, and the entire Stoliar family. David Berman, President

title: How Germ-Phobia Can Lead to Illness
description: To listen to the manufacturers of an ever-growing list of germ-fighting products -- including antibacterial soaps and sprays, toothbrushes and toothpastes, pajamas and slippers, sheets and mattresses, potty chairs, high chairs, toys, sponges, cutting boards and even chopsticks and paper towels -- my family and I should have been riddled with disease all these many years.

title: Lazio Rebuts Mrs. Clinton With His Own Attack Ad
description: Three days after Hillary Rodham Clinton began running television advertisements critical of him, Representative Rick A. Lazio shot back yesterday with his own pointed advertisement, even as he promised to take the high road.

title: Senate Democrats to Introduce Plan for Medicare Drug Benefits
description: Five Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee, the panel responsible for Medicare legislation, plan to introduce a bill on Tuesday to establish prescription drug benefits for the elderly, even as senior Senate Republicans appear to be floundering in efforts to develop a proposal of their own.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN FUND IN AMERICAN DEAL
description: One of the biggest financial services companies in South Africa, Old Mutual P.L.C., reached an agreement to acquire the United Asset Management Corporation, a Boston-based fund manager, in a deal valued at nearly $1.5 billion. Old Mutual, which is based in London, will pay $25 a share for United Asset Management, which has $188 billion under management and caters to institutions, mutual funds and affluent private investors. Last month, Old Mutual completed its purchase of the Gerrard Group, a British fund management and specialty banking company, and the company says it still is in the market for more assets. Henri E. Cauvin

title: Study Sees Hard Future If Climate Keeps Heating
description: If global warming and its effects continue at present rates for the rest of the century, the tristate region around New York City will face much more frequent and more severe floods, more sickness and death from heat, and the loss of fragile marshes, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Riches Hidden in Plain Sight
description: When I was in graduate school, a friend who thought I needed to get out of the lab more often pointed out a newly arrived graduate student she thought I might find attractive. I remember saying, ''He looks like a bird.'' I did not mean this in a nice way.

title: CANADIAN OIL MERGER
description: The Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-Shing plans to create a large publicly owned company in the Canadian oil sector -- Husky Energy Inc. -- by merging the privately held Husky Oil Ltd. with Renaissance Energy Ltd., both of Calgary. Husky Oil will pay the equivalent of 19.40 Canadian dollars in cash and stock for each Renaissance share, a total of 2.8 billion Canadian dollars ($1.9 billion). Shareholders of Renaissance will own 35 percent of the new company and the current owners of Husky Oil will own 65 percent. The Li family owns 49 percent of Husky Oil directly and controls the remaining 51 percent. Timothy Pritchard

description: To give an idea just how perfect Valentino, the Roman designer, is, two people, both Americans who don't wish their names to be used, tell a similar story involving a hair dryer. Evidently, when Valentino and his business partner, Giancarlo Giammetti, were moored off Capri last summer in Valentino's 152-foot yacht, T. M. Blue One, there was a lot of coifing going on.

description: Dr. Ferrel Loki Osborn loves elephants. But he also loves the villagers of the Zambezi River Valley in northern Zimbabwe, whose fields of carefully tended corn, cotton and banana crops have long tempted elephants looking for a convenient midnight snack.

title: CONOCO TO BUY NORSK HYDRO GAS AND OIL PROPERTIES
description: Conoco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy assets in British waters of the North Sea of Norsk Hydro A.S.A. for $540 million to increase output at a time of rising oil and natural gas prices. The purchase will increase Conoco's British oil output by 30 percent. It also includes a stake in Britain's biggest gas field, stakes in seven other oil and gas fields, and more than 30 exploration licenses. Conoco is based in Houston. Norsk Hydro, Norway's largest publicly traded company, is selling the assets to focus on Angola and other promising deep-water exploration areas.

title: Inspired to the Heights of Whimsicality
description: ''The Orchid Show,'' a new suite of dances by Neta Pulvermacher, is clearly a way station on an exploratory journey from dark drama to lighter, more playful work. Performed by the Neta Dance Company on Friday night at the Kitchen, ''The Orchid Show'' takes the Israeli choreographer and her six immensely appealing dancers into the outer stratospheres of giddiness.

title: A Tory's Populism Turns Tables on Blair
description: There is a new smartness in the step of Britain's Conservative leader, William Hague, putting him in closer reach of the front-running Prime Minister Tony Blair and in distant sight of the previously unimaginable destination of 10 Downing Street.

title: Rechanneling The Flow Of Outrage
description: THE hideous sexual assaults in Central Park have been chewed over pretty thoroughly by now, but one aspect deserves a bit more attention. This is the reaction of leading black and Hispanic figures, who have stepped forward over the last week to denounce the park thugs and to demand that they be turned over to the police.

description: LAZARUS - Henrietta Creamer (Hindy). Sculptor, on June 19, 2000. Beloved wife of Leonard. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the National Association of Women Artists or the New York City Ballet.

title: HEALTHEON TO PAY MORE SHARES FOR MEDICAL MANAGER
description: The Healtheon/WebMD Corporation, the biggest Internet company linking doctors, patients and insurers, said yesterday that it had increased by 52 percent the number of shares it would exchange for the Medical Manager Corporation, the parent of a rival, CareInsite Inc., amid speculation the transaction could unravel. Healtheon shares have plunged 70 percent since it announced a $5.4 billion purchase of both companies Feb. 14, cutting the value to about $1.68 billion. The company will swap 2.5 shares, up from 1.65, for each share of Medical Manager, the largest maker of software used to run doctors' offices. Based on Friday's closing price, the transaction is now valued at about $2.26 billion. Medical Manager, based in Elmwood Park, N.J., rose $6.125, or 23 percent, to $33 in Nasdaq trading. CareInsite, also based in Elmwood Park, fell $3, or 15 percent, to $17.625. Healtheon, based in Atlanta, fell $2.3125, or 14 percent, to $14.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, MARJORIE
description: MAY-Marjorie. On June 18, 2000 at age 89. Beloved sister of Bettina May Barasch and Henry May. Dear aunt of Philip and Jonathan Holstein, Stephen Barasch, Bettina B. Plevan and Laurie Trippett. Service and interment private.

title: Nancy Marchand, 71, Player of Imperious Roles, Dies
description: Nancy Marchand, the distinguished character actress who excelled at playing wise and imperious authority figures -- newspaper publishers, queens, grande dames and a madam -- and who achieved perhaps her greatest fame as the domineering mother of a mob boss in the television series ''The Sopranos,'' died on Sunday at her home in Stratford, Conn., one day short of her 72nd birthday. She also had a home in Manhattan.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen rose after Yutaka Yamaguchi, the deputy governor of the Bank of Japan, suggested the bank was closer to raising interest rates. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.75 yen, down from 106.31.

title: Bush Raises Cash and Discusses Educational Technology
description: Gov. George W. Bush used part of a Western campaign swing today to discuss what modern technology could do for public education. But there was also a lesson in what that technology -- or at least its wealthy purveyors -- could do for Mr. Bush and fellow Republicans.

title: Unlikely Ally Ends Her Ties To Buchanan
description: One of the oddest couples in American politics have divorced.

title: Recalling a Vanished Hero, in Present Tense
description: ON sunny days, Mengistu Melesse, a sad-eyed stick figure of a man, drags a hose in front of the limestone town house at 20 East 65th Street, for him a vaunted house turned haunted house, and nourishes the conifers his vanished benefactor, Irene Silverman, planted in more positive times.

title: Putting Dietary Supplements to the Test
description: A chemist took a dozen pills from plastic sandwich bags, dissolved each in water, poured the solutions into tiny test tubes and placed them on a machine attached to the computer. A robotic arm then picked up each small vial and moved it into position, while an automatic needle drew out several drops of solution for the computer to analyze.

title: These Are Hard Times for Uranium Enrichment
description: Ever since Richard Nixon proposed it in 1968, policy makers have talked about having the federal government quit the business of enriching uranium for nuclear power plants. It took decades, but the Clinton administration finally completed the job two years ago, with Vice President Al Gore claiming it as a victory for reinventing government. It may, however, have come at the worst possible time.

title: Egan Installed; He Cites Hope To Be Teacher
description: Five weeks after bidding farewell to Cardinal John J. O'Connor, New York's rich and powerful returned to St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to see his successor, Edward M. Egan, installed as New York's ninth archbishop, in a ceremony that reflected many of the elements that would inevitably shape his tenure.

title: Foreign Affairs; Knight Is Right
description: Some things are true even though Phil Knight, the chairman of Nike, believes them.

title: Publicis Said To Be Ready To Buy Saatchi In Stock Deal
description: Publicis S.A., which last month lost out to the WPP Group in an effort to buy Young & Rubicam Inc., plans to buy Saatchi & Saatchi, the British agency company descended from the empire of the acquisitive Saatchi brothers, for at least $1.5 billion in stock, advertising executives close to the deal said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, HERBERT
description: WOLFF-Herbert. The entire staff of Canal Jean Co. mourns the loss of our dear friend and colleague. Herb was an invaluable leader at Canal Jean Co.for over 20 years. He was an outstanding retailer for over a half century, a source of knowledge and inspiration to all who worked with him, always offering understanding and guidance. Herb's door was always open. We will dearly miss you, Herb. You will never be replaced. Ira Russack, President and Canal Jean Co.'s Entire Staff and Friends

title: More Money for Debt Relief
description: Last year the United States and other industrialized countries pledged to provide $27 billion to reduce the foreign debt of 36 of the world's poorest nations, if those countries adopt sound economic policies and use the savings for health, education and other basic needs. Debt relief has bipartisan supporters, including humanitarian aid groups and religious conservatives. Washington pledged to pay only 4 percent of the wealthy nations' total, or $920 million over four years, with most of the money up front. But today in both the House and Senate, votes are scheduled that are likely to slash Washington's contribution to debt relief. This imperils the whole project, as several other nations will meet their commitments only if Washington meets its own.

title: New (Friendly) Craze in South Korea: The North
description: Suddenly, South Koreans are enthralled with all things North Korean.

title: Sound Ruling on School Prayer
description: The Supreme Court performs a valuable if sometimes under-appreciated public service when it rises above politics and popular opinion to prevent harmful erosion of the First Amendment's wall between church and state. Yesterday the court admirably fulfilled that mission in refusing to permit organized student-led prayers before public high school football games.

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Opinions on Prayer
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that public school districts may not allow students to lead organized prayer before football games. The vote in the case, Santa Fe Independent School District v. Doe, was 6 to 3. Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the majority opinion and was joined by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy, David H. Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the dissent and was joined by Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICKERSON, VIRGINIA MOFFAT
description: NICKERSON-Virginia Moffat. It is with great sadness that the Trustees, staff, and volunteers of The Children's Aid Society acknowledge the loss of its Trustee. A long-time member of the Society's board, Virginia Nickerson chaired the 1200 member Volunteer committee. In 1997 she was singled out by the Office of the Mayor as the Volunteer of the Year for New York City. We will miss her warmth and humor and the impact she has made on all of our lives, young and old. To her beloved husband, Adams, her children, Douglas, Emily, and William Bateson, and Rosina Bateson Barker; to her grandchildren, Maria Bateson, Hoyt Bateson, Farrar Cooper, Nathaniel Cooper, Taylor Barker and Eleanor Barker, and to her brother, Keith Moffat, we send our sympathy and condolences. Services will be held at 11 AM, Wednesday, June 21 at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. In lieu of flowers the family has asked that contributions be sent to The Children's Aid Society, 105 E. 22 St., NY, NY 10010. Edgar Koerner, Chairman Philip Colpoff, Executive Director

title: Tiger Makes Golfing History
description: You know things have changed in the decorous game of golf when spectators paint their faces in orange and black and hoot and holler as if they were watching the New York Jets. Of course there is always excitement in the gallery when Tiger Woods is playing, but Sunday at the U.S. Open at Pebble Beach was something special, mainly because Woods was something special. Crushing 350-yard drives, lofting wonderful recoveries from the rough, putting with supreme confidence, Woods won the U. S. Open with a 12-under-par 272 and a 15-stroke margin over his nearest competitor. This was the lowest score in relation to par in Open history, and the largest margin of victory in any of golf's four ''majors'' in the history of the game.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about ''children of Chernobyl'' visiting the United States for a summer of medical care and relaxation referred imprecisely to the number of deaths and illnesses caused by the accident at the nuclear plant in Ukraine in 1986. As was noted in a correction in this space on Saturday, referring to an article published on June 6, the Nuclear Energy Agency of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has said that 31 people died in the first weeks after the accident. Other estimates of deaths ultimately caused by it range from dozens to tens of thousands; estimates of illnesses range from hundreds to tens of thousands.

title: A Warning From Putin and Schroder

Ten years after victory in the cold war, the United States is still No. 1 by any conceivable measure. But the lesser actors -- Russia, Europe, China -- are beginning to make true what history and political theory have predicted all along: Great power will generate ''ganging up.'' Nos. 2, 3 and 4 will seek to balance against Mr. Big.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLE, THOMAS P.
description: BARTLE-Thomas P., Jr. The colleagues, employees and partner of Wesley, Brown & Bartle, Inc. deeply grieve the loss of our company President and co-worker, Thomas P. Bartle, Jr. His indomitable optimism, unflagging spirit of adventure, literary skills and business inventiveness are irreplaceable. His unrelenting embraciveness of workforce diversity in the executive search business leaves a major impact and creates a metric for all of us to meet. Most cherished of all, however, was his pursuit of a love and beauty of living. It is in this regard that we are left with a void and memories that will always live on. Tom, you touched our hearts in ways that go far beyond having been your coworkers. You had an ability to make all around you feel so special and part of your extended family. Your intellectuality, sense of humor, natural grace and social charm, a life buoyancy that will continue to carry us along on a tide and be forever a ''BARTS'' legacy. Wesley Poriotis, Partner, Wesley, Brown & Bartle, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, DR. HOWARD
description: ROSEN-Dr. Howard. We have lost a true giant amongst friends of Israel. Throughout her past wars and in times of peace, the soldiers of the Israel Defense Forces and the population of Israel have been blessed by the medical expertise, hands-on service and exceptionally kind heart of Dr. Howard Rosen. In all of his endeavors, both professionally and charitably, he gave his all. He considered his medical work for Israel his vacation and vocation. His efforts at teaching and operating at the medical center go back nearly three decades. Appreciative patients and admirers have long supported the Professor Howard Rosen, M.D. Orthopedic Institute at Shaare Zedek, which was named in his honor. His persistence and charm were responsible for arranging the donation of state-of-the-art orthopedic equipment to hospitals throughout Israel. We shall miss his presence (his moustache) and wonderful smile. Sincerest condolences to his wife Connie, daughters Terry, Aileen and the entire family. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERBILT, OLIVER DEGRAY
description: VANDERBILT-Oliver DeGray, of Jupiter Island, FL., 85, an industrialist and investment banker, died Tuesday, June 20, 2000. He had lived on Jupiter Island, Hobe Sound since 1983. Vanderbilt was active in the railway supply business until 1942 when he joined the U.S. Army during World War II. He saw service in England, North Africa and the E.T.O. and was honorably discharged as Major in 1945. After his return, he became President of Taylor-Wharton Iron & Steel Co. and was a charter member of the Young Presidents Organization (YPO). He also served as an officer and director of Harsco and Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corp. and was Trustee of Penn Mutual Life Insurance Co. before joining Blair & Co., a member firm of the N.Y.S.E. which he subsequently served as Chairman. While with Blair, Vanderbilt arranged the financing for the acquisition and merger of several industrial companies. Occasionally he acted as interim C.E.O. of such companies as Dorsey Trailers, Chattanooga Glass Co., etc. Vanderbilt formed and became C.E.O. of Capital Management Corp. a company heavily involved in the early days of equipment leasing. Such novel financing was very important in the initial development of new industries such as CATV. Most recently, Vanderbilt cofounded and served as the first Chairman of Seaboard Savings Bank, Stuart, FL. After graduating from St. Paul's School and Princeton Class of 1937, where he was a member of the Ivy Club, Vanderbilt married the former Frances Phillips. They spent their early years in Cincinnati, OH and later in Philadelphia, PA. He was a member of Maidstone Club, Seminole Golf Club, the Jupiter Island Club and the U.S. Seniors Golf Assoc. Survivors include his wife, Frances; a son, Oliver DeG. Vanderbilt, Jr. Molokai, Hawaii; a daughter, Madelon V. Peck, Altadena, CA; eight granchildren and eight great grandchildren. A memorial Service will be held at a later date at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter, Island. Burial will be in Christ Memorial Garden, Jupiter Island. title: Introduction
