But, unless you're a fisherman, the preparation of an imposing whole salmon or a red snapper is probably a relatively unfamiliar task and may well be an intimidating one, too. The irony is that, as scary as the prospect can seem, the process is relatively easy and involves a lot less fuss than you might imagine. Moreover, if ever there was a time of year to try poaching a whole fish (the subject for this lesson) or roasting one (next time) this is it. Served chilled or at room temperature it makes a wonderful warm-weather dish. Served hot it's great, too, of course -- any time of year.

In March, it agreed to buy Globetrotter for 11.2 million shares, but changed the terms because of accounting issues. The new deal will also include the assumption of Globetrotter's stock options. Globetrotter, which is based in San Jose, Calif., makes software that allows companies to license their software electronically. Macrovision develops technology that scrambles video to prevent unauthorized viewing of video stored on videocassettes or DVD players or broadcast by cable TV and pay-per-view providers.

Jackson, who died this year at 76, was a master at building sophisticated castles out of the blues. And though he was a peerless vibraphone player, his sense of narrative pacing and the clear statement may have come from his early experience as a gospel singer.

title: INDIA TO ELIMINATE POLLUTANT

The grant is part of an international agreement intended to preserve the earth's ozone layer. Chlorofluorocarbons were once widely used as refrigerants and propellants in aerosol products. India is the second-largest producer of them, after China. P. J. Anthony

Profit a year ago was $9.2 million, or 14 cents a share, on sales of $70.5 million. With sales of its older graphics design products in decline, Corel has tied its future to acceptance of the Linux operating system. The staff was cut 21 percent earlier this month to help trim costs by $40 million a year, and an equity financing has been arranged to shore up a cash position of less than $10 million. The chief executive, Michael Cowpland, said recently that Corel would be in the black by the fourth quarter. Timothy Pritchard

title: VIRATA TO ACQUIRE EXCESS BANDWIDTH FOR $315 MILLION
description: The Virata Corporation, which sells semiconductors and software to makers of digital subscriber line equipment, said it agreed to buy the closely held Excess Bandwidth Corporation of Cupertino, Calif., for about $315 million in stock. Virata also said it expected revenue of $25 million to $27 million for its first quarter, which ends on July 2, as shipments of communications processors have tripled in the last three months. Shares of Virata, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., rose $9.25, to $59.25 each, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. The acquisition is expected to make Virata more competitive in the fast-growing market for digital subscriber lines, which provide high-speed Internet service through traditional phone lines.

He was also a leader in sports medicine who was as dedicated to the care of professional athletes and dancers as he was to weekend athletes. A gifted teacher, Dr. Liebler took great joy in sharing his knowledge with young physicians. It was apparent to all those who knew him that Dr. Liebler loved his profession and, in the practice of it, exemplified its highest standards. The Lenox Hill Hospital family extends its deepest sympathies to his family. James S. Marcus, Chairman, Board of Trustees Gladys George, President & CEO Allen H. Newmont, which is based in Denver, said it believed Battle Mountain's Phoenix reserve was one of the best undeveloped gold properties in North America. The deal would also allow the companies to consolidate their Nevada properties. The purchase price represents a 25 percent premium over Battle Mountain's closing price of $1.938 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The stock was unchanged.

title: Similarity Breeds . . . Similarity
description: Pottery Barn, which brings high-priced design to the mass market, has done it again -- twice. The Paris Cubes, below, and the Bamboo Armoire, below right, available in August through stores and catalogs, are similar to other companies' designs. Coach, the New York City leather company, introduced the Manhattan Small Ottoman, above, in January last year and in May of last year, Interieurs, a Manhattan shop, brought out its bamboo armoire, right. Although Celia Tejada, vice president of product design at Pottery Barn, knew of Coach's and Interieurs' designs, she said, ''We were absolutely not influenced by Coach, and we were not inspired by Interieurs.'' The pieces merely extended the company's line of furniture, she said. Heidi Harvey, an intellectual property lawyer at Fish & Richardson, a Boston law firm, said, ''You can make designs that are similar, but you can't go so far as to confuse the public between the original high-end design, and the second, mass market design.'' How do they differ? A Pottery Barn Cube 19 1/2 by 19 1/2 by 17 1/2 inches in brown cow leather costs $399. Coach's Ottoman (18 by 18 by 15) starts at $990 and comes in seven leather treatments. Pottery Barn's mass-produced bamboo armoire (43 inches wide, 70 inches tall) is $1,450, Interieurs' handmade bamboo, maple and steel armoire (48 inches wide, 67 inches tall) is $10,970. Pottery Barn: (800) 922-5507. Coach: (800) 262-2411; Interieurs: (212) 343-2201. ELAINE LOUIE

description: James E. Goodwin, the chief executive of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, describes his proposed $4.3 billion purchase of US Airways as a ''win-win for consumers'' that will usher in a glorious new era of global air service.

title: City Dropping Managed Care For Its Jails After Disputes
description: Three years after the city brought managed care to its jails and gave one hospital a set fee to care for the roughly 17,000 inmates at the Rikers Island jail complex and the Manhattan Detention Center, the initiative has been quietly abandoned and the city appears set to return to the system it once derided as too costly and inefficient.

title: A Peculiar Piece From Denmark Morphs to Suit Many Needs
description: Quiz: The Phantom is a molded plastic 1. chair, 2. bench, 3. stool, 4. table. Answer: It's whatever you want it to be. It was one of the last designs by Verner Panton of Switzerland, who died in 1998. The lightweight molded plastic piece, produced in Denmark, was introduced in this country at last month's International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York. Meant to be flexible furniture for young people, it can be a seat for one person, turned upside-down to accommodate two or placed on its side and used as a table. Put a group of Phantoms together, and you have a sofa. The quirky Phantom is available in blue, black, orange, pink, white and purple and costs $375. At Totem, 71 Franklin Street (Broadway).

title: Ramos Shows MetroStars How Important He Can Be
description: Tab Ramos has been one of the most skillful American players in recent years but has been hampered by injuries for the last two seasons. The MetroStars suffered last year when Ramos was limited to five games, and finished with a record of 7-25, the worst in Major League Soccer.

title: Tighter Rules for 527 Groups
description: After an earlier setback, the drive to end the secrecy surrounding a pernicious form of campaign fund-raising is gaining in the House. Today a House subcommittee is to begin drafting a bill that could stop shadowy political slush funds from raising and spending undisclosed sums for campaign ads. A disclosure requirement for these groups, which have been created under Section 527 of the tax code, passed the Senate two weeks ago. It fell short in the House the next day because of promises that supporters of disclosure would get a chance to vote on an alternative later. The moment to cast such a vote has now arrived.

title: OPEC Raising Supply
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided to increase oil production limits by about 708,000 barrels a day, or 2.5 percent, beginning on July 1. The increase is slightly higher than expected, but analysts said it remained too modest to bring down gasoline prices that have reached more than $2 a gallon in some parts of the United States.

title: Guilty Plea Is Accepted In the Slaying Of 8 Women
description: A 28-year-old man admitted today that he strangled eight women here over two years, entering a guilty plea that will spare him the possibility of execution.

title: Botched in Boston: Yanks' Relievers Give None
description: It would not have mattered in the seventh inning tonight if the Yankees had Juan Gonzalez or Sammy Sosa or both. It would not have mattered if they had fielded nine superstars and recruited five future Hall of Famers to cheer them from the bench.

title: Knoblauch Sees Shift To D.H. as Therapy
description: Chuck Knoblauch tipped a plastic foam cup forward and allowed the coffee to slowly roll closer to the edge before easing the liquid back to the bottom. He did it again to challenge himself and never spilled one drop. Knoblauch did it because it was a competition. He devised the test so he could compete against himself and he won. You could tell Knoblauch expected to succeed.

title: Partners in a Translucent Alchemy of Color and Freedom
description: ''Alchemy,'' answered Stanislav Libensky. The question was how Mr. Libensky and his wife, Jaroslava Brychtova, arrive at the sublimely pure colors that define their work as glass artists, and it seemed an almost plausible explanation for the genius that has made them among the most respected artists in their medium today.

title: Decision Time on Gary Graham
description: We seldom comment two days in a row on the same subject, but the case of Gary Graham, who is scheduled to die by lethal injection at 6 p.m. today in Texas, merits concentrated attention. It has demonstrated to the nation the serious deficiencies in a capital punishment system that Gov. George W. Bush defended again yesterday as ''fair and just.'' Mr. Graham's situation has also exposed the timidity of both Governor Bush and his Democratic presidential opponent, Al Gore, in addressing the risks of wrongful execution of inmates who have been deprived of fair trials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTBADER, MORRIS S.

title: Rivals in the Race to Decode Human DNA Agree to Cooperate
description: After months of fitful negotiation that seemed to flame out in a final angry exchange in February, the two sides racing to decode the human DNA have contrived a last-minute truce. The first element of the resurrected pact is likely to be a joint announcement next week of the effective completion of the genome.

His loyalty, humor, gentleness and good sense will be forever missed. We love you and your memory will live with us forever.

description: The B train that derailed Tuesday night in downtown Brooklyn, injuring 95 passengers, was traveling along a route it did not usually take and was crossing back to its own tracks when its third car jumped off the rails, transit officials said yesterday.

description: IT is the little computer that won't. Die, that is. For years, the little Amiga, a machine regarded highly but not widely, has been considered all but extinct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONNER, MARILYN A.
description: BRONNER-Marilyn A. Zweck age 62, a resident of Vero Beach, Florida and summer resident of Dorset, Vermont for the past 11 years, died at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, NH following a courageous battle with cancer. Mrs. Zweck-Bronner was born in Westchester County, New York the daughter of Philip and Maryl (Browning). Lochner. Marilyn made her debut in 1955 at the Westchester Catillion. She received her early education at Greenwich Academy and continued at Wheaton College in Boston and Manhattanville College in Purchase, NY. Marilyn graduated with a master's degree from Loyola College in Baltimore, Maryland. She married Stanley ZweckBronner January 3, 1960 in Rye, NY. She is survived by her husband and her two sons, Michael and Stephen. A funeral mass will be held Friday June 23, at 1:00 pm at Saint Paul's Church in Manhchester, VT. For further information please contact the Brewster Funeral Service in Manchester Center, VT.

description: The Mets have held a lead in each of their last 17 games, but they have lost eight times in that span. Their defeats have been bitter -- a blown save, a missed chance to score, a wild throw -- and last night's may have been the worst.

title: Original Faberge, Again
description: In 1997, original stamping dies like the one above were found in a deserted warehouse in Estonia. The dies were for five patterns of luxurious sterling silver flatware designed by Peter Carl Faberge in St. Petersburg, Russia, at the end of the 19th century. Now, the flatware, originally designed for Alexandra, wife of Czar Nicholas II, for use in imperial Russian palaces, is being produced in Sweden in limited quantities. Because they are made from the original molds, the pieces are considered originals and not reproductions.

title: Report Says School Board Neglected Building Safety
description: A state commission investigating possible mismanagement in the New York City school system charged yesterday that the Board of Education has failed to conduct required annual safety inspections of the city's aging school buildings and has inordinately delayed the repair of hazardous conditions endangering students and teachers.

title: Moonlight Strolls (No Moon)
description: Coming next summer, a garden on Fifth Avenue near 78th Street that will be modern yet verdant, and will glow at night. Stan Allen, a Manhattan architect, and James Corner, a landscape architect in Philadelphia, won the French Embassy competition to design the garden next to the Cultural Services of the French Embassy. The winner: honey locust trees, a steel grate parquet floor and translucent fabric lanterns, all lighted from beneath. ''It's an urban garden with an artificial surface, because the floor is a counterpoint to the neo-Classical walls, and because there's no competing with Central Park,'' Mr. Allen said. The $150,000 garden will be used for embassy parties but will not be open to the public. ELAINE LOUIE

description: The chief prosecutor of the international war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia said today that she would not withdraw the indictment against Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav president, and that she opposed any action by Washington or other governments to let him escape justice.

title: Web Sites Make It Hard To Peddle Hot Renoirs
description: THE price was just too good to be true. When a man came into Lewis Bobrick's gallery in Denver recently trying to sell antique Navajo rugs for next to nothing, Mr. Bobrick worried that the rugs might be stolen. While the man waited in his store to see if there was a buyer for the unique rugs, Mr. Bobrick went to the Antique Tribal Art Dealers Association Web site (www.atada.org), where photographs and descriptions of stolen tribal artifacts can be posted.

title: Earnings Triple at Topps
description: The Topps Company, the maker of Bazooka bubble gum and baseball trading cards, said profit in its most recent quarter more than tripled as sales of products featuring the Nintendo Company's Pokemon video-game characters took off in Europe. Net income in the period, which ended on May 27, rose to $29 million, or 62 cents a share, from $9.3 million, or 20 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales surged 70 percent, to $144.3 million, with Pokemon-related items accounting for $75 million of that total.

title: Even in Charity Events, The Play Can Be Wicked
description: Since its inception in 1963 the most successful charity game in the world has taken place in New York City. This month it was played at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, Manhattan, and raised $84,000 for UJA-Federation, which supports Jewish charitable efforts in New York, Israel and around the world. The chief organizer was Marci Miron, with help from one of the founders, Tubby Stayman. The event was in memory of Alfred Rand, long a familiar bridge figure in New York, and was underwritten by his widow, Rita Rand.

title: ARGENTINE TELECOMMUNICATIONS INVESTMENT
description: The GTE Corporation plans to spend $450 million in Argentina's telecommunications market, pushing investment pledges by global companies to more than $4 billion. CTI Movil, GTE's Argentine wireless unit, plans to upgrade its service in the country's market, which is set to open to competition on Nov. 9. GTE's latest investment follows announcements that the AT&T, BellSouth and others will invest $3.6 billion over the next 18 months.

description: Opponents of the death penalty are focusing on Texas as they try to shift the debate about capital punishment from whether it is moral and effective to whether the trial-by-jury foundation of the American judicial system itself is flawed.

title: Energy Chief Is Questioned About Lapses
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson endured a bipartisan storm of criticism today over his handling of the latest security breach at Los Alamos National Laboratory, even as he assured Congress that investigators now believed that the mysterious case of nuclear lost and found at the laboratory was not a result of espionage.

description: After decades as one of the most ambitious songwriters alive, Ruben Blades continues to push himself. Unlike the current wave of Latin pop singers reaching for a Pan-American common denominator of dance and romance, Mr. Blades wants to reach both head and hips. His lyrics can be character studies, social comments or cinematic vignettes; his music combines elements from all over the hemisphere, seeking what he calls ''globalization without victims.''

title: ERNST & YOUNG SPINNING OFF INTERNET SECURITY PRACTICE
description: Ernst & Young, the world's third-largest accounting and consulting firm, said yesterday that it would spin off part of its Internet security practice into a separate company. The operation, ESecurityOnline.com, has been preparing to be spun off for the last six months. The service allows customers to assess their risk for current Internet security breaches and notifies them of new ones electronically. High-profile computer viruses like the ''Love Bug'' and ''Melissa'' that crippled some computer systems have led to an increased interest in antivirus and online security products.

title: Nets Have Questions, and Thorn Is Looking for Answers
description: Rod Thorn has been the president of the Nets for less than three weeks, but he has tried to cram in a year's worth of work before next Wednesday's draft. There are daily workouts with players who dream of becoming the top pick -- the Nets' pick. There is the search for a head coach. And there are the many question marks that litter the roster.

description: Richie Adubato, the Liberty coach, was musing about his team's poor shooting in the second half of its last several games.

title: George Bush's 60's Were Real, Too
description: In the spring of 1968, the same season in which George W. Bush graduated from Yale, the university's blue-collar workers went on strike. Similar strikes would shut down the school's dining halls later on, but not this time, thanks to students who crossed the picket lines to keep the kitchens cooking. Remember those students the next time somebody suggests that there was something odd about George W. Bush's noninvolvement in the student militancy of the 1960's.

title: Texas Instruments Is Paying $7.6 Billion for Chip Maker
description: Texas Instruments Inc., the semiconductor giant, said yesterday that it would acquire the Burr-Brown Corporation, which is also a computer chip maker, for $7.6 billion in stock.

description: Gazprom, Russia's biggest company, began a campaign of pressure today against the owner of the nation's largest independent media conglomerate, demanding that his company repay a large debt.

description: First Union Real Estate Equity and Mortgage Investments said it would sell the bulk of its assets to its former management team for $205 million in cash and assumed debt, moving closer to a full liquidation. The New York-based real estate investment trust will sell office buildings, parking garages, a mall and other assets for $79.9 million in cash and $125.1 million in assumed debt. The buyer is closely held Radiant Partners, a firm recently set up by the former president and chief executive, Daniel Friedman, and former executive vice presidents David Schonberger and Anne Zahner.

title: SWEDISH MERGER
description: Metso Oyj, a Finnish pulp and paper machine maker, agreed to buy Svedala Industri A.B. of Sweden for 13.7 billion kronor ($1.6 billion) in cash and assumed debt to become the biggest maker of mineral processing machines. Metso will pay 185 kronor a Svedala share and assume 4.6 billion kronor of debt. The combined entity will control more than a fifth of the world market for machines that process rock and minerals. The Finnish company is expanding its rock-crushing business to offset falling orders for pulp machines as paper makers like Stora Enso Oyj, Europe's largest, buy rivals instead of new equipment.

title: Cries of racism in the filming of a commercial ensnare Ford in actors' strike against ad agencies.
description: STUNG by accusations of racism for having used makeup to darken the face of a white stunt driver in the filming of a television commercial, the Ford Motor Company said late yesterday that it would postpone making new commercials until a nationwide strike by unionized actors against advertising agencies is resolved. Ford also said it would review its makeup policies.

The company was expected to earn 14 cents, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial.

She was the wife of James Daniel, retired Roving Editor of Reader's Digest and the last of 7 daughters of Eladio Teijeiro and Ramona Alvarez of New York and Santiago de Compostela, Spain. Born December 17, 1916 ''Nenita'' Teijeiro and her husband were graduated from the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill in 1937. Married April 15, 1939 they had daughters Jane Clare Daniel of Gloucester, Ma., mother of Liza Daniel Butler of Uxbridge, Ma., and James Daniel Nagy of Weston, CT; and Nina Ramona Daniel, mother of Daniel Allen Ritts and James Paul Ritts, all of Weston. title: SPANISH ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: Spain's economy grew a greater-than-expected 1.0 percent in the first quarter and the government revised growth higher for the three months that ended in December, with the gains fueled by a construction boom. Gross domestic product expanded 4.1 percent from a year ago, the fastest pace in almost two years, after a 3.9 percent pace in the fourth quarter, the National Statistics Agency said. The economy grew 1.1 percent in the three months, more than the 0.9 percent originally reported. Economists expected growth of 0.9 percent in the quarter and 3.9 percent in the year. Low interest rates and falling unemployment have encouraged Spanish consumers and companies to spend, making the economy the fastest growing among the four largest nations in the euro zone.

title: Shielding Tobacco From a Lawsuit
description: Republicans in the House are engaged in a brazen effort to protect the tobacco industry from a federal lawsuit. The House is expected to vote today on an appropriations bill with a provision that would make it practically impossible for the Justice Department to finance its lawsuit against the industry. If this provision survives, Congress will have allowed a powerful lobby to stop legitimate federal litigation simply because it has bought the allegiance of some members of Congress.

title: FORMER REDSKINS OWNER BUYS FLORIDA KEYS NEWSPAPERS

The price was not disclosed. Closely held Cooke Communications L.L.C., which was formed to make the purchase, will get The Key West Citizen, a 10,500-circulation daily, and six nondaily newspapers. Thomson has agreements to sell all but four of its United States daily newspapers for more than $2 billion. It also plans to sell five of its six Canadian papers by early next year. The Toronto-based company is focusing on Internet-related units, including First Call/Thomson Financial for financial data.

title: Vulnerability Shows Itself, If Briefly

Freed from the austere jazz settings she favors, Ms. Krall's sharply accented, blues-embellished piano relaxed into a minimalist pop mode, and her voice took on a startling dramatic intensity. Certain lines were punched out (''Constantly in the darkness/Where's that at?''), while other words and phrases (especially the word ''darling'') found her trailing off into a smoky whisper.

title: Editorial Observer; The 'Mississippification' of California Schools
description: California's public schools were among the most admired in the country until 20 years of disinvestment and teaching fads drove them into the ground. The decline announced itself dramatically in the mid-90's, when a succession of disastrous performances on national tests placed California's children at or near the bottom of the country in reading, math and science. The slippage has national implications, given that one in every nine public-school children in the United States is enrolled in California. The shock of dismal test scores has propelled the governor and the legislature into a frenzy of reform that has committed more than $7 billion and touched on every aspect of public education.

The Canadian Auto Workers union walked off the job at the strike deadline yesterday morning. title: FAMILY DOLLAR SAYS IT PLANS TO ADD UP TO 500 STORES
description: Family Dollar Stores said yesterday that it would add as many as 500 stores in the next fiscal year, increasing the pace of expansion as it shifts to selling more food and seasonal items. The company also said fiscal third-quarter net income rose 20 percent, to $50.13 million, or 29 cents a share, from $41.77 million, or 24 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 14 percent to $770.8 million in the quarter ended May 27. Family Dollar has been allocating more shelf space to items like food, household chemicals and paper products, as well as gifts and seasonal items, while reducing offerings of clothes and similar goods.

title: SETTLEMENT OF COMPUTER ASSOCIATES SUIT IS APPROVED
description: Computer Associates, a top software maker, won a judge's approval yesterday for a $234 million settlement with shareholders who contended that executives wrongly received more than $500 million in stock. Two shareholders sued the company in Delaware Chancery Court in 1998, contending that three executives should return 9.5 million of the 20.25 million shares they received in executive compensation. The suits contended that the awards exceeded the 1995 plan's limits and forced the company to take a $1 billion charge against earnings, causing the stock to plunge 31 percent in a day. A judge later ordered the executives to hand over the 9.5 million shares, but during appeal, company officials and lawyers agreed to settle the case for return of 4.5 million shares.

title: PEGASUS IS PAYING $100 MILLION FOR 12 DIRECTV AFFILIATES

The acquisitions let Pegasus expand in Texas, the upper Midwest and central Plains. The rural affiliates serve about 52,000 DirecTV subscribers. After the acquisitions, Pegasus, based in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., will have 1.2 million customers for the DirecTV satellite service, which is owned by the Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors. Patrick Fuhrmann, an analyst at C. E. Unterberg Towbin, said the agreement ''brings Pegasus a small step closer to being acquired by Hughes.''

title: FERRO SAYS IT IS ACQUIRING CHEMICALS UNIT FROM SOLUTIA
description: The Ferro Corporation, a chemicals maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a chemicals unit from a rival, Solutia Inc. Ferro said the unit, which makes additives for sealants and caulks, would complement its leading position as a maker of plastics additives. The unit's additives are also used in flooring, wall coverings and adhesives. Ferro will acquire Solutia's Delaware River plant in Bridgeport, N.J., and manufacturing units in Antwerp, Belgium, and Newport, Wales. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. Solutia said it was selling the unit to focus on its other businesses, like nylon used in carpet. The company said the additives unit had 1999 sales of $140 million.

title: A Pioneer in a Man's World, She Was Tough Enough
description: Give people a picture or two with the news, and they'll come crying for more. When Joseph Pulitzer bought the faltering New York World in 1882, he planned to increase circulation by inserting sensational woodcuts, then gradually decreasing their number to restore the paper to dignity. A trade journal condemned the new images as pandering to low interests and predicted they would persuade people that ''a newspaperman has no conscience, and that when he enters the house it is a good time to lock up the spoons.'' But readers would not give them up. When Pulitzer began to weed out the woodcuts, circulation plummeted until he gave the public what it wanted once again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLE, PHYLLIS L.
description: FOWLE-Phyllis L. Propp, 92, a retired lawyer and lieutenant-colonel in the Army Reserve, died June 22. In 1944 she was the first woman officer in the Army Judge Advocate's Generals Corps. The JAG cited her for this in April 1999 at a banquet at its school in Charlottesville, VA at which she was guest of honor. Later that year, the American Bar Association's Commission on Women in the Profession awarded her its Trailblazer certificate. She was born in Laurel, IA on the farm of her father, Henry J. Propp and his second wife Martha Knoble Propp. She grew up in nearby Marshalltown where she graduated from its high school. She graduated in 1930 from the University of Iowa and received her J.D. from its law college in 1933. After practicing in Mason City, she entered the Federal civil service in the regional office of the Farm Credit Admistration in Omaha, and later at the Federal Land Bank. Active in democratic politics, Miss Propp also served on the board of the Omaha Urban League. When Congress established what became the Women's Army Corps in May 1942, she was an original volunteer. She was commissioned after completing its OTC course at Fort Des Moines to which she returned early in 1944 as a captain and Post Judge Advocate and was formally detailed in the JAG in May 1944. In January 1945 she was assigned to the JAG office at General Dwight D. Eisenhower's European Command in Paris. Shortly after the German surrender, she was promoted to major and moved with the headquarters to Frankfurt, Germany and later to Heidelberg. In 1947 she left active duty as a lieutenant-colonel but continued the same work heading the civil affairs section as a civilian. She resigned from this post in the summer of 1951. In November she was married to Farnsworth Fowle, then a New York Times correspondent in Germany. After a year in London, they returned to the United States and settled in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Continuing in the Army Reserve, Mrs. Fowle was admitted on motion to the New York Bar and established a solo law practice in midtown Manhattan. She served on the Bronx and city boards of the YWCA. She was a past president of the former Riverdale Committee on Intergroup Relations, the local chapter of the United Nations Association and the Villa Charlotte Bronte cooperative. Survivors include her husband; her nieces Charlotte Gaden of Waterloo, IA, Grace Bluck of Preston, MN, Esther Schmidt of Newton, IA, Phyllis Gaddis of Portland, OR and Marjorie Tuomi of Clatskanie, OR and two nephews Myron Lorenzen of Waterloo, and David Bollhoefer of Newton. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts are suggested to Christ Church Riverdale, 5030 Henry Hudson Parkway, NY 10471 or the Iowa College of Law Foundation, PO Box 4550, Iowa City, IA 52244 or other good causes. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church on Tuesday at 1:30PM. Her ashes will be buried in Thetford, VT. after a service there later this summer.

description: ''Twelfth Night'' is something of a community affair in the version mounted by the Gorilla Repertory Theater in Fort Tryon Park. This is the second year that Gorilla, a late-summer fixture in Washington Square Park, is taking its free Shakespeare to this spectacular setting almost at the northern tip of Manhattan. The company presents ''Macbeth'' on Thursdays and Saturdays at 8 p.m. and ''Twelfth Night'' on Fridays and Sundays, also at 8.

Although the Alumni and Friends of La Guardia Inc. is allowed to use an office inside the school, it is a separate tax-exempt organization that is independent of the school, and donations it receives go to the organization, not to the Board of Education.

title: CASTLE & COOKE'S CHIEF AGREES TO RAISE BID FOR COMPANY
description: David H. Murdock, the chief executive of Castle & Cooke, has agreed to increase his bid for the company, Hawaii's largest real estate developer, to settle shareholder lawsuits in a transaction that values the company at $615 million. Mr. Murdock, Castle & Cooke's largest shareholder and the chief executive of the Dole Food Company, increased his per-share offer by 4 percent, to $19.25, from a bid of $18.50 on May 22 under a tentative settlement. The transaction value includes the assumption of debt. The settlement is subject to court approval. The company did not say why it was being sued. Murdock owns 26.4 percent of Castle & Cooke's shares through his Flexi-Van Leasing Inc. of Kenilworth, N.J. He originally bid $17 a share March 30.

title: Bankrolling Colombia's War on Drugs: House and Senate Will Now Reconcile Bills
description: Nearly a year after President Andres Pastrana of Colombia asked the United States for emergency aid to battle narcotics traffickers and their rebel allies, the Senate cleared the way today for a package of $1.3 billion.

title: Once Dismissed as a Force, Nader Rocks Gore's Boat
description: Months after they dismissed Ralph Nader as a fringe third-party candidate who would fade quickly, Democratic and Republican strategists now say that he has emerged as more politically potent than Patrick J. Buchanan and could deeply complicate the candidacy of Vice President Al Gore.

title: Metro Business; Power Plant for L.I.
description: The company that owns Pennsylvania's second-largest electric utility said yesterday that it planned to build a $300 million power plant on Long Island, where power prices are among the highest in the nation.

title: Accounts
description: UPromise Inc., Brookline, Mass., which is planning to offer an Internet rewards program, to the McCann-Erickson World Group, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as its first marketing communications agency, handling duties like advertising and promotion. Billings were estimated at $30 million to $40 million.

title: A Grant for Green Delivery Trucks
description: THE Internet economy may allow consumers to leave their cars in the driveway as they shop online, but every time they point and click to buy something, a delivery truck will come to their door, adding to pollution on its way.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COMMODITY PRICES SOAR. A rally in energy markets has led to soaring commodity prices. The Commodity Research Bureau/Bridge Index rose 2.04 points, to 227.08, the highest level since April 1998.

title: She Stands Tall for Architectural Integrity
description: AS chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, Jennifer J. Raab cuts skyscrapers, and even arrogant moguls of the real estate rat race, down to size. Neighborhood character, architectural integrity: tamper with them and you answer to her; honor them and she's a friend forever.

title: SINCLAIR TO SELL 6 STATIONS TO EMMIS, SETTLING LAWSUIT
description: Sinclair Broadcast Group agreed yesterday to sell six radio stations in St. Louis to Emmis Communications for $220 million, settling a lawsuit filed by Sinclair in January. The suit challenged the right of Emmis, based in Indianapolis, to buy the radio stations and Sinclair's television station in St. Louis. Barry Baker, Sinclair's former head of television and radio, sold the option to acquire the properties to Emmis last year. Sinclair had also sued Mr. Baker, who resigned as president and chief operating officer of USA Networks yesterday. Sinclair, based in Baltimore, will keep the St. Louis television station, KDNL-TV, one of 61 it owns or programs.

title: Unrelenting Taste Test
description: In Peter and Bobby Farrelly's ''Me, Myself and Irene,'' Jim Carrey, left, uses his rubberized body and latex fright-mask face to play a Rhode Island state trooper in the throes of ''advanced hallucinatory schizophrenia,'' ''involuntary narcissistic rage'' and love.

Husband Is Convicted, But Jeanine Pirro Is Topic
description: She came to Albert J. Pirro Jr.'s tax fraud trial, nudging him to fix his tie and shaking her head when he got too friendly with the reporters. Even as embarrassing details spilled out about his illegitimate child and their lavish lifestyle, she remained at his side.

description: The independent counsel will seek no charges against Hillary Rodham Clinton in the firing of seven White House employees, but he said evidence suggested her role was greater than she acknowledged. Page A14.

title: FISHER SCIENTIFIC IN $840 MILLION DEAL FOR PSS
description: Fisher Scientific International, one of the largest sellers of laboratory equipment from test tubes to microscopes, agreed yesterday to buy PSS World Medical for $840 million in stock to expand sales of medical products. Fisher will also assume about $260 million in PSS debt. PSS shareholders will receive 0.3121 Fisher shares for each of theirs. That values PSS shares at $11.86 each, or 20 percent above Wednesday's closing. The transaction will add 150,000 PSS customers, including doctors, hospitals and nursing homes, and make Fisher one of the top three medical suppliers in the nation, the company said.

title: With Relations Warming, Albright Presses China on Taiwan
description: More than a year after the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Serbia, the United States and China officially declared today during a visit by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright that the interlude of bitterness had given way to an era of improved relations.

description: Pseudo Programs Inc., which bills itself as an online TV network, laid off about a quarter of its staff yesterday, continuing a trend in the Internet industry that began with April's stock market gyrations.

title: Big Inning Gives Jones More Than He Needs
description: The choice was obvious but not easy. Bobby J. Jones had seven years in the major leagues and the pride that goes with it. But the Mets' right-hander was pitching poorly, and because of off-days in the schedule, the plan was to skip him for two turns through the rotation. The Mets wanted Jones to go to Class AAA Norfolk for a while, to stay sharp and, just maybe, rediscover something. Jones had enough major league service time to veto the demotion, but he accepted it and is glad he did.

He cleared enough space beneath the salary cap to acquire the game's most dominant center, shrewdly maneuvered a draft-day deal to sign a prodigy out of high school and, to top it all off, helped woo the league's most successful coach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSWICK, RUTH EDITH
description: ROSWICK-Ruth Edith. Passed away June 22. Beloved mother of Diana Burr and Janis Menken, grandmother of Anna, Nora, Jeremy and Kenny. Mother-in-law of Jamie and Alan. She will live in our hearts forever. Funeral service will be Sunday, June 25 promptly at 12 noon at Clark Associates Funeral Home in Katonah.

description: GROSSINGER-Irwin. The Board of Governors & Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Irwin Grossinger. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Sharon, and their family. Richard Bornstein, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: Paul Bartel Memorial
description: A tribute to the filmmaker Paul Bartel is to be held on Wednesday at 10:30 a.m. at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. Among those who are to take part in the event, which is open to the public, are Bob Balaban, Amanda Plummer, Jim Jarmusch, Laurence Luckinbill and Marshall Efron. Mr. Bartel, whose films include ''Eating Raoul,'' died on May 13 at 61.

He was a model to children in his respect for them and in his outstanding basketball ability. He brought light and happiness to all. May he rest in peace. description: This is a 15-second commercial that Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign began broadcasting yesterday in upstate New York.

title: Churchill Downs Is Adding Arlington Park to Its Stable
description: Churchill Downs, home of the Kentucky Derby, continued its aggressive strategy of buying racetracks yesterday when it signed an agreement to acquire Arlington Park near Chicago for stock worth more than $71 million.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen surged to a two-month high then swiftly retreated ahead of Japanese elections on Sunday and on fears the Bank of Japan would raise rates. In New York, the yen weakened to 104.62 per dollar, from 104.44.

title: New Evidence in a Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: A former official of the Central Intelligence Agency has provided fresh evidence to support accusations that a top Democratic Party official sought to enlist the agency to aid a major donor to President Clinton's 1996 re-election campaign.

title: Safety Board Still Studying Kennedy Crash
description: Investigators at the National Transportation Safety Board writing a report about the crash that killed John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife and his sister-in-law last summer have not found a mechanical problem with his plane, but the staff has yet to reach a conclusion about the crash, according to people at the agency.

title: GROWING UP, GROWING APART
description: It happens in the confusions of adolescence and the yearning for identity: Black children and white children who were fast friends move into separate worlds. How Race Is Lived in America: the ninth article of a series.

title: An Unknown Lifts the Yanks, but Rivera Lets Them Down
description: The Yankees were pummeled last week by the Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadium. The two-time defending World Series champions lost four games in their backyard in emphatic fashion and trudged around like shadows of their former selves. They were also ornery about losing two games to the Boston Red Sox this week and splitting a pivotal series they could have swept.

title: Los Angeles City Council Approves $4 Million to Bail Out a Host Group
description: By a one-vote majority, the Los Angeles City Council approved $4 million today to bail out the local host committee for the Democratic National Convention here, assuring enough cash to begin building the stage at the Staples Center next month and avoiding a big political embarrassment for Mayor Richard J. Riordan.

title: Pirros' Neighbors Pour Out Sympathy for One
description: Above the cash register at a dingy doughnut shop on Halstead Avenue here hangs a letter from Jeanine F. Pirro, thanking the proprietor for a $100 donation to the Westchester County Alliance Against Crime.

title: Where the Complexity of Cultures Meets Nature's Simplicity
description: In his most famous essay, written almost 30 years ago, the anthropologist Clifford Geertz dissected the ritual of a Balinese cockfight. In preparation for the fight, men would groom choice roosters, nurture them and coddle them. A villager would suggestively sit with a bird between his thighs, ''bouncing it gently up and down to strengthen its legs.'' And when the time came, a master craftsman would fit the bird's legs with razor-sharp spurs and send it into a 50-foot square ring, to slash another similarly equipped cock, while village men bet on which bird would slaughter the other. The owner of the winner would eat the loser.

title: Dummy Became an Island, And a Slam Sank Helplessly
description: A lead that might be the most devastating of the year contributed to a result that might be the most surprising of the year. It occurred in January at the Tri-State Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y., and the event was a bracketed knockout teams, in which the best teams, based on masterpoint holdings, form the top bracket.

title: Editorial Observer; In Korea, an Embrace That Shook the World
description: Tomorrow marks the 50th anniversary of the start of the Korean War. As all schoolchildren in North Korea know, the war began when South Korea invaded its peaceful neighbor to the north. Since then the government in Seoul has remained enslaved to a clique of generals, spies and capitalists who are puppets of the United States.

title: Generation Gap Threatens Ruling Zimbabwe Party
description: The old heroes sing liberation songs and predict an overwhelming victory for President Robert Mugabe and his ruling party. But one of the party's youth leaders smells trouble as he campaigns in poor villages.

title: Religion Journal; A Puritan Judge's Antislavery Voice
description: If Judge Samuel Sewall, a prominent and pious Bostonian of Puritan times, is remembered for much these days, it is the literary and historical value of the diaries he kept and his repentance for his role in the Salem witchcraft trials.

title: To Some an Eyesore, To Others a Home
description: Woody Allen has won and New Yorkers have lost. The filmmaker led a celebrity-studded opposition to a 17-story apartment tower at 91st Street and Madison Avenue in Manhattan, even creating a video to depict its alleged horrors. Last week the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission obliged him by rejecting plans for the tower.

title: Songs of Innocence and Experience (and Screaming)
description: In the role of band leader, the drummer Brian Blade works with two useful aesthetic tools: innocence and experience. His compositions, some of which use parallel chords and open harmonies that make them sound as if they're written on the guitar, stand apart from mainstream jazz -- the field in which Mr. Blade began his career behind musicians like Joshua Redman and Kenny Garrett. As heard on his new record, ''Perceptual'' (Blue Note/ EMI), they're hymnlike semi-pop tunes with improvisation, using dreamy drones and sentimental themes recalling the work John Coltrane produced out of his religious conviction.

title: Wrestler Two Victories From Dream
description: Terry Brands was scaling a fence four years ago this June, desperate to escape his humiliation, manic to leave his defeat on the other side and be alone with his misery in the mountains outside of Spokane, Wash.

title: Polls Show Virtual Tie in the Crucial Presidential Race in Mexico
description: Public opinion surveys show the two leading presidential candidates in a virtual tie before the election on July 2, with as many as one-fourth of the voters undecided.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Monday about a study released by Time Inc. on pharmaceutical ads misstated the percentage of consumers who said they had been deterred from taking a drug by information provided about side effects. Of the respondents who saw medication ads on television and said they would avoid a particular drug as a result, 61 percent said the reason was information on side effects. Of those who saw medication ads in magazines and said they would do so, 38 percent attributed their reluctance to information on side effects.

title: Legislators Approve Web List Disclosing Missteps by Doctors
description: The State Legislature voted yesterday to notify the public about malpractice judgments and disciplinary actions against doctors practicing in New York State. The information would be posted on the Internet and available through a toll-free telephone number.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on June 13 about the book ''Nuestros Cuerpos, Nuestras Vidas,'' a Latina version of the women's health book ''Our Bodies, Ourselves'' imprecisely characterized comments by Dr. Jane L. Delgado, president and chief executive of the National Alliance for Hispanic Health, a nonprofit network of Hispanic health providers. Dr. Delgado said that in saying that a book's acceptance should be helped by paying respect to the cultural cornerstones of faith and family, she was referring to her own book, ''Sa-lud!''a guide to health for Hispanic women, not to ''Nuestros Cuerpos, Nuestras Vidas.''

title: VITRISEAL, CORROSION PROTECTOR MAKER, ADDING DISTECH
description: VitriSeal Inc., which makes products that protect against metal corrosion, said yesterday that it would buy Distech Ltd. of New Zealand for about $54.7 million in stock. VitriSeal said it would issue 16.2 million common shares for the closely held Distech, which makes water-purification equipment for car washes. VitriSeal, based in Draper, Utah, said Distech's V-Still equipment recycles and purifies water for commercial uses. In January, VitriSeal agreed to buy the closely held Thermoflow Corporation, whose equipment recycles antifreeze, and the Liquitek Corporation, which uses Thermoflow's technology to clean waste water, for $86.4 million in stock.

title: Barkley Relieved Only Draft Remains
description: Sitting before a group of fans yesterday at the NBA Store on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, Erick Barkley was relaxed. The troubles of the National Collegiate Athletic Association were behind him and so was a grueling week of workouts, flying from one city to another, finishing with a session with the Knicks yesterday.

title: Questions for Mrs. Pirro
description: ''I still believe in the process and the system,'' Jeanine Pirro declared on Thursday, professing her hope that future appeals would overturn the conspiracy and tax evasion conviction a federal jury had just delivered against her husband, Albert Pirro Jr. Mrs. Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney, was speaking as the loyal spouse, who appeared almost every day during the four-week trial of her husband, an influential real estate lawyer and Republican fund-raiser.

title: Japan's Leading Wireless Company May Seek Foothold in Britain
description: NTT DoCoMo Inc., Japan's leading wireless communications company, dropped hints today that it might soon establish a presence in Britain, a lucrative mobile phone market that would significantly add to DoCoMo's increasingly fast-paced international expansion.

title: In Expansion Draft, Devils Emerge With a Gain of One
description: Neither the Rangers, the Devils nor the Islanders lost any significant players today when the two expansion teams, the Columbus Blue Jackets and the Minnesota Wild, each drafted 26 veterans as they joined the National Hockey League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLEW, THERESA. (NEE WALSH)
description: BELLEW-Theresa. (nee Walsh) Of Pearl River, NY, on June 23, 2000. Former school teacher at Marymount, Fifth Ave. She is survived by her husband, Patrick W. Bellew of Pearl River, her sister, Sister Claire of the Felician Sisters of Lodi, NJ and aunt, Ella Behan of North Arlington, NJ. Visiting will be held Saturday and Sunday 3:005:00 and 7:00-9:00 at the WymanFisher Funeral Home, Inc., Pearl River, NY. Mass of Christian burial to be held Monday, 10:00 AM at St. Aedan RC Church in Pearl River. Burial to follow, St. Anthony's Cemetery, Nanuet, New York.

title: HAGEMEYER, DUTCH WHOLESALER, BIDS FOR CAMERON
description: Hagemeyer N.V. said it is bidding for the Cameron & Barkley Company as Hagemeyer, a Dutch wholesaler, continues to bolster its equipment-distribution business through purchases. Hagemeyer will pay an undisclosed cash sum for Cameron & Barkley, based in Charleston, S.C. The company is an industrial equipment distributor and has annual sales of $850 million. Cameron & Barkley is Hagemeyer's third United States acquisition in seven months. The company bought the Houston-based Vallen Corporation, which has sales of $450 million, for $201 million and Tristate Electrical and Electronics Supply Company of Hagerstown, Md., with sales of $200 million, for an undisclosed amount in November.

title: Gore Raises Millions for 2000 While an Inquiry Takes Him Back to 1996
description: Within hours of ordering his lawyers to release the transcript of his interview into his 1996 fund-raising activities, Vice President Al Gore was back to business as usual today -- trolling for money.

title: Lazio Camp Maintains Focus During Rocky Week
description: After spending five minutes at a press briefing following a breakfast with business leaders at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, Representative Rick A. Lazio bolted down 15 flights of stairs and into an elevator, a gaggle of reporters in pursuit.

title: After an Attack, Chinese Won't Print Expatriate's Novel
description: A major Chinese publisher has canceled its plans to translate and publish the celebrated novel ''Waiting,'' by the Chinese-born emigre Ha Jin, after a harsh attack in a literary review here denouncing the book as an attempt to portray China as backward and repressive.

title: IRON ORE TAKEOVER FIGHT
description: Opening a possible bidding war, Rio Tinto P.L.C., one of the world's leading iron ore producers, made a $1.67 billion hostile offer for North Ltd., an Australian rival in which it already holds a 14.5 percent stake. Rio Tinto offered 3.80 Australian dollars, or $2.26, a share in cash, but North's stock shot up 33 percent, to 3.92 Australian dollars, indicating that investors are anticipating further bids from companies like Anglo American P.L.C., Billiton P.L.C. or WMC Ltd. North called the Rio Tinto offer inadequate. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Witnesses in the Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Arbitrator's Ruling Roils Team Executives at Entry Draft
description: On the eve of the entry draft for amateurs, the focus today was on a significant arbitration decision that cost the Devils a former first-round draft choice but added to their stash of picks on Saturday.

title: The Times Plans a Children's Best-Seller List
description: The New York Times Book Review will print a separate best-seller list for children's books starting on July 23. The change is largely in response to the expected demand for the fourth in the Harry Potter series of children's books, editors at the Book Review said.

title: A Growing High School Trend: Opting to Take an Extra Year
description: The prom was last month, graduation was the second Saturday in June, and Geoff Blumenfeld is now officially finished with Granite Bay High School, outside Sacramento. But next fall, when his classmates start college, he will come East for another year of high school -- a ''post-graduate'' year at Northfield Mount Hermon, a boarding school in Massachusetts.

title: Of Prayer and Coercion
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing Drugs as a Choice Or as a Brain Anomaly
description: Dr. Alan I. Leshner, the director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, a division of the National Institutes of Health, is known for his slide shows. Two or three times a week he gives a speech -- to treatment counselors and prevention specialists, physicians and policymakers -- and almost all feature slides culled from the work of the 1,200 researchers supported by his institute. The slides are of brain scans, and they usually come in pairs. The ''before'' slides show the activity of a normal brain; the ''after'' ones depict a brain that has had prolonged exposure to drugs. Lacing his presentation with jokes and Yiddish expressions -- as a youth, Dr. Leshner summered at a Catskills hotel owned by his grandparents, and he has a bit of Alan King in him -- he tries to translate the science into plain English.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRYNIN, EVELYN J.
description: TRYNIN-Evelyn J. On June 22, 2000 at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Adored mother of Margot Aronsohn, Janet and James Stovin. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. She was loved by all who knew her. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday at 10AM. Interment at Knollwood Cemetery.

title: ALANTRO COMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO A $300 MILLION DEAL
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held chip maker Alantro Communications for $300 million in stock. Alantro, based in Santa Rosa, Calif., makes semiconductors for wireless networks that let multiple computers or other devices link to the Internet through one high-speed connection. The products work in tandem with Texas Instruments' digital-signal processors, the crucial chips in fast Internet connections like cable modems and digital subscriber lines. The acquisition builds on Texas Instruments' purchase of Butterfly VLSI Ltd. of Israel in January 1999. Butterfly makes chips that let cell phones, computers and digital cameras interact with one another.

title: On Trade, Cuba Is Not China
description: Some lawmakers, including a number of Republicans, have argued in recent weeks that if Congress believes trade will promote democratic change in China, then why not adopt the same policy for Cuba? Here is why: Cuba is not China.

title: Motorman Tests Positive For Cocaine
description: The motorman who was driving the subway train that derailed in Brooklyn Tuesday night, injuring 95 people, tested positive for cocaine shortly after the accident, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Maker Says Gulfstream Jet Orders Are Up
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said second-quarter orders for its Gulfstream business jetliners rose to their highest level in the last five quarters.

title: AT&T Revises Its Plan
description: AT&T submitted a proposal that would allow customers to save money on some long-distance calls, but would raise rates for other calls. Consumer groups praised the plan's flexibility but were unhappy with price increases that will affect tens of millions of customers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIEBLER, WILLIAM AMEND, MD.
description: LIEBLER-William Amend, MD. A memorial service commemorating the life of Dr. William A. Liebler, who died Monday June 19, will be held on Monday, June 26 at 11AM at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave, New York. Those wishing to make donations in Dr. Liebler's name may do so in C/O The National Dance Institute, 594 Broadway, Rm 805, NYC 10012 and Lake Champlain Maritime Museum, 4472 Basin Harbor Rd., Vergennes, VT 05491.

title: Analysts Talk and Amazon.com Shares Reel
description: Shares of Amazon.com, the Internet industry's bellwether stock, plummeted 19 percent in heavy trading yesterday as investors grew nervous about the company's financial health and its prospects for profitability. Other Internet companies were sucked into the downdraft; shares of eBay fell 7.4 percent and America Online lost 5.3 percent of its value.

title: Shots Fired at TV Reporter in Mexico
description: Three men in dark suits fired high-caliber weapons at a television reporter's car and at a second car with two bodyguards on Thursday night, the police said.

title: New Jersey Legislators Preview Budget That Has Yet to Appear
description: The State Constitution required that it be released by this week, and the chairman of the Assembly Budget Committee had promised it for today, but New Jersey's budget for the coming fiscal year will not make an appearance until Monday at the earliest, legislative officials said today.

title: 3 Men Are Fatally Shot Within 8 Hours
description: Three young men were fatally shot yesterday in unrelated homicides in New York, the police said.

title: CHINA TOUGHENS TALK ON W.T.O. ENTRY
description: A top Chinese trade negotiator warned that his country would not make any more concessions to open up markets for goods and services in its bid to join the World Trade Organization. The negotiator, Long Yongtu, said some countries had raised ''unreasonable requests,'' apparently referring to an insistence by developing countries that they receive the same trade privileges that China had negotiated with the European Union and the United States. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: After Defeat, Campaigner for 'Free Burma' Begins Anew
description: SO sanguine is Simon Billenness that he seems not the least bit downcast by this week's United States Supreme Court decision overturning the Massachusetts ''Burma Law,'' which he co-wrote.

title: Con Ed Memo Cites Flaws in Handling Radiation Leak
description: In the crucial minutes after a radiation leak, emergency workers at the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant were hampered by equipment failures, inadequate training and a general disorderliness that could have been prevented, according to a recent memorandum from the plant's owner, Consolidated Edison.

description: No Rehearing in Boy's Case

description: ''I have admitted that I have made mistakes in fund-raising. But I want the American people to know that I have always told the truth on this matter.''

description: Lou Savarese believes there are two ways to defeat Mike Tyson.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Post Rise of 1.8% on Big Board
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange rose 1.8 percent in the most recent monthly period, the stock exchange reported this week.

title: Sounding Out the History Of Black American Music
description: David Hidalgo, half of the blues-guitar duo Houndog, looked defeated. Finishing a tepid version of Big Bill Broonzy's ''It Was Just a Dream,'' he appealed to his Carnegie Hall audience on Thursday night: ''It's kind of hard . . . we're asked to represent giants, and we're just a couple of midgets.''

Loving father of Megan McGoldrick Donahue, Laura Preisser Grozier, Claire Preisser and grandfather of five. Dear brother of Maryellen McGoldrick Schwarz and her husband Carl. The family will receive friends at Westchester Funeral Home, Inc in Eastchester, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, June 26, 9:45 AM at Immaculate Conception Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, Long Island, NY.

Bernstein & Company by Alliance Capital Management misstated the amount paid in another recent deal between money management firms. Last week, Nvest agreed to be acquired by CDC Asset Management for $1.9 billion, not $700 million.

description: For about the 200th time this year, Dana Quigley played a round of golf today.

description: He was a Vietnam veteran from Arkansas who was moved by the story of a little-known heroine and victim of the Holocaust. So Fletcher Clement decided that a racehorse should bear the name of Roza Robota, a young Polish woman who was instrumental in a brief uprising at Auschwitz.

description: The shareholders of both America Online and Time Warner voted yesterday to approve the merger of the companies into the world's largest media conglomerate.

title: Pentagon Sees China's Forces as No Foreseeable Threat to U.S.
description: China is modernizing its armed forces to counter military threats from technologically superior enemies, but ''significant shortcomings'' in its weapons and training will leave it unable to challenge the United States for ''an indefinite period of time,'' according to a Pentagon study released today.

title: Op-Art
Enrico Cuccia Is Dead at 92; Key Figure in Italian Banking
description: Enrico Cuccia, a famously reclusive Italian banker who was at the center of Italian finance for half a century, died today in Milan. He was 92.

title: Mass Transit Fare Raised in Atlanta To Expand System
description: After a long struggle to balance the need for expansion into suburban areas with the goal of keeping mass transit fares low for city residents, a $12 million deficit has forced public transit officials to make a choice, and they moved clearly in the direction of expansion.

description: To the Editor:

title: Michel Droit, Prolific Novelist And de Gaulle Biographer, 77
description: Michel Droit, a man of letters and a journalist who was a member of the Academie Francaise, died on Thursday in La Celle-Saint-Cloud, a suburb of Paris. He was 77.

title: HYUNDAI ALLIANCE PLANNED
description: DaimlerChrysler said it was forming an alliance with the Hyundai Motor Company, cementing plans to cooperate in vehicle production and raising the likelihood they would make a joint bid for the Daewoo Motor Company.

title: Aventis Unit Sets Big Investment in Biotechnology Start-Up
description: Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc., a biotechnology company, will receive up to $450 million in financing from Aventis Pharma, the European drug company, as part of a wide-ranging drug development and technology alliance announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKERMAN, SARAH
description: ACKERMAN-Sarah, 81, of Coconut Creek, FL. Died June 21, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Aaron Ackerman. Adored mother of Beverly Allen, Marilyn Suzan and Larry Ackerman. Cherished grandmother of six and great grandmother of 3. Dearest friend to devoted, long-term caregiver, Charmaine Glegg and her family. Memorial service to follow.

title: The Thrill, Never Gone, and Now in New York With the Latest Lucille
description: Wearing a silver-brocade tuxedo, with diamond rings glittering on both hands and his current guitar named Lucille in his lap, B. B. King surveyed his newest domain on Thursday night: the B. B. King Blues Club and Grill at 243 West 42nd Street, where he is performing through tonight. It's a plush basement club with a stage that could hold a big band. The carpets are patterned with guitars, the chair backs have eighth-note cutouts, and images of Mr. King's records are laminated into the tables. A T-shirt concession greets visitors. But with the kind of set he played on Thursday night, Mr. King is entitled to his own theme restaurant.

title: On Internet, David-and-Goliath Battle Over Instant Messages
description: From a cramped, three-room office near Wall Street two weeks ago, four young programmers started a frantic virtual duel with America Online, the Internet behemoth.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELWYN, ELIZABETH (LISBE)
description: ELWYN-Elizabeth (Lisbe), died June 16th, 2000. Private burial. Write to K. Elwyn, 98 Grand St, Croton-on-Hudson, NY 10520 regarding memorial service.

title: Plan to Offer Drug Program In Lieu of Jail Is Questioned
description: The ambitious plan that New York State's chief judge announced Thursday -- in which most nonviolent criminals who are addicts will be offered drug treatment instead of jail -- would be extraordinarily complicated to set up, some prosecutors said yesterday, even as they praised the concept.

title: The Execution of Gary Graham
description: To the Editor:

title: Charges of Bias Challenge U.S. Death Penalty
description: In the current debate over the death penalty, the focus has been largely on the states, primarily Illinois, whose governor has declared a moratorium, and Texas, which puts more inmates to death than most countries and whose governor, of course, is running for president.

title: 5 One-Acts to Celebrate Gay Pride
description: Anyone tromping around Greenwich Village in June is likely to pass more than a few rainbow flags. Gay pride is in the air. And it's on the stage as well, in Fourth Unity's festival of one-act plays, inspired by Gay Pride Month and staged at the Bank Street Theater.

title: Twists on Two Man-Haters: Katherina and the Novice
description: The ballet season continues to offer different, sometimes unexpected debuts. After Maxim Belotserkovsky injured himself in rehearsal, William Marrie from the National Ballet of Canada appeared as a surprise guest, partnering Irina Dvorovenko for her debut in American Ballet Theater's ''Taming of the Shrew'' on Wednesday afternoon. In the evening, New York City Ballet presented Jennie Somogyi in ''The Cage,'' where she took on Jerome Robbins's man-hating Novice for the first time.

title: New York Attitude, Made for Tokyo; Japanese Hooked on Fads Tune In for a Slice of Night Life
description: As the Japanese television cameras rolled, the break-dancers and rap artists, the rave kids and a drag queen in a glittering pink dress swaggered off a humid street in the Flatiron district and into the wall-thumping interior of the Cheetah Club.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the installation of Archbishop Edward M. Egan of New York misstated the given name of a spokeswoman for Hillary Rodham Clinton, who explained that Mrs. Clinton had attended the ceremony in her role as first lady, not as a Senate candidate. She is Lissa Muscatine, not Ilissa.

title: We Still Can't Stop The Biological Clock
description: At 48, Wendy Wasserstein becomes a first-time mother-to-be and chronicles her triumph in The New Yorker. The pregnancies of Annette Bening and Jane Seymour make headlines. Other stories tell of women having babies using their own eggs, their husbands' sperm and surrogates' uteruses. The nonstop media parade of midlife women producing offspring is stunning.

title: CARDINAL HEALTH UNIT TO BUY PART OF ADVANCED POLYMER
description: The R. P. Scherer Corporation, a subsidiary of the drug wholesaler Cardinal Health Inc., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the rights for two skin medication technologies from Advanced Polymer Systems Inc. for $25 million. Scherer, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., may pay up to an additional $26.5 million over the next three years depending on the profits of the acquired businesses. The purchase, which is expected to close in 90 days, includes the rights to Advanced Polymer's Microsponge and Polytrap technologies, sponge-like chemical compounds that are ingredients in gels, creams and powders. The deal also includes a plant in Lafayette, La., that produces the chemical compounds. Advanced Polymer is based in Redwood City, Calif.

title: New Player Shakes Up Coca-Cola Bias Case; Some Workers Face a Tough Choice
description: To his old friend the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Willie E. Gary is ''a bigger-than-life character.'' Indeed, whether the topic is compensation for a client in one of the hundreds of personal-injury cases he has taken on, or the fine points of his private jet, a Gulfstream II soon to be replaced by a Boeing 737, Mr. Gary is a man who thinks in outsized proportions.

title: AN ANGERED GORE DEFENDED '96 ROLE TO INVESTIGATOR
description: In a caustic exchange with a senior Justice Department prosecutor two months ago, Vice President Al Gore denied being told by aides that a 1996 luncheon at a Buddhist temple was a fund-raising event, according to a transcript of the interview that the vice president's lawyers released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAMELOK, ALFRED E., M.D.
description: MAMELOK-Alfred E., M.D., on June 22, 2000. Beloved husband of Judith. Loving father of Susan Wexler, Jonathan, Edward Mamelok, Avis Brodess, Dr. Mark Fromer and Dr. Susan Fromer. Cherished grandfather of Adam and Sara Wexler, Laura, Yann, Danielle and Samantha Mamelok, Daven Brodess, Gabrielle & Nicole Fromer. Service Sunday 10AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: Napster Eyes New Business Models While Preparing Defense

title: New Death May Be Linked To 5 More Brooklyn Killings
description: The killing of a woman whose partly clothed body was found Thursday on a mattress in a vacant lot in Williamsburg, strangled with her sneaker laces, may be linked to the slayings of five other women in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday.

description: Troubled Drkoop.com Boosted By New Financing
