description: The village elders met under a litchi tree, applying their collective wisdom to put a value on Peyara Begum's grotesquely ruined face.

title: Davies Feels Cozy And Leads By 2 Shots
description: Shortly after arriving at DuPont Country Club this week, Laura Davies felt good about her chances.

title: BRITISH BIOTECH SHARES FALL
description: British Biotech P.L.C. lost a fifth of its value after a study showed the company's most advanced experimental medicine provided no benefit in fighting a form of brain cancer. Shares in the company, a biotechnology concern based in Britain, fell 5 pence, to 19.25 pence. British Biotech's shares trade at less than one-tenth of their value four years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OSTRAU, IRENE
description: OSTRAU-Irene. Still miss and love you as much as ever. Stanley and Bert

title: Animals Have Taken Over Art, And Art Wonders Why; Metaphors Run Wild, but Sometimes a Cow Is Just a Cow
description: Why have real animals -- clothed, splattered, slaughtered and hatching -- become players in the art world? These days it seems that every contemporary art exhibition must have its animal, dead or alive.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Yankees and Gonzalez Are Trying Their Best to Make It All Work Out
description: One of Juan Gonzalez's agents stressed today that his client had not rejected a trade to the Yankees and that he still had an interest in playing for New York. That kept alive the possibility that Gonzalez could soon be acquired from the Detroit Tigers.

title: Nassau Gets $105 Million and Oversight Unit
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed into law today a two-tier bailout plan for troubled Nassau County that will create an independent board to oversee the county's finances and provide $105 million in state aid to help it pay its bills over the next five years.

title: E.P.A. Plan to Stem Flow of Smog To East Coast Is Upheld by Court
description: A federal appeals court has upheld a new air-pollution program meant to drastically reduce smog that flows from the Middle West to the East.

title: ENERGIZER OFFERING BATTERIES FOR HIGH-TECH DEVICES
description: Energizer Holdings Inc., the nation's No. 2 maker of alkaline batteries, said yesterday it had begun selling a line of premium-priced batteries for high-tech devices in an attempt to take sales from the Gillette Company's top-selling Duracell brand. Energizer, based in St. Louis, plans to spend $100 million in the next year on a global marketing campaign as it introduces the Energizer e2, company officials said. A package of 4 AA batteries will sell for about $4.59, or about a third more than its main brand. Energizer, spun off by the Ralston Purina Company in April, has been losing market share to Duracell in the last five years.

title: Philippe Chatrier, 72, a Force On International Tennis Scene
description: There was a time in the 1970's and the 80's, when Philippe Chatrier wore dual chapeaux as president of the International Tennis Federation and president of the French Tennis Federation, that all roads in tennis led through Gaul. That era officially ended Thursday when Mr. Chatrier, the man responsible for the return of tennis to the Olympics and the renaissance of his home Grand Slam tournament, the French Open, as one of the game's four most prestigious championships, died at age 72.

title: The Big City; Urban Menace Stalks Streets In Diapers
description: ANY journalist who covers the Upper West Side quickly becomes combat-hardened, but even the veterans at The West Side Spirit have never seen anything like the current war. It was set off by their front-page headline: ''Your Kids Are Driving Me Crazy!''

title: McCORMICK, SPICE MANUFACTURER, SEEKS HERB BUSINESS
description: McCormick & Company, the world's largest spice and seasonings maker, said it was in talks to buy the Ducros herb business of Eridania Beghin-Say of France to bolster sales in Europe. McCormick said in a statement that the discussions were at an advanced stage, but the company declined to comment further. Ducros is France's biggest maker of herbs and spices, with about $234 million in sales last year. It owns five plants in France, Albania and Portugal and employs about 930 people. McCormick, which is based in Sparks, Md., has been working to cut costs in Europe to free cash for new products.

title: The Execution of Gary Graham
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Fever Spiked by a Funk Revue's Beat
description: The time was ripe for a dance party on Monday at Irving Plaza. A giant pair of headphones was parked outside, designed by students from the School of Visual Arts using a grant (and two cars, incorporated into the sculpture) from the evening's sponsor, Toyota. A film and video installation enhanced the rave-like environment.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-5

title: UNILEVER SHARES FALL
description: Shares in the food and consumer giant Unilever P.L.C. fell 9 percent after the British-Dutch company lowered its forecast for annual sales growth from 3 to 4 percent to 2 to 3 percent. The outlook excluded recent acquisitions in the United States like Bestfoods and Ben & Jerry's. In London, Unilever shares fell 41 pence, to 413 pence, or about $6.20.

title: Albright Says U.S. Pullout Isn't Planned In South Korea
description: Trying to dampen speculation that the prospects of reconciliation on the Korean peninsula would lead to a smaller American military presence in South Korea, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright stressed today that United States troops would not be withdrawn any time soon.

title: Web Site Lists Iran Coup Names
description: A Web site about international security has published a list of names from a Central Intelligence Agency document that The New York Times had deleted when it originally posted the report on its own Web site. The document outlined the C.I.A.'s involvement in a 1953 coup in Iran.

title: CANADA-BRAZIL TECHNOLOGY DEAL
description: Celestica, a Canadian electronics hardware manufacturer, purchased an equipment plant in Brazil for $1.2 billion from NEC of Japan as part of a five-year supply deal. Celestica will take over the plant, which produces telecommunications and Internet equipment for the Latin American market, while continuing to supply NEC's Brazilian subsidiary.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Out column in Weekend yesterday about Spanish restaurants misstated The Times's most recent rating for Meigas in Manhattan. It received two stars, not one.

title: Trenton May Abandon Part of Auto Inspection Test
description: Citing a new glitch in its problem-plagued automobile inspection system, New Jersey officials said yesterday that they might abandon a part of the inspection process and instead turn to businesses to help the state meet its federally mandated goals for reducing emissions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLMEIER, WILLIAM E.
description: DILLMEIER-William E. Died at his home in Garden City, NY on June 23, 2000 on his 89th birthday. Survived by his sons, William E., Jr. of Lambertville, NJ, and Robert L. of Garden City, NY, and their respective families. Reposing at Fairchild Funeral Home, Garden City, NY, Sunday, June 25, 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Funeral will be held at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, NY on Monday, June 26 at 10:00 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERMAN, JAMES B.
description: LIBERMAN-James B. At home on June 22, 2000, at age 84. Beloved husband of Deen Freed Liberman and, after her death, of Nadine C. Zamichow, Father of Lee Liberman Otis and the late John Liberman, Father-in-law of Mary Beth Liberman Traynor and William G. Otis, Grandfather of Harry, Dean, Emma, Bert, Jessie, Zachary, Bernie and Audrey. Cherished Brother of Lee Liberman. A gentleman of exceptional generosity, dignity, modesty and achievement, graduate of Yale Law School and Chairman of its 60th Reunion Class last year, United States Army during World War II, General Counsel of General Public Utilities, Founding partner of Berlack, Israel and Liberman, recently joined Thelen Reid and Priest. Contributions may be made to the Yale Law School or The Federalist Society. Memorial Services at Temple Emanu-El, One East 65th Street, Monday, June 26, at 11 AM.

title: Appeals Court Rejects Bid By Cuban Boy's Relatives
description: A federal appeals court in Atlanta has refused to reconsider the case of Elian Gonzalez, leaving the United States Supreme Court as a last hope for the Miami relatives who want to prevent his return to Cuba.

title: Dispute Costs New York City $100 Million in Tax Cuts
description: Nearly $100 million worth of cuts in New York City taxes -- intended largely to benefit the middle class, the elderly and the poor -- failed to win approval from the State Legislature yesterday, because of a dispute over a $2 surcharge on hotel rooms.

title: Mayor and Biggest Rivals Come Together, Virtually
description: Call it a case of Internet expediency or detente in cyberspace. An odd thing is being beamed from City Hall. Yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced the merger of the city's main Web site with those of his primary rivals in city government, the City Council, the public advocate and the city comptroller.

title: Rambus Rises 18% as Hitachi Agrees to Pay Royalties
description: Rambus Rises 18% as Hitachi Agrees to Pay Royalties

title: In Mock Palestinian Hill Town, Israeli Troops Prepare for Worst
description: Near the ancient caves of Bet Guvrin in Israel, army officials say, there is a secret Palestinian village on a hill. It consists of about 15 houses and a mosque. It is for Israelis only.

title: Corrections
description: The Inside Art column in Weekend yesterday omitted a numeral from the title of an exhibition scheduled to open on Jan. 1 at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. It is ''01.01.01: Art in Technological Times,'' not ''01.0.01.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLER, DOROTHY GANFIELD
description: FOWLER-Dorothy Ganfield. The History Department of Hunter College regrets the death of Dorothy Ganfield Fowler, our colleague and friend. A respected scholar in United States history whose books include studies of the Postmasters General, sensorship in the post office and the First Presbyterian Church of New York. A teacher who inspired two generations of students, the Chair of the History Department, an administrator of rare widsom and skill, she was a member of the Hunter faculty for over 40 years.

title: Knee Surgery Planned For Archbishop Egan
description: As the new archbishop of New York, Edward M. Egan oversees a network of 17 Catholic hospitals and medical centers. But when he undergoes surgery on a knee next month, the archbishop will return to his former diocese in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Sports of The Times; Kindness Just Might Unravel Him
description: IT is time for New Yorkers to turn the other cheek, to embrace with open arms, to bestow a Big Apple welcome to John Loy Rocker, that renowned deep thinker and man of generous insights.

title: An Old-Guard Candidate Struggles in a Changing Japan
description: For a powerful politician seeking re-election to Parliament for the fifth time, Kazumi Mochinaga is a man of few words.

title: Excerpts From Gore's Interview With the F.B.I. on Campaign Fund-Raising
description: Following are excerpts from Vice President Al Gore's April 18 interview with the F.B.I. about political fund-raising during the 1996 presidential campaign. Among other topics, Mr. Gore discussed a trip to Taiwan, the purpose of invitations to coffee at the White House and a visit to a Buddhist temple. At one point his lawyer, James F. Neal, joined the discussion. The transcript was released by the Gore campaign.

title: AT&T Files New Proposal On Its Rates
description: AT&T submitted a new proposal yesterday that would give telephone users more flexibility in seeking to save money on some long-distance calls but that appeared to fall short of stemming the outcry from consumer groups and federal regulators over its plans to raise certain costs for tens of millions of customers.

title: Auto Sales May Be Feeling First Pinch of Higher Rates
description: Automakers say that despite recent deep discounts, auto sales have not picked up in June from the relatively subdued pace of May, providing evidence to the Federal Reserve that recent interest-rate increases may be slowing the American economy.

title: PROFIT AT RUSSIAN METALS PRODUCER
description: The Russian metals company Norilsk Nickel, which has been fighting a prosecutor's effort to reverse its 1995 privatization, reported a higher-than-expected profit for 1999, reflecting the effects of the ruble's devaluation on export revenue. Norilsk, a leading producer of platinum and palladium, said it earned $1.2 billion last year, beating estimates of the Moscow-based Troika Dialog brokerage of $900 million. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Abroad at Home; Into The Quagmire
description: When the Senate approved the Tonkin Gulf Resolution in 1964, giving President Johnson carte blanche for war in Vietnam, only two senators said no: Wayne Morse and Ernest Gruening. We have made some progress since then. When the Senate voted this week for an open-ended commitment to aid a war against drug cultivation in Colombia, 11 senators dissented by supporting a modest amendment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTBADER, MORRIS S. ''BUD,''
description: LUSTBADER-Morris S. ''Bud,'' died peacefully in New York on June 20th, 2000 at the age of 92. Son of the late Samuel and Sarah Lustbader, for many years a civil engineer in this city, Bud was educated at Exeter and Yale, served proudly in the Seabees on Guadalcanal in World War II and became a commander USNR, married the late Marion Lustbader, and is now mourned by his daughter, Susan Friedman, his sister, Ruth L. Israel, his beloved friend, Joan Strausberg, & his many nieces, nephews and friends. A private memorial service will be held Monday, June 26th. Contributions may be made to Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street, New York City, for its Caring Committee.

title: JAPAN'S GOVERNMENT DEBT RISES
description: Debt reached a record 493 trillion yen ($4.7 trillion) at the end of March as the government continued public works spending to encourage growth. Debt grew 12.7 percent from March 1999, the Ministry of Finance said. The debt is greater than the nation's gross domestic product, which grew to 482.4 trillion yen.

title: Russian Media Tycoon Won't Answer Prosecutors' Queries
description: Vladimir A. Gusinsky, the media tycoon whose arrest last week raised fears of a press crackdown, refused to answer prosecutors' questions today.

description: DUCHNOWSKI-Alfred, of Staten Island. Beloved husband of Alicja Duchnowska, M.D. Loving father of Paul and Michael Duchnowski. Dear son-in-law of Zofia Kalisciak. Reposing at Casey McCallum Rice Funeral Home, 30 Nelson Ave, SI. Funeral Mass Monday, 11 AM, Our Lady of Czestochowa Chapel, Doylestown, PA. Visiting Sunday, 2-4, 7-9. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Y.A.C. Scholarship Fund in memory of A. Duchnowski. Call Marcia Novak at Boston University, 617-353-5881.

title: Where Tchaikovsky Becomes a Russian-Italian Blend
description: In a city where you spend the day living through your eyes, the annual music festival provides compensatory evenings for the ears. It is one of the oldest such festivals -- the present is the 63rd -- and it long ago outgrew its name of Maggio Musicale (Musical May): events start in the middle of April and go on until the end of June.

title: A Campaign Finance Ruse
description: No one wants to come out against the public disclosure of fat-cat donors to political ad campaigns. That would be too embarrassing when the public is so disgusted with fund-raising abuses. So House Republican leaders have done what must have seemed like the next best thing. They want a disclosure requirement that is so inequitable and destructive of First Amendment rights that it cannot pass. Their scheme is to use this hopelessly defective legislation as a tool to prevent a serious, evenhanded disclosure measure from getting a fair vote, even though it has broad bipartisan support. Reformers must defy these leaders and stand up for real reform this week.

title: Schools Show Slight Increase In Math Scores
description: Students in New York City performed only slightly better on a citywide mathematics test this year than last, with 68 percent still failing to meet tough new standards.

title: A Trial Lawyer Who Is Linked To Jesse Helms
description: When Attorney General Janet Reno appointed Robert J. Conrad Jr. to direct the Justice Department's campaign finance task force late last year, she praised his prosecutorial skills and said she expected him to ''expand upon the successes'' of the campaign finance inquiry.

title: Israeli Rivals Use Media Leaks In the Fight Over Peace Talks
description: A campaign of leaks is under way to pre-expose Israel's bargaining positions in its peace negotiations so as to put pressure on Prime Minister Ehud Barak against making significant concessions to the Palestinians.

title: MEDICAL ASSURANCE IS SET TO ADD PROFESSIONALS GROUP
description: Medical Assurance Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Professionals Group Inc. for $232 million plus debt, creating the nation's third-largest medical malpractice insurance provider. Professionals Group stockholders will receive $12 cash and $14 in stock of the new holding company or $26 in cash for each of their shares, a 62.5 percent premium over Thursday's closing price. Medical Assurance shareholders will exchange their shares one-for-one. Stock in Professionals Group, which is based in Okemos, Mich., jumped $6.859, to $22.859. Medical Assurance is based in Birmingham, Ala.

description: GINSBURG-Ruth. On June 22, 2000. Beloved wife of Nathan. Devoted mother of Monroe and Carol. Dear sister of Ashley, Rosalind and Sarah. Cherished grandmother of Jason, David and Emily. Services Sunday 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Clinton Visits Olympic Training Center
description: President Clinton saluted American athletes at an Olympic training center here today and received some expert instruction in pole vaulting, race walking and archery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALAUTTI, WILLIAM
description: CALAUTTI-William. 85, Died June 22 in Virginia. He was a musician and artisan who designed chandeliers for hotels, theaters and restaurants in New York and in the Unites States Capitol Building in Washington DC. He was born March 14, 1915 in New York and served in the U.S. Navy during World War II. After the war, he ran a chandelier business. He also started a band and played the saxophone, clarinet and trumpet under the stage name of Bill Caldwell. In his later years in Richmond, Virginia, he donated his time to perform at senior centers. He is survived by his children Lee, Lucy, William Jr., Kevin, John and Patricia; nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild. The family will receive Guests Mon. title: Falling In Love With Art's Orphans
description: FOR years, Robert Rosenblum, a curator and scholar who likes to find connections between the curiosities of art history, visited the Church of the Ascension at 10th Street and Fifth Avenue near his Greenwich Village home. There he stood pensively in front of a strange 1899 painting depicting a monk assisting crippled, naked boys on crutches at the ocean. The picture, originally titled ''Children of Pleasure'' and then renamed ''Sad Inheritance,'' was unusual for several reasons. Its subject was not a sacred one but rather a moralizing tale of children afflicted with syphilis, a portrayal of Christian charity, an example of both church propaganda and the way religious themes were secularized in the late 19th century. The daring depiction won Joaquin Sorolla y Bastida, a Spanish artist from Valencia, a gold medal at the Paris World's Fair in 1900.

As the series shows, the new multiracial society announced into our national consciousness by the breakthrough victories of the Southern civil rights movement is not free of economic and cultural tensions, of mistrust and plain old prejudice. The series documents that no part of America, North or South, East or West, has fully created what Representative John Lewis calls ''the beloved community.'' It also shows that what was once viewed as a regional story told in black and white is now national in scope and multi-ethnic in content.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Apparitions
description: As a self-taught artist, Vincent van Gogh found drawing the human figure difficult. Yet he wrote in 1890, ''What impassions me most -- much, much more than all the rest of my metier -- is the portrait, the modern portrait.'' The lavishly illustrated VAN GOGH FACE TO FACE: The Portraits (Thames and Hudson, $50) traces the development of the artist's self-expression in his portraits. Unlike his contemporaries John Singer Sargent and Gustav Klimt, van Gogh was concerned with conveying larger human truths through portraiture. His intense religious feelings, as well as his straitened personal circumstances, drew him first to the poor and downtrodden as subjects of his paintings, but those anonymous figures also served as shorthand for a range of sociological types. Intimate though a portrait might be, in the end it was a portrayal of a class rather than an individual. Even his self-portraits are so many character sketches: van Gogh as worker, bourgeois or bohemian. The self-portraits in particular reveal his roots in the work of the Dutch Old Masters, but as the essays in this volume explain, van Gogh could not have gained his command of color without exposure to the French Impressionists. It was the synthesis of those influences that leads Joseph J. Rishel, a curator at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, to assert, ''The modern portrait begins with van Gogh.'' He himself summed up the effect of his work best when he wrote in June 1890, a month before his suicide, ''I would like to make portraits that a century later might appear to people of the time like apparitions.'' Anna Rohleder

Microsoft was jubilant; penalties that were to take effect in September are now on hold for at least a year, maybe longer. But some government officials say they believe Microsoft, freed from scrutiny for a while, might continue the sort of behavior that got the company in trouble to begin with, and help convince the appeals courts to uphold the lower court's ruling. title: Pole Beans: Tall, Tasty And Worth the Wait

The fine, sunny weekends came when I was off seeing someone else's garden. So it was mid-June before I got my seeds in the ground. Which is plenty of time for a bush bean like Royal Burgundy, which only takes 60 days, but pole beans, which grow on vines that like to wind up strings or trellises, often take more like 70 or 80 days to mature. And since they keep coming, as long as you pick them, all summer long, it's a shame to lose a month to the vagaries of weather and the gardener.

Through her films and her critical writing, she made the case that cinema was as serious an art as painting and poetry.

title: Bookend; Par Avion
description: Rarely have an author and a character been so intimately bound together as Antoine de Saint-Exupery and his Little Prince. They make for an odd couple: the hulking, balding aviator who preferred stapling to buttoning his shirts; the dapper little extraterrestrial with the mop of golden curls and what seems an extensive wardrobe for someone who hails from an asteroid the size of a house. Where the Little Prince religiously tends his planet, his creator was a champion procrastinator. (If the wreckage found off the coast of Marseille this spring, weeks before Saint-Exupery's centennial, proves to be that of his lost World War II airplane, it will be one of the first occasions on which he has turned up on time.) The Little Prince is a determined walker; Saint-Exupery -- the toast of every cabdriver in Paris -- was allergic to exercise. He had no use for nature. Yet the two remain tangled together, twin innocents who fell from the sky.

United boasts that it has removed a row of seats to make coach passengers more comfortable, but its interior decorating is mediocre at best. Continental shows lots of movies, but the selection (not to mention the sound and the picture quality) is much better at the local cineplex.

So I recall hearing a Club Med staff member bark at me in the summer of 1966 as I lay sunning on a white sand beach on the Tunisian island of Djerba. An Ella Fitzgerald tape was playing in the background. I was the only American staying at a camp full of young French. Naturally, my fellow holiday makers wanted to berate me about Vietnam. I just wanted somebody to rub oil on my back.

description: Through her years as a solo artist, Juliana Hatfield, former Blake Babies singer, has created appealing songs with powerful guitar hooks, agreeable melodies and confessional lyrics. She's a mighty guitar player and her new offering, a double album package displaying her gentle side as well as her take-no-prisoners persona.

title: Where Do Amish Train Their Horses?
description: THIS Dutchess County village is several hundred miles from Amish country in Pennsylvania, but on a recent brilliant day, a young stallion belonging to an Amish farmer was going through his paces at a horse farm here. Bill Broe, a genial man who has worked with horses for most of his 48 years, was training Lego, a 2-year-old black Morgan, to draw a carriage.

description: Considering that on successive days, the two recognized contenders for the American League East championship lost games by scores of 17-4 and 22-1, that the Toronto Blue Jays, in the space of six recent games, lost by scores of 16-3 and 18-6 should not rule them out as a third contender for that title.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

title: The Problem With Kids Today? Today's Parents, Some Say

JAMES VARGA, a pediatrician, has been in practice in Santa Monica, Calif., for 21 years, enough time for a generation of well-educated, middle- and upper-middle-class parents to have visited his examination room with their children. His diagnosis of those parents: ''Absolutely too permissive.''

title: A Roadside Stop for Dishes of India
description: STONE lions flank the heavy wooden entrance door to India House, for more than 16 years a welcome bit of brightness on a dreary stretch of the Albany Post Road here. Inside, the glow continues from polychromatic patch-worked canopies lining the ceiling to ruby glass, which screens the candle atop every table. All of this brilliance is an appropriate backdrop for India's cuisine -- equally splendid in its varied flavors.

title: EMISSIONS TESTING
description: State officials said last week they may drop or delay part of the state inspection process that was to account for 7 percent of all smog-related emissions reductions. The test, scheduled to be added to the inspection process on July 1, is intended to detect leaks in a car's exhaust system not detected by tailpipe emissions testing. But it would increase inspection and waiting times, and would be a danger to technicians, according to the State Division of Motor Vehicles. STEVE STRUNSKY

title: Still Uninsured, and Still a Campaign Issue
description: THE problem of Americans who lack health insurance has been debated endlessly for the last decade, yet theranks of the uninsured keep growing. Having risen by more than a million a year in the 1990's, the number of uninsured now stands at 44.3 million - 16 percent of the population - even though the United States is enjoying the longest period of economic growth in its history.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., Monday, 3:30 PM. Interment private. title: For Experimental Treatments, 'Somebody Has to Be First'

But religion had a role, too. Since providence had brought her to Dr. Overmoyer just in time for a new, experimental treatment, she thought she must be meant to try it.

title: Joining the Million-Mile Club
description: INTENTIONALLY or not, airline frequent-flier programs have moved the target for mileage trophy hunters: it's now a million free miles. One of the latest examples is courtesy of LatinPass, a frequent-flier consortium representing 10 Latin American airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, THELMA
description: BLUMBERG-Thelma. On June 15, 2000. Devotion to family; warm camaraderie with friends; an intellectual excursion starting at Lincoln HS and Brooklyn College and continuing through many elder hostels and the Brandeis University National Women's Committee; a satisfying career as a math teacher at Andrew Jackson HS and John Bowne HS; an active appreciation of the arts, nature, good food, playing bridge, swimming, and travel; and we particularly remember Thelma for her vigorous dedication to progressive politics and humanist values. We hope family and friends revitalize their efforts for justice and peace in her memory.

description: SOME filmmakers say it is invaluable in helping them gauge an audience's response. Others say it threatens their integrity. But nearly everyone concedes that movie testing has become a studio addiction not to be kicked any time soon.

Lockman of Nassau County ordering a former operator of a Mobil gas station in Bay Shore to pay attorney's fees as well as cleanup costs in a 1999 case involving contamination from leaking underground storage tanks.

Houghton II of Pawleys Island, S.C., and the late Lyle Stewart Houghton. The Rev. Thomas Omholt performed the ceremony, in which the bridegroom's father, an Episcopal priest, took part, at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Washington.

title: The Last Safari
description: I found your photograph of the four empty chairs at Little Governor's Camp, Masai Mara, interesting. I have stayed at Little Governor's on each of my trips, the most recent this past April. The only time I saw four empty chairs was when everyone was out on safari, even last April, which is the off-season. As I prepare to return in five weeks for an extended stay, I find it interesting that a friend who is traveling with us is wait-listed for a tent for July and August because the camp is currently overbooked. Yes, Kenya has deteriorated, but so have many other destinations as life becomes more complex and the gap between the haves and have-nots broadens. Perhaps Blaine Harden's long absence left him searching for memories he had of a more simple time.

title: After Campaign Marked by Intimidation, Zimbabwe Voting Opens With Relative Calm
description: The first day of long-awaited national elections was reported largely peaceful today, apparently free of the brazen intimidation and violence that marked the campaign and threatened to mar a vote seen as the biggest challenge to the grip of President Robert Mugabe in the 20 years since white minority rule ended.

But in recent weeks rates on the benchmark 30-year fixed-rate mortgage have been easing somewhat. Adjustable-rate mortgages, meanwhile, have been steadier in recent weeks.

title: WHITE PLAINS: NEW SOLID WASTE CHIEF
description: Bruce B. Berger, a lawyer who worked on the four-year investigation of New York City's private carting industry, has been named executive director of the Westchester Solid Waste Commission. His job will be to enforce Westchester's new trash haulers' law, which requires all carters to undergo a background investigation before obtaining a county license. Mr. Berger said that he wants to make sure there is fair competition in the industry and that customers will not be overcharged. A resident of White Plains, he will be paid $109,730. He takes over for Roger Rokicki, who resigned last month. ELSA BRENNER

title: Doyle Finds That Winning Doesn't Guarantee Celebrity
description: Allen Doyle will play to a huge crowd in the final round of the Cadillac N.F.L. Golf Classic on Sunday, but he does not fool himself into believing the crowd will be there to watch him. Entering the final day tied with Lee Trevino for the lead at 11 under par, the two will play with Gary McCord, who is one stroke off the lead. And Doyle will just be someone who provides a break between the applause from Trevino's adoring fans and the comic style of McCord.

Lazio violated insider trading laws, acted on the basis of information that suggested -- but hardly proved -- that he might have known about a pending takeover that had not been disclosed to the public.

title: The Nation: Death Penalty Defense; The Lawyers Live to Fight Again
description: WHEN the State of Texas executed Gary Graham last week for the 1981 murder of a man outside a Houston supermarket, death-penalty opponents pointed a spotlight on Mr. Graham's court-appointed trial lawyer, whom they criticized for failing to mount anything near an adequate defense. He barely investigated the case, they maintained, and failed to alert the jury to two witnesses who said Mr. Graham was not the killer and to ballistics evidence that could have exonerated his client.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: HOLLYWOOD hasn't come up with many movies that are sophisticated, political, heart-warming and life-affirming at the same time. But Morton DaCosta's AUNTIE MAME (1958) is all those things, and it makes single parenthood look great. Sure, there's the musical version of Patrick Dennis's story about the eccentric Beekman Place aunt who reared him in the 1920's and 30's, but who needs singing and dancing when you have the incomparable Rosalind Russell as Mame? Peggy Cass is adorable, too, as Agnes Gooch, the mousy secretary who takes Mame's advice (to get out there and live life) a little too much to heart - Saturday at 12:30 p.m. on TCM.

title: The Messages That Got Away
description: Without question, modern technology, notably in the form of the telephone, voice mail, e-mail and the fax, has speeded communication. Whether it has enhanced communication is another matter. As these anecdotes indicate, haste continues to make waste, chips prove no substitute for the human brain and many an ill-considered word find an unintended audience.

title: June 18-24; A Chance for Addicts
description: New York State moved to expand pilot programs that had shown some success in changing the lives of convicted drug addicts, by offering every nonviolent addict the option of treatment instead of jail. While all 50 states offer some form of court-mandated treatment, New York will be the first to make it an integral part of the system. The move is expected to move one-tenth of the state's 95,000 inmates from behind bars and into treatment programs, and save $500 million a year in prison, foster care and mental health costs. KATHERINE E. FINKELSTEIN

title: MUSIC; In Early Music, an End of Hostilities
description: EVEN a concertgoer who had somehow missed the nationwide barrage of pre performance hype would have known that something was up from the biographies in the program booklet of the Berkeley Festival and Exhibition this month. Interspersed among the accounts of musicians' educations, affiliations and discographies were items like this: ''Heidi Riddle has been a horse trainer in the East Bay for 20 years and owns a show barn in Martinez called Half Halt Farms.''

title: California and Connecticut: The Robust, the Almost Shy
description: THE show called ''The California Impressionists at Laguna'' is a stimulating blend of similarities and differences. The summer show, at the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, is designed for comparison with the Lyme Art Colony that flourished early in the 20th century, and also to demonstrate what was innately Californian about the Western brand of Impressionism.

title: I Married a Dummy
description: In the beginning there were Dummies books for computer users, and they were fruitful and multiplied. Soon the publisher, IDG Books Worldwide, found that Dummies needed help with practically everything from investing to beer. Now there is ''Making Marriage Work for Dummies'' by a Tenafly couple, Dr. Steven Simring, an associate professor and vice chairman of the Department of Psychiatry at New Jersey Medical School and Dr. Sue Klavans Simring, a social worker. The book, written with Gene Busnar, is a fix-it manual for marital error messages. Troubleshooting tip: Don't automatically blame your spouse for the problem. Thinking about a second child? Warning! ''One child is relatively portable and you can still travel and do many of the things you did when you were childless.'' Romance? Tip! ''Do All the Corny Things.'' The Simrings, who have been married for 30 years and have three children, say they have found lots of corny things in Bergen County that keep love alive, like taking walks along the Palisades or dining out in a Japanese or Middle Eastern restaurant. ''You don't have to traipse into the city for that,'' said Dr. Simring. MARGO NASH

description: Julian Adams followed the Korean summit meeting earlier this month with keen interest. Apart from the fact that it was the first event of its kind in half a century, the meeting fascinated him for a very tangible reason: Kim Jong Il, the elusive North Korean leader, owes him some money.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-25-00: Economics of Phone Bills; Please Deposit 72.4 Cents
description: When William E. Kennard can't explain to his wife the complexities of their phone bill, it's time for the telephone companies to make their bills simpler. Kennard is the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. And that's why he was the one to announce recently that the government and the nation's leading telecoms have agreed both to simplify their bills by clarifying hidden subsidies and to pass on to consumers the savings from reduced access charges that long-distance companies pay to the regional bells.

title: Amy Rhodes, Daniel Froehlich
description: Amy Janet Rhodes, a daughter of Hiroko Yajima Rhodes and Samuel Rhodes of Englewood, N.J., was married last evening to Daniel Shea Froehlich, a son of Lynn Bush and David Froehlich, both of Doylestown, Pa. Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated in the Snuff Mill at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

description: WHEN temperatures in Manhattan reached the Venusian mid-90's in early May, I found my thoughts migrating, gooselike, to the cooler north: Canada.

title: Habitats/145 Nassau Street, Near City Hall Park; Seeking Space and Quiet, Couple Move Downtown
description: ANNABEL MANNING and Michael Kelly were expecting their first baby, and suddenly their apartment on the third floor of an East Village brownstone didn't seem like the best place to live. Although it was large, 1,000 square feet, and charming, with two fireplaces and wide pumpkin-pine floors, it didn't have a second bedroom, and it posed the problem of stairs, which are intimidating with a baby in one arm and a stroller in the other.

title: The Last Safari
description: Blaine Harden's article (June 4) came just one week after I returned from my fourth trip to Nairobi. After reading it, I realized that I, too, have struggled with what to tell people regarding this country that I love so much. Do I tell of my amazing visits, of the people and places that have so inspired me, in the hope that more tourists will make the trip and revive the economy once again? Or do I ''expose'' the reality of the poverty and decline of Kenya, with the idea that if enough people hear about it, something may be done? I have never come up with a satisfying answer. I just hope that I never get ''out of the sun,'' as Harden writes so bitterly, and give up on ever seeing a prosperous, healthy Kenya.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for BIJAN NAMDAR ZANGANEH; Toward Oil Price Stability, Step by Step

It certainly was for me until, at age 44, I was given a diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and told that I was going to die in a couple of years and that there wasn't a damn thing I could do.

title: BRONXVILLE: YEARBOOK RECALLED
description: Bronxville High School has recalled its 2000 yearbook because of inappropriate content. A school official said the yearbook had a picture of a student with his buttocks exposed, two others in a simulated sexual pose and a section that read, ''You know you're from Westchester if . . . ,'' which included the statement, ''You recall your Jamaican nanny with great fondness.'' Superintendent of Schools John Chambers said it would cost thousands of dollars to recall the yearbooks, ''but it has to be done.'' ELSA BRENNER

title: A Magic Carpet of Cultures in London
description: LONDON today is radiant and self-aware, no longer seeming like a venerated museum the whole world feels obliged to visit because it is so cutely Olde Worlde. Even grumpy Londoners like myself, who have to grapple with these pilgrims, now concede that there is something exhilarating in the air, and that it is qualitatively different from the 80's, when shallow yuppies seemed dangerously close to taking over the metropolis. What we are witnessing feels portentous, a key historical juncture that tomorrow's scribes will look back on and note. In her diary entry for May 26, 1926, Virginia Woolf wrote: ''London is enchanting. I step out upon a tawny coloured magic carpet and get carried into beauty.'' Today she would look down on a place less beautiful, perhaps; infinitely more unsettling, at times like Babel, yet magnetically attractive and engaging.

title: European Travel Agents Fear Airline Web Sites
description: TAKING a cue from the travel industry in the United States, European airlines and hotel companies have begun setting up their own Web sites, where customers can shop for flights and rooms. And as in the United States, the action is angering travel agents who fear the sites will cut them off from some of the more tempting offerings.

Measles, mumps, chicken pox -- these were definable ailments that would likely go away with proper treatment. Now, Dr. Jack Swanson, a pediatrician in Ames, Iowa, spends his days dealing with more elusive problems: depressed children, anorexic and bulimic teenagers, sexually precocious tweens, young substance abusers, younger perpetrators and victims of violence.

Dozens of houses are either being built or rebuilt. The village is rapidly regaining the 190 houses that were once lost or made uninhabitable by three decades of severe beach erosion. A $17 million publicly financed beach rebuilding project, completed in 1997, stablilized and expanded the beach and restored its dunes, leading to the current building boom.

title: Inside Jihad U.; The Education of a Holy Warrior
description: About two hours east of the Khyber Pass, in the North-West Frontier Province of Pakistan, alongside the Grand Trunk Road, sits a school called the Haqqania madrasa. A madrasa is a Muslim religious seminary, and Haqqania is one of the bigger madrasas in Pakistan: its mosques and classrooms and dormitories are spread over eight weed-covered acres, and the school currently enrolls more than 2,800 students. Tuition, room and board are free; the students are, in the main, drawn from the dire poor, and the madrasa raises its funds from wealthy Pakistanis, as well as from devout, and politically minded, Muslims in the countries of the Persian Gulf.

title: Crime

The beguiling narrative of THE DEATH OF AN IRISH LOVER (Morrow, $23) takes us to the ''storybook village'' of Leixleap, where the well-heeled international anglers who put up at the great stone inn can fish for fast-running salmon in the River Shannon and have a bit of fun in the pub next door. Not even the crime of passion that bloodies the carpet in one of the inn's bedrooms -- where two officers with the Shannon River Fisheries Board are shot to death while in flagrante -- ruffles the tranquillity. The senior officer was a notorious rake, after all, and what's a cuckolded husband supposed to do?

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; West Is More East
description: Meera Syal's smart, sprightly second novel, LIFE ISN'T ALL HA HA HEE HEE (New Press, $22.95), begins with an Indian wedding procession down a snowy London street. Dowdy Chila is marrying the dashing and worldly bachelor Deepak, who has chosen her precisely because she is so dowdy -- and plump, compliant and traditional. He has decided he is through with ''snappy witty women with low-fat bodies and high-maintenance demands.'' Chila's oldest friends, Tania and Sunita, are understandably a little worried for her. The book is about how these three childhood companions struggle to move between the cloistered, samosa-nibbling world of their parents and freewheeling contemporary London. Chila, at first, appears to have it easiest. Prone to deferential giggling, she seems content to stay at home and organize her spices. Sunita is in a tougher spot: a onetime campus feminist, she can't understand how she became an overweight and depressed mother of two, stuck in a sexless, surprisingly traditional Indian marriage. Beautiful, provocative Tania lives with an English boyfriend and works as a documentary filmmaker. But she is perpetually restless and at war with her past. The story revolves around a film Tania makes about love and marriage among Indians in England, using her friends as subjects. The film reveals the fissures in their lives -- and her own. Syal is a television actress who has written extensively for the screen, and while her new novel veers occasionally into melodrama, it is gossipy, funny and thoroughly entertaining. She manages to get inside the heads of three very different characters, inspiring sympathy for both tricky, adulterous sirens and sari-clad housewives. Jennifer Reese

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKFIELD, ALFRED
description: MARKFIELD-Alfred. Age 84, died on Father's Day, June 18. He had fought asthma and heart disease but finally succumbed peacefully at his Florida home with his wife, Sylvia (nee Knopf) after holding hands and a final kiss after 57 years of marriage. Alfred is also survived by two daughters, Penni (nee Markfield) Schultz and Linda (nee Markfield) Bogart, along with five grandchildren. Alfred was a successful businessman venturing into many different areas. After retiring, Alfred returned to Lynn University and obtained four diplomas in computer programming while becoming the first to instruct senior citizens where he lived in computer classes and also assisting in a local elementary school. These were all volunteer activities. His charitable and philanthropic acts were always done anonymously and the careers of many successful businessmen today were due to his generosity and guidance. Alfred loved tradition and his beliefs also lead him to support and help build three synagogues, the last one being Shelter Rock Jewish Center of Roslyn, NY. May God grant peace and serenity to Alfred and his family. The family requests in lieu of flowers that donations be made to your favorite charity. Services were held Tuesday at Star of David Cemetery.

In late April, Leonard Eto, a master of the large, ceremonial Japanese drums known as taiko, had traveled from his native Tokyo, marginally equipped with English, to work in this tiny New England town, which Pilobolus calls home, with people who spoke not a word of Japanese. Now, I've lived in a lot of cities -- Chicago, New York, Los Angeles, Nashville, Seattle -- and met a lot of people. But this is the first time I've spent time with anybody who sings along with country-music radio. Even in Nashville, where the people who manufacture the music live, rock 'n' roll, rap or alternative country reigns in cars. Country radio listening, in general, is strictly business.
