description: Bridget Claire Kule, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher A. Kule of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Brandon Wilson Lower, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Lower II of Winnetka, Ill. The Rev. Jay Sidebotham performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: Cary Hollinshead, Terence Strick
description: Cary Elizabeth Hollinshead, a daughter of Mary Berg Hollinshead and Dr. William H. Hollinshead III of Rehoboth, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Terence Rossignol Strick, a son of Dr. Martine Rossignol Strick and Joseph Strick of Paris. The Rev. Michael Coburn performed the ceremony at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Providence, R.I.

title: The Death of the Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: June 18-24; A Grim Trade
description: The growing trade in people transported by criminal gangs from their impoverished lands to Europe produced a grisly new statistic when the bodies of 58 refugees from Fujian province in China were discovered in the overheated and airless container of a Dutch truck when it came ashore from a channel ferry at Dover, in southern England. Two survivors were recovering in a Canterbury hospital. The British police charged the driver, Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, with 58 counts of manslaughter. WARREN HOGE

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota MR2 Spyder; Hugging the Lonesome Highway
description: TO drive the new Toyota MR2 Spyder is to appreciate the Mazda MX-5 Miata all over again. For more than a decade, an eternity for a sports car, the plucky little Mazda roadster has defined the road-going romantic idyll. The Miata is small, even intimate, with a trunk that can handle a couple's bags for a romantic weekend getaway. Leave the golf clubs at home; you're going no farther than the hot tub.

title: Assistance for New Buyers
description: For some people, a few dollars a month can make the difference in buying a home or not. Neighborhood Housing Services, which works to stabilize poorer communities, has devised a program that eliminates a first-time buyer's mortgage insurance premiums.

title: Brownouts in Kenya Highlight Its Chaos and Misrule
description: The generator, somewhere out back, groaned and the bare bulbs blinked. Smokin Wanjala, a lawyer who studies corruption in a nation where there is plenty to study, walked up a dim stairway to his office just before lunchtime.

title: Volunteers Who Offer a Life Line
description: WHEN a single mother of three young sons was trying to cope with the illness of her youngest child, she called on Friends of the Family.

title: Promises in the Sky
description: ONE year ago this month, the nation's major airlines announced that they would make travel more pleasant by improving customer service. Fearing that Congress was about to pass a bill of rights for passengers in response to the increasing chorus of consumer complaints, airline executives pre-empted the government's plans by coming up with their own list of a dozen promises. They vowed to give travelers information about low fares and flight delays. They said they would make a ''reasonable effort'' to feed people who were waiting on runways for hours at a time. They promised to explain frequent-flier rules clearly.

title: The Smart Set
description: At a time when the almighty dollar and MTV define culture, it is refreshing to know that students like these are not only out there, but in an interesting way, defining a new ''hip.''

title: A Poet of Timeless Images Turns to Another Medium
description: FANS of the great Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, whose credits include ''Through the Olive Trees'' and ''Taste of Cherry'' (winner of the Palme d'Or at the Cannes International Film Festival in 1997), are familiar with this signature image: A man alone in his car, driving along the winding contours of bare mountains. Few know that Mr. Kiarostami has spent years traveling the same remote roads, in search of landscapes to photograph.

title: Let the Voters Rule on Mr. Gore
description: Because of her brazen dereliction of duty as attorney general, Janet Reno has now stirred up a political mess for herself and Vice President Al Gore and created an electoral quandary for the public. It turns out that yet another top official in the Justice Department has concluded that Ms. Reno should name a special counsel to investigate Democratic campaign fund-raising irregularities in 1996, especially the activities and statements of Mr. Gore. Had Ms. Reno agreed to such an investigation years ago, as the law clearly required, the public would have answers about the legality of Democratic fund-raising in 1996. Such an inquiry might have exonerated the vice president, just as Robert Ray has closed the Travel Office inquiry with no charges against Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: A Passion That Began At the Water Hole
description: L. JOHN WILKERSON was 7 when he dug up a shiny stone arrowhead at a water hole near the family's small ranch in Elko, Nev. Collecting arrowheads remained a passion throughout his youth, spent among the children of ranchers and Shoshone Indians, and much later, when he returned from college to work summers as a cowboy and do research on the economics of raising cattle in the West. Yet he never dreamed that in finding that arrowhead at the water hole he had taken his first step toward becoming, 50 years later, the president of the Museum of American Folk Art in New York.

title: Thinner: The Male Battle With Anorexia
description: DR. THOMAS HOLBROOK often wonders, as he stands at the lectern and tells his story, what his colleagues in the audience are thinking. Are they disgusted? Bored? Disbelieving? He scans the rows of faces, but finds them without expression.

title: Stacey Roth, Robert Goergen Jr.
description: Stacey Marie Roth, the daughter of Mary E. and Donald C. Roth of Washington, was married yesterday to Robert Blyth Goergen Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Goergen of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Michael R. Moynihan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Students Get Good Look At Look-Good Business
description: As one of their teachers began a lecture, 10 students sat with uncharacteristic attentiveness. That day, instead of looking at blackboards and maps in a drab classroom, they sat in the 37th-floor conference room of a corporate tower, surrounded by cosmetics displays. And instead of No. 2 pencils and erasers, their learning tools were Clinique's 7-Day Scrub Cream, Moisture Surge, Skin Cushion Body Wash and Long Last Soft Shine Lipstick. The lesson: the finer points of promotional packages, taught in part by William Lauder, the president of Clinique.

title: In Nascar, the Deals Are Short-Lived, but the Memories Last Long
description: Every sport has its deals.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Keeneland

title: Jessica Viertel, Stephen Swenson
description: Jessica Viertel, the daughter of Toni W. Viertel and Thomas Viertel, both of New York, is to be married today to Stephen Andrew Swenson, a son of Nancy and James Swenson of Hernando, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, will officiate at the TriBeCa Rooftop in New York.

title: Hilary Glasberg, Joel Goldberg
description: Dr. Hilary Jennifer Glasberg and Dr. Joel Edward Goldberg are to be married today at the Essex House in New York. Rabbi David Hoffman will perform the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRYNIN, EVELYN J.
description: TRYNIN-Evelyn J. On June 22, 2000 at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Adored mother of Margot Aronsohn, Janet and James Stovin. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. She was loved by all who knew her. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday at 10AM. Interment at Knollwood Cemetery.

title: Footlights; In Rock, Spelling Doesn't Count
description: The Y-100 Feztival, at 1:30 p.m. Wednesday at the Blockbuster Sony Entertainment Center in Camden, is as alternative as a radio-friendly music concert can get this summer. From the Stone Temple Pilots who serve up a grinding mix of coherent hard rock to the energetic ska-punk of Gwen Stefani's No Doubt, much of what the current modern rock format represents is showcased here.

title: Happy Birthday, Herman
description: To wish a happy birthday to Herman Melville, Mystic Seaport in Mystic, Conn., annually stages a reading of all 135 chapters of ''Moby-Dick.'' The readings, aboard the whaling ship Charles W. Morgan, begin at noon July 31 and conclude 24 hours later. Singing and costumed actors augment the readings. Visitors can follow along with copies of the book. When the gates close at 5 p.m. on July 31, staff members and volunteers will continue reading through the night, and the public can rejoin the marathon at 9 a.m. At noon Aug. 1, Melville's birthday, a great white cake will be brought out.

title: Footlights
description: Making Practice Perfect

title: Even 'Background' Levels Of Radiation Are Harmful
description: In his letter June 4, saying Brookhaven National Laboratory does not cleaning up because the contamination there is no worse than natural background radiation, Lewis Friedman shows he is uninformed about the health effects of ionizing radiation, regardless of source. With respect to cancers and inherited afflictions, natural radiation is no more benign than man-made radiation.

title: Dot-Com Web Alliance
description: Netcigar.com, a subsidiary of Synergy Brands Inc. of Syosset (Nasdaq: SYBR), announced a link with Thinkersgroup .com to obtain Internet technology and wireless Web applications. Thinkersgroup, of Great River, provides software solutions for gathering and delivering dynamic content for Internet businesses.

title: Joshua Myron, Zionist Who Fought the Turks, Dies at 102
description: Joshua Myron, one of the last of the camel-mounted Zionist brigade that fought with Vladimir Jabotinsky against Turkey in Palestine during World War I, died in Manhattan on June 8. He was 102.

title: War Memories Temper Korean Euphoria
description: As a marine during the Korean War, Chang Kyong Hak saw many of his friends die and nearly lost his own life defending South Korea from invading Communist troops from the North.

title: William A. Liebler, 76, Expert On Injuries in Dance and Sports
description: William A. Liebler, a specialist in sports and dance medicine whose clients included the New York Rangers hockey team, the American Ballet Theater, the New York City Ballet and the Martha Graham Dance Company, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 76.

title: BRIEFING: LEGISLATION; OFF-TRACK BETTING
description: The Assembly Commerce, Tourism, Gaming and Military and Veterans Affairs Committee last week approved a bill that would authorize 15 off-track betting parlors in the state and allow gamblers to place bets over the telephone. The bill follows up a 1998 referendum in which voters granted the legislature the right to set up off-track betting parlors and telephone wagering. KUSHANAVA CHOUDHURY

title: Study Says Gun Traffickers Arm Criminals
description: More than half the investigations of firearms trafficking conducted by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms recovered at least one gun that had been used in other crimes, a study by the bureau has found.

title: Geraldine Bucci, Kevin Keating
description: Geraldine Bucci and Kevin Christopher Keating were married Friday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Jude in Monroe, Conn. The Rev. Joseph Karcsinski performed the ceremony.

title: Gardens That Harness Nature's Healing Powers
description: IT was a sunny day in the garden at the Pleasant Bay Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Brewster, Mass. So sunny that Kaleigh, a yellow Labrador, would not leave the shade of his favorite zelkova tree, where he kept an eye on his human, Bill Ellis, 69, reading in a wheelchair.

title: United States Wins Reining Competition
description: Using the Nations' Cup format adapted from show jumping, the United States equestrian team's reining horse squad won the first internationally sanctioned reining horse competition at the team's Festival of Champions yesterday in Gladstone, N.J.

title: Why Hollywood Asks Them to Strip
description: Sex Sells

title: Hey, Everybody, Let's Start a Hedge Fund!
description: THE newspaper ad for the 90-minute seminar was clear and, apparently, compelling, because it drew more than 250 people to an auditorium in Midtown Manhattan to learn how to start a hedge fund.

title: Bloody Harvest
description: Martin Olds was attacked one day last April just after dawn. A hundred men, many of them armed with AK-47's, arrived in a convoy and opened fire on his farmhouse from six separate ambush positions. He was shot in the leg but managed to attach a makeshift splint and kept his assailants at bay in a furious gun battle for another three hours. A plea for help was made to the nearby police station, but they refused to assist him. Finally his attackers lobbed Molotov cocktails into the house, and when he stumbled out, overcome by the smoke and the heat, they shot him in the head. Then they beat his body to a pulp.

title: At Herricks, Arts Program Lasts Forever
description: ONE is a sound engineer with his own studio in Manhattan who just signed a contract with Disney for the use of a song he wrote for the show ''Who Wants To Be a Millionaire.'' Another received an Emmy Award last month for a PBS documentary series, ''The Souls of New York.'' Another was the first cameraman/ steadicam operator for the film ''Titanic.'' Another produced the first season of ''Once and Again'' for ABC in Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: The table of contents on June 11 misspelled the given name of the author of an article on jetpacks. He is Jaime Wolf, not Jamie.

title: June 18-24; To Deal or Not to Deal
description: With six months left in office and frustrated by the ability of Slobodan Milosevic to keep his job, the Clinton administration is exploring with America's allies suggestions that Yugoslavia's president might leave office if he were given guarantees for his safety and savings, despite his indictment on charges of war crimes in Kosovo. Greece is doing the intermediary work. American spokesmen denied any thought of a bargain, but senior American and NATO officials said differently. STEVEN ERLANGER

title: Jab, Feint, Then, Surprise! The Knockout Combination
description: Although there are no pieces hidden from view like the cards of poker or bridge, chess is also a game of deception. The higher the level of play, the more the outcome depends on penetrating to something the opponent has not fathomed.

title: Sports of The Times; Whaddaya Mean You Don't Wanna Play Here?
description: RANTING, apparently, is in style. Dennis Miller, the new man in the booth for ''Monday Night Football,'' is known for his rants.

title: A Business Venture That Is, Well, Scary
description: RICH BLACK lives and works in a dank basement in his father's house in Ronkonkoma. It is a house of horrors.

title: Corrections
description: A credit for a cartoon last Sunday misspelled the name of the cartoonist, Tom Toles.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Private Sector column on June 4, about the campaign of Larry Otis Graham of Chappaqua, N.Y., for a Congressional seat, misstated the given name of his wife, the chief executive of CNBC.com She is Pamela Thomas-Graham, not Patricia.

title: Wire to Wire in Hempstead, Beautifully
description: Belmont Park was treated to a solo performance of superior strength and speed yesterday when the champion mare Beautiful Pleasure went wire to wire and won the Hempstead Handicap by 7 1/4 lengths.

title: A Tragedy, at Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; String Fever
description: You may have noticed. Risotto and polenta have become ubiquitous in restaurants, yet you can't get a bowl of spaghetti.

title: Corrections
description: An art review on June 11 about a show called ''Welcome'' at the Glyndor House at Wave Hill in the Bronx misidentified the visual arts curator who devised the exhibit. She is Jennifer McGregor; Julia Waters is Wave Hill's assistant director of public relations.

title: Citizen Car Ticketer Should Be Commended
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Somebody Told Me

title: Finding Stolen Moments, Clippers in Hand
description: PASSIONATE commitment does not lend itself to rationing. Just ask any gardener. Most of us would gladly spend hours in our borders. In reality though, most of us are also constrained to earn our livings, raise families, and devote ourselves to the worthy causes and mundane chores that make up a full life.

title: Favorites Have Feast In Tuneup for the Trials
description: As Michael Johnson crossed the finish line at 400 meters, the Hayward Field scoreboard registered 43.16 seconds, two-hundredths of a second below his world record. An excited murmur flashed like static electricity through the crowd. But the scoreboard was wrong. The posted time was like a word passed from student to student in the old classroom game until it bore no resemblance to what was actually said.

title: Nightmares Sprout on the Grassy Courts
description: The strawberries are off the vine, the Pimm's Cups are on ice, the grass courts await their yearly trampling, and the Duke and Duchess of Kent have trophies for everyone who survives the world-famous fortnight: prime time to revisit the top three Wimbledon nightmares of Martina Navratilova, who can't get enough of the temple of tennis, awake or asleep.

title: Money Can Set You Free
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of This Hemisphere
description: IN Cuba the expression ''making a zafra'' which means harvesting sugar cane -- signifies doing well. At the opening of Zafra in January, the father of Maricel Presilla, the Cuban-born chef and an owner, gave her a vibrant mural he had painted, depicting the sugar cane harvest, as a good-luck present.

title: Mendoza Is Yankees' Most Valuable Pitcher
description: Ramiro Mendoza was not even supposed to be in the starting rotation for the Yankees this season. The Yankees had marquee names like David Cone, Roger Clemens, Orlando Hernandez and Andy Pettitte, and they wanted the fifth starter to be the unproven rookie Ed Yarnall. As always, Mendoza was destined to do the grunt work in the bullpen.

title: If You Bought the Brooklyn Bridge, Here's Another One for Sale
description: Did you hear? The Department of Transportation is finally building that bridge from Rye to Oyster Bay. I know because some neighbors told me. They saw it on the Internet. They heard about it in the supermarket. Work crews are widening a road to accommodate it. There is even a photograph of it.

title: Legislator Challenges Spano for Senate Seat
description: IN what could become one of the state's most closely watched political contests, Thomas J. Abinanti, 53, the county legislator from Greenburgh, has announced his second bid to unseat Nicholas A. Spano, 45, the state senator from Yonkers and one of the county's most visible Republican officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, EVELYN
description: KAUFMAN-Evelyn. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Morton L. for 57 and 3/4 years. Loving father of Dr. Richard and Lois, and Dr. Jerome and Elaine. Cherished grandmother of Erika, Lauren and Deborah. Former President of Sisterhood, East Midwood Jewish Center Shaare Torah. Services are at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn (at Avenue L), today at 1:00 PM.

title: Researchers Fix Their Sights on an Elusive Silent Killer
description: OVARIAN cancer has been nicknamed the silent killer because it is difficult to detect. When found, it has often spread beyond the ovaries and is too advanced to cure. Even the symptoms are vague and easily ignored: who hasn't felt bloated and tired from time to time?

title: Susan Adams, Grattan Baldwin
description: Susan Ann Adams and Charles Grattan Baldwin were married yesterday at the Haddam Neck (Conn.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Dr. Mary Klaaren performed the ceremony.

title: Clinton Keeps a Frenetic Fund-Raising Pace
description: They call him the fund-raiser in chief. The money man. The closer. The Democratic Party's biggest draw, elder statesman, marquee attraction. Put him on the bill. Lead him to the podium. Wallets will open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACRAE, CAMERON F.
description: MacRAE-Cameron F. The Board of Directors and the entire CLEARPOOL family mourn the loss of our dear friend and former leader. He provided extraordinary service to CLEARPOOL from 1951 until 1968, guiding the organization with remarkable distinction as President for much of his tenure. His generosity, wisdom and kindness profoundly affected the lives of thousands of children from New York City. Cameron MacRae established a legacy of pro bono legal service at the firm he founded, LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae, that has served CLEARPOOL for over forty years. We extend our condolences to his son Cameron F. MacRae, III and his family. Charles Dombeck, Chairman of the Board Peter Rose, President of the Board CLEARPOOL, Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article last week about the school budget in Bedford misspelled the surname of Philip Christe, a resident, and misstated how he publicized the earnings of top school administrators. He did so in an advertisement in a local newspaper, not a letter to the editor.

title: Simplicity Via Unheard Complication
description: THINK of a music so sure of its power that it need not raise its voice above mezzo piano. Think of graceful arcs of phrase reminiscent of Bellini. The harmonic and rhythmic language is received, not invented, yet its predictabilities are paradoxically filled with surprise. Wonder as well at how such extremes of civility emanate from a region seemingly condemned to political turmoil and chronic violence. What Latin America struggles to achieve in its civic life it produces effortlessly in its musical art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COREYS, SAMUEL A.
description: COREYS-Samuel A. Formerly of Westbury, NY. Died June 14, 2000, in West Palm Beach, FL. Those who knew Sam will always remember his great love of music and the arts and his endless study of their interrelationship with scientific thought. Sam is survived by his devoted wife, Esther, two loving daughters, two beloved sons-in-law and cherished grandchild. He was deeply loved by his family and will be sadly missed by all who have had the privilege of his friendship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPP, ROSALIND THROPE
description: HOPP-Rosalind Thrope. 83, died peacefully on June 23 in New York City. Adored mother of Penny, Nancy, and Robert, and grandmother of David, Jeffrey, Amanda, Marisa, Dana, and Jenna, great-grandmother of Kaitlin, Allison, Ian, Matthew and Eric. Burial service to be held on Monday June 26 at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERMAN, JAMES B.
description: LIBERMAN-James B. At home on June 22, 2000, at age 84. Beloved husband of Deen Freed Liberman and, after her death, of Nadine C. Zamichow, Father of Lee Liberman Otis and the late John Liberman, Father-in-law of Mary Beth Liberman Traynor and William G. Otis, Grandfather of Harry, Dean, Emma, Bert, Jessie, Zachary, Bernie and Audrey. Cherished Brother of Lee Liberman. A gentleman of exceptional generosity, dignity, modesty and achievement, graduate of Yale Law School and Chairman of its 60th Reunion Class last year, United States Army during World War II, General Counsel of General Public Utilities, Founding partner of Berlack, Israel and Liberman, recently joined Thelen Reid and Priest. Contributions may be made to the Yale Law School or The Federalist Society. Memorial Services at Temple Emanu-El, One East 65th Street, Monday, June 26, at 11 AM.

title: If These Walls Could Talk
description: Mockingbird Years

title: Coping With Luxury Fever
description: IT'S a puzzling sight -- and, frankly, a vaguely comic one. On a beautiful spring morning, a few minutes before 8, a parade of vehicles -- many the glossy, leather-appointed, cupholder-laden destroyers favored by today's suburbanites -- make their way slowly along a driveway to the front door of the Dobbs Ferry High School. There, after clawing through this jungle of a traffic jam, they drop off their charges -- healthy, fully ambulatory teenagers.

title: PATIENT POWER; Turning a Medical Mountain Into a Manageable Molehill
description: DR. VICTOR STRECHER, the associate director for cancer prevention and control at the University of Michigan's Comprehensive Cancer Center in Ann Arbor, is well aware of the profound influence of the Internet on the practice of medicine. ''Huge numbers of my patients,'' he said, ''come in with stacks of information from the Web and demand, 'See, this is what I've learned; now, what do you know?' ''

title: Cutting the Bach Choir Down to Size
description: ON this 250th anniversary of the death of Bach or in any other year, there can be few musicological questions more pressing than that of how the composer's music sounded when it was being performed for the first time, week after week, under his direction in St. Thomas's Church in Leipzig, Germany. Light is now being shed on this subject by one of the leading practitioners of early music, the English conductor Andrew Parrott, in performances, recordings and a book, ''The Essential Bach Choir'' (University of Rochester Press).

title: An Early Warning for Parkinson's
description: PARKINSON'S disease, which affects about one million Americans, is a progressive, incurable illness in which the death of brain cells leads to loss of muscle control, paralysis and, in the worst cases, death. It is usually diagnosed with a PET scan, but the positron emission tomography machines that do the scans are expensive, and only a handful exist in American hospitals.

title: Where Streets Are the Threat To Scholars
description: LIKE so many young people growing up in besieged neighborhoods, Muhamed Berte grew tired enough to quit. Tired of violence, tired of despair, tired of poverty and cynicism. But his mother, who learned to read and write as an adult, told him that there was no progress without struggle. So Mr. Berte kept at school and work, turning his back on the streets.

title: Mizrahi Models His Latest, a Cabaret Act
description: WHEN Isaac Mizrahi abandoned fashion two years ago, thus reducing by 100 percent the number of designers who whimsically affixed fur doughnuts to women's suits, he announced that he would focus his energy on a career in show business.

title: June 18-24; Bumps on the Road to Nomination
description: Democrats were livid over a rival of Vice President Al Gore in the race for president. ''He's on an ego trip,'' said Senator Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat. ''He has no respect for the process.''

title: Business; In Praise of the Freedom to Take Chances
description: JEFFREY PFEFFER, co-author of ''The Knowing-Doing Gap,'' teaches organizational behavior at Stanford University, in the heart of Silicon Valley. In an interview, he described how Internet companies in particular could learn to put their best ideas into practice. Following are excerpts from the conversation. FRED ANDREWS

title: Man's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Russell Had Another First
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERSON, JOHN
description: GERSON-John, June 20, 1997. Three years without you. Sadly missed now and forever. All my love, E.G.

title: Kristen Gerard, Graham Saladino
description: Kristen Rose Gerard, a daughter of Charles and Terry Gerard of Northford, Conn., was married yesterday to Graham Hendrick Saladino at Robin Hill, the country home of the bridegroom's father, the interior designer John Saladino. The Rev. Ronald D'Angelo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Competition and Camaraderie for Gay Athletes
description: When Laura Moore was growing up, she dreamed of being an Olympic figure skater. While living in East Africa, she read a book about a poor, sickly child befriended by a star skater. The sickly girl became the star.

title: Ostrovsky's 'Forest' Casts Bewitching Spell
description: THE artistic alliance between the director Bonnie J. Monte and the playwright Aleksandr Ostrovsky is becoming more like an affair of the heart. People are talking.

title: A TV Family That Happens to Be Latino
description: Dad works hard at an auto repair shop. In his off hours, he and his oldest son head for the neighborhood gym where they're training the middle son, a boxer with a shot at the championship. The youngest son is a pre-med student at U.C.L.A. The older daughter works as a paralegal at a Beverly Hills firm. The younger daughter is in high school and has been hanging out with the wrong crowd. Their dead mother's sister, who lives across the street, owns a beauty salon and spends a lot of time with the family, which also includes a brain-damaged uncle.

title: A Very Big Picnic For Bastille Day
description: On July 14, tanks will roll down the Champs-Elysees and fighter planes will swoop overhead for the traditional military parade that marks the birthday of the French Republic. Across the nation, there will be fireworks and open-air dances.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-25-00; Competitive States of America
description: The ancient Greeks -- and after them, Hollywood -- were clear about what happens to the greatest competitors, and it wasn't pretty. Sure, they vanquish all opposition, but then in Act 2, with no one in sight who might pose a legitimate challenge, they grow fat and complacent. And in Act 3, just when they least expect it. . . . Looking at Bill Gates on television these days -- at his untamed shag, his Redmond casual attire, his benevolent photo ops with school kids and politicians -- you have to wonder: did he ever so much as consider the possibility that he might lose? That the government might win? That he might ever meet a rival whom he couldn't, by pressures subtle or overt, simply crush?

title: Fishing for Bass, and Big Profits
description: THE phone rings and Irwin L. Jacobs, the fabled corporate raider of the 1980's, cannot hide his emotions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHLIN, GREGORY N., M.D
description: ROCHLIN-Gregory N., M.D. of Cambridge, on Monday, June 19, 2000. Husband of Helen (Buker) Rochlin. Father of Martha (Rochlin) Kapos of London and Gregory M. Rochlin of Cambridge. Also survived by 3 grandchildren Andrea M. Kapos and Peter B. Kapos both of London and Katherine F. Rochlin of Cambridge. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend a Memorial Service on Friday, June 30th in the Story Chapel of Mount Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge, Mass at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Health Care Dimensions, 254 South St., Waltham, MA 02453-2707 or Perkins Institute for the Blind, 175 No. Beacon St., Watertown, MA 02172. For information call J.S. Waterman - Eastman - Waring Funeral Service, 495 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, MA. 02215 (617) 536-4110.

title: A Happy Gathering of the Ballets Russes
description: EVERYONE kissed everyone else and the kisses were wonderful to behold. People kissed on lecture platforms, in a hotel lobby, at an art gallery, at receptions. There were delighted cries of, ''My dear, I haven't seen you for 50 years!'' And the remark was not hyperbole. Happy tears flowed like Champagne. Champagne also flowed.

title: When Fillings Were in Favor: A Short History of My Teeth
description: PIECE by piece my body is being plundered by time. ''Wear and tear in exchange for experience and wisdom'' is my mother's reasoned thinking about the physical changes that accompany aging. And while I accept this with relative ease, I dispute the equation vigorously when it comes to teeth.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Memory Trouble? Maybe Your Brain Just Needs a Workout
description: AS more baby boomers creep into middle age and forget where they put their glasses, keeping the brain sharp and functioning is taking on a new urgency. Fortunately, there are ways to maintain a nimble mind, reduce the effects of aging on the brain and ensure that the little hamster runs around the wheel at a healthy pace.

title: The Valley of Death, Another Boomer Test
description: AMERICANS still work out at health clubs because it is not yet fashionable to get sick and die. But in a few years, the baby boomers are going to be entering the prime perishing years, and we all know what that means. They're going to turn dying into a form of self-expression.

title: QUICK BITE/Cedar Grove; The Pilgrim's Progress
description: In high school, my friends and I made the Pilgrim Diner our late-night hangout. Even though we were from Verona and the Pilgrim was in rival Cedar Grove territory, we made a beeline for the place most weekends. We'd sit for hours in the worn-out booths, depositing quarter after quarter in the table-side jukeboxes and singing along with Bon Jovi. Since there was a $2 minimum per person, we would always order something -- maybe French fries with mozzarella and gravy, a Pilgrim staple -- and then scrape together whatever money was left for a tip. We graduated from high school in 1995. Since then, although it still welcomes students in search of a late-night snack, the Pilgrim has graduated from diner to restaurant. When the Diakos family took over several years ago, they had the place gutted, and when it reopened after a year of renovations, almost nothing was the same. The tableside jukeboxes are gone and the menu is far different. Instead of the usual greasy-spoon fare, it now includes such cuisine as wraps named after rap artists (get it?). For $7.95, you can order a Tupac, for example, a Southwestern-style wrap filled with grilled chicken, refried beans, jalapeno peppers, guacamole, cheddar cheese, salsa and Spanish rice. Or, if you're a vegetarian, you might consider the Queen Latifah ($6.95), which includes zucchini, carrots, avocados, red and green peppers, onions and tomatoes; it is complemented by rice and beans. There is filet mignon ($17.95) too, and twin lobster tails ($24.95). Which is not to say that diner staples like hamburgers ($4.95 for a deluxe with lettuce, tomato and French fries) are not available. There's still a $2 miminum, and hungry students can still order fries with cheese and gravy ($4.50). And those students can still play Bon Jovi tunes, but only on one large jukebox, so everyone can hear, and it they want to, sing along. SARAH TREFFINGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, ELIZABETH
description: LAWRENCE-Elizabeth. Star of film, radio, stage and television, packed her backpack Friday, June 9 and started on a new adventure. Her films include ''Four Friends,'' ''The Crucible,'' ''Sleeping with the Enemy,'' ''The Butcher's Wife,'' ''Isn't She Wonderful?'', and an untitled film finished the day she died. Stage roles included ''Strange Interlude,'' with Glenda Jackson, ''Look Homeward, Angel'' with Anthony Perkins, and ''A Matter of Gravity'' with Katharine Hepburn. Early radio days brought her fame in soaps from which she transfered to television soaps and became famous playing ''Myra'' in ''All My Children'' for over five years. An expert in the field of autism, she saved hundreds of children from the darkness. Greenthumbed, she kept East 26th St. & Second Avenue a lush paradise. Environmentalist and lover of children she not only saved all the children, she saved all the trees in Murray Hill. If there were more than 30 hours to stay awake, one could understand how Liz could keep on such a path with growing and giving. She brought incredible hope to me dealing with my own struggle in the theatre and with my own struggle with the AIDS virus. I was not the only one she helped. Somehow she found the time to gather an armful of friends for coffee and compassion when the world seemed to be filled with too much pain. On Friday, Ms. Lawrence, who often said she had lived a glorious life, passed ''through the looking glass.'' I was fortunate that she loved my 60-year-old theatre stories, she helped me laugh. She can be seen on reruns every night of the week on television, and when you watch the way she works you may have some idea what ''civilized'' means. A memorial will be held the second week of July. Please call Sidney Morris, phone 212-541-6873.

title: The Pressure To Take It Off
description: When it comes to nudity, actresses are just like you and me -- self-conscious, vain, insecure, eager to please and sometimes miserable. Except that when they take their clothes off, they have to do it in front of the people they work with, knowing that they have little if any control over how the images of their naked bodies -- which will then be projected onto 30-foot screens in front of millions of complete strangers -- will ultimately be presented in the context of the finished project. And that their families will probably see them. And their friends. And that owing to the miracle of video rental, the Internet and enormous media interest, these images will be preserved, if not forever, at least for long enough that whatever the actresses' original thoughts about getting naked were, they'll probably have second, third and fourth thoughts about it.

Harrison voters, by 2,190 to 1,784, supported the $56.6 million budget, reduced by about $1.6 million. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, MICKEY
description: HAYES-Mickey, died June 14 in Beverly Hills, California. He was eighty-seven. Hayes was a Miami Beach resident for more than fifty years. Born in New York, he began his career as a window dresser for men's shops. He moved to Miami Beach in 1945 and opened a men's clothing store on Lincoln Road. A year later, he moved to Roney Plaza Hotel where he became a fixture for over twenty years, known as the store ''where the stars shop''. Celebrities on the Miami Beach nightclub circuit touted his wares. Pictures throughout the store featured Hayes's famous friends: Sinatra, Don Rickles, Lucille Ball, etc. In 1957 an advertisement in The Miami Herald listed one hundred three stars who patronized his shop including Tony Bennett, Milton Berle, Red Buttons, Jan Murray, Sid Caesar, Jimmy Durante and Liberace. In 1966 the store moved to 23rd and Collins, with Buddy Hackett and Alan King cutting the opening ribbon. He remained there until 1985 when at seventy-two he retired, planning to live half of each year in Beverly Hills and half in Miami Beach. Mickey has contributed a significant portion of his estate to South Florida Charities. Anyone wishing to make a charitable contribution in Mickey's honor should contact Danny Welkes at 310657-5000.

title: Last Lap in the Genome Race

The publicly financed Human Genome Project has put together a ''working draft'' of the genome, while Celera Genomics, a private company, has completed its ''first assembly'' of the genome. Neither side in this bitter rivalry has deciphered every single chemical unit of the human genetic material -- that is not possible with today's technology -- but each side has made tremendous contributions toward what future historians will surely rate as a pivotal scientific achievement, ushering in an exciting new stage of biological exploration.

They applied breakneck velocity for sheer momentum and for lavish ornamentation; they also drew from it a shimmering, pointillistic delicacy that offered tranquillity within all the fast finger work.

Not so Gregory Wolfe, the director of Moonwork's majestic production. He has a chorus from Greek tragedy in mind -- 22 actors embodying what Mr. Wolfe takes to be the audience's reaction to the tragedy.

title: Jerome Richardson, 79, a Flutist And Saxophonist in Demand

title: PULITZER MAKES DEAL TO TAKE OVER 38 SUBURBAN WEEKLIES

Pulitzer said the Suburban Journals, which had sales of about $51 million in 1999, would be run independently of The Post-Dispatch. No job cuts are planned. By buying the Suburban Journals, Pulitzer expects to save on newsprint, real estate and other costs in the home area of its flagship newspaper.

title: VALSPAR AGREES TO BUY LILLY INDUSTRIES, A RIVAL
description: The Valspar Corporation, a manufacturer of paints and coatings, agreed to buy a rival, Lilly Industries, for $762 million to expand its product line and cut costs. Valspar will pay $31.75 in cash for each share of Lilly, based in Indianapolis, almost 2.5 times Lilly's closing price Friday, or about $762 million total. The company also will assume $213 million in debt. Valspar, which makes corrosion protection for metal products and has more than $1.4 billion in annual sales, wants to use savings from the acquisition to offset rising raw materials costs. Valspar said some of Lilly's 39 plants might be closed.

title: Traveler's Tricks for Riding Out The Waves of Motion Sickness
description: I've known since childhood that I was susceptible to motion sickness. I never could read in the back seat of a car, and in my early 20's I got queasy as a passenger riding down a winding mountain road (though I was fine if I drove). But I hadn't experienced the full-blown syndrome until I took my sons on a fishing boat in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: A Historic Chance for Conservation
description: The most important land conservation bill in many years is now before the United States Senate, and time is running out. The bill, which passed the House in May by a resounding margin despite the opposition of the House Republican leadership, would set aside nearly $3 billion a year, most of it guaranteed, to buy parks and open space, provide wildlife protection and restore damaged coastlines. The House bill was largely the handiwork of two members who rarely agree on anything -- California's George Miller, a Democrat and staunch conservationist, and Alaska's Don Young, a Republican who has been fighting environmentalists for most of his career but who, on the verge of retirement, has done a surprising about-face.

title: Where the Genome Leads Us

The moral overtones in much of the commentary have favored the Human Genome Project, led by Francis Collins and financed by the National Institutes of Health, over the profit-driven Celera Genomics and its flamboyant lead scientist, J. Craig Venter. But what the race really demonstrates is the value of scientific competition.

title: RUSSIA TO RAISE OIL TAX
description: The Russian government will impose at least a 35 percent increase on a crude oil export tax on Aug. 1, a move to provide additional budget revenue from rising world demand and higher prices. Russia will raise the duty to 27 euros, or about $25 a metric ton, from the current 20 euros, Russian news agencies quoted Deputy Prime Minister Viktor Khristenko. If the price of oil exceeds $29 a barrel on Aug. 1, the government will raise the duty to 34 euros a metric ton -- a 70 percent increase.

The billing was to have brought together Puente and the pianist Eddie Palmieri, two titans of Latin music who had just made an album together, ''Masterpiece,'' due for release in July. After Puente's death on May 31, the concert was split between Mr. Palmieri's group and a showcase for singers who record for the same label Mr. Palmieri does, RMM.

title: UNCERTAIN FUTURE FOR FREESERVE
description: Shares of Britain's largest Internet service provider, Freeserve, were pummeled after the company confirmed that talks to be acquired by Deutsche Telekom's Internet arm, T-Online, had collapsed and that a takeover of the company in the near future was unlikely. Freeserve's stock fell 17 percent, to 365 pence, or about $5.48. Shares of Freeserve's parent, the Dixons Group, a British electronics retailer, which owns 80 percent of the company, fell 7 percent, to 263.5 pence. Freeserve also said it lost $:5.8 million, or about $8.7 million, in its fourth quarter. The results met analysts' expections. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: LYCOS AGREES TO BUY METROSPLASH.COM FOR $44 MILLION
description: Lycos Inc., the Internet-search service being bought by Terra Networks S. A., agreed to buy MetroSplash.com for $44 million in cash to add Matchmaker.com's online personal ads to its network of Web sites. In buying MetroSplash, which is closely held, Lycos adds a Web site ranked No. 1 among online dating sites in terms of how much time users spend at the site. Lycos has been adding Internet sites to its community of Web sites in an effort to generate more advertising revenue to compete with rivals like Yahoo and Go.com. Matchmaker.com has about four million members.

In addition, Babs had many friends, including in-laws, Hazel Scott, and nieces and nephews. Babs will be sadly missed by her many friends as well as her caregivers. Babs and her husband have been members of the Banyan Country Club for many years and have been active members as well as substantial contributors to many charities such as the Israel Cancer Association, Weizmann Institute of Science, American Society for Technion, Ben-Gurion University and Johns Hopkins University. Services will be held Wednesday at 12:00 p.m. at the LevittWeinstein Memorial Chapels 5411 Okeechobee Blvd., West Palm Beach, followed by a reception at the Leibowitt residence. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Israel Cancer Association, 230 Royal Palm Way, suite 210, Palm Beach, Florida 33480.

title: The Court Reaffirms Miranda
description: The Supreme Court yesterday reaffirmed one of the finest legacies of Chief Justice Earl Warren's era -- the court's Miranda ruling of 1966, which requires police to advise suspects of their rights before beginning an interrogation. Seven members of the court chose to uphold Miranda's constitutional vitality, and the majority decision was written by one of the court's more conservative members, Chief Justice William Rehnquist. That should help discourage future efforts to portray Miranda's sensible safeguards against coercion as an extreme and extraconstitutional ''milestone of judicial overreaching,'' which is how Justice Antonin Scalia sought to depict them in a dissent joined by Justice Clarence Thomas.

From the late 1960's to the early 90's, when this Japanese-born dancer was based in New York, she was known for works depicting existence as an endless struggle. She returned to Japan in 1992 and has visited New York only occasionally since then. Yet ''The Absence of Izanagi,'' the new 35-minute solo she offered on Thursday night at the Annex at La MaMa, suggested that she remains concerned with existential ordeals.

title: AT&T UNIT TAKES PART IN JOINT CABLE TELEVISION VENTURE
description: Liberty Media Group, the AT&T Corporation's cable television programming unit, and UnitedGlobalCom agreed to combine most of their international cable businesses in a transaction worth $4.02 billion. Liberty will provide stakes in cable businesses in Britain, Argentina, Puerto Rico and Mexico to UnitedGlobalCom in exchange for $200 million in cash and a 72 percent voting interest. UnitedGlobalCom, which controls Europe's No. 2 cable company and businesses in Australia and Chile, will keep management control. Liberty will gain access to more countries outside the United States, where AT&T is the largest cable and long-distance company. UnitedGlobalCom will become the biggest cable company in Latin America and get an option to acquire more of Liberty's overseas holdings. The combined companies will have about 14.5 million subscribers.

description: Spurred by two pharmaceutical companies that want to take their cholesterol-lowering medications over the counter, the Food and Drug Administration is considering whether many more medicines -- from antibiotics to birth control pills -- should be made available without a doctor's prescription.

title: Hold the Syrup
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: No Longer Just Another Gig; After a Strike Over Absenteeism, City Ballet Musicians Are Changing Course
description: The British conductor Andrea Quinn, who takes over as the music director of the New York City Ballet in August of next year, brings some clear attributes to the job: youth, dynamism, solid musicianship, long involvement with 20th-century music and a wealth of pragmatic experience as the music director of the Royal Ballet in London. The City Ballet orchestra musicians, who were involved in the selection process, are said to be excited by the appointment. And Ms. Quinn, 35, who has been a guest conductor with City Ballet, is eager to join it full time.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about Vice President Al Gore's plan to encourage consumers to buy clean-energy products misstated the environmental impact of carbon dioxide. It is a heat-trapping gas associated with global warming, not a component of smog.

title: Subway Plan Stalls for Rocker
description: John Rocker may not be riding the No. 7 train to Shea Stadium after all, but his pending four-day visit remains a headache, and police officials said yesterday that undercover police officers would be in the stands to protect the Atlanta Braves pitcher from unruly fans.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Proof That There's Nothing That Can't Be Improved
description: MEASURING spoons have a clear purpose and a simple design that you would think should be foolproof. And yet, aside from the food processor with all its parts, there may be no other tool that can be more of a pain in the neck to use and clean. There are those bound by an inseparable ring, so that every time you use one, you must clean them all. There are others with seams that catch specks of flour or grease, and those that inevitably spill their contents when set down on a counter.

title: Airlines Are Faulted on Candor and Promises
description: Airlines, required to tell their passengers if a flight will be delayed, often blame air traffic control, even if the real reason is bad weather, a shortage of crew members or maintenance problems, the Transportation Department said in a report today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HALPERN, RICHARD L.
description: HALPERN-Richard L. May 18, 1948-June 28, 1992. As always, we miss you. Mom, Dad and Robert

title: CAR AUCTION NETWORK PLANS TO BUY 9 AUCTION SITES
description: Minnesota Power Inc., owner of North America's No. 2 wholesale auto auction network, said yesterday that it would buy nine auto auction sites for more than $160 million to expand its business in the West and the South. The nine auctions are from the Atlanta-based Cox Enterprises Inc.'s Manheim Auctions unit, the world's biggest auto-auction company. Together, the nine auctions sold about 400,000 vehicles and had about $130 million in revenue for the year ended March 31. A week ago, Minnesota Power, which is based in Duluth, bought the Canadian Auction Group, which owns 13 auction sites in Canada.

title: Bid to Keep Apple Tours Closed Is Rejected
description: New York Apple Tours' red double-decker buses, which have been banished from the city's streets for nearly a month, may be rolling again as early as this weekend. On Monday, a panel of state appellate judges rejected an attempt by the city and state to sideline the buses while they try to shut the company down permanently.

title: Brazil Weighs Foreign Investment in Media Companies
description: Congress is scheduled to vote Wednesday on a constitutional amendment that would allow foreigners to invest in the country's media companies, ending a prohibition that has lasted for 66 years.

title: Success of Zimbabwe's Opposition Signifies Big Changes
description: In a pointed rejection of President Robert Mugabe, voters here have taken away what was his governing party's almost unchallenged authority in Parliament by electing a powerful, new opposition party to more than a third of the seats.

title: What Have They Done To My Ice Cream Now?
description: When I first tasted Frosty Bites at Sassy's Sliders, 1530 Third Avenue (86th Street), they reminded me of the nuggets of freeze-dried astronaut ice cream that every parent who takes children to the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum in Washington feels compelled to buy. Frosty Bites, ice cream bits the size of peppercorns, do have a futuristic quality, but they taste a lot better than freeze-dried. They are served in a cup, and you spoon them up like breakfast cereal. The sensation is a little odd, since they lack the softly melting surface of a scoop of ice cream. I can't imagine a rippled flavor like vanilla-fudge or caramel swirl being satisfying in this form, but for crunchy Oreo cookie it's just fine. Frosty Bites are $3.25 a portion and also come in vanilla, chocolate, strawberry, mint-chocolate and rainbow sorbet. Mixing's allowed.

title: Helping Principals Learn to Use Business Management Skills
description: Throughout the New York City school system, principals and other administrators are increasingly being asked to take a business approach -- rather than an educational one -- to problem solving. From the chancellor's quarters of Harold O. Levy, a former corporate executive, to the principal's office, where administrators are being given more authority over budgeting, a new attitude is being fostered.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: A School's Grandpa

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: When the Nautical Meets the Political

title: 'Survivor' And CBS
description: The ''Survivor'' connection to CBS News will be extended next week when the news magazine program ''48 Hours'' broadcasts a segment featuring two of that adventure show's contestants in an edition devoted to the subject ''The Price of Fame.''

title: Politicizing Gasoline Prices
description: Few politicians have been able to resist exploiting public anger over $2-a-gallon gasoline in the Midwest. But none have shed much light on the subject. Vice President Al Gore suspects that oil companies are gouging customers, and he would not mind if voters took revenge on Gov. George W. Bush, a former oil company executive. Mr. Bush accuses the administration of having sat back while OPEC tripled the price of crude oil. He also cites Mr. Gore's book on the environment to suggest that Mr. Gore thinks gas prices are too low to begin with. Others have called for relaxing environmental standards.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: The Big City; Losing Money On the Birds Or Bombers
description: WHEN a politician anywhere in America wants to build a stadium, it is customary to make a pilgrimage here to Oriole Park at Camden Yards. New York City officials have already performed the ritual twice. In 1998 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani came to watch the Yankees play and personally inspected the luxury sky boxes.

title: Per-Pupil Spending Significantly Exceeds Peak Reached Before Recession in Early 90's
description: For the first time in a decade, inflation-adjusted spending on public school students in New York City has significantly exceeded the peak it reached before the city plunged into recession in the early 1990's, the Board of Education reported yesterday.

title: Kelley Is a Suicide; Won 1936 Heisman
description: Larry Kelley, the Yale end who won the Heisman Trophy as college football's top player in 1936, was found dead at his home in Hightstown, N.J., yesterday of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was 85.

title: AIRLINE DEBT SETTLEMENT
description: An Alberta court has approved a proposal by Canadian Airlines to settle with creditors holding 3.5 billion Canadian dollars ($2.4 billion) worth of debt, paving the way for its integration with Air Canada of Montreal. Canadian Airlines was bought by its larger and healthier rival in January for 92 million Canadian dollars, or about $63 million, and in March was forced to seek protection from creditors. Under the court-approved restructuring plan, Canadian Airlines' secured creditors will get 97 percent of what they are owed, while unsecured creditors will get 14 percent. The Calgary-based carrier's chief executive, Paul Brotto, said integration with Air Canada could come this year. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Capriati Finds Her Way With Her Father's Help
description: A bewildered Jennifer Capriati once searched out a coach capable of salvaging the confidence she had lost during the haze of her dysfunctional disappearance from tennis. With her spirits in a puddle, she found a faith healer of sorts in Harold Solomon to push her through a remarkable revival last year.

title: The Search for Encores to a Nonevent
description: A year ago, they were the highest-profile technology managers ever, making presentations to top executives and corporate boards, testifying before Congress and spending billions of dollars as the world worked feverishly to avert computer chaos as the year 2000 arrived.

title: Trade Center Leasing Project Goes Forward
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has begun moving on a major project that was delayed for nearly a year as the governors of the two states squabbled over the agency's spending: leasing the World Trade Center to private interests.

title: Army Hires Burnett In Recruiting Campaign
description: The Army has ended an unusually public review for its account, with ad spending estimated at $95 million annually, by hiring a new lineup of agencies led by Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago, part of the B Com3 Group.

title: Business Travel; It's summer, and air traffic delays are starting to pile up as the nation's airport traffic increases.
description: SUMMER is here, business travelers! Time to glare at those airport tote boards and boil.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the acquisition of the interactive science fiction assets of Centropolis Entertainment by USA Networks Interactive misidentified the creator of the Web character WhirlGirl. She was created by Visionary Media, an independent production company in New York, not USA Networks Interactive.

title: The Classic With a Pornographic Pedigree
description: It was on Thanksgiving Day in Dublin in 1949 that J. P. Donleavy had the idea for the novel that would change his life. He and his friends, many of them Americans studying at Trinity College on the G.I. Bill, were leaving the school. They were all headed in different directions, professionally as well as geographically.

McMahon. Mother of Gabrielle Jazwiecki, Christine Pike and the late Patricia McMahon. Mother-ln-law of Leonard Jazwiecki and Dennis Pike, and proud grandmother of James and Ryder Jazwiecki. title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Gas Prices Under Scrutiny
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said today that Midwest gasoline prices were still too high and that the Clinton administration was working to alleviate refinery problems and investigating oil companies for ''potential price fixing.'' Gasoline at the pump has fallen 7 to 12 cents a gallon in the Midwest the last week. Before last week, gasoline prices had surged for eight straight weeks.

title: Sports of The Times; The Yanks Don't Need Sosa's K's
description: IN all the conversations about Sammy Sosa, two numbers are invariably mentioned, 66 and 63, his total of home runs for the Chicago Cubs in the past two seasons. Hardly anybody has mentioned the numbers 174, 171 and 171, his total of strikeouts for the Chicago Cubs in the past three seasons.

title: Flash Trend: Custom Tossing
description: Delis and other food shops are suddenly offering custom-made salads assembled by a designated tosser from ingredients of the customer's choosing, or from a set menu. Perhaps they got the idea from Tossed, a salad spot with locations on Park Avenue South and at Rockefeller Center. Could the salad bar the size of a football field, with lunchtime crowds picking over the goods, be on its way out?

title: Assad's Son Designated Sole Candidate for Syrian Presidency
description: As Hafez al-Assad, absolute ruler of Syria for 30 years, slipped into a final coma several days before he died on June 10, his closest circle of aides and advisers worked swiftly behind the scenes in Damascus to ensure that his untested 34-year-old son would have a smooth, well orchestrated ascension to power.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose against the dollar as investors bet the interest-rate gap between Europe and the United States will narrow. In New York, the euro settled at 94.63 cents, up from 93.83 cents on Monday.

title: Italian Jews Denounce Vatican's Decision to Beatify Pius IX
description: To Vatican historians, Pius IX was the pope who locked papal infallibility and the Immaculate Conception of the Virgin Mary into church doctrine.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Changing Designs, A Project Revives
description: In 1985, 20 years after the blackout that plunged much of the Northeast into darkness, New York commemorated the anniversary with a festival called Urban Light. Among the enthusiastic participants, even though it would not formally open for another year, was the International Design Center in Long Island City, Queens, for which the architectural firm of I. M. Pei & Partners designed the master plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDINDER, FLORENCE
description: EIDINDER-Florence. Tifereth Israel-Town and Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member of long standing and extends heartfelt condolences to her husband Albert and the entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Asst Rabbi Abby Sosland Carol J. Green, President

title: New Law On Lobbying Brings Jump In Fines
description: The state lobbying commission assessed $133,600 in fines today, quadruple what it levied in all of 1998, in a sign that a new lobbying law and a get-tough attitude by the commission are affecting a culture of lax compliance with disclosure rules.

title: Reno Defends Her Decision On Inquiry Of Campaign
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today at a Senate hearing that no one ever pressured her into deciding to refuse to seek an outside prosecutor to investigate President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore for their political fund-raising activities during the 1996 campaign.

title: Hearst, Man and Mogul: Going Beyond the Myths
description: THE CHIEF

title: You Can Paint This Corporate Benefit Gray
description: The number of American households that cared for parents or relatives afflicted with the infirmities of old age tripled between 1988 and 1996, to 21 million from 7 million. And corporate America was quick to lend a helping hand.

title: Nets Look At Options With No. 1 Draft Pick
description: The safe and logical pick is to go with the sure thing, the player who will help you next season, the power forward from Cincinnati who can block shots, rebound, score inside and fill the void left by the imminent retirement of Jayson Williams. But the latest high school phenom is also available, and in four years, while Cincinnati's Kenyon Martin could be very good, East St. Louis High's Darius Miles could be sensational.

title: On Edge but Optimistic, New York Blacks Offer Complex Views in Poll
description: Black residents of New York City are afraid of being brutalized by the police, but they welcome and appreciate officers who keep criminals out of their neighborhood.

title: Conde Nast Set To Close Down A Magazine
description: After less than four years of publication, Women's Sports & Fitness, an enthusiast magazine for women that was perhaps best known for featuring the volleyball player Gabrielle Reece on its cover more times than any other magazine in the world -- will cease publication with the September issue.

Donations for the family can be made to The Jeffrey Willick Memorial Fund, c/o Stanford Federal Credit Union, P.O. Box 10690, Palo Alto, CA 94303-0843.

title: New York Joins the Gun Suits
description: In two important new cases, New York State and New York City have filed lawsuits against gun manufacturers for injuries to their citizens from unsafe and illegal weapons. Attorney General Eliot Spitzer filed the first state lawsuit in the country on Monday with a forceful new argument that gun makers are contributing to a public nuisance by flooding the state with illegal firearms. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's lawsuit against gun makers last week also lends a powerful political voice to the gun control debate, since he is the first Republican mayor to join more than 30 communities taking the manufacturers to court. For that reason, Mr. Giuliani helps rob the nation's gun makers of their expectation that the issue will go away if more Republicans are elected this November.

title: In a Crowd of Braves, Rocker Stands Alone
description: John Rocker strolled into the visiting clubhouse at Olympic Stadium by himself this afternoon, shouted to a few teammates and did not receive much of a response. Rocker approached the picnic table where a few Atlanta Braves were playing cards and tossed a piece of crumpled paper at the strength coach. It hit the coach, who looked up at Rocker and then returned to studying his cards.

title: Naive Detective Packing Goofy Malapropisms
description: Few filmmakers are as generous toward actors as Alan Rudolph. That's why they flock to be in his films, even though the chances of a box office hit are next to nil. Like his actor-friendly mentor, Robert Altman, Mr. Rudolph is a maverick who has always gone his own way, strewing behind him a filmography (now 17 movies), the bulk of which might be described as ambitious failures.

title: Michel Richard
description: WHEN I was a child in the Champagne region, my mother served us a dessert called gateau de semoule. It may sound exotic, but it's really just a cake made of semolina, the same as the American breakfast cereal Cream of Wheat. Its grainy, creamy texture was so soothing.

title: Coin Flip Goes in U.S. Team's Favor
description: The United States women have become accustomed to dramatic finishes but never before have they had to rely on something as obscure and unsatisfying as a coin toss.

description: CONBOY-Marie. Forever loved, forever remembered. Always in our hearts and thoughts. Jack, Julie, Fred, Lauren and Mike

title: Endgame Arrives at Last In the Sosa Trade Talks
description: The Sammy Sosa trade talks envelop the Yankees like a fog that won't go away. But the president of the Cubs wants the discussions settled, one way or the other. And the Yankee manager, Joe Torre, has suggested to club executives that for the good of the team, they should make a deal or move on.

title: THE BOSS; Big on Peaks
description: After high school, I moved to Santa Cruz, Calif., to go to college. This was before the big earthquake, and before the city was rebuilt, and Santa Cruz had a very dark underside. I got into racing motorcycles there, which will be news to my mother when she reads this. In my sophomore year, I moved to San Diego and promptly got into a motorcycle accident down there.

title: Report Faults Energy Dept. as Failing to Gain Lab Staff's Support for Tighter Security
description: The Energy Department has failed to convince scientists at the government's nuclear weapons laboratories of the need for tougher security and counterintelligence measures to prevent espionage, according to a new Congressional report.

description: Leon Johnson, the versatile running back whose career was threatened recently by knee surgery, was cut outright by the Jets yesterday.

title: Clinton's Drug Plan Attacked by Industry
description: First, the drug makers rolled out advertisements featuring ''Flo,'' an arthritic bowler who warned against a Clinton administration proposal for a new Medicare prescription drug benefit. Now the industry is enticing twenty-somethings to call their grandparents and urge them to lobby against the Clinton drug plan.

title: The N.B.A. Drafts Today, but the Emphasis Is on the Future
description: Kenyon Martin is still rehabilitating the leg he fractured three months ago, but insists he will be healthy for training camp. ''I should be fine,'' he said. ''I just have to work extra hard.''

title: Reckonings; Japan's Memento Mori
description: Japan's Liberal Democratic Party is neither liberal nor democratic. Nor is it exactly a party in either the European or American senses: it is more like a coalition of patronage-driven political machines. And it does not exactly have a track record to be proud of, having presided over a decade of stagnation in an economy that was once the wonder of the world.

title: A Jewel Box of Tomatoes
description: Red, yellow, orange, purplish and white miniature heirloom tomatoes, some as tiny as nicoise olives, others almost the size of a golf ball, are all part of the Earthbound Farms Tomato Fest. The different varieties, which are packed in a clear one-pint container, offer an array of flavors, from sugar-sweet (the golden pears) to tangy (the scarlet minis). They are $3.99 a box at Garden of Eden Markets, 310 Third Avenue (23rd Street), 162 West 23rd Street and 7 East 14th Street.

title: Taking a New Look at Uniforms And Their Impact on Schools
description: FOR Carl Cohn, the path to educational innovation began a decade ago on a gritty Long Beach street when a few dozen children, caught in the middle of a gang shootout, were forced to the floor of a school bus.

description: Joseph Jerome Ruvane Jr., a pharmaceuticals executive who capped 50 years in the industry by helping turn Glaxo Inc. into America's fastest-growing major drug company, died last Wednesday at a hospital in Durham, N.C., where he lived. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, STEVE

description: German Urges Global Rules on Hate on Web

title: POSSIBLE FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN MEDIA-MOST
description: Russia's biggest independent media conglomerate, Media-Most, said a major international investor might buy a stake in the company, which could help alleviate pressure on it just weeks after its offices were searched and its owner, Vladimir A. Gusinsky, was temporarily detained by prosecutors on embezzlement charges. The investor, who was not identified, has expressed interest in buying a $211.6 million debt Media-Most owes to Gazprom, the country's natural gas company. The government is Gazprom's main shareholder. Such a transaction would reduce Gazprom's influence in Media-Most, owner of NTV, Russia's biggest television channel. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Bill Papas, 73, Artist and Widely Syndicated Political Cartoonist
description: Bill Papas, an artist and political cartoonist whose work was syndicated worldwide, died on June 19 in an airplane accident in British Columbia, Canada. He was 73 and lived in Portland, Ore.

title: CHINA EXPLOITS LOW JAPANESE RATES
description: China issued 30 billion yen in so-called Samurai bonds, taking advantage of low interest rates in the Japanese debt market in case the Bank of Japan decides to raise interest rates for the first time in a decade. Interest rates in Japan hit bottom more than a year ago as the country's central bank struggled to lift the economy out of recession. Many international borrowers are issuing yen-denominated bonds to take advantage of the low rates. China has not sold yen-denominated bonds since 1995. It does not need the money; the country's foreign exchange reserves total about $159 billion, the second largest in the world behind those of Japan. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Chocolate, Lemon, Clove: Yes, This Is Basil
description: THE summer our grandmother, a ninth-generation Manhattanite, moved down South to live nearer to the family, she brought with her a truckload of sleek, blond mid-century furniture, a closetful of spike heels and a tattered, handwritten recipe for pesto Genoese. The year was 1982, and we had never tasted anything like it. Shining through the richness of Parmesan, pine nuts and garlic was the sunny, uplifting flavor of fresh basil, an epiphany we would forever associate with summer and urban sophistication.

title: In a Bus Station, Surrounded by Stories and Lies
description: ''That's why people lie, out of necessity,'' says Judith (Heather Matarazzo), the clear-eyed protagonist of Lisanne Skyler's entrancing ''Getting to Know You.'' The movie, which opens today at the Film Forum, is based on Joyce Carol Oates stories and conjures an alluring spell of mistrust and hope, getting to the self-deception that Ms. Oates's characters often weave for themselves.

title: Media Metrix Plans to Merge with Jupiter Communications
description: Media Metrix Inc., an influential arbiter of who's hot and who's not in the Internet world, will acquire Jupiter Communications, a leading analyst of Internet trends, the two companies said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, THEODORE
description: KLEIN-Theodore ''Ted'', on June 27 at NYU Medical Center, NYC. President of Ted Klein & Company, a New York public relations firm specializing in health and medical issues, and founder of Medical Marketing Distaff (MMD), which was acquired by Snyder Communications in 1998. Ted leaves a grieving family: Carole, his wife of 45 years, his son William and daughter Emily, his sister Joanne Kaufman, and her family, his son-in-law Arthur McGrath, and daughter-in-law Caroline Kenner, and his grandchildren, Sam, Sophie and Dylan. Ted was a rare mix of drive, savvy and compassion allied with strength. His work introducing the first prescription drug products to assist with smoking cessation brought together a network of researchers, physicians, government officials and communications professionals who continue to benefit from his wisdom, passion and skill. Among his many activities, Ted provided funding for researchers at the University of Michigan School of Public Health to examine ways to discourage adolescent smoking, and for the study of pharmaceutical public relations at the University of Mississippi School of Pharmacy. He is the author or co-author of five books, including ''A User's Guide to Bypass Surgery'' (1996), ''How to Be Heard: Making the Media Work for You'' (1974) which was reissued as ''Publicity'' (1985), ''The Father's Book'' (1970) and ''Nine Months to Go'' (1956). Memorial contributions may be made to the New York Community Trust for the Ted Klein Fund and sent to 2 Park Avenue, 24th Floor, New York, NY 10016. The family will receive visitors at 39 East 10th Street, Apt 1W, on June 28 and June 29 from Noon to 7PM.

title: Miranda's Value in the Trenches
description: I was delighted by the Supreme Court's decision on Monday to uphold Miranda, the 34-year old constitutional mandate that requires the police to advise anyone arrested of the right to remain silent. Miranda retains an almost sacramental value; it is a vivid emblem of central ideas about the law. But the truth is that by now, Miranda has little practical impact on the interaction between suspects and cops.

title: Suspect in Stabbings Escapes From Hospital in the Bronx
description: A prisoner with a history of violence escaped from Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx early yesterday after what officials suspect was a feigned seizure, and the three veteran corrections officers who were guarding him have been suspended without pay pending an investigation.

title: Japan Sells Tokyo Sowa Bank to an Investment Fund
description: The Japanese government said today that it would sell the bankrupt Tokyo Sowa Bank to an investment fund led by Wilbur L. Ross, a specialist in corporate rescues who has made a name for himself through investing in financially distressed companies in the United States.

description: Andrew Chambers has the easy manner of a friend you can trust. Federal agents trusted him, and so did drug dealers. Over a 16-year career as an undercover informer, Mr. Chambers helped send 445 drug dealers to prison.

title: Sotomayor, Banned for Drug, Is Out of Games
description: Javier Sotomayor, the Cuban world record-holder in the high jump and the only person to leap eight feet, was suspended yesterday for a positive drug test and barred from competing in the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, track and field's international governing body announced.

title: Didn't I See You Here Yesterday?
description: ''It's always like this,'' said Marilyn Soto, an editor at Young & Rubicam, who was in a line of more than 20 people inching their way to the counter of Rainbow Cafe Falafel, 26 East 17th Street. Just then two men joined the line. ''It's always like this,'' one said. The owner, Mohammad Jamal, confirmed that it had been like that since the day he opened -- with a line -- about six years ago.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS RISES. Natural gas rose to a record on signs that production is falling short of demand. In New York, natural gas for July delivery rose 12.6 cents, or 2.8 percent, to $4.686 for a million B.T.U.'s.

Finding Gold in Scientific Pay Dirt

title: INGERSOLL-RAND TO BUY GERMAN SOFTWARE MAKER
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company, a maker of road paving machines, refrigeration systems and other industrial products, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Interflex Datensysteme, a privately held German software and manufacturing company. The price was not disclosed. Interflex, which is expected to have $67 million in revenue this year, develops software that keeps track of employees' attendance and makes securities devices like keypads. Ingersoll-Rand is based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: PINNACLE AGREES TO ACQUIRE THE BLACKFORD BROKERAGE
description: The Pinnacle Global Group, a financial services company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Blackford Securities Corporation, a brokerage with $10 million in revenue the last year, for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock. Blackford is based in Garden City, N.Y. Pinnacle, based in Houston, had revenue of $19 million in 1999 and is the holding company for units that provide brokerage, investment banking, asset-management and other services. Pinnacle said recently that it would close its mortgage-backed securities unit.

title: Lazio Accuses Mrs. Clinton Of Waging Fear Campaign
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio last night accused Hillary Rodham Clinton of waging a campaign based on fear and warned that her latest television commercials attacking his record would backfire.

title: Group Says City Fails to Keep Its Part of a Clean-Water Pact
description: An environmental group that helped broker a 1997 agreement exempting New York City from building a $6 billion water filtration plant said today that it would sue the city to try to scuttle that agreement.
