title: JAPANESE CABLE MERGER
description: The Jupiter Telecommunications Company and the Titus Communications Company, Japan's two largest cable television operators, said they planned to merge on Sept. 1, a move that will intensify the budding competition to supply Japanese consumers with high-speed Internet access. The merged company will have two major American shareholders: Liberty Media, a subsidiary of the AT&T Corporation, will own 35 percent, while the Microsoft Corporation will own 24 percent. Combined, the two companies will have 750,000 subscribers. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Correction
description: An editorial last Thursday misstated the number of white farmers in Zimbabwe who have been killed by President Robert Mugabe's supporters. The number is five, not one. And an editorial yesterday gave the wrong location for next month's economic summit meeting in Japan. It will be in Okinawa, not Osaka.

description: If seizing the moment were an Olympic event, like figure skating, Noel Coward's characters would surely take the honors for form. True, they generally don't have the athleticism of American hedonists; ''seize,'' in fact, may not be quite the correct word for what they do.

description: An Oregon jury said today that the American Home Products Corporation should pay $29.2 million to a man and his mother who contended the company's withdrawn diet drugs damaged their hearts.

description: Microscopic particles of air pollutants from tailpipes, power plants and other sources are causing measurable increases in deaths and the hospitalizations of the elderly, a study of the nation's 90 largest metropolitan areas has found.

description: Pokemon, it seems, may not be immune to children's very rapid aging process, in which 1.5 adult years can be equal to, say, 86 kiddie years.

description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose 1 percent in the most recent monthly period, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which operates the market, said yesterday.

title: 3 Ex-Officers Are Sentenced for Roles in Louima Torture
description: A former Brooklyn police officer was sentenced yesterday to 15 years and eight months in prison for taking part in the savage assault on Abner Louima and plotting to cover up his role in the attack. Two other former officers convicted with him in the cover-up scheme were sentenced to five years in prison each at the same impassioned, two-hour hearing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, ARNOLD
description: BLACK-Arnold. Musician, composer/violinist, Founder and Artistic Director of Mohawk Trail Concerts Chamber Music Series in Western Massachusetts died suddenly and peacefully at his home Charlemont, MA, June 24, aged 77. Beloved husband of Ruth, adored father of Hilary, he was predeceased by two sons, Sandy and Tony. He leaves countless colleagues, music lovers, neighbors and friends saddened but cherishing gratefully his abiding generosity, warmth and irrepressible humor. A memorial service will be held at The Federated Church, Charlemont, July 3rd at 3:00 PM. Gifts in his memory may be made to the Mohawk Trail Concerts, Shelburne, Falls, MA 01370.

title: Strong Presence By U.S. Colleges

They make up the majority of this year's overseasentry that begins five days of knockout competition today at Henley-on-Thames, England.

title: 'Tutti Frutti' Indeed! (Alop-Bam-Boom, Too)
description: ''I am the beautiful Little Richard,'' said Richard Penniman, with the utmost assuredness, opening his eyes wide and grinning. ''I know you've seen me on television, but now I'm in person so you know I ain't lying.'' He spotted a professional photographer in the audience fiddling with a camera. ''You're a picture-maker,'' he said. ''I can see it in your eyes. Would you mind getting up and going? I'm almost 70 years old. They've been doing that to me forever, and I never did make a dime from those pictures.'' He waited until his request was honored.

description: Timing, in constitutional law no less than in life or love, can mean everything, and when it came to timing, the opponents of the Miranda decision who finally managed to push the Supreme Court into revisiting the case after 34 years turned out to have been spectacularly unlucky.

title: Remote Streams Worth the Effort
description: Trout fishing on many of the Catskills' blue-ribbon streams has become so crowded in the last year or two, especially on weekends, that it is S.R.O. The trout streams' surge in popularity parallels the rise in fly fishing's growth in America and has also ushered in a new-found economy among these verdant hills. Local entrepreneurs have responded by refurbishing restaurants and motels, adding new tackle shops, museums and a booming guide service.

description: Juan Gonzalez stepped into the batter's box tonight, and just like last week the signals he received were decidedly mixed. One day after the Yankees effectively folded on a trade for the two-time most valuable player by offering him a one-year contract extension they knew he would not accept, Gonzalez returned to Comerica Park to face the Detroit fans.

title: The New Store: A Review
description: THE familiar forest-green awnings and instantly recognizable white ''B'' adorn the new West 66th Street branch of Balducci's, the Greenwich Village speciality market. But without the name on signs throughout the new place, longtime patrons of the downtown store would be hard-pressed to see a connection. description: BESIDES being an accomplished architect, Aydin Boysan is perhaps Turkey's most famous bon vivant. That means, inevitably, that he is a passionate drinker of raki.

title: Bush Would Use Power of Persuasion to Raise Oil Supply
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said today that if he was president, he would bring down gasoline prices through sheer force of personality, by creating enough political good will with oil-producing nations that they would increase their supply of crude.

title: To Sip, Perchance to Spoon
description: A stunning new gazpacho, a silken palate-pleaser at the Brasserie, 100 East 53rd Street, looks like a bloody mary served in a martini glass. It even has enough spice to suggest the cocktail. Topped with mint cream, it hovers between sippable and spoonable. The Brasserie's gazpacho is $8, but you can easily whip it up at home. I'd even consider spiking it with vodka or silver tequila for a summer brunch.

description: To get what you want as a legislator, it is not always enough to be in the majority party. Sometimes you have to be a threatened member of the majority; then you are cared for like an endangered species.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, LAWRENCE R.
description: GOULD-Lawrence R. Passed away on June 25, 2000, after a long illness. Age 85. Brilliant lawyer, inspiring speaker, patient advisor, beloved husband, cherished father, revered grandfather, loyal friend. Greatly respected, enormously loved. You were the steady ship that guided us through the rough waters. We will always be grateful for the gift of your integrity, wisdom, kindness and guidance in our lives. He is survived by his devoted wife of 59 years, Diana Klotz Gould, his loving daughters, Jane G. Bensahel and Suzanne G. Davis, both of Manhattan, and his cherished three grandchildren, Nora J. Bensahel, Bryan J. Davis, and Ariana V. Davis. Memorial service Wednesday, June 28, 1PM at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Boulevard, New Rochelle. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to UJA/Federation or to the American Red Cross.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. IS SET TO ALLOW THE SALE OF FOOD TO CUBA
description: House Republican leaders agreed today to end four decades of sanctions on sales of food to Cuba, in a decision that carried great political significance.

title: 100 Voices for Democracy, as France Clears Its Throat
description: To ensure that its disapproval of the conference on democracy organized here by the United States is officially noticed, France declined today to accept the document summarizing the principles and agreed to by other participants.

title: Letting Go Of Dreams But Keeping It Cheerful
description: Imagine Edna St. Vincent Millay resurrected as a Los Angeles-based songwriter and performer and you have Amanda McBroom, the composer of ''The Rose'' and a theatrically trained singer whose plummy folk-pop alto is a perfect match for her own material. Although some of those songs settle for greeting-card platitudes, the best ones, like ''The Portrait,'' ''Errol Flynn'' (a tribute to her father, a supporting actor who worked with that star) and ''Ship in a Bottle,'' are beautifully precise, insightful verses that transcend the homespun to convey a deep personal sadness.

title: Still Looking for New Vineyards to Conquer
description: ONE of the most remarkable figures in the French wine business, Jean-Michel Cazes, has retired at 65. Sort of. In 1986, when the conventional wisdom held that most French businessmen were still trapped in the dark ages, Mr. Cazes was already well ahead of the crowd.

title: How to Say Barbecue in Baltimore
description: I SPENT the first 18 years of my life in Baltimore, and not once did I eat pit beef. I am not particularly proud of this fact, but it does reflect the parochialism of the region's food. I grew up in the suburb of Pikesville, Md., and the foods of my childhood embraced the four C's of Baltimore gastronomy: crab, corned beef, coddies (leaden cakes of codfish and potatoes) and chocolate tops (cookies crowned with a rosette of chocolate icing).

title: Diane Blair, Professor of Politics; Friend of the Clintons Was 61
description: Diane Divers Blair, who taught and practiced politics in Arkansas for 30 years, becoming fast friends with Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, died on Monday at her home in Fayetteville, Ark. She was 61.

title: The Mets Warm Up For Atlanta In Style
description: In what has become a midseason pennant race if not a morality play, the Mets mowed down still another victim last night and began to set the table for the four-game visit by the Atlanta Braves that starts tomorrow night.

title: Higher Demand Raises Pressure On Power Grid
description: The breakdown of three electric feeder cables on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on Monday forced Consolidated Edison to take emergency measures to prevent a widespread power failure. It was, on a smaller scale, exactly the same type of failure that started a chain of events leading to the 19-hour blackout in northern Manhattan during a heat wave last July.

description: KUALA LUMPUR  Exhorting Muslim leaders to reduce divisions among themselves, Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad of Malaysia urged government officials and diplomats from around the world Tuesday to embrace science and technology and combat those who "oppress" Muslims.

title: Merci, No Legs of Frogs
description: ''Eating and Drinking in France'' is an opinionated little compendium. Its authors, Andy Herbach and Michael Dillon, hate to eat brains and such and do their best to steer their readers away from dishes like gras-double, or tripe. But their 128-page pocket-size book (Capra Press, $8.95) is handy for travelers who might not know that in France an entree is a first course, not a main dish, or how to say ''table for two'' (''une table pour deux''), for example.

description: ROYER-Jim. Former long time Pro Personnel Director of the New York Jets and beloved husband of Linda and father of Brian and Jamie. Spent 20 years with the Jets before retiring in 1996, with a total of 25 years working in the NFL as a scout and coach. A 1957 graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy and member of the Marine Corps, 1957-1961. Born in Baltimore, MD September 15, 1932 he grew up in Philadelphia. Visitation Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave, Garden City, NY, Thursday and Friday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral at the Holy Name of Mary RC Church, 55 E. Jamaica Ave, Valley Stream, Saturday, 9:45 AM. Flowers may be sent or donations made to the National Colorectal Cancer Research Alliance.

title: After the Genome Announcement
description: Now that decipherment of the human genome has been so grandly trumpeted, practical and highly personal questions inevitably arise. What difference will this make to me? How soon will it help or hurt me? The answers were not always easy to discern in the torrent of commentary after Monday's triumphal announcement that a public consortium of academic institutions and a private company had each determined the exact sequence of the vast majority of chemical letters in the human genetic material. It is those letters that determine, when strung together as genes, how all the cells in the human body develop and function. In the commonly used metaphor, the genome is a blueprint for life.

title: U.N. Warning AIDS Imperils Africa's Youth
description: About half of all 15-year-olds in the African countries worst affected by AIDS will eventually die of the disease even if the rates of infection drop substantially in the next few years, the United Nations reported yesterday.

title: A Gentle Farmer Who's Good at Violence
description: In the Revolutionary War epic ''The Patriot,'' Mel Gibson is Benjamin Martin, a gentle farmer in his 40's whose eyes glimmer with love for his family. Among the film's assets is Mr. Gibson's complicated love for his own children, who are similar to his brood in the film, ranging in age from very young to teenage. This may seem trivial, but it's a theme that most contemporary movies, with their incessant focus on prolonged adolescence, avoid.

title: Metro Business; Bankers on Broadway
description: Times Square has been made safe in recent years for tourists, magazine editors and accountants. Now, it's apparently safe for commercial bankers.

title: The Menu Winks, And Catches the Eye
description: ON the menu at Blue Hill, a new restaurant on Washington Place, there's a dish that might give diners pause. It's called ''Not Another Roast Chicken.'' Dan Barber, one of the chefs, said he wants diners to know that this isn't the cliched dish found in every restaurant. It's a free-range organic chicken from a small, obscure farm, roasted in a fancy high-tech oven imported from Austria.

title: The Name's a Hint of the Lures That Await
description: AT Esca, the most important word in the Italian language is crudo. It means raw, and that's the way the fish comes to the table in a dazzling array of appetizers that could be thought of as Italian sushi, except there's no rice, or as Italy's answer to ceviche, except the fish doesn't sit long enough in its pool of olive oil and lemon to ''cook.''

Anyone who has seen the huge piles of cabbage harvested annually in Korea knows that it cannot all be eaten in the next days or weeks. Pickling allows the cabbage to be kept for months.

title: A. H. BELO WILL SELL PROPERTIES TO LIFT ITS STOCK PRICE
description: The A. H. Belo Corporation, publisher of The Dallas Morning News and operator of 18 television stations, said it would sell its stake in the Dallas Mavericks basketball team, and three smaller newspapers and repurchase some of its stock. The steps are being taken to improve the company's stock price, which is down 13 percent this year. The Dallas-based company said it had reached an oral agreement to sell its minority interest in the Mavericks and its related stake in the arena to the team's majority owner, Mark Cuban, for about $34.5 million. Belo also said it would sell The Messenger-Inquirer in Owensboro, Ky., and The Gleaner in Henderson, Ky., as well as The Eagle in Bryan/College Station, Tex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REEMTSMA, KEITH
description: REEMTSMA-Keith. The faculty and staff of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and the New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Keith Reemtsma. Internationally recognized as a pioneer of organ transplants and transplantation immunology, Dr. Reemtsma's contributions have had a profound influence in medical education, research and clinical care. He established one of the leading heart transplant programs in the world and co-founded one of the first programs to bioengineer artificial organs. Dr. Reemtsma was the first to show that non-human organs could successfully be transplanted into humans and was devoted to finding a cure for diabetes through the transplantation of islet cells. Dr. Reemtsma received his surgical training at Columbia University and later returned as Chairman of the Department of Surgery in 1971. He was a trusted advisor to generations of medical students and faculty. A long time friend and colleague whose many contributions enriched the field of medicine, he will be greatly missed and his memory cherished. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Judy, his sons Dirk and Lance, and to the entire Reemtsma family. Thomas Q. Morris, M.D, Interim Dean for Clinical & Educational Affairs Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons David Hirsh, Ph.D. Interim Dean for Research Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons Herbert Pardes, M.D. President & CEO New York-Presbyterian Hospital

title: CURRENTS -- URBAN RENEWAL; Plaza Into Park, With Coffee Kiosk and Greenmarket
description: Just a few years ago, homeless people made themselves at home in Sheffield Plaza, built in 1978 at 57th Street and Ninth Avenue. Now, neighborhood residents are making themselves at home by sipping coffee and bringing their toddlers to play. The landscape architect Thomas Balsley, whose specialty is remedying unsuccessful urban plazas, and the developer Rose Associates, reprogrammed the plaza into a park, adding a small lawn (above), a sheltered play area and a coffee kiosk with smart aluminum tables and chairs. A Greenmarket draws shoppers to the park twice a week. ''It's a fresh perspective on what public open space could be,'' said Mr. Balsley, after whom the revamped space is named. The backdrop of Balsley Park is green corrugated metal walls (left). ''This is an escape from the grid of the city,'' Mr. Balsley said. ''I think people will appreciate the walls more in winter, when they see that fresh spring green we all look forward to.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, THEODORE
description: KLEIN-Theodore ''Ted'', on June 27 at NYU Medical Center, NYC. President of Ted Klein & Company, a New York public relations firm specializing in health and medical issues, and founder of Medical Marketing Distaff (MMD), which was acquired by Snyder Communications in 1998. Ted leaves a grieving family: Carole, his wife of 45 years, his son William and daughter Emily, his sister Joanne Kaufman, and her family, his son-in-law Arthur McGrath, and daughter-in-law Caroline Kenner, and his grandchildren, Sam, Sophie and Dylan. Ted was a rare mix of drive, savvy and compassion allied with strength. His work introducing the first prescription drug products to assist with smoking cessation brought together a network of researchers, physicians, government officials and communications professionals who continue to benefit from his wisdom, passion and skill. Among his many activities, Ted provided funding for researchers at the University of Michigan School of Public Health to examine ways to discourage adolescent smoking, and for the study of pharmaceutical public relations at the University of Mississippi School of Pharmacy. He is the author or co-author of five books, including ''A User's Guide to Bypass Surgery'' (1996), ''How to Be Heard: Making the Media Work for You'' (1974) which was reissued as ''Publicity'' (1985), ''The Father's Book'' (1970) and ''Nine Months to Go'' (1956). Memorial contributions may be made to the New York Community Trust for the Ted Klein Fund and sent to 2 Park Avenue, 24th Floor, New York, NY 10016. The family will receive visitors at 39 East 10th Street, Apt 1W, on June 28 and June 29 from Noon to 7PM.

title: The Accidental Journalist: A Teenager Finds a Vocation
description: TAMEEKA MITCHEM remembers her first foray into journalism as something of a disaster. In April 1999, she volunteered to work for Harlem Live, a nonprofit Web site (www.harlemlive.org) produced by New York teenagers. When another reporter could not make a scheduled interview at a local community organization, Tameeka went instead.

title: A Historian Presents the Civil War, Online and Unfiltered by Historians
description: WAS the American Civil War inevitable? Many popular histories, like the epic television documentary by Ken Burns, portray the conflict as an unavoidable corrective that rid a great nation of slavery. But people of the 1850's and 1860's didn't see the issues leading up to the war that clearly. According to letters, diaries, newspapers and other records, many Northerners of the period expressed support or sympathy for slavery, and many on both sides longed for a compromise.

Mattson, based in Fremont, Calif., would exchange 0.5223 share for every CFM share, about a 50 percent premium based on yesterday's close of $15, up $1.25, in Nasdaq trading. It was the proper legal conclusion to a bitter family dispute that dragged on for months and drew international attention. The high court was right not to take the case because there were no important issues of law that had not been resolved by lower courts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REEMTSMA, KEITH
description: REEMTSMA-Keith. The Department of Transplantation at the University of Rome ''La Sapienza'' mourns the loss of Professor Keith Reemtsma, a great friend and colleague. Professor Keith Reemtsma has revolutionized the field of transplantation by successfully performing the first organ transplant from a chimpanzee into a man. This generated a new field of research on the biology of xenotransplantation. Educator, scientist and organizer, Professor Keith Reemtsma will always be remembered for his integrity, wisdom, kindness and guidance. Our deepest sympathy goes to his wife, Judy, and his sons. Professor Raffaello Cortesini Director of the Interuniversitary Consortium of Transplantation

title: An End to Secret Campaign Funds

It was hard to remember that this very bill was narrowly defeated two weeks ago and belittled by foes as something the public did not care about. In trying to combat this supposedly unwanted measure, Representative Tom DeLay and the Republican leadership cooked up a sham alternative that was so punitive toward unions and violative of the privacy rights of nonpolitical groups that their own members could not swallow it. In the end, Mr. DeLay had no choice but to get out of the way and allow a vote on reform or be stampeded by fellow Republicans.

title: CURRENTS -- INSTALLATIONS; Early Christmas in July for London
description: The British sculptor Andy Goldsworthy turns nature into short-lived installations, ''painting'' boulders with wet leaves, for instance. His latest work was a cool tribute to summertime in London called ''Snowballs in Summer,'' a cross between public art and ephemeral street furniture. The artist trucked in 14 giant snowballs from Scotland -- each 6 feet in diameter and weighing a ton -- and placed them on street corners around London's Barbican Center on June 21, the summer solstice, or Midsummer Day to the English. The melting of the snowballs -- most of which took 24 to 36 hours -- left behind colored pebbles, bits of chalk, metal, cow hair and wool. The project is part of an exhibition at the Barbican through September.

The purchase was announced after the close of trading Tuesday. Tech-Sym shares rose $4.1875, to $28.3125 each, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday. Tech-Sym's holdings include the Metric Systems Corporation, a maker of airborne training systems and shipboard electronics; Trak Communications Inc., a maker of components for wireless telecommunications; and the Continental Electronics Corporation, a maker of radio transmitters.

''Mission: Impossible 2'' racked up $91.8 million in American theaters on the long Memorial Day weekend, fueling a record-breaking $171 million holiday and causing swoons of ecstasy to ripple through the corporate corridors of major movie studios. After that, who knew what the rest of the summer of 2000 might bring? Perhaps there would be yet another bumper crop of $100 million movies, just like last summer. title: CORNING PLANS TO EXPAND FACTORY AND ADD 700 JOBS
description: Corning Inc., a leading maker of glass fiber used in high-speed communications, plans to add 700 jobs and spend $50 million to expand a plant in Erwin, N.Y. The decision to expand the plant, near the company's Corning, N.Y., headquarters, comes less than three months after Corning said it would spend $50 million and hire about 1,000 workers to set up a similar plant in Benton Township, Pa. Demand for optical amplifiers, which manipulate light traveling through fiber optic networks and let those networks offer more and better-quality data and voice services, has surged as the Internet has grown.

title: VIAGRA FOR CHINA
description: The State Drug Administration in China approved domestic sales of Viagra, the anti-impotence drug. Its manufacturer, Pfizer Inc., is expected to produce Viagra at a plant in the northeastern city of Dalian. Government doctors have recommended that the drug be priced about $12 a tablet, retail, and be available by prescription only, the state-owned Shanghai Daily reported.

title: Eager Buyers Lift Nasdaq as Dow Ekes Out Small Gain
description: The Nasdaq composite index had its biggest gain in seven sessions yesterday as investors flocked to technology shares while shunning most blue-chip standbys.

title: Homework Help From an Expert
description: WHEN 9-year-old B.J. Pinchbeck could not find a good Web site to help him with his science project, he and his father decided to build one. Four years later, B.J. Pinchbeck's Homework Helper (www.bjpinchbeck.com) has become an indispensable bookmark for many middle-schoolers and their parents. The site, operated by DiscoverySchool.com, has amassed more than 580 links organized by subject and B.J. has become a kind of Stephen Jay Gould for preteenagers.

title: New State Rules Aim to Curb Loan Abuses
description: The New York State Banking Department released new rules yesterday meant to prevent the abuses of high-cost loans that have victimized thousands of homeowners.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's arrival in Jerusalem for talks intended to lead to a Middle East summit meeting with President Clinton misstated the day of Mr. Clinton's news conference this week. It was yesterday; it is not today.

title: Larry Kelley, 85, a Yale End Who Won the Heisman, Dies
description: Larry Kelley, the Yale University end who won the Heisman Trophy in 1936, then found himself back in the public eye six months ago when he sold the statuette at auction for $328,100, died Tuesday at his home in Hightstown, N.J., of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was 85.

title: Arbitrator Keeps Yashin In Ottawa
description: When the National Hockey League's restricted and unrestricted free agents begin shopping for contract offers on Saturday, there will be one fewer member of the group than the players association had hoped.

description: SEGAL-Steve. ''No more Mr. Nice Guy.'' How sad a loss it is. The Strongwaters, Poppers and Lewis' miss the nicest guy we knew. Love from your tennis bums.

title: Arrests Made in Drugs-for-Green-Card Scheme
description: Nearly 160 Colombian and Mexican suspected drug traffickers believed to have been operating along the Eastern Seaboard were charged yesterday with trading vast quantities of cocaine and heroin for green cards from an undercover agent posing as a crooked official of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

Blue'' and, after riding the train home to Jackson Heights, Queens, stopping at the corner store for some strawberry ice cream.

title: Red Cross Says Three Diseases Kill Many More Than Disasters
description: Although earthquakes and floods usually receive the most prominent news coverage, infectious diseases are claiming far more lives than natural disasters, according to a report made public today by the Red Cross.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, URIAH
description: JONES-Uriah, 75, of 92 Hinman St., West Haven, CT died June 14, 2000. He had worked for the City of New Haven in the engineering department. He had served as a merchant marine. Mr. Jones, an Olympic Fencing Champion, officially ranked among America's 10 best fencers for 10 consecutive years. He was a member of the U.S. National, the U.S. World, the U.S. Olympic & U.S. Pan American Championship Teams and was the 6 time CT, 4 time North Atlantic & two time American Champion; he also was a 4 time Medalist in the Martini & Rossi International Tournament and recently had been elected to the Fencing Hall of Fame and was to have been inducted next week in Austin, TX. He leaves four sons, Uriah Jones III of Middletown, CT, Douglas of Essex, CT, Jeffrey of Birmingham, AL., and Noah of Westbrook, CT. Contributions may be made C/O Patricia A. Petro, Fleet Bank, 125 Westbrook Road, Essex, CT. 06426. Visiting hours at Maresca Funeral Home, 592 Chapel St. New Haven, CT Thurs 4-8 pm. Memorial services will be held at a later date.

title: CURRENTS -- EXHIBITIONS; Flexible and Modular in Venice
description: The seventh Architecture Biennale fair opened on June 18 on the grounds of the Giardini di Castello in Venice. The United States pavilion, sponsored by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, boasts flexible modular systems from a 20-year-old Italian furniture company called Zero. The company donated gridded, perforated metal panels (above), storage units, worktables and chairs for the pavilion's two design labs. Greg Lynn, who teaches architecture at the University of California at Los Angeles, designed a studio with a translucent wall, using Zero's Silvergate storage system. Hani Rashid, of Columbia, employed structural beams by Zero to support projection screens and display areas in a studio he designed. Zero is at 560 Broadway (Prince Street), Suite 509; (212) 925-3615. The fair runs until Oct. 29.

title: Who Will Blink First, Yankees or the Cubs?
description: If the Sammy Sosa deal is going to be finished, somebody is going to have to give it a good shove. Maybe that will be George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, who is eager to make a big deal. Maybe it will be the Cubs, faced with the possibility that the Yankees' current offer might be the best they can get.

title: ESSAY; Should a Novelist Feel Bitter Losing to Stephen King? You Bet
description: STEPHEN KING, as I'm sure you know, made headlines -- and a small fortune -- when his e-novella, ''Riding the Bullet,'' was published online in March. It was heralded as an innovation, the beginning of a new era in publishing. A vision thing.

title: Bush Says Gore Has Oil on His Own Shoes
description: Who is more tarred by the big oil companies and therefore more responsible for the high price of gasoline? That was the burning question in the presidential contest today as both Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore campaigned in Ohio.

title: Propelled Into Motion by Japanese Drums
description: Alas, the first program in Pilobolus Dance Theater's new season at the Joyce Theater is more or less a bust. The exception among the four pieces on Tuesday night was ''A Selection,'' created last year in collaboration with Maurice Sendak and Arthur Yorinks, directors of the Night Kitchen, a children's theater company.

description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today that the Boy Scouts of America can exclude gay members. The vote in the case, Boy Scouts of America v. Dale, was 5 to 4. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the decision; Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the dissent.

title: Hospital Reverses Itself on Hinckley Visits
description: A Washington psychiatric hospital reversed itself yesterday and withdrew its recommendation that a court permit John W. Hinckley Jr. to leave the hospital for unsupervised weekly visits with his parents.

title: FORD SAID TO LEAD IN DAEWOO BID
description: South Korean news reports said Ford Motor had won exclusive negotiating rights to buy the heavily indebted Daewoo Motor from a committee of creditors, beating out rival bids from an alliance between DaimlerChrysler and Hyundai Motor and an alliance between General Motors and Fiat. The Korea Economic Daily said the Ford and Daimler-Hyundai bids were each about $6 billion and the G.M.-Fiat bid was lower. G.M. said its alliance was still bidding. None of the other companies or the creditors would comment on the reports. Samuel Len

title: Nets Hoping Top Pick Can Add Sudden Impact
description: Late last season, Stephon Marbury pulled a reporter aside and told him that the Nets needed a thug. Not a criminal, of course, but a player who would push opponents around, make them think twice about barreling down the middle of the defense, finish his nifty passes with power dunks and play with the tenacity Marbury grew up seeing on the playgrounds of Brooklyn.

description: The focus should be on baseball when the Atlanta Braves play the Mets beginning Thursday night, not on John Rocker. This should be about two teams meeting in an intense pennant race, not about one player who has made himself a villain with his disparaging remarks. The Braves have expressed these thoughts so much in the last two days that they sound scripted.

title: The Oops Girl With the Big Smile and the Little Voice
description: ''What you see is what you get,'' Britney Spears sang at the Jones Beach Theater on Tuesday night. And what you get from this 18-year-old singer is a big smile, a little voice, gushes of sincerity, hardworking dance routines, shameless advertising and a determination to play both sides of pubescence for all they're worth. To an audience full of squealing little girls, Ms. Spears previewed adolescent romance as a realm where all that matters are a girl's feelings and her wardrobe.

title: Iraqi Gunman Kills 2 in Hostage Siege at U.N. Office in Baghdad
description: An Iraqi man brandishing two machine guns and explosives shot his way into a United Nations office today in Baghdad, Iraq, killing two officials, wounding seven and taking some 50 hostages. After a siege of nearly three hours, he gave himself up and said he had taken the hostages to demand an end to United Nations sanctions against his country.

title: Governments Tighten Goals For Restoring Chesapeake
description: A toughened Chesapeake Bay restoration agreement intended to achieve a tenfold increase in oyster production and a 30 percent drop in watershed land lost to suburban sprawl was signed today by state and federal officials who hailed it as an environmental model for the nation.

title: Hypertext Authors Meet The Pen and Ink Crowd
description: Two divergent literary groups converged this month on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. One was made up of the editors of The Paris Review, a distinguished quarterly of literature and poetry. The other was the Electronic Literature Organization, a new group founded to support the works of hypertext authors. A quirky clan of writers who write for the computer screens, hypertext authors invite readers to chart their own paths through stories by clicking on seemingly random words.

title: In America; A Different Republican?
description: George W. Bush is telling all who will listen that he is a ''different kind of Republican.'' He insists that while he remains a conservative, he nevertheless is willing to address the concerns of ethnic minorities and others who, to one degree or another, have perceived the Republican Party to be hostile to their interests.

His humor, devotion and loyalty will be deeply missed. He is survived by his wife, Judith, sons, Richard, Robert, Ronald, and Daniel, brothers, Bert and Stanley, four grandchildren, and eight nieces and nephews. title: An Ending, but Not a Happy One
description: One midday, years ago while traveling in Spain, I was sitting in a Madrid bar watching a bullfight on television. A handsome and gallant young man had dispatched the bull, which lay dead on the arena floor. Hailed as a future great, the matador was taking his bows before the cheering crowd when the bull suddenly stirred to life -- not with a few wearied motions, but with great vigor, rising violently up and abruptly goring the matador to death.

title: Plants for a Changing Earth
description: ONE morning in early June, Dr. Peter Del Tredici led the way around the Arnold Arboretum at Harvard University to some of the beautiful old plants he says are tough enough to ride the roller coaster of recent climate changes. Among them was the Chinese fringe tree (Chionanthus retusas), with its masses of little white blossoms covering its broad branches like a silken shawl. The fragrance was so intoxicating I wanted to open my arms and walk right into it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPELLETICH, MARGERY FOWLER
description: SPELLETICH-Margery Fowler, 80, of Corona del Mar died June 26, 2000. She was preceded in death by her husband, Kalman Spelletich, Jr. in 1996. Born in Glen Ridge, New Jersey in 1919, she graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in New York and then joined BBDO in New York City as an account executive from 1943-1958. More recently, she was a homemaker and secretary to Mr. Spelletich's business. An avid volunteer, she participated in the Garden Club, the Orange County Philharmonic, an investment group, children's theatre and was a fifty year member of the Junior League. She is survived by her daughter, Joan (Mark Lowenstern); grandchildren, Seth, Aimee; nieces, Patricia Parsons, Georgia Hazard, Betsy Borden; nephews, Peter Fowler, James Parsons, Robert Borden and Stephen Borden. Memorial Services will be 11:00 a.m., Thursday, June 29, 2000 at St. James Episcopal Church, 3209 Via Lido, Newport Beach, CA 92663. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to St. James Epicopal Church or to the charity of your choice.

title: The Medium Is the Message

title: Forget Sosa: Yanks Trade for Justice
description: Refusing to make a high-priced trade for Sammy Sosa, the Yankees instead acquired outfielder David Justice from Cleveland tonight, the first substantial move to bolster their sagging team.

title: The AIDS Epidemic in Africa
description: The United Nations' prediction this week that about half of all 15-year-olds in AIDS-plagued African countries will eventually die of AIDS is the latest measure of the devastating impact of the epidemic on the African continent. It is difficult to imagine what kind of future may be in store for countries if half of their adult populations will have died of the disease within coming decades.

title: Privatization and Failing Schools
description: New York City's schools chancellor, Harold Levy, raised eyebrows this week when he said that he would consider turning some failing schools into charter schools that would be run by private companies or not-for-profit groups. The charter option should not be ruled out -- as long as schools developed under its rubric remain open to all citizens and are held accountable to rigorous performance standards and taxpayer scrutiny, and provided that privatization is not a cover for channeling money from public education to parochial schools. In addition, City Hall, which has long pushed for privatization, needs to understand that there is nothing magical about privatization and that rebuilding failing schools requires the same grit, determination and patience no matter who undertakes the job.

title: GOODYEAR WARNS THAT PROFIT WILL NOT MEET FORECAST
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it would report less-than-expected second-quarter profit on increased raw material costs, customers' unwillingness to pay higher prices for tires and a weaker euro versus the dollar. Shares of Goodyear, the world's biggest tire maker, fell $2.125, to $21.25, after the company said that profit from operations was in line with the 37 cents a share earned in the year-earlier quarter. That would be well below the 58-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Goodyear's shares have fallen 59 percent over the last year as it has faced increased competition and rising costs.

title: 2 Indicted on Charges of Murder at Wendy's
description: Two men charged in the execution-style slayings of five workers at a Wendy's restaurant have been indicted by a grand jury on multiple counts of first- and second-degree murder, District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens announced yesterday.

title: XEROX SAYS S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING MEXICAN OPERATIONS
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating accounting practices at Xerox's Mexican operations. The investigation is coming less than two weeks after Xerox warned investors that unexpected problems with customer receivables in Mexico, which accounts for about $400 million of Xerox's $19 billion in annual sales, could pare more than 5 cents a share off its second-quarter earnings. At the time, Xerox assured Wall Street that the receivables shortfall did not indicate any deep-rooted problems with Xerox's internal financial controls. Xerox said it would cooperate fully with the S.E.C. Claudia H. Deutsch (NYT)

title: Rangers Sign Center
description: The Rangers agreed to contract terms yesterday with Brandon Dietrich, a St. Lawrence University center who had 15 goals and 26 assists last season.

description: The House passed a bill that would give doctors an exemption from antitrust laws so they could bargain collectively with insurance companies over fees and other issues. Page A22.

title: FOES OF ABORTION START NEW EFFORT AFTER COURT LOSS
description: A day after the Supreme Court effectively struck down bans on a medical procedure its opponents call partial-birth abortion, supporters of those bans said they were already planning a new generation of laws intended to withstand further legal challenges.

title: NORWAY TO INCREASE OIL OUTPUT
description: Norway, the world's second-largest oil exporter, will lift limits on its oil output starting Saturday, allowing production to increase by 3 percent. Norway will add 100,000 barrels a day to its current daily oil production of 3.2 million barrels. ''There seems to be a need for more oil in the market,'' said Olav Akselsen, Norway's oil minister. ''To allow stocks to build and avoid too tight an oil market, it is necessary to increase production.''

title: F.A.A. Faults Alaska Airlines but Will Not Shut It Down
description: Alaska Airlines has allowed mechanics to perform work for which they were not qualified, skipped maintenance on test equipment and failed to tell pilots when equipment was inoperable, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

description: In a final day of housekeeping after concluding its term, the Supreme Court agreed today to settle a longstanding and increasingly bitter boundary dispute between New Hampshire and Maine about which state includes the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard.

title: Residential Real Estate; Smaller Building With Bigger Apartments
description: By the standards of current Manhattan construction, the Montrose, with 97 luxury rental apartments on 20 stories, is a small building. But when leasing begins next month, its developers are betting that the combination of a smaller building and large units -- 60 percent of the apartments are two-bedrooms -- and a location in a residential neighborhood in eastern Murray Hill will be attractive to prospective tenants.

From Jan. 3 to June 21, shares of Salon.com fell to $1.375 from $4.875; Insweb.com dropped to $2.75 from $25.75.

title: Giving a Face and a Voice to Kafka's Cruel Fantasy Father
description: In Stanley Walden's one-act opera, Franz Kafka's famous ''Letter to My Father'' is furnished with an addressee who not only can be seen but also sings. The original document -- long, tortured, accusatory and confessional -- was never delivered, nor perhaps was it ever intended to be. If its solitary and private nature is in fact genuine, the premise on which ''Kafka: Letter to My Father'' is made to stand becomes shaky indeed.

title: After Boy's Return, Castro Tries to Keep Momentum
description: ''At Last in the Fatherland!'' declared the front-page headline in the official newspaper, Granma, above pictures of Elian Gonzalez stepping off the plane and being swept up in a relative's arms, an emotional end to the seven-month custody battle that captivated Cuba.

title: NEWSPAPER BRAWL IN TORONTO
description: Bus and train commuters in Toronto now have a choice of three free tabloid newspapers. Four daily newspapers already serve the Toronto metropolitan area's 4.7 million people. But the newspaper war suddenly heated up when word got out that the Modern Times Group of Stockholm was coming out with a free tabloid aimed at commuters. Two of Canada's largest media groups, Quebecor Inc. and the Torstar Corporation, decided to publish competing weekday tabloids. James Brooke (NYT)

title: For a Generous Donor and Bush, The Support Is a Two-Way Street
description: In October 1997, George W. Bush placed a call to his friend Tom Ridge, the Republican governor of Pennsylvania, to vouch for the Enron Corporation, the giant Houston energy and trading company that, at the time, was battling to sell electricity in Pennsylvania.

title: London Museum Gets a Cimabue
description: After months of intense negotiations, the National Gallery of Art in London announced today that it was acquiring its first painting by Cimabue, the 13th-century Italian painter and mosaicist who paved the way for early Renaissance artists.

title: True Love and a Crisis at Christmas (When Else)?
description: ''The Crumple Zone,'' a new play by Buddy Thomas at the Rattlestick Theater in Greenwich Village, has a lot going for it. It has a nicely structured plot about a gay household with a love triangle coming to a crisis at Christmastime; sequences of physical comedy directed by Jason Moore to be antic without being overblown into slapstick; and an effective set by Dawn Robyn Petrlik that evokes a pleasantly chintzy holiday atmosphere in a two-bedroom rental apartment on Staten Island.

title: Lawmakers Pass $21.5 Billion Budget; Action Delayed on Road and School Plans
description: In a daylong burst of lawmaking before its summer recess, the New Jersey Legislature easily approved a $21.5 billion budget today and took action on dozens of lesser bills.

title: Personifying The Agony Of Betrayal
description: Thrilling is the word for the performance that Amanda McKerrow and Jose Manuel Carreno offered in Natalia Makarova's staging of ''La Bayadere'' with American Ballet Theater on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Marius Petipa's epic ballet about love, intrigue and spiritual redemption in the India of the 19th-century imagination spoke forcefully through this performance, eloquently and intelligently put across by its principals.

title: Watching Mexico's Election
description: Mexico's presidential election Sunday will determine the outcome of a very tight race between Francisco Labastida, of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, and his center-right rival, Vicente Fox. The vote will also be a test of how far Mexico has progressed from the fraud-tainted elections of the recent past. The close contest makes it imperative that all aspects of the voting and ballot counting be scrupulously fair and transparent.

title: 12 of 19 Dodgers' Suspensions Overturned
description: In what for Major League Baseball is a stunning development, its new appellate judge of disciplinary action yesterday overturned 12 of the suspensions imposed against 19 members of the Los Angeles Dodgers by the game's new dean of discipline for a brawl with fans at Wrigley Field in Chicago.

title: POTLATCH TO LAY OFF 260 AND TAKE $16 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Potlatch Corporation, a maker of tissue paper and lumber, said yesterday that it would lay off 260 employees, or about 3.7 percent of its work force, as it struggles to meet profit forecasts. Potlatch, which had 7,000 employees as of December, will take a second-quarter charge of $16 million, or 55 cents a share, to cover the costs of the job cuts. The company, based in Spokane, Wash., said in May that it would eliminate jobs, without saying how many. Potlatch projected $21 million in annual pretax savings from the cuts. Shares of Potlatch gained 43.75 cents, closing at $34.9375.

So began the pitcher's first day in the city he so notoriously insulted in a magazine article last December, a day that ended without any ugly incidents and with Rocker contributing to the Braves' 6-4 victory over the Mets.

description: The presidential election this Sunday may be the most important in Mexico's modern history, the one that culminates years of democratization. title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICO TRADE DEAL
description: Just two days before the free- trade agreement between Mexico and the European Union comes into force, President Ernesto Zedillo signed another trade agreement with three Central American neighbors which are known collectively as the Northern Triangle. The trade pact with Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador will take effect in January and will dismantle trade barriers among the countries over a 12-year period. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES

title: A New Phish Season Begins, The Groove Still Insistent
description: The Phish groove surged through the PNC Bank Arts Center here tonight as the Vermont band turned on its juice for the first Northeastern date of its annual summer tour. This groove, as always, had a distinctive effect on fans. They twitched, twirled and watched themselves move their own hands in mysterious patterns. Walking through this captivated group was as challenging as jumping into the most raucous punk mosh pit. So long as Phish kept pushing its buoyant, speedy beat, hardly anyone could step out of the electrified dance.

title: SETBACK FOR MONSANTO SOYBEANS
description: Brazil's federal district court voted to uphold a cautionary ban on the sale of Monsanto's genetically modified soybeans until an environmental impact study can be completed. The court had ruled last August that Monsanto would have to conduct a one-year study before the ban would be lifted. The decision came at the same time that a separate federal regional court in Brasilia was also deliberating on an appeal by Monsanto to lift the ban. That decision was suspended until August. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Opinions on Nebraska's Abortion Law
description: Following are excerpts from a Supreme Court decision on Wednesday overturning a Nebraska law dealing with abortion. The vote in the case, Stenberg v. Carhart was 5 to 4. With the continuation of a front-page article on Thursday, The Times published excerpts from the majority opinion by Justice Stephen G. Breyer and a dissent by Justice Clarence Thomas. But six other justices -- John Paul Stevens, Sanda Day O'Connor, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, William H. Rehnquist, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy -- also wrote opinions. The excerpts below provide a fuller range of views on the court on this case.

title: Endurance as Heroism, in a Faraway Enemy Land
description: This weekend on the History Channel, Senator John McCain discusses his imprisonment in a North Vietnamese prison. ''I was not a hero,'' says Senator McCain, heroically, ''I was witness to a hundred, thousands of acts of courage, compassion and love by men who remain my heroes to this day.''

title: Less Strange Than of Old, A Poet of Brazilian Pop
description: The great harvest of songcraft that was MPB -- Musica Popular Brasileira, or Brazilian popular music, the catchall term for the work of the country's most urbane singer-songwriters from the 1960's to the 80's -- has one major limitation. These great songs are products of single imaginations or, sometimes, small consortiums of songwriters. And by the normal practice of the Brazilian pop music business, singer-songwriters tend to be somewhat disembodied from working bands.

title: Fed Vote in May to Raise Rates Was Unanimous, Minutes Show
description: Federal Reserve policy makers voted unanimously to raise interest rates by half a percentage point in May and to indicate that they suspected the risks to the economy were weighted mainly toward escalating inflation pressures, according to minutes of their May 16 meeting released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ARTHUR DAVID.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Arthur David. Beloved husband of Muriel (nee Kessman). Deeply loved father of Rochelle and Mark Schaevitz, Jane and Gary Buscemi, Warren Goldstein and Victoria Spetter. Proud grandfather of Jessica, Samantha, Julia, Benjamin and Elisabeth. Cherished brother of Robert and Michael Goldstein. Arthur Goldstein was a founding member of the New Democratic Coalition. He was instrumental and played a leading role in almost every liberal movement in New York State. He developed the charter of the Congress of Racial Equality and was the braintrust of much civil rights legislation. For many years he served on the local Democratic County Committee and as zone leader. Graduate of Cornell Law School, President of the Student Council at Brooklyn College. Lover of birds, gems and photography, he will be greatly missed. Arthur died on June 28, his 47th wedding anniversary, at the age of 70 after fighting a major battle with colon cancer. Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth El in Great Neck on Friday, June 30 at 11 AM.

title: WANADOO SHARE OFFERING
description: France Telecom will sell 10 percent of its Internet access provider, Wanadoo, to investors today at a share price of 17 to 20 euros, or $16 to $18.85. The offer values Wanadoo at more than $18 billion. Wanadoo, which offsets losses in its Internet business with profit in yellow pages publishing, will use the proceeds from the offering to lift the number of subscribers. John Tagliabue (NYT)

description: LOHR-Steve. Devoted husband of Ruth, died suddenly on June 21st. Steve embraced life with rare zest and great joy and optimism. He will be sorely missed and always remembered by all those who had the opportunity to have known him. Sincere sympathies to Ruth. A friend

description: Shares in Priceline.com dropped 8.4 percent yesterday after a report that six major airlines planned to invest in a competing Web site for customers looking for discounts on plane tickets online.

description: The International Monetary Fund, which has ordered developing nations to enact wrenching reforms as the price for emergency aid in recent years, is likely to curtail the demands it makes of clients who borrow money in the future, a senior fund official said today.

title: ENESCO CALLS OFF ITS PURCHASE OF PRECIOUS MOMENTS
description: Enesco Group Inc. said yesterday that it would not proceed with its proposed purchase of Precious Moments, a collectible doll and gift company. Enesco, which did not say why it was calling off the purchase, had agreed in April to acquire Precious Moments for $125 million in cash plus other considerations worth up to 40 percent of the cash price. Enesco said it would remain the largest licensee of Precious Moments and would continue to work with the company to expand the brand. Enesco, based in Itasca, Ill., sells gifts, collectibles and home decor products. Its stock rose 37.5 cents, to $4.8125.

title: A Case the Scouts Had to Win
description: To the dismay of gay rights groups and some civil libertarians, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that it is unconstitutional for the state to require a Boy Scout troop to admit a gay scoutmaster. The court's decision, however, goes to the heart of the First Amendment's guarantee of free association. It may be a civil right to have access to employment, or to transportation, or to hotels and restaurants. But it is not a civil right to assist in raising other people's children.

title: Enthusiasm For Verdi Survives In the Rain
description: Six years ago, when the conductor Vincent La Selva, the intrepid artistic director of the scrappy New York Grand Opera company, began his Viva, Verdi festival at SummerStage in Central Park, it was hard not to view the project as an act of ambitious insanity. No other opera company in the world would think itself capable of amassing the artists and resources necessary to properly perform all 28 Verdi scores consecutively, from early oddities like ''Alzira'' to challenging masterworks like ''Otello.''

title: How Alice Neel Used Talk In Service to Her Painting
description: Alice Neel could be witheringly blunt. ''Art is not as stupid as human conversation,'' she was once quoted as saying. I wrote it down and pinned it up at my desk, struck by its weirdness. In its unequivocal dismissal of daily discourse, Neel's remark gives one a glimpse of a certain darkness: the misanthropy and self-protective brutality that, along with more positive instincts, may be part of the commitment to being an artist.

title: Hey, Moose, Do You Hear an Iron Curtain Falling?
description: Remember the old ''Rocky and Bullwinkle'' cartoons? If you do, either from their initial run in the early 1960's or their long afterlife in syndication, you will recall that they were short, clever (albeit in a stupid kind of way) and proudly two-dimensional. The drawing and animation were defiantly crude, cheap and fast. The show's low-rent look was as integral to its aesthetic as the narrator's goofy modernist intrusions or the moose's barrage of bad puns and loopy malapropisms.

title: Goethe and the Lure of Italian Vistas
description: One of the virtues of the small Dahesh Museum, young but with both feet planted in tradition, is its mounting of academic theme and individual shows involving minor yet sometimes significant artists that would be hard to come by elsewhere. The museum has grown (if not physically, at least in aesthetic stature) since its rocky beginning in Manhattan five years ago, when its exhibition policy was based on the kitschy 19th-century academic paintings acquired by its founding father, a Lebanese philosophical writer and art collector (1909-1984) known by his adopted moniker, Dr. Dahesh, which means ''inspiring wonder'' in Arabic.

Nothing much happened once that world had been posited. But that is the way of luscious, mysterious dreams like the one created by Mr. Tracy and his collaborators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HASKELL
description: COHEN-Haskell, a pioneer in the world of basketball, was the firstever contributing editor to PARADE magazine and the creator of its long-standing All-America High School sports teams. Mr. Cohen's influence in the sport of basketball is historic. As public relations director for the National Basketball Association, he created the annual NBA All-Star Game, brought the first television contract to the NBA and started the Maurice Stokes Memorial Game, which benefits indigent former NBA players. Mr. Cohen came to PARADE in 1957, where he created the All-America High School Boys Basketball Team-the first in history-a precedent that has been copied throughout the years. In 1963, he instituted the PARADE All-America High School Football Team, followed by the All-America Girls Basketball Team in 1977, boys soccer in 1979, and girls soccer in 1993. Walter Anderson, chairman, publisher and CEO of Parade, said ''Haskell Cohen should be remembered not only as a pioneer of high school and professional sports, but also as a man who cared deeply about the well-being of America's young athletes and everyone he came in contact with. His memory should be honored and respected accordingly. He was an American original and a great sportsman. We will miss him.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAVLAKIS, JIM
description: PAVLAKIS-Jim. The Estee Lauder Companies mourns the untimely passing of Jim Pavlakis, Vice President, Business Operations, Aveda, who died suddenly Wednedsay, June 28, at his home in New York. ''Jim was a valued colleague and friend to everyone,'' stated Jeanette S. Wagner, Vice Chairman, The Estee Lauder Companies, Inc.. ''He was a warmhearted person, a first rate Manager and was instrumental in developing Aveda into a truly global brand. We will miss him greatly,'' she concluded. An 18-year Estee Lauder veteran, Mr. Pavlakis, age 55, worked in several brands, including Aramis and Prescriptives, before joining the corporate human resources department in 1995 as a senior executive overseeing financial and administrative areas. He assumed his most recent position in 1998 and oversaw finance, human resources, manufacturing, legal, packaging, information services and quality assurance for Aveda at the Blaine, Minnesota offices. The Estee Lauder Companies

Products made by Dot Wireless will be used in future cellular phones and mobile computers designed by companies like Nokia and Ericsson. Shares of Texas Instruments fell $2.125, to $69.125.

title: As in a Childhood Dream: Getting the Hang of Gliding

It was an idyllic spring day, and we were on the edge of a grassy field, backed by woods, a stream and the rounded summits of the Catskills. I was gently swinging under what looked like a huge, rooftop television antenna. And the orange harness I was hanging in was vaguely reminiscent of a fantasy bondage device. title: Mr. Nader's Misguided Crusade
description: Ralph Nader's long history of public service championing the causes of consumers, the environment and economic justice automatically commands respect. But in running for president as the nominee of the Green Party, he is engaging in a self-indulgent exercise that will distract voters from the clear-cut choice represented by the major-party candidates, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush. His candidacy will be especially harmful for Mr. Gore, the contender closest to Mr. Nader on the environment and other issues. This political reality casts doubt on Mr. Nader's claim to be driven by policy differences rather than ego.

Quest, based in Irvine, Calif., helps companies manage and retrieve information from large databases. FastLane will become a unit of Quest, and Jan Kaminski of FastLane will continue as president. Shares of Quest were unchanged at $53.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUEH, NORMA N., M.D.
description: YUEH-Norma N., M.D. died Wednesday morning at home. She was 72. Born in China, she emigrated to the U.S. on a full scholarship to St. Joseph's College, West Hartford, CT. She later attended Stanford University in Palo Alto, CA and received her doctorate in Library Sciences from Columbia University, New York, NY. During her career, Dr. Yueh worked for the United Nations, The New York Public Library, William Paterson University in Wayne, NJ and at Ramapo College of NJ, where she held the positions of Director of Library Services and most recently, Director of Research. During her tenure at Ramapo College, she received several Managerial Merit Awards from the college and the library was commended by the Middle States Association accreditation team. Dr. Yueh held four presidencies: Council of National Library and Information Association, the Chinese American Librarians Association, New Jersey Library Association and Council of New Jersey College and University Librarians. She served on various executive boards and chaired numerous national, regional and state committees in the college library and higher education fields. Ramapo College recently named a conference room after Dr. Yueh and was to award her ''Emeritus'' status, effective upon her scheduled retirement on June 30, 2000. She was the first woman in the college's history to receive this status. Survivors incude two daughters, Brenda Yueh of Mountain Lakes, NJ and Dara Yueh of Wayne, NJ, a sister, Colleen Shen of St. Louis, MO; a brother, Robert Yu of Beijing, China; and a mother and step-father, Mr. and Mrs. F. Lin of Beijing, China. Viewing will be on Friday, June 30 from 2-4 and 7-9 at Norman Dean Funeral Home, 16 Righter Avenue, Denville, NJ. Funeral services will be on July 1 at 9:30am at St. Catherine's of Siena Church, N. Pocono Road, Mountain Lakes, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to St. Joseph's College, West Hartford, CT.
